DOC.HEAD: Plane Crash Leaves Three Dead; Recovery Effort Suspended
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6-8 grafs, bgng ``It is snowing ...' to CORRECT official's name to Mock, sted Hock; pks up last graf, `Federal Aviation ...'
DOC.TEXT: Three bodies and the wreckage of a small airplane were found Tuesday on treacherous ledges near the windy, snowcapped summit of Mount Washington, authorities said. Police said poor weather forced rescuers to suspend efforts to recover the bodies. They were to go back up the mountain Wednesday. The victims' identities were not immediately disclosed. Hikers spotted the crash site Tuesday afternoon. The plane is believed to be a Cessna-172 that disappeared from radar early Tuesday during a night flight from Syracuse, N.Y., to Bangor, Maine. Residents reported seeing a red light and flash, presumably as the plane slammed into the northern side of the mountain near its 6,288-foot summit. ``It is snowing. The winds are very high. This is all going to make (the salvage effort) very difficult,'' said Fish and Game Maj. Henry Mock. Recreational hikers spotted the wreckage on the Great Gulf trail on this mountain in eastern New Hampshire, the Northeast's highest peak. Officials would have to use ropes and other climbing gear to bring down the bodies and wreckage, Mock said. Federal Aviation Administration officials said the pilot of the Cessna-172 that disappeared from radar had not filed a flight plan, so they did not know how many people were aboard. A Cessna-172 usually has four seats.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Rebukes Cabinet Minister Who Slurred Blacks
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has reprimanded for the ``unpardonable'' remark a Cabinet minister who insulted U.S. blacks, according to a government official. Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama's Sept. 21 comments touched off a series of angry protests. At a news conference, the 64-year-old political veteran compared foreign prostitutes in Japan to black Americans who ``ruin the atmosphere'' of neighborhoods they move into. Following a Cabinet meeting last week, Kaifu called Kajiyama into his office and told him his remarks were ``inappropriate and unpardonable,'' giving him a ``stern warning,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe told a news briefing on Tuesday. The prime minister also ``wanted to make sure similar remarks would not be uttered by others,'' Watanabe said. Asked whether Kajiyama would be forced to resign, Watanabe indicated the justice minister would retain his post because he later apologized for the comments and retracted them. The comments were the latest by a Japanese politician to provoke outrage from U.S. minorities. On Friday, angry demonstrators outside the Japanese Embassy in Washington threatened a boycott against Japanese products. A group of about 30 foreigners also protested the remarks in a demonstration at the Justice Ministry in Tokyo in Tuesday, Kyodo News Service reported.

DOC.HEAD: Battle Against River Blindness Gets New Weapon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY39 of Sept. 28
DOC.TEXT: The gray-haired woman stood motionless as the health worker's fingers gently probed for the hard nodules under her skin that signal river blindness. The ravages of years of infection are evident in the drooping skin of her face, in her strangely elongated earlobes. Victoria Morales is 49; she could pass for 69. In her case, the disease was curbed before the parasite spun a blinding web of microscopic filaments over her eyes. It took years of painful treatment with a drug whose side effects made many afflicted peasants flee the rural health workers that prowl the rich coffee country of southern Chiapas state. Mexico has been fighting river blindness for nearly a half-century. Suddenly it has a new weapon: a gentler new drug called ivermectin. Rural health worker Jose Alfredo Gordillo, 32, recalls how he used to pressure people to take the old medication - diethyl carbamazine, used in Mexico since 1953. ``They'd say: `You have come to make us sick,''' the six-year veteran of the federal health department's river blindness brigades said. Some people simply refused, the treatment was so unpleasant. They paid the price with disfigurement, premature aging or blindness. But the side effects of ivermectin are milder and patients now readily come forward for treatment. ``We have a problem,'' Gordillo said, smiling. ``The community leaders want everyone treated - even if they aren't sick!'' Ivermectin has raised hopes worldwide in the battle against a disease the World Health Organization says afflicts 18 million people in West Africa, Latin America and parts of the Middle East. An estimated 300,000 of them, mostly in West Africa, have been blinded. Ivermectin was developed in the 1970s for livestock parasites. When researchers discovered it was a safe, effective treatment for onchocerciasis, or river blindness, the manufacturer, Merck and Co. of Rahway, N.J., decided to provide it for free. A committee of medical experts based at the Carter Center in Atlanta was set up to handle applications. Dr. Bruce Dull, the committee's secretary, said Mexico, which has one of the world's oldest river blindness control programs, began using ivermectin in May 1989. The three varieties of black fly that carry river blindness in Mexico are found in Chiapas and nearby Oaxaca only at the high, cool altitudes that coffee grows best. Their larvae thrive in fast-moving streams. ``Coffee workers are those that are primarily affected and coffee is very important to our economy,'' said Dr. Andres Martin, a federal health official in Mexico City. He said 250,000 people live in areas where river blindness is found. About 20,000 active cases have been diagnosed and 16,000 people are now taking ivermectin, he said. Worldwide, up to 500,000 people take the drug, which carries the brand name Mectizan, Dull said. Twenty-five brigades of health workers spend up to 40 days at a time in the field, hiking to remote villages, sleeping on floors and treating the ailment peasants here call ``dog's skin'' or ``bad bruise'' (piel de perro, or mal morado) because of the discoloration and disfigurement it causes. There are 76 families on the ejido, or communal farm, of Nuevo Victoria in the heart of river blindness territory. Nearly all are affected by the disease, said Jorge Velasco, head of the regional river blindness program. Velasco dips his hand into a stream that runs through the ejido. A squirming black goo covers his fingertip. It is the larvae of the black flies that carry the disease. The adult flies in turn inject the larvae of the parasite worm into humans with their bite. The larvae grow into adult worms, some as long as two feet, which can live inside humans for 12 years and often cluster insie hard nodules under the skin. But it is not the adults that do the damage. It's their offspring - hundreds of millions of microworms called microfiliariae - that swarm through human body tissue. Blindness is more common in Africa than Latin America. But the microworms produce fierce itching and disfigurement in most victims. They cause the skin to decay; it becomes dark, scaly, flaccid. And in the severest cases, lesions develop over the eyes until sight is gone. The effects are not reversible. The only hope is to control the infection before the worst damage is done. Both drugs kill the microworms. Reactions to diethyl carbamazine - swelling, itching, low blood pressure, joint pain, rash, fever, swollen lymph nodes - can be so intense that it is not used in some rural areas where patients could not be hospitalized. Although ivermectin also produces swelling and itching, the effects usually pass in days. ``We give thanks to God that this was invented to help us,'' said Rumalda Raymundo Perez, 51, who has taken both drugs. Neither drug is preventative or a complete cure. But both kill the microworms, and ivermectin appears to reduce the rate at which the adult worms breed. Although it appears annual treatment is effective, Mexico has permission to administer it twice a year to see if the rate of infection drops, Dull said. The war against river blindness is a tropical disease success story in a country where thousands of children die each year of simple ailments like measles and diarrhea. But hopes of eradication depend on elimination of the disease-bearing flies. ``In my 23 years here, nothing has been done to attack the vector (carrier),'' said Vicente Ardines Martinez, head of the transmittable disease program in Chiapas, a state famed for its lush forests, mountains, jungles and waterfalls. ``But the environment is fragile. We don't want to destroy it.''

DOC.HEAD: Doing Their Job: Women Sportswriters Cope With Obstacles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report; version also on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: The justice of gender in the locker room was supposed to be settled 12 years ago. Courts gave women sportswriters equal access to dressing rooms so they would have the same chance as men to do their jobs. Yet the issue of women in the clubhouse keeps making headlines. Denise Tom of USA Today was barred Monday night from the Cincinnati Bengals' dressing room hours after the National Football League named an investigator to look into charges of harassment of Boston Herald reporter Lisa Olson. ``We go into locker rooms not because we want to, but because we have to,'' wrote Christine Brennan, a sportswriter with The Washington Post and one of pioneers who fought for equal access. ``It's not exciting or sexy or tantalizing. It's cramped and steamy and messy,'' she said. ``But most stadiums are too old to have a room big enough for all reporters and all players to meet for interviews. So the only place we can do our jobs is the locker room.'' About 500 women work as sports journalists, according to the Association for Women in Sports Media. They have the same right to do their jobs as women who drive trucks, mine coal, doctor the sick or practice law. Precedent was established in 1978 when a federal judge ruled Melissa Ludtke, a reporter for Sports Illustrated, could go into the New York Yankees' clubhouse. Barring her violated her constitutional right to equal protection under the law, Judge Constance Baker Motley ruled. In 1985, Commissioner Pete Rozelle ordered all NFL teams to treat reporters equally in interview areas, regardless of sex. Some teams like the Dallas Cowboys set up rooms where players could be interviewed; others handed out bathrobes or towels to players. Major league baseball provided equal access that year, too. Basketball and hockey already had set open policies. The National Basketball Association schools rookies on how to deal with the media - male and female. But the going has hardly been easy for women in the world of jocks, where clubhouses smell of sweat and salve and soiled athletic supporters but where reporters have to go for interviews. In 1986, Susan Fornoff of The Sacramento (Calif.) Bee received a live rat wrapped in a shoe box from Dave Kingman of the Oakland Athletics. Joan Ryan of The Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel once told of a player from a defunct football league who ran a razor up her leg as she conducted an interview. Earlier this year, intern Jennifer Frey of the Detroit Free Press was told by Detroit Tigers pitcher Jack Morris: ``I don't talk to people when I'm naked, especially women, unless they're on top of me or I'm on top of them.'' When the newspaper complained, Tigers president Bo Schembechler wrote back: ``No female member of my family would be inside a men's locker room regardless of their job description.'' Now, former Watergate investigator Philip Heymann has been named to look into charges that New England Patriots' players exposed themselves and made suggestive remarks to Olson on Sept. 17. The Herald reporter called it ``nothing less than mind rape.'' Tight end Zeke Mowatt was fined $2,000 and apologized, but denied making lewd gestures or comments. He said the only thing he told her was: ``You are not writing; you are looking.'' Patriots owner Victor Kiam at first called the locker room incident ``a flyspeck in the ocean,'' then told the paper it was ``asking for trouble'' by sending a female reporter into a football dressing room. He was also quoted as calling her ``a classic bitch.'' After the National Organization for Women called from a boycott of Remington Products Inc., which Kiam owns, he took out full-page ads in The New York Times, the Boston Herald and The Boston Globe. Kiam apologized and said ``there's no excuse for what happened.'' He also denied calling her a name. She was booed at Sunday's game. In Seattle, Bengals Coach Sam Wyche kept USA Today's Tom from the locker room because ``our guys don't want a woman to walk into a situation like that.'' In the past, Wyche has closed the locker room to all reporters in violation of NFL policy and was fined last year. Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said Wyche faces another fine for not letting a woman into the locker room. ``If he wants to make a stand on the issue, he can make a stand on the issue. He will be fined very heavily for it. If he wants to quit, he can quit, because he has been warned twice already,'' Tagliabue said. Tuesday's edition of USA Today contained a column by sportswriter Rachel Shuster aimed at NFL brass. She concluded: ``We've earned our place in the locker room. Now, just give us some respect, and we'll do our jobs and let you do yours.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet General Sees Prospects For US-Soviet Military Ties
DOC.TEXT: As Germany ended 45 years of division, the Soviet military chief of staff said the end of the Cold War opens the road to cooperation between the armed forces of the United States and the Soviet Union. Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev embraced and toasted his American counterpart, Gen. Colin Powell, at a dinner reception in New York on Tuesday on the second day of his first visit to the United States. ``We have buried the Cold War and I don't think that General Powell or I are going to try to dig it back up,'' Moiseyev, 51, told an audience of about 120 U.S. and Soviet military officers and New York politicians and businessmen. ``There are not only wide prospects for friendship between our people and the American people, but also wide prospects for cooperation between our armed forces,'' Moiseyev said. Earlier, Moiseyev commented on the possible use of force against Iraq by multinational troops stationed in Saudi Arabia. He said the economic sanctions against Iraq were working and that no force should be used in the Persian Gulf unless it was approved by the United Nations, according to a report in Wednesday's editions of The New York Times. Saddam Hussein ``is finding himself in economic and political isolation and he can't survive very long that way,'' Moiseyev told the newspaper. But Powell, who joined Moiseyev in the Times interview, said President Bush has not ruled out any options in the current crisis. Moiseyev, his country's first deputy minister of defense and chief of the general staff, is the highest-ranking Soviet military officer to visit the United States since Soviet Marshall Sergei Akhromeyev met with then-Secretary of Defense Frank Carlucci in December 1987. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, accompanied Moiseyev from Washington, where the Soviet general arrived Monday for his six-day visit. ``The alliance of our countries lives again in our time under the leadership of Bush and (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev,'' Powell told the audience. He referred to himself and the Soviet general - a former railroad worker - as ``old soldier Powell'' and ``old soldier Moiseyev.'' Earlier Tuesday, Moiseyev visited Fort Drum in upstate New York and observed the 10th Mountain Division training drill - a battle exercise once intended to prepare American soldiers for a military encounter with a Soviet foe. The Soviet military leader said he had ``a typical soldier's lunch meal, and everything was fantastic.'' ``The very soul of what it is to meet the American military was what we have accomplished,'' Moiseyev said, adding that he's ``a little jealous of General Powell, because he's a man who pays so much attention and does so much for the U.S. Armed Forces.'' From New York, Moiseyev is to travel to other military installations in Michigan, South Dakota, California and Colorado. In Washington, Moiseyev visited the Pentagon and the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, received a 19-gun salute and met with President Bush. ``In our hearts, we've felt much more than we have seen. In meeting the average American citizen we felt care, attention, affection,'' the Soviet general said.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker Marks Unity Behind Hospital Wall
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Erich Honecker, the ousted and reviled leader of the vanished East Germany, spent reunification night behind the walls of the Soviet military hospital where he is confined. Like the other 16.6 million citizens of the now extinct state he ruled for 18 years, the ex-Communist party chief became a citizen of united democratic Germany at the stroke of midnight Tuesday. Residents of Beelitz, 20 miles south of Berlin, had decorated buildings with German flags for the occassion, and Mass was celebrated in the town church. The 77-year-old Honecker, who withdrew in seclusion and disgrace after he was ousted a year ago amid massive pro-democracy protests, can sometimes be seen strolling through the pine and birch forest on the hospital grounds. ``You can see him at night walking around quietly. It's a very restful place,'' said a Soviet civilian taking a walk along the road next to the hospital. The Soviet did not give his name and said he was receiving treatment for an eye ailment at the facility. The hospital and old-fashioned brick villas on the grounds are surrounded by a thick white wall. Honecker directed the building of the 1961 Berlin Wall that kept East Germans trapped in the Communist state for 28 years. Most of them detested Honecker. Asked once what he liked most about unity, Wolf Biermann, the former East German dissident expelled to West Germany in the 1970s, replied: ``That Honecker became a citizen of united Germany and can't do anything about it.'' Honecker was accused of corruption and expelled from the Communist Party in December, but was spared the indignity of imprisonment when doctors determined that he suffered from a kidney tumor and was too ill to survive jail life. He was transferred to the Soviet military hospital earlier this year. Soviet officers at the gate declined to allow a Western reporter on the grounds. ``Unity is the business of the Germans. We won't interfere,'' said one. He said the base had no plans to celebrate unification. The 360,000 Soviet troops in what was East Germany are scheduled to return home by 1994. Honecker could face trial and imprisonment in the united Germany, where he is under criminal investigation for allegedly giving shoot-to-kill orders to border guards and harboring leftist terrorists wanted in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: There's Far More Than Food at America's Farmers Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The bumper crop of farmers markets blooming all over the country is forging ties between city dwellers and the source of their food, and providing growers with a way to hang onto their farms. Farmers markets - in parks and school yards, along downtown malls or in church lots in hundreds of communities - are great equalizers: Sophisticated chefs shop alongside poor working mothers, both in search of inexpensive, fresh food and perhaps a conversation with the farmer who harvested it the day before. ``It's much more than a simple economic relationship,'' said Elizabeth Ryan, who with her husband farms 35 acres of apples and other food in Staatsburg, in New York's Hudson River Valley. ``It makes you take what you do very seriously. You see the people who buy your food, you see the people who put it in bottles and feed it to their baby,'' said Ryan, who does 90 percent of her sales through New York City's Greenmarket, which has 17 sites and an estimated 40,000 shoppers a week. There are nearly 2,000 farmers markets nationwide, compared with 1,200 in 1980, according to Public Markets Collaborative, which works to establish and preserve markets. Massachusetts had six markets in the mid-1970s; it has 85 this year. California had just one market 15 years ago; today there are 140. Greenmarket farmers took in at least $9 million last year, said Barry Benepe, a planning consultant who founded Greenmarket in 1976. American Demographics magazine estimates consumers will spend $1 billion to $2 billion for fresh food directly from 200,000 farmers this year, but that includes roadside stands and other outlets as well as farmers markets. Places like the 200-year-old French Market in New Orleans and Pike Place Market in Seattle, for example, combine farmers markets and permanent shops. Farmers markets are urban or suburban sites where growers bring fresh food and sell directly to consumers. They are supported by local or state governments or by non-profit organizations, and are set up for many reasons: to support family farms, revitalize downtowns, provide fresh, inexpensive food to urban residents. When Lynn Bagley started four markets in Northern California, she said, she was primarily interested in nutrition. ``But you quickly find out that what you're really doing is supporting the small farmer, and in the long run helping maintain a regional food belt.'' In a study, Robert Sommer, director of the Center for Consumer Research at the University of California-Davis, found that people shop at farmers' markets for high-quality food, lower prices and atmosphere, in that order. ``In the old days people went to the dump; now they go to the farmers market. It's become a big social event,'' said August Schumacher, outgoing commissioner of Food and Agriculture in Massachusetts. ``Market shoping is really a form of entertainment. ... You don't go to an open-air farmers market because it's convenient,'' said Hilary Baum of Public Markets Collaborative. All year, every Wednesday, Friday and Saturday, dozens of growers do business in Manhattan at Union Square Park - once a haven for drug dealers - and provide more than ample atmosphere amid fragrant waist-high stalks of basil, chef demonstrations, tours and tastings. One recent day shoppers could choose white eggplant, cider, peaches, apples, okra, sour cherries, squash blossoms, raspberries, eggs, chickens, bursting sunflowers, and apple and blueberry pies. A woman at a fish stand hands out cards with a number to call a day ahead to find out what kinds of fish will be spread out on ice the next morning. The Blews, who farm in Pittstown, N.J., offered 13 kinds of peppers. New York City's markets range from the sprawling Union Square market - where, Benepe said, growers can make up to $10,000 a day - to one on the Lower East Side, six farmers once a week. Farmers pay less than 5 percent of gross for their stalls, he said. Growers first came to Greenmarket ``with great skepticism,'' Benepe said. ``They feared they'd come with full loads and go home with empty pockets. Rip-off city.'' They found otherwise. Merrie Kernan gets up at 2:30 a.m. three days a week to drive a truckload of produce 125 miles from Bridgton, N.J. She likes talking with New Yorkers, even those who ask when banana season starts, or will she have oranges or artichokes soon. Then there are the kids she brings lightning bugs for. And the customer who just bought a small farm and told Kernan she was going to pay someone to cut the hay. ``I told her - you don't pay somebody. They pay you.'' ``Running a farm is very grueling and very demanding. There are times you feel discouraged,'' Ryan said. ``And the thing that really makes it worth it, honestly, it's such a shot in the arm to get in that truck and go to market on Saturday and know that it's all worthwhile.'' And for consumers, studies show prices are 5 percent to 30 percent lower at farmers markets, where there are no ``middlemen'' and low transportation costs. There is more than good shopping at work, however. Without the markets, many family farms - too small to comply with demands for volume and uniformity of whole distributors - would be forced to sell out. A Greenmarket survey found that 70 percent of its farmers said the market was either essential or important to their economic well-being, Benepe said. In Connecticut, the non-profit Hartford Food System found that farmers could not afford to run full-scale markets in the poorest neighborhoods. So it linked up with neighborhood organizations, bought food from farmers and opened farmstands, said Mark Winne, the organization's executive director. Connecticut also is one of 10 states in the federal Farmers Market Coupon program. Last year an estimated 275,000 poor women and children were issued coupons worth $2.5 million. Many farmers also accept food stamps. In Massachusetts, government made a difference, Schumacher said. ``The mayors of many cities wanted to link consumers to local growers. They gave us wonderful spots, many in front of city halls - Boston, Brockton, Springfield.'' The markets, in turn, can help a city. A twice-weekly market saved downtown Pasco, Wash., said Linda Sue Williams of the Pasco Downtown Development Association. Seventy farmers drive to a lot where the city has in the last five years built 48 shelters for growers and their food. Three thousand to 5,000 people shop there a week, she said. ``It's been credited by many many people with sving the downtown,'' Williams said. ``It's the best thing that's happened to Pasco in a long, long time.'' But a Saturday market in Columbus, Ohio, across from a convention center under construction, may be threatened by related commercial development. ``There is support, but our future is still a little unknown,'' said Nancy Duncan Porter, executive director of the North Market Development Authority, which formed to save the market from becoming a parking lot just three years ago. ``Some people just like to tear down and build more than they like to preserve,'' she said. ``The market is a very `people' activity and social in nature, and we think a great drawing card for downtown.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Hoping to Break 22-Year Statehouse Stranglehold
DOC.TEXT: Republicans have won the Iowa governor's race in every election since 1968, but Democrat Don Avenson is within striking range and thinks he can beat Gov. Terry Branstad to break the streak. ``Our time is coming,'' says Avenson, the state House speaker. ``We have a chance.'' Recent polls vary, showing Branstad with a lead ranging from a statistically insignificant three points to as much as 13 points. Avenson's campaign is pursuing the following strategy: -Raise one-third of the more than $3 million Branstad will spend. -Play off of Iowa's recent economic problems, even though the state appears to have come through the worst. -Reap some voter support from Avenson's pro-choice position on abortion, even though he's not counting on the issue to dominate the campaign and provide his margin of victory. ``It's not a silver bullet,'' he says. Avenson hopes to chip away at the lead of a governor who is a tireless campaigner and who has never lost an election. ``The last election I beat the majority leader and this time I'm going to beat the speaker of the House,'' says the 43-year-old Branstad, who also has been a state representative and lieutenant governor. ``This governor's been at it six days a week, 14 or 16 hours a day, for eight years,'' says Branstad. ``I oftentimes have said, the harder I work, the luckier I get. You kind of make your own luck.'' While Democrats have a lead of about 100,000 in voter registration among the state's 1.5 million registered voters, Branstad discounts that. He argues there were more Democrats than Republicans when he won in 1982 and again in 1986. Branstad has called for restoring the death sentence, a move polls show has broad support. ``He feels the sentiments are changing among Iowans and among legislators and this year the Legislature may accept a limited death penalty,'' said Branstad spokesman Richard Vohs. ``I think the governor is nervous. I think he's saying this because he's politically nervous,'' says Avenson, a veteran politician of 18 years in the state Legislature, eight as speaker. In an era when many polls show voters leery of government, Avenson, who is 46, takes an activist role. ``We don't need more government, we need more of the government we have,'' he said. ``I think we need to let government go, unleash it and let it do its job. We need to find ways to make government work again. ``In the last 10 years, we've grown older, smaller and poorer,'' he says. ``If he were a football coach, they would have fired him a long time ago for that kind of a record.'' That approach may not be effective, with the state's economy stronger than during the depths of a farm-based recession throughout the 1980s. ``Our goal in the '90s is to continue the economic comeback that we began in the past few years,'' says Branstad. Avenson admits he has big hurdles to overcome and points to the growing Branstad presence on television. ``They are going to inundate this state,'' said Avenson. ``He just doubled that. I cannot double my effort. I don't have the money.'' Another wild card in the election is abortion rights, supported by Avenson and opposed by Branstad. With polls showing that two-thirds of Iowans consider themselves pro-choice, Avenson hoped that would translate into votes. He conceded that his private polling shows pro-choice voters still split between the two candidates and not familiar with their positions. While Branstad takes an anti-abortion position, he hasn't asked the Legislature to impose restrictions and he picked a pro-choice woman - state Sen. Joy Corning - as his running mate. ``I don't want to tear this state apart over an emotional issue,'' Branstad argues. ``You see, the anti-choice vote, all of them, support Terry Branstad,'' said Avenson. ``But the pro-choice vote hasn't come all the way over because I haven't made it clear. ``We will cause that movement to take place because we will make it very clear,'' said Avenson. Other activists argue the issue will help pro-choice candidates, but only around the fringes. Iowa Democratic Chairman John Roehrick said movement will come as independent voters focus in the final weeks. ``We've still got five weeks to go until the election,'' said Roehrick. ``I don't think it will be the only issue. I think it means two to four points.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Wants to Lift Nuclear Ban as Condition for Aid to Pakistan
DOC.TEXT: President Bush wants to keep U.S. aid flowing to Pakistan even though there is evidence the country is violating rules against nuclear weapons proliferation, administration and congressional sources say. Senior State Department officials are working on Capitol Hill to lift the legal requirement that bars Pakistan, the third largest recipient of U.S. aid, from getting any money if it presses ahead with nuclear bomb development. U.S. aid to Pakistan technically came to a halt Monday, the beginning of the 1991 fiscal year, because Bush had not issued the required annual certification that Pakistan does not possess a nuclear bomb and that continued U.S. aid will reduce the prospect for development of atomic weapons. Pakistan has scheduled national elections for Oct. 24 to replace the government of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who was removed from office two months ago amid charges of corruption. The administration wants to give the new government that emerges after those elections time to curb or roll back the country's nuclear weapons program before making a decision on cutting off aid, said sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Senior administration officials, including Undersecretary of State Reginald Bartholomew and Deputy Assistant Secretary Teresita Schaffer, went to Capitol Hill last week to ask for a waiver. The idea was received coolly among key House officials, including Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., chairman of the foreign aid appropriations subcommittee; and Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., chairman of the subcommittee on Asia. The administration, which typically finds a warmer welcome in the Senate, is hoping it can pursue the waiver there, either as an amendment to the foreign aid bill that comes up for committee consideration today or on another bill before Congress adjourns later this month. Leonard Spector, a weapons proliferation analyst at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said policymakers appear afraid to assert U.S. values. Adopting a waiver, he said, would mean ``we are in effect announcing to the world that Pakistan has nuclear weapons, and we just don't care.'' But an administration official said it is prudent to withhold judgment on the certification until after ``we get beyond this point of flux and set up a dialogue with the new government.'' While the White House would like to see a year-long waiver, it will settle for six months, the official said. ``Nobody's jumping up and down about it, but they are sympathetic and they understand the seriousness of the issue,'' the official added. Pakistan has provided the base for covert U.S. aid to Afghan rebels in the 1980s, and also has promised troops to help defend Saudi Arabia from Iraq. Bhutto, who was warmly received when she promised her country would not develop a nuclear bomb during a 1989 speech to Congress, was removed from power on Aug. 6. While she is among those vying for control in the new elections, analysts say she is unlikely to regain power. U.S.-Pakistani relations have benn shaky since Bhutto's ouster. A minister in the caretaker cabinet urged that U.S. Ambassador Robert Oakley be recalled for questioning the impartiality of tribunals looking into government corruption, and Pakistan lodged an official protest of his remarks. Sources on Capitol Hill and others with access to top Pakistani officials said there are fears that Pakistan has produced enriched uranium in a form that could be the basis for a bomb, stepping over the line that both sides understood would trigger an aid cutoff. At the State Department, spokesman Richard Boucher said only that the question of whether to issue the presidential certification is ``still under review'' and that aid cannot be provided until a certification is issued. Pakistan received nearly $580 million in U.S. military and economic aid in fiscal 1990, making it the third largest recipient of American largess, after Israel and Egypt. Similar amounts have been requested for this year. The administration has quietly told Pakistan's interim government that it must roll back the nuclear steps taken this year, said one source. Those moves have the effect of reducing the time it would take Pakistan to field nuclear weapons from a matter of months to a matter of weeks, several sources said. Bomb-making requires enriching uranium hexafluoride, a gas, then solidifying it into a metal that is milled into a hollow sphere for use as a bomb core. Pakistan already has taken some of those steps, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Exiles Depressed, Uncertain About Future
With PM-Bush-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti families gather each day in hotel lobbies on this small island nation. The adults are depressed and uncertain about their homeland's future; their children troubled by nightmares. ``We pass our time, day after day, reading newspapers, meeting other Kuwaitis, thinking and praying,'' said a Kuwaiti lawyer who brought his mother and sisters to Bahrain. ``We are depressed and idle. We are emotionally very tired.'' But a 10-year-old Kuwaiti boy said he knew what to do: wait until his 12th birthday, then join the underground resistance and die killing Iraqi soldiers. The boy's aunt said ``all he does is talk about killing Iraqis, and dying himself.'' A 10-year-old girl with dark circles under her eyes has suffered frequent nightmares since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``I don't know how to comfort her,'' said her mother. ``We keep telling her she is in Bahrain, not Kuwait. But she is still frightened.'' The two children are among the thousands of Kuwaitis who fled to Bahrain, about 180 miles south in the Persian Gulf. The Kuwaitis in Bahrain, once enjoying one of the world's highest standards of living, now must depend on their savings outside Kuwait as well as help from friendly Arab governments. The Kuwaitis interviewed spoke on condition their full names not be used, seeking to avoid possible reprisals by Iraqi forces against family members remaining in Kuwait. ``We threw away our passports and ID cards. We were told there would be strict inspections on the way out,'' said one woman sitting in a hotel lobby. The Kuwaitis are placed by their embassy at hotels in Manama until their identities can be verified. Until then, they cannot collect full benefits from their government-in-exile or put their children in school. Instead of school, the children gather in the lobbies with their mothers and spend most of the time drawing or playing. Their games almost always involve shooting and fighting. ``Their attitudes have changed,'' a Kuwaiti woman said of the children. ``They draw soldiers, tanks, and blood. They have lost the carefree spirit they once had.'' ``We are trying to raise the morale of everyone, and we have social workers going from hotel to hotel trying to pinpoint those suffering from severe psychological problems,'' said a social worker at the Kuwaiti Embassy in Bahrain. ``But sometimes their dignity will not let them come forward to ask people for help.'' In a radio broadcast heard in Bahrain, the exiled crown prince of Kuwait, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, on Monday hailed the refugees for ``heroic steadfastness in the face of the despot of Baghdad,'' a reference to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``Do not despair of the crimes of the brutal aggressor, for he will not be able to destroy your will nor weaken your resolve and resistance,'' said Sheik Saad. His exiled government is now based in neighboring Saudi Arabia. ``History has not seen such world unanimity in support of a cause as that given to the just one of Kuwait, to tightening the noose around the Iraqi occupation until its forces pull out by peace or war,'' the sheik said. Abdullah, chairman of the Information Committee at the Kuwaiti Embassy in Bahrain, said he sometimes chats with friends and momentarily forgets the troubles. ``But, when we go to our beds and put our heads on the pillow and think about what's happening, we almost go crazy from the pain. ``How are we coping psychologically? Through hope. The hope that we will return to our country soon.''

DOC.HEAD: Oldest Astronaut Getting Older Waiting To Fly
DOC.TEXT: The man destined to become the oldest person to fly in space is not getting any younger as he waits - and waits and waits - for NASA to fix and launch the shuttle Columbia. But the on-again, off-again launch doesn't have 59-year-old Vance Brand worrying whether if he's past it. ``Only if you let problems really get you down do you feel older,'' Brand, commander of Columbia's astronomy mission, said Monday. ``We're just all having to be very patient,'' he said. ``Time is passing. But I don't think it's hurting any of us, just the sake of the shuttle program. I'd just like to get going.'' Brand's mission has been on hold since late May, when Columbia's hydrogen leaks first were detected. NASA tried three more times to launch the shuttle before stopping two weeks ago to make way for Discovery's high-priority flight. Discovery lifts off Saturday with five astronauts and a satellite that will be sent on a five-year journey to study the sun's poles. It will be the first shuttle flight since Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit in April. ``I'll be a little jealous'' watching Discovery go up, Brand said in a telephone interview from Johnson Space Center in Houston. ``But we'll get there.'' Brand, an astronaut since 1966, made his first space flight in 1975 on the Apollo-Soyuz mission, in which the crews of the American and Soviet spacecraft docked in space. He has flown in space two other times. Brand said he isn't any more nervous about flying on a shuttle than he was before hydrogen leaks struck Columbia and then Atlantis. Crew member Mike Lounge, while frustrated, also takes it in stride. ``You just go home and mow your lawn and pay your bills and take a little leave. We're still getting paid,'' Lounge, 44, said. ``We don't get a lot of sympathy about what an awful job we have here.'' Brand figured he and his six crewmates have broken at least one record while waiting to fly - the most time spent in quarantine for a mission. The seven men have been confined to crew quarters for a week before each launch attempt, adding up to about a month. ``We've had the supreme test, and we all get along great,'' Brand said. ``I'd like to be an astronaut until I'm 80,'' Brand said. ``But I think when I finish this flight, there will just be a switch that flips in my head that says, `OK, you're going after your second career and it's going to have its own challenges and interesting things, so let's get with that.' '' Brand plans to move into management at Johnson Space Center after the Columbia mission.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Scandalous Past, Lottery Idea May Prevail in Louisiana
DOC.TEXT: A century after a crooked Louisiana lottery bilked an entire nation, voters in this state will decide whether to give a new one a chance. Louisiana voters will consider a constitutional amendment Saturday ending the state's ban on lotteries. Louisiana stands to become the 33rd state to enact a lottery to help finance state government. The Legislature already has passed a bill establishing a quasi-public corporation, answerable to lawmakers and the governor, to operate the games. Despite opposition from Gov. Buddy Roemer, the horse racing industry and others who question its economic value, recent polls favor passage. ``It's a good alternative to the sales tax,'' said state Rep. Raymond Lalonde, who sponsored the measure in the House. ``The lottery will bring as much as a penny (in sales tax) on milk and bread.'' Opponents led by the Coalition Against Legalizing a Lottery argue a lottery would drain money from the state's weak economy and take advantage of the poor. ``It's a senseless leech on our economy. It's a pernicious cancer on the pocketbooks of the poor,'' said Ed Steimel, a coalition spokesman. But proponents are so confident of passage that an organization to push for a lottery was formed only in the past few weeks after an anti-gambling group began a grass-roots campaign. Meanwhile, voters in neighboring Arkansas will consider adopting a lottery on Nov. 6 to boost education funding. Opponents, including church leaders who denounce it on moral grounds, hope to get the state Supreme Court to rule it off the ballot. A poll commissioned by the Arkansas Democrat and reported last week found that 52 percent favor the lottery, 36 percent oppose it and 12 percent are undecided. Since Louisiana's economy declined along with oil prices in the 1980s, the Legislature has routinely renewed a sales tax on food and utilities to balance the state's books. Such items were traditionally exempt from the sales tax. Lotteries have been banned by the Louisiana Constitution since a scandal-plagued private lottery operated in the state during the late 1800s. Tickets for that operation were sold all over the United States, and the people who had been duped complained to Washington. In 1890, President Benjamin Harrison addressed a special message to Congress, asking for relief because ``the people of all the states are debauched and defrauded ... by the Louisiana lottery.'' Congress responded with legislation that blocked the use of the mail for selling lottery tickets. Since the lottery sold as much as 93 percent of its tickets outside Louisiana, the enterprise collapsed. That postal prohibition still applies today. Because of the debacle, there has been deep-rooted opposition to a lottery in Louisiana for years. But favorable sentiment has been growing. Estimates of state revenue for the first full year range from $59 million to $111 million, according to the Public Affairs Research Council, a research and government watchdog group. But Steimel said that for the state to net $110 million annually from a lottery, at least $300 million would have to be wagered - money that otherwise would go into the private economy. ``We have an economy that is in real deep trouble,'' he said. ``Instead of a transfusion, we're getting a blood sucker.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Proposal Would Raise Gas Taxes, Cut Medicare Benefits
With PM-Budget Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two months after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein forced a gasoline price increase of about 25 cents a gallon, the U.S. government is moving to tack on another 12 cents. A gradual 10-cent increase in the 9-cent-a-gallon tax and a new 2-cent levy on refined petroleum productions, including gasoline, is one of the biggest items in a $500 billion, five-year plan for reducing the budget deficit. The energy taxes would raise almost $57 billion. The Energy Information Administration said Monday the price of self-service, regular unleaded gasoline averaged $1.311 a gallon on Sept. 27, compared with $1.075 July 31, two days before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait disrupted oil markets. The budget proposal, backed by President Bush and leaders of both parties, relies heavily on excise taxes and makes few changes in income taxes. As a result, analysts say, the impact is likely to be felt most by poorer, younger and rural families, who spend a larger portion of their disposable income on gasoline, tobacco and alcoholic beverages. Other parts of the plan target fliers; state and local government employees; workers whose wages exceed $51,300; taxpayers with incomes over $100,000, and anyone with a taste for expensive cars, furs and jewels. The proposal also would mean more Internal Revenue Service audits in an effort to corral more tax cheats and raise $9.4 billion. Earlier this year, the Congressional Budget Office found that Americans spend 2.7 percent of after-tax income on gasoline, 1.1 percent on tobacco and 2 percent for liquor, wine and beer. The poorest 20 percent, with after-tax income averaging $8,200 - spent 6.9 percent for gasoline, 4 percent on tobacco and 3.7 percent for alcohol. The 20 percent just below the richest, with income averaging $38,000 after taxes, spent 2.9 percent for gasoline, 1.1 percent for tobacco and 2.2 percent for alcohol. Here are some major parts of the tax plan, which congressional leaders hope will become law this month: ENERGY: The federal gasoline tax of 9 cents a gallon would rise by 5 cents Dec. 1 and another 5 cents next July 1. On Jan. 1, a 2-cent-a-gallon tax on most refined petroleum products, including gasoline and home heating oil, would take effect. Almost 94 percent of families buy gasoline. TOBACCO: The 16-cent-a-pack tax on cigarettes would rise 4 cents on Jan. 1 and another 4 cents two years later. Taxes on cigars, chewing tobacco and snuff would be increased at each step by 25 percent. About 46 percent of Americans use tobacco. ALCOHOL: About 71 percent of taxpayers would be affected. The tax on hard liquor, now $12.50 for a gallon of 100 proof (50 percent alcohol), would rise to $14, up 30 cents for a fifth. Lower-proof liquor would go up by the same ratio. The tax on beer, now 16 cents for a six-pack, would double. Most wines also would face higher taxes. The 3-cent tax on a fifth of table wine would rise to 25 cents. AIRLINE TICKETS: More than 1.2 million passengers fly each day. The 8 percent tax would rise to 10 percent. On the average round-trip ticket, costing about $300, the tax would go up about $6. LUXURIES: A 10 percent luxury tax would apply to the portion of the sales price of certain commodities above certain thresholds. For cars, the threshold would be $30,000; for private boats, $100,000; for jewelry and furs, $5,000. The buyer of a $35,000 car would pay a tax of $500 (10 percent of $5,000). ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS: A couple or individual with adjusted gross income above $100,000 could continue to deduct all allowable medical expenses and investment interest expense. But they would have to reduce other deductions by $3 for each $100 that their income exceeds $100,000. A person with $120,000 income and $20,000 in allowable deductions, for example, could deduct 97 percent, or $19,400. About 2.5 million people would be affected. MEDICARE WAGES: About 8 million workers earning more than $51,300 would pay more tax for Medicare coverage. The tax (withheld from paychecks as part of the Social Security levy) is 1.45 percent of the first $51,300 earned each year. That wage limit would be raised to $73,000, meaning a $315-a-year tax increase. Employers match employees' taxes. About 2 million employees of state and local government hired before April 1, 1986, who do not now pay for Medicare, would be required to pay the 1.45 percent tax for the first time. SOCIAL SECURITY: About 4 million state and local workers not covered by a public retirement plan would have to start paying the 6.2 percent Social Security tax on their first $51,300 of wages. The employer would pay an equal amount. EDUCATION: The guaranteed student loan program would be trimmed by $2 billion. Negotiators suggested eliminating all schools with default rates above 30 percent, which officials acknowledge would include many trade and vocational schools, as well as historically black colleges. AGRICULTURE: Agriculture programs would be cut by $13 billion, which is one-fourth of the $54 billion being sought for the next five years. POST OFFICE: The price of stamps would rise faster because the Postal Service would absorb about $5 billion in cuts over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Survives Threat in House Panel
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts emerged unscathed from an assault by House critics but faces a floor battle later this week over attempts to impose new anti-obscenity curbs. By voice vote Monday, the House Appropriations Committee resoundingly defeated a proposal by Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas, to eliminate all funds for the federal arts agency until Congress votes separately to extend the NEA's life. Rep. Sidney Yates, D-Ill., and other endowment supporters on the panel said a vote for DeLay's amendment would be a vote to abolish the 25-year-old agency. DeLay is among the NEA's most vocal conservative opponents. The committee voted to give the endowment a 5 percent spending increase in the fiscal year that began Monday, from $171 million to $180 million. And it persuaded Rep. Ralph Regula, R-Ohio, to withdraw a proposal to forbid the NEA to finance any obscene or indecent works. Instead, at the urging of Yates and Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif., the committee sidestepped the ``obscene art'' issue in favor of House action on a separate measure authorizing a five-year extension of the NEA's life. Floor debate on that measure was tentatively scheduled to begin Wednesday or Thursday. The endowment's statutory authority expired Sunday night. Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., a staunch NEA supporter, and Rep. E. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., a conservative who is seeking restrictions on the kinds of art eligible for endowment support, circulated the outlines of a proposed compromise among their House colleagues Monday. Their proposal reportedly would embrace a bipartisan Senate measure that would require the NEA to recoup money from any grant recipient who is convicted in court of using federal funds to violate obscenity laws. Fazio said the compromise also would call for increasing to 27.5 percent the share of NEA grant money allocated to state arts agencies. The current state share is 20 percent. Coleman originally had sought to shift 60 percent of NEA funds to state control. For the time being, the arts endowment is operating under a temporary extension of last year's $171 million spending level, until Congress approves appropriations bills for the NEA and other federal agencies for fiscal 1991, which began Monday. That means the endowment is still working under an obscenity ban that Congress imposed last fall at the request of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and other conservative lawmakers. They were angered by NEA support for exhibitions of works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano which they denounced as obscene and blasphemous. The proposed $180 million budget for the NEA was included in a $14.5 billion appropriations bill that the House committee approved by voice vote Monday and sent to the floor. The measure also includes money for the Interior and Energy departments, the Forest Service, the Smithsonian Institution and the National Endowment for the Humanities.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Citizens Oppose Cut in Medicare Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Senior citizens say the proposed deficit reduction package that would increase Medicare premiums and deductibles requires them to shoulder more than their fair share of budget cuts. ``The (budget) summiteers have declared budget war on the elderly,'' said Ron Pollack, executive director of Families USA, which represents the elderly. ``Those that wage this war shouldn't expect older Americans to be pacifists on election day,'' he said. Of the $119 billion in domestic programs that would be saved over the next five years under the budget compromise, $60 billion would come from Medicare. Half of the savings in the health care program would be achieved by requiring its beneficiaries - 33 million elderly and disabled Americans - to pay more out of their own pockets for medical services. Their $28.60 monthly premium for doctors' care would rise to $34.30 next year; their $75 deductible on doctors' bills would double by 1995; and a 20 percent co-payment for laboratory costs would be restored. The rest of the savings - about $30 billion - would come from cutting growth in reimbursement rates for hospitals and physicians. ``We're very disappointed that seniors have beensingled out for this unfair tax treatment,'' said Martha A. McSteen, president of the National Committee to Preserve Social Security. The American Association of Retired Persons was concerned about the size of the Medicare cuts as well as protections for the poor. ``It's clearly going to take a very big hit,'' said Judy Schub, a legislative representative for AARP. Instead, the government should ``resort to the progressive income tax,'' said Arthur Flemming, a Republican and head of the Save Our Security coalition of elderly lobbying groups. ``Change it so it puts a heavier burden on the wealthy.'' President Bush, asked about senior citizens' displeasure with the plan, said Monday, ``Well, what are you going to do? You can't keep everybody happy. I learned that long ago. You've got to do what's right. That's what we're trying to do.'' House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., defended the plan, saying the Medicare program has been the fastest rising cost of any federal entitlement program. AARP and the other senior citizens' groups were relieved that budget negotiators decided against cuts that would affect Social Security recipients. They had considered proposals to delay cost of living adjustments and to tax a larger portion of Social Security benefits. Gail Wilensky, head of the Health Care Financing Administration, which handles Medicare, said the compromise package protects the poorest elderly by continuing for them Medicaid coverage of Medicare's out-of-pocket costs. Also, she noted, all Medicare beneficiaries will be protected by a provision passed by Congress last year limiting the amount physicians can charge beyond what Medicare will pay. That limit will be 25 percent on Jan. 1 and will drop to 15 percent by 1993. Additionally, she said, the higher cost-sharing for recipients is still far less than it was when the program began in 1965. Then, beneficiaries paid 50 percent of the cost of premiums for doctors' care. Now, it is 25 percent but would rise to 30 percent under the budget compromise. ``I do believe you can say these are reasonable and justified changes,'' Wilensky said. Also as part of the package, higher paid workers would see the 1.45 percent tax that helps support the Medicare program apply to a larger part of their income. Currently, the tax is applied only to the first $51,300 of income, but under the agreement it would be applied to the first $73,000. Wilensky said this would help extend the solvency of the Medicare trust fund, which could go bankrupt in the early part of the next century if changes are not made.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Lucy lookalikes and near-Desis are out of luck. Two professional actors, Maurice Benard and Frances Fisher, will play the wacky couple in a TV movie. The two were introduced Monday as the stars of ``Lucy and Desi: Before the Laughter.'' Hundreds of lookalikes, many of them amateurs, turned out for cattle calls in New York, Miami and Los Angeles during the search for the perfect Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz. Miss Fisher, who bears little resemblance to Miss Ball without makeup, has appeared in the TV movies ``Cold Sassy Tree,'' ``Home'' and ``Broken Vows.'' Benard, who played Nico Kelly on the soap opera ``All My Children,'' looks a little like a young Arnaz. Benard is practicing on a conga. ``It's big shoes to fill. I'm an actor. I'm not an impersonator. But he's a lot like my father,'' Benard said. CBS plans to broadcast the movie in February. It covers the couple's private life from 1940 to the night they filmed the first episode of ``I Love Lucy,'' which premiered in 1951. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Gov. Mario Cuomo got a high-five from a young paisan. The governor appeared Monday with the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Michelangelo, Leonardo, Donatello and Raphael - and thanked them for help with a new drug prevention program. ``And I love their names,'' Cuomo said. Michelangelo dubbed Cuomo ``your honorable dudeship'' during a ceremony at a grade school. ``Anybody here know the Ninja Turtles?'' the governor asked a gymnasium filled with squealing first-, second- and third-graders. He got a deafening, affirmative response. ``Man, I hope they don't run for office,'' Cuomo said. Donatello high-fived Cuomo before the pizza-loving, TV turtles performed their anti-drug song, ``Walk Straight.'' The turtles recently launched a singing career and a national tour. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Teen-age actor Corey Feldman pleaded innocent to heroin possession and got another warning to stay in drug abuse treatment. A Municipal Court commissioner on Monday ordered Feldman to remain in a rehabilitation program as a condition of his $5,000 bail. The 19-year-old actor, who appeared in the movies ``Goonies,'' ``Stand by Me'' and ``Gremlins,'' has been in a residential drug abuse program since Sept. 21, when he was arrested on a heroin possession charge for the second time. Feldman got a similar admonition in Superior Court last week during a hearing on the first charge after he failed to appear for a hearing. --- NEW YORK (AP) - For Cybill Shepherd and Peter Bogdanovich, the movie ``Texasville'' was a trip home. Nineteen years after Bogdanovich left his wife, Polly Platt, for Shepherd on the set of ``The Last Picture Show,'' the three were reunited in Archer City, Texas, during the making of the sequel. ``Even though I wasn't born or raised in Archer City, that's where my career began,'' Shepherd said in the Oct. 8 issue of People magazine. ``So it was like going home again.'' Platt came briefly to the set to visit her daughter, Antonia Bogdanovich, 22, a still photographer for ``Texasville.'' ``It was just so satisfying to give up that pain,'' Platt said of the reunion. ``It was the most bizarre experience, but to me it was exhilarating. Who ever gets a chance to go back?'' The three say they're just friends now. --- LONDON (AP) - Princess Alexandra, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, will visit Southern California this month. The princess will attend the opening of the Festival of Britain, which will be held Oct. 11-17 in Orange County, a spokeswoman for her said Monday. Married to businessman Angus Ogilvy, the 53-year-old Alexandra is a popular member of the British royal family but shuns the limelight. Her father, Prince George, was killed in a flying accident during World War II when she was 5. The princess and her two brothers were raised by their mother, Princess Marina. Alexandra, trained as a nurse, has traveled around the world on royal visits. She was last in the United States on an official visit in 1987 as guest of honor at a dinner at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes Halt to Overseas Construction Projects
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is calling a halt to military construction projects overseas until President Bush draws up a plan for basing a smaller military force. By voice vote on Monday, the Senate approved an $8 billion spending bill for fiscal 1991 that eliminates most of the projects Bush proposed for Europe and deletes all construction in South Korea and Japan. ``It would be premature to proceed with construction at specified locations until the Defense Department has finalized overseas base closure plans,'' the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on military construction said in its report on the bill. The bill trims $1.1 billion from Bush's budget request for the fiscal year that began Monday. It is about $400 million below the amount approved by the House. Conferees from the two chambers will meet later this month to craft a compromise measure. The Senate bill cuts $151 million from Bush's budget of $153 million for West Germany, $43 million from the request of $44 million for Italy and $46 million from the budget of $47 million for Britain. The bill eliminated all $83 million the administration sought for South Korean projects and all $18 million for Japan. ``The Defense Department should seek host-nation funding for all construction requirements in those countries,'' the subcommittee report said. Certain to draw the ire of the Bush administration is a provision of the bill that prevents the use of U.S. dollars from the NATO Infrastructure Fund and the Air Force for construction of new air base in Crotone, Italy, to house the 401st Tactical Wing of F-16 jet fighters. The United States and its allies agreed to build the new facility in Italy after Spain refused to allow the fighter wing to remain at the U.S. base in Torrejon de Ardoz, Spain. The committee report said ``financing for a new $800 million foreign air base is simply not available when dozens of domestic bases are being closed.'' Domestically, Missouri and Washington state were hit hard as the Senate targeted construction projects associated with the B-2 stealth bomber and the plan to place MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars. In Missouri, the bill cut $41 million from the administration's budget request, including $9 million for B-2 maintenance docks. Washington lost $93 million in construction projects, including $73 million for rail garrison facilities. The Senate was kinder in the home states of several of the subcommittee's members. In Utah, home of Republican Sen. Jake Garn, construction projects increased $40 million. Funds for Georgia, home state of Democratic Sen. Wyche Fowler, increased $30 million, including $10 million for a soldier service center at Fort Gordon. In Alaska, home of Republican Sen. Ted Stevens, the bill adds $13 million over the administration's request. In Hawaii, home of Democratic Sen. Daniel Inouye, the bill added $2 million. The same amount went to Nevada, home of Democratic Sen. Harry Reid. In Iowa, home of the subcommittee's ranking Republican, Sen. Charles Grassley, funds for military construction were $14 million over the administration's request. But in Tennessee, home of the panel's chairman, Democratic Sen. James Sasser, funds for projects dropped $43 million with all the money coming from a large rocket test facility at the Arnold Engineering Development Center. In West Virginia, home of the chairman of the full Senate Appropriations Committee, Sen. Robert Byrd, projects for the Army National Guard, Army Reserve and Air National Guard were increased $26 million.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Apartment Dwellers are on the Move - All at Once
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: Synchronized leasing. A fancy name for moving hell. Not enough vans. Not enough crews. Not enough room on the streets for thousands of Chicago apartment dwellers who pack up and head for new digs at the same time twice each year when their leases expire simultaneously. Monday, Oct. 1, was one of those days. May 1 is the other. ``We started at 10 a.m. and it is now 4 p.m.,'' said Jim Marchesi, who had to maneuver his rental truck around four others on his North Side block Sunday. ``I have only had to move about five blocks, and it feels like I have moved from five different countries.'' So-called ``synchronized leasing'' has been around a long time, but most cities abandoned the practice. No one seems to know why it lingered in Chicago, but many people believe it may have something to do with the city's weather. ``No one in their right mind wants to move in a Chicago summer or a Chicago winter,'' said leasing agent Tom Lucido. ``By May 1 it's usually warm - but not hot - and the weather really does change significantly from September to October. By Oct. 1, it's cool - but not cold.'' Synchronized leasing, Lucido said, is horrendous. ``The typical nightmare is that you have a tenant whose lease expires Sept. 30, and they haven't moved out yet when the new tenant's supposed to move in Oct. 1,'' he said. ``You end up with a tenant sitting out there in a moving van with no place to go.'' Commonwealth Edison Co. and Peoples Gas Co. estimated that more than 50,000 rental units were up for tenant changes on or about Oct. 1. A similar number of moves were made about May 1. ``You can't get a truck. You can't get a mover. You can't get an elevator,'' said Joel Kline. ``You're moving into an apartment someone's moving out of. You're moving out of an apartment someone's moving into. It's just terrible.'' Kline was among the lucky. He got a four-day lease extension. ``It's been total chaos,'' said Dave Beard, assistant manager of a U-Haul outlet. ``We never seem to have enough equipment come May and October. People get frustrated. There are attitude problems.'' Chicago Student Movers, which uses leased trucks and a temporary work force of college students to provide inexpensive moving for apartment dwellers, averages 10 moves a day most monts. It had 80 Sunday. More were lined up for Monday. Company owner Guy Wojciechowski said he brought in 155 additional trucks and hired 100 extra men to handle the business. Truck and trailer rental companies recommend reservations at least several weeks in advance of the May 1 and Oct. 1 deadlines. But many renters never seem to learn. ``Simply put, if they reserved a truck weeks in advance, they're very happy people,'' said Charlotte Adams, who works for Ryder Truck Rental. ``If they just walk in hoping to get one, they're very unhappy people.'' Some accuse landlords and real estate agents of clinging to synchronized leasing to manipulate the availability and price of rental housing, but Lucido maintained it really doesn't benefit building owners and managers. ``When the worst happens, and the October renter can't move in, you have to provide him with emergency housing - rent free - until you manage to get the old tenant out,'' he said. ``By law, it takes 21 days to get eviction proceedings going, and the sheriff's department is always backed up three or four weeks this time of year, so you can wind up losing several months' rent.''

DOC.HEAD: Regan Claims Deregulation Helped Limit S&L Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDS: McNamar is correct in 12th graf, bgng Sen. Joseph
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: The deregulatory policies of the Reagan administration helped contain the savings and loan crisis, former Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan is telling skeptical congressional Democrats. ``I think the thrift industry would have gone into the tank sooner and may have never emerged,'' Regan told the House Banking Committee at the first in a series of hearings on the causes of the S&L mess. Regan, who was Treasury secretary from 1981 to 1985, said that after interest rates soared in the early 1980s it became clear that a financial business confined to taking deposits from savers and lending the money to home buyers could not survive. He said he had favored giving thrifts the same investment powers as commercial banks, but had opposed the broader deregulation in some states that had given thrifts non-bank powers. The committee also heard on Monday from Richard T. Pratt, who served as the nation's top thrift regulator from 1981 to 1982. Pratt defended his decision to allow S&Ls to hide their losses with accounting techniques. Pratt said when he took office, nearly every S&L in the country was technically insolvent because soaring interest rates had drastically cut the value of their low-interest, fixed-rate mortgages. Regulators' strategy was to close the worst institutions and to buy time for the others until interest rates fell, as they did, he said. Panel members pressed Regan, who was chairman of Merrill Lynch before becoming treasury secretary, on his involvement with the development of so-called brokered deposits. Such high-interest deposits, placed by Wall Street brokerage houses, usually in amounts just under the $100,000 deposit insurance limit, are blamed for fueling the explosive growth in risky investments at many S&Ls. Regan, however, said he had disqualified himself from any policy matters affecting brokered deposits because of his connection to Merrill Lynch. He said the firm did not deal in them extensively until after he left. ``I want a blood test as far as being the father of brokered deposits. I am not - in no way, shape or fashion,'' he said. Rep. Joseph Kennedy, D-Mass., countered that Regan allowed his subordinate, Deputy Treasury Secretary R.T. McNamar, to forcefully advocate their use. Edwin Gray, the nation's top thrift regulator from 1983 to 1987, has accused Regan of trying to force him from office when he tried to rein in the industry in general and brokered deposits in particular. Regan, who previously had not had a chance to reply to Gray in a public forum, described him as an absentee, lax regulator. ``In 1985, when I became (White House) chief of staff, I began to hear rumors that this man was not paying attention; he was part of the problem, not the solution. ... He was sort of a front for the industry. I didn't like that,'' Regan said. He said that between September 1983 and June 1986, Gray was in his office only 397 weekdays and absent 466 days. He also noted that Gray was forced to repay his agency, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, $26,000 for travel and entertainment. ``He want to Pebble Beach. He went to Greenbriar. My crack was, `I think he's working more on his (golf) handicap than he's working on the thrifts,''' Regan said. Gray and former Federal Reserve Board Chairman Paul Volcker are scheduled to appear before the committee Wednesday. The committee chairman, Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, plans to hear from Carter administration officials later. In other S&L developments Monday: -Federal regulators said they had transferred most offices of the Phoenix-based Merabank to Bank of America, estimating the bailout of the thrift - once Arizona's largest - at $1 billion. Bank of America Arizona, a subsidiary of the San Francisco-based holding company, is taking over Merabank's 66 Arizona branches, the Resolution Trust Corp. said. The agency will keep Merabank's seven Texas branches for later sale. -Texas and California savings and loans dominate a list of the top 100 federal thrift investigations by the Justice Department, National Mortgage News, a weekly trade newspaper, reported. There were 36 Texas S&Ls on the list, which has not been publicly released, and 20 from California. Oklahoma and Illinois and eight institutions listed, Florida had six; Colorado, five, and Louisiana and New Jersey, four each.

DOC.HEAD: `Pacific Heights' Opens in First Place
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The thriller ``Pacific Heights'' opened in first place at the nation's movie theaters, while director Martin Scorsese's acclaimed Mafia drama, ``GoodFellas,'' was No. 2 at the weekend box office. The yuppie nightmare ``Pacific Heights'' grossed $6.9 million, Exhibitor Relations Co. reported Monday. The film stars Matthew Modine and Melanie Griffith as San Francisco landlords tormented by tenant Michael Keaton. ``GoodFellas'' took in $5.9 million in its second week of release. ``Texasville'' didn't strike oil. The sequel of sorts to 1971's ``The Last Picture Show'' opened to arid reviews and empty seats. It made $823,534 for 12th place. The supernatural thriller ``Ghost'' collected $5.4 million for third place and has now made $155.3 million. Fourth was the Meryl Streep growing-up-in-Hollywood comedy ``Postcards From the Edge,'' with $4.1 million. ``Narrow Margin,'' a thriller with Anne Archer, Gene Hackman and a passenger train, rolled away with $2 million for fifth. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Pacific Heights,'' 20th Century Fox, $6.9 million, 1,278 screens, $5,409 per screen, $6.9 million, one week. 2. ``GoodFellas,'' Warner Bros., $5.9 million, 1,291 screens, $4,556 per screen, $14.9 million, two weeks. 3. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $5.4 million, 1,766 screens, $3,078 per screen, $155.3 million, 12 weeks. 4. ``Postcards From the Edge,'' Columbia, $4.1 million, 1,323 screens, $3,100 per screen, $23.2 million, three weeks. 5. ``Narrow Margin,'' Tri-Star, $2 million, 1,253 screens, $1,563 per screen, $6.6 million, two weeks. 6. ``I Come in Peace,'' Epic-Triumph, $1.91 million, 1,041 screens, $1,837 per screen, $1.91 million, one week. 7. ``Death Warrant,'' MGM-UA, $1.88 million, 1,077 screens, $1,748 per screen, $11.8 million, three weeks. 8. ``Flatliners,'' Columbia, $1.7 million, 1,435 screens, $1,167 per screen, $53.7 million, eight weeks. 9. ``Funny About Love,'' Paramount, $1.6 million, 1,213 screens, $1,358 per screen, $5.3 million, two weeks. 10. ``Presumed Innocent,'' Warner Bros. $1.4 million, 1,097 screens, $1,243 per screen, $80.6 million, 10 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes Near Canton After Apparent Hijacking
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with details of crash, airport closed. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese passenger jet traveling between two southern provinces on a domestic flight crashed Tuesday after the Boeing 737 apparently was hijacked, officials said. Airport officials at Canton international airport said the crash occurred near the large southern city that is capital of Guangdong province. Hong Kong radio, quoting the Canton People's Broadcasting Station, said the plane, carrying 90 passengers, ``collided'' with two other planes at the airport. There was no immediate explanation for the conflicting information. The radio report said there were survivors but gave no further details. Officials at the airport said it was closed soon after the 8 a.m. crash. Hong Kong is about 70 miles southeast of Canton. The flight apparently originated from the Fujian province city of Xiamen, which is north of Guangdong province. Its destination was not immediately known, but according to airline schedules the only plane due to leave Xiamen early this morning was a Boeing 737 bound for Shanghai. An airport official and a reporter for the Guangdong People's Broadcasting Station said they believed the plane, owned by China's state airline CAAC, was first hijacked before it crashed. Richard Stites, a spokesman at the U.S. Consulate in Canton, said the consulate had not been notified about any Americans on board. In Beijing, officials at the state airline's headquarters refused to even confirm the crash. Editors at various official news media in the capital said they had no information on it. No further details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Votes to Continue Ban on Offshore Drilling
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices may be soaring and America's dependence on foreign petroleum may be all too clear, but a key congressional panel says those aren't reasons enough to open the nation's coastal waters to oil drilling. The House Appropriations Committee voted Monday to extend for a year the wide-reaching prohibition on oil and gas leasing along thousands of miles of coastal waters from Alaska to New England. The moratorium on the leasing was included in the Interior Department's budget and goes even farther than the curbs on drilling announced by President Bush last June. ``This was the first real test to protecting the offshore areas since Iraq invaded Kuwait,'' said Lisa Speer, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental organization. ``We had been nervous about this,'' she said, noting that the oil industry has been pressing the administration and Congress to open new areas of the Outer Continental Shelf for exploratory drilling in light of the Persian Gulf crisis. Industry groups greeted the action by the House panel with disappointment. ``The Outer Continental Shelf contains enough oil to replace our imports from the Persian Gulf for the next 25 years,'' said Robert Stewart, president of the National Ocean Industries Association. The group represents companies involved in offshore oil drilling. The action was seen widely as an attempt to preempt any action by the administration to reverse itself on the decision last June when the president announced a postponement, in some cases as long as 10 years, of oil and gas leases off much of the West Coast, southern Florida and New England. ``This extension guarantees the protection of the California coastline to avoid any possible retreat by the president,'' said Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``It provides the protection that we need.'' White House officials have said Bush has no intention of backing away from his June announcement, despite lobbying from industry to ease some of the prohibitions. Some congressmen as well as environmentalists have been worried that the administration might change its mind amid the clamor over jumping oil prices, the threat of possible shortages and pressures to ease America's reliance on foreign crude. The Appropriations Committee voted to extend the moratorium on oil leases for one year in all the areas singled out for special protection by Bush last June and went a step further. It extended the ban on leases in Alaska's Bristol Bay, the eastern Gulf of Mexico off northern Florida, and along a 50-mile buffer in the North Atlantic from Connecticut to northern Virginia. The measure must still be approved by the House and the Senate, but environmentalists called the vote a key victory for protecting the offshore areas from oil companies. Traditionally the House appropriations panel has taken the lead in pushing for moratoria on offshore leasing, with the full House and Senate likely to go along.
