The oil industry has cited the Persian Gulf crisis as clear evidence that domestic oil production should be expanded including more offshore drilling along the Outer Continental Shelf. ``Many observers in the past month have noted the irony in the fact that the U.S. is risking the lives of American troops and spending billions to protect Middle East oil while the domestic supply lies dormant in our own backyard,'' said Stewart, the drilling industry spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel to Quiz Five Senators on Aid to Keating
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee is summoning five senators to explain their assistance for Charles H. Keating Jr. at a time his Lincoln Savings and Loan was plummeting toward a massive collapse. The senators will appear over the next two weeks, the committee announced Monday, after which the panel will act on recommendations from its special counsel. Congressional sources said counsel Robert S. Bennett has recommended that the investigation go forward for Democratic Sens. Alan Cranston of California, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and Dennis DeConcini of Arizona. Bennett, also recommended that the investigations of Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz., and John Glenn, D-Ohio, be dismissed, the sources said. Continuation of any of the cases could mean trial-like hearings would be scheduled, probably next year. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Bennett's report establishes crucial links between the timing of contributions by Keating to Cranston, Riegle and DeConcini and actions they took on Keating's behalf. ``The conclusion was there was no connection between the contributions and actions'' of Glenn and McCain, one source said. The links were instrumental in Bennett's recommendations, said another source, who added Bennett's conclusions are not based on a single factor but o a pattern and practice of behavior by each senator. Glenn and McCain are scheduled to appear before the six-member ethics panel this week, sources said. It was not known when the other senators will testify. ``Under our existing practices, the committee must give each senator under investigation the opportunity to be heard by the committee in executive session before any decisions are made,'' a committee statement said. ``Following these meetings with the senators, the committee will meet to decide how it will proceed.'' The five senators received a total of $1.3 million from Keating and his associates for their campaigns and causes, and intervened with U.S. banking regulators on behalf of the former head of Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif. The federal government seized Keating's thrift in April 1989. It could cost taxpayers more than $2 billion to cover the losses from the collapse The senators have said they intervened with regulators - especially in two key meetings in April 1987 - because Keating made a persuasive case that his S&L was being treated unfairly. All have denied that their intervention was driven by the donations. Public documents and statements show some links between the contributions and contacts with regulators by Riegle, Cranston and DeConcini. However, Bennett reportedly has much more precise connections involving the timing. The public record shows that: -Keating was the host of a fund-raiser for Riegle in Detroit on March 23, 1987, less than two weeks before four senators met with the nation's chief thrift regulator April 2, 1987. Riegle said he received $78,250 from Keating and his associates at the fund-raiser. Riegle didn't attend that April 2 meeting, although he suggested it be held. He was at an April 9 meeting between all five senators and regulators examining Lincoln. -Cranston solicited $850,000 from Keating for three voter registration projects. The contributions began in June 1987, two months after the meetings with regulators, and continued through February 1988. Cranston also received $39,000 from Keating and his associates for his 1986 re-election campaign. -DeConcini received $15,000 in campaign donations from Keating or his associates in 1986, before the meetings with regulators, and an additional $5,000 in October 1987. In addition to the April 1987 meetings, DeConcini and Cranston continued a series of contacts with regulators right up to the time the thrift was seized in April 1989. Both said they intervened in an effort to get Lincoln sold, rather than seized by the government, in order to save jobs. The links between those contacts and contributions could not immediately be determined. At the April 2, 1987, meeting, Cranston, McCain, DeConcini and Glenn discussed Lincoln with Edwin J. Gray, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Gray told the House Banking Committee last November that Riegle suggested the meeting with senators. Riegle acknowledged that such a meeting was ``one of the issues'' he discussed with Gray a month earlier, but he denied actually arranging the session. Gray testified that the four senators at the April 2 meeting offered a deal on Keating's behalf: If regulators waived a rule prohibiting risky investments for Lincoln, the thrift would finance more home mortgages. All four senators vigorously denied that a deal was offered. On April 9, 1987, all five senators, meeting with the San Francisco-based regulators who were examining Lincoln, were told that allegations against Keating's thrift were so serious that criminal referrals were being made to the Justice Department.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Say They May Give Trustees Six Months to Quit
DOC.TEXT: Students barricaded inside a building at the University of the District of Columbia say they may give some members of the school's board of trustees until March 31 to resign. Leaders of the protest, which began Wednesday, had said the students wouldn't leave the building unless the 11 mayoral appointees to the 15-member board submitted letters of resignation immediately. However they softened that demand on Monday. ``That gives everybody six months to determine whether or not there are some members we want to reinstate or some we want to replace,'' protest leader Mark Thompson said. The protesters are demanding extensive changes in the way the 12,000-student university is run and improvements in several athletic and academic programs. They say the board has allowed the quality of the school to decline and put the accreditation of some of its departments in jeopardy. The students and the board have reached agreement on nearly all of the students' other demands. But negotiations remain stalemated on the issue of resignations, with most of the board refusing to quit. ``It would not appear to be in the best interests of the university for them to quit,'' UDC spokesman John Britton said. ``We've made progress, and honestly, the dialogue has become a bit more candid and a bit more cordial, but we're still discussing and neither side has really bent any,'' Thompson said. Thompson said about 500 students remained in the building Monday, down from the 1,000 he said participated in the demonstrations this weekend. Trustees have estimated the number of students involved from 150 to 300. Thompson said protesters were successful in persuading most students to stay away from classes Monday, despite administrators having officially opened the university for the first time since demonstrations began. ``As far as we are concerned, school is still closed,'' Thompson said. All buildings except an administration building occupied by the students were reopened. But instructors were seen conducting classes with fewer than 10 students each. Two trustees have agreed to resign for personal reasons, Britton said, but the protests had not forced the actions. A third trustee has agreed to quit because of illness, Thompson said. Trustee Nira Long has agreed to step down as board chairwoman but has refused to leave the board.

DOC.HEAD: Near Chaos in Downtown Berlin Just Before Unification
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Poles have poured into Berlin by the tens of thousands, packing buses, jamming trains and sputtering along in tiny cars. Their goal: one last, mad shopping spree to get Western goods before German unification. Poles could freely come to East Germany and then pass unhindered into the consumer nirvana of West Berlin. But at midnight today East Germany won't exist and Poles and others will have to meet rigorous visa requirements. Others seeking a quick profit in Berlin's frantic days before unification were East European gypsies, a few Soviets, Germans and even an enterprising Afghan. The Poles were especially noticeable on downtown streets Monday. There were Poles pulling baggage carts loaded with stereos, video equipment, television sets and boom boxes. Rushing through Berlin's hectic streets, the Poles pushed their goods and loaded them into dozens and dozens of waiting buses parked along broad avenues. Berliners sat in outdoor cafes despite an uncomfortable wind and threatening dark clouds. They seemed subdued compared with the euphoria of the days in November when the Berlin Wall was opened. Millions of East Germans then poured across the border and West Berlin's streets were a circus of consumerism. But the most cosmopolitan of German cities was still enjoying the show on Monday, throbbing with life as it prepared to become Germany's capital, the biggest city between Paris and Moscow. At the Brandenburg Gate, hundreds of tourists browsed through the bazaar that has mushroomed along the former ``death strip'' that separated East and West. An Afghan sold his native-country rugs, East German soldiers' fur aps, Soviet-made watches and Islamic literature. The symbols of an outdated ideology and its military might were being auctioned off at the once-forbidding Cold War barrier. A German was peddling East German flags, Soviet army belts and a large blue, gold-edged banner that said, `Always Ready for Peace and Socialism.'' Next to him, two Soviets were offering records of Lenin's thoughts, excerpts from speeches by their late hard-line leader Leonid Brezhnev, and heroic martial songs performed by the Red Army choir. At row after row of stands, Eastern European gypsies were doing brisk a business in Soviet military belts, spy glasses, night-vision infra-red binoculars, pistol holsters, East German army helmets and Soviet and East German uniforms. A Soviet woman was unloading a bagfull of red Lenin banners to a gypsy seller. Another group of Soviets was selling Lenin pins to a group of Americans. Above the crowd, television technicians used cranes to hoist floodlights in preparation for unification, which comes at the stroke of midnight. Asian manufacturers of electronics will be celebrating German unification too; their countries are receiving another boost to their bulging trade surpluses. West Berlin merchants were struggling to meet the demand on Monday as Poles scrambled to beat the imposition of visas that will come with unification. To get visas, Poles will have to have 50 marks (about $30) for every day they plan to spend in Germany and will have to show they have medical insurance coverage for their stay. Across from the seedy Zoo train station, a truck was unloading TV sets. Impatient Poles were crowding around the truck. A worker wiped his sweaty brow and begged for space so that he could carry the packed sets into the store. In front of the City Radio store, ropes were put up to form lines. The stereos, the TV sets, the videos never got unpacked as scores of Poles snapped them up. Polish cars took nearly all parking spaces around the station, and in some of them weary shoppers took naps. Families took breaks, sitting on boxes of newly bought stereo equipment. Others fanned across the city to search for their buses. Perhaps hundreds were parked along the broad avenues leading to the Brandenburg Gate, even blocking the view to the Bellevue Palace, the official residence of German presidents. Thousands went back to Poland in train cars packed with people, food and the latest in electronic gear. One man pushed a supermarket cart on top of which a huge TV set, too big to fit into the cart, swayed precariously, tied with a rope. One woman took off her shoes and lay across several boxes containing stereos. A large grocery bag served as her pillow.

DOC.HEAD: About 90 People Treated After Food Poisoning Outbreak
DOC.TEXT: About 90 people were taken by ambulance to hospitals after an apparent outbreak of food poisoning at a hotel, officials said. The victims were attending a hardware convention and apparently were poisoned at a Sunday night banquet at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, said Fire Department spokesman Tom Sheppard. They were taken by ambulance Monday night from three hotels where they were staying. ``I'd say about 95 percent of the victims walked out on their own power,'' Sheppard said. At least two dozen of the victims were reported in fair condition. Iowa residents Darwin and Donna Springer complained of vomiting and diarrhea after the dinner of chicken, bread pudding and salad. A person who answered the telephone at the Hyatt said the hotel had no comment.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Party Plans $20 Million Lawsuit Against Democrats
DOC.TEXT: The Harold Washington Party is filing a $20 million federal lawsuit accusing Cook County Democratic Party leaders of conspiring to keep the predominantly black third party off the Nov. 6 ballot. R. Eugene Pincham, attorney for the Washington Party, said the Cook County Democratic Party and a number of its leaders were named as defendants, as were five private citizens who challenged the Washington Party's nominating petitions. Pincham, a former appellate judge running for the Cook County Board on the Washington Party ticket, said the lawsuit contends the Democratic Party concealed its involvement in challenges to the nominating petitions. The lawsuit, filed Monday in U.S. District Court, also contends that one sheet of objections to the petitions was duplicated 6,000 times and that copies were attached to each petition. Pincham said election law requires that objections be made out for individually for each challenged petition sheet. ``There never has been such a massive fraud disclosed,'' Pincham said at a news conference. The lawsuit contends Democratic leaders hired influential former U.S. District Court Judge George N. Leighton to serve as attorney for the five citizens who objected to the legitimacy of the Washington Party's petitions. Spokesmen for the Cook County Democratic Party could not be immediately reached for comment because no one answered the party's office telephone Monday afternoon.
DOC.HEAD: School Administrators Back Edgar for Governor
DOC.TEXT: A group representing 1,000 Illinois school officials is breaking with tradition to endorse Republican Jim Edgar over Democrat Neil Hartigan for governor. The Illinois Association of School Administrators said Monday it backed Edgar because of his education program and his support for making permanent the temporary income tax surcharge that generates more than $350 million a year for education. John Wargo, the group's executive director, saidtthe organization had never before endorsed anyone in a political campaign but decided to back Edgar because of his ``clear difference'' with Hartigan on education issues.
DOC.HEAD: Fire Hits Congressman's Campaign Office
DOC.TEXT: Authorities were investigating the possibility of arson in a fire that caused minor damage at Republican U.S. Rep. Denny Smith's campaign office in downtown Salem, says a campaign spokesman. The fire began in a storage room and burned itself out before causing any major structural damage to the storefront office, said Smith spokesman Tony Williams. A campaign worker discovered the damage early Monday when she opened up the office, Williams said, adding that some campaign literature and other items were damaged in the fire. Williams said the Salem police and fire departments were investigating the blaze as a possible arson-caused fire. Smith, running for a sixth term in Congress, is being opposed by Democrat Mike Kopetski.

DOC.HEAD: Gingrich Launches Fight Against Bush Over Deficit-Cutting Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Newt Gingrich, the second-ranking Republican in the House, is staking out his opposition to President Bush's effort to pass a $500 billion deficit-reduction agreement. ``It is my conclusion that it will kill jobs, weaken the economy, that the tax increase will be counterproductive and it is not a package that I can support,'' Gingrich told reporters Monday. ``We need to do better than this.'' The Georgia Republican was one of the negotiators during the 4{ months of budget talks, but he refused to attend the announcement ceremony. He didn't announce his opposition immediately, waiting instead until Monday afternoon when it was clear there was strong apprehension among his House constituents and the public. Gingrich and his allies were careful not to attack the president directly, instead trying to pin the package - which is bound to be politically unpopular - on the Democrats. ``The Democrats basically extorted the president,'' said Rep. Duncan Hunter, R-Calif. who joined Gingrich at his press conference.

DOC.HEAD: Odd Aircraft Spotted in West
DOC.TEXT: Several large, quiet, triangular wing-shaped aircraft of unknown origin have been spotted in the air near Air Force bases in California and elsewhere in the West, reports Aviation Week and Space Technology. A different aircraft whose engines produce a loud roar that resembles heavy rocket engines also has been spotted, the magazine said. The Air Force declined to confirm or deny that the sightings were of new warplanes. The publication, the current week's edition that became available Monday, says the triangular aircraft are possibly prototypes of the Air Force B-2 or Navy A-12 aircraft. The A-12 is a new fighter under development, which has not been displayed. The B-2 is the ``stealth'' bomber, which has been displayed, and its shape is well-known. Aviation Week published what appeared to be pictures of the A-12 without explaining whether they were actual aircraft in flight, artists' conceptions, models or something else. The magazine said the triangular craft did not resemble the production B-2 with its distinctive sawtooth wing trailing edge. It quoted ``well qualified observers'' as reporting that the aircraft are ``fairly flat'' and triangular shaped with ``a rounded nose, rounded wingtips and probably no vertical tail surfaces.'' The observers were not otherwise identified. One observer in Nevada was quoted as saying the shape of the aircraft was ``like a manta ray.'' The magazine said there have been at least 11 sightings of the triangular aircraft near Edwards Air Force Base in California and one near Fresno, Calif. It said there have been other sightings of similar aircraft in central Nevada near ranges operated by the Air Force and the Energy Department. It described at least 14 sightings of the loud craft, called the ``pulser'' from the pulsating nature of the sound, varying up and down in intensity once or twice a second, plus other reports of the sound, often at night. It said that typically the pulser aircraft are seen flying a southwest to northwest track near Edwards Air Force Base and the China Lake Naval Weapon Center. ``This routing would suggest the aircraft are returning from test ranges or `work areas' off the western U.S. coast where airline pilots have reported seeing very high-speed vehicles at altitudes above 50,000 feet,'' the magazine said. A companion article said research aircraft flying from Nevada sites include ``both manned and unmanned hypersonic-capable aircraft designed to perform strategic reconnaissance and other, less conventionally defined missions.'' Some aircraft were said to have ``exotic propulsion and aerodynamic schemes not fully understood at this time.'' Col. Joe Purka, an air force public affairs officer, said he could say nothing.

DOC.HEAD: Hitler Quote in Review Prompts Campus Commotion
DOC.TEXT: The Dartmouth Review, a politically conservative Dartmouth College weekly that has attacked women, blacks and homosexuals, is under fire for printing an anti-Semitic passage from Hitler's ``Mein Kampf.'' The student newspaper was distributed Saturday on Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement and Judaism's most solemn day. Dartmouth spokesman Alex Huppe said Monday a student petition drive against the newspaper collected more than 1,000 signatures, and a protest rally is planned for Thursday. The off-campus paper is not affiliated with the college. The Dartmouth Student Assembly, which represents the 3,200 undergraduates, condemned The Review, and university President James Freedman accused the paper of ``an act of moral cowardice'' and a pattern of discriminatory attacks. The passage from Hitler's manifesto was inserted, without attribution, into the credo on The Review's masthead: ``Therefore, I believe today that I am acting in the sense of the Almighty Creator: By warding off the Jews, I am fighting for the Lord's work.'' Editor in chief Kevin Pritchett said the quote was inserted without the editors' knowledge. He said someone could have gotten access to the paper's computers. ``It was an ugly, awful, anti-Semitic prank,'' he said. ``It caused a lot of hurt feelings. We at The Review are sickened by this.'' The newspaper, in a statement, offered ``heartfelt apologies to Jews at Dartmouth and to the Dartmouth community at large'' and said it is investigating how the passage got into print. ``Our office is not secure,'' Pritchett said. ``It's Hanover, New Hampshire, not New York City.'' The paper, which has been published since 1980 with backing from some of the nation's most prominent conservatives, has been vilified over the years for its views on women, homosexuals and blacks. Most recently, William Cole, a black music professor, resigned in August after The Review attacked him for seven years in print, belitting him as mediocre. Cole said his effectiveness was compromised by the attacks. Cole filed a $600,000 libel suit against the paper that was settled out of court two years later for no money. After Cole refused to talk about a scathing Review article in 1988, four student staff members confronted him in his classroom after a lecture. The students photographed and tape-recorded the encounter, saying Cole swore at them and broke the flash attachment off the camera. The college suspended three of the students. A judge ordered them reinstated. The petition distributed against The Review accused it a series of actions that have ``fostered an intolerance of diversity at the college'' and ``undermined our college's reputation and hindered unity.'' ``The opinions expressed by the 24 staff members of The Review do not represent those of the Dartmouth Community,'' the petition said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops Use Oasis for Urban Warfare Training
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Army troops have turned an abandoned oasis into a training ground for a kind of warfare not usually associated with the desert - street fighting. It's called MOUT - for Military Operations in Urban Terrain. The exercise Monday shows the determination of U.S. forces to be ready to defend Saudi towns from any Iraqi invasion or possibly to dislodge Iraqi occupation forces from Kuwait City. It was an otherworldly setting to play out fearsome possibilities. The site, which one officer described as ``right out of a 1950s Foreign Legion movie,'' was a town that once had about 200 inhabitants. The town has stood vacant, silent but for the desert wind whining through scrub pines, since the residents picked up and left about 10 years ago for a new town that was built for them by King Fahd. A wall bore evidence of incongruous foxhole humor - a sign saying ``Master Charge and Visa accepted here.'' But for military reasons, this cluster of stone and mud buildings, some still bearing ornate wooden doors, was ``an ideal setting,'' said Capt. John Madigan. Madigan, of Springfield, Va., a company commander in the 101st Airborne Division, said he had trained in street fighting at a site in California, but ``that doesn't replicate the distance or size that you have out here in the Saudia desert.'' In Monday's exercise, his troops advanced building by building through the sand-swept streets, employing the tactics they would use in actual street fighting. They simulated combat without using live ammunition. Although the town is uninhabted, Madigan said his troops were instructed to avoid further damage to crumbling walls. Some soldiers complained about suddenly finding their bottled drinking water replaced by well water with an unpleasant, brackish taste. Front-line units have had liberal supplies of water in plastic bottles since the beginning of Operation Desert Shield, the U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia. ``We've gone to an oasis well water here,'' said 1st Sgt. Joseph Mudd, of St. Louis. ``It's the only type of water we may see in combat.'' He said chlorine had been added to purify it. Maj. Dan Grigson, a division spokesman, said the bottled water took up too much space in helicopters. The oasis water came from a 100-foot well and ``has been tested and is perfectly safe,'' he said. Some troopers said the packets of flavored drink mix in the meal rations helped to overcome what Spec. Anthony Stewart of Bessemer, Ala., said was ``like swimming pool water.'' Spec. Lorenza Abrams of Richmond, Calif., said, ``regular water goes down easy. Not this one. They say to close your eyes and your nose. That way you won't taste it.''

DOC.HEAD: Museum Witnesses Defend Explicit Photographs as Art
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Trial scheduled to resume at 10:15 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Robert Mapplethorpe was one of the most important photographers of the 1980s, says a museum director who rushed to get his work on display before he died of AIDS. ``I felt it was my responsibility as a curator to work with him while he was alive,'' Janet Kardon, director of New York's American Craft Museum, testified Monday at the obscenity trial of a colleague for showing seven of the pictures. ``It's the job of a contemporary curator to record history even while it's happening,'' she said. More defense testimony was scheduled for today in the trial of the Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, on charges of obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. If convicted in the nation's first obscenity trial of a museum, Barrie could receive a year in jail and a $2,000 fine. The gallery could be fined $10,000. Ms. Kardon was director of the University of Pennsylvania's Institute of Contemporary Art when the Mapplethorpe exhibit was assembled. The seven photographs in question are among 175 pictures in the exhibit, which was on display in Cincinnati for seven weeks ending May 26. The work is now in Boston. Mapplethorpe died of AIDS in March 1989. Jurors on Monday got their first look at the seven photos, glancing at them with no visible reaction as they were passed around. Five of the photographs show sexually graphic acts involving men, and two show naked children. Ms. Kardon, asked by a prosecutor to describe the artistic merit of four of the sexually explicit photos, said they were artistically lighted and framed and showed symmetry and use of horizontal and vertical lines. ``He was one of the most important photographers working in the '80s,'' Ms. Kardon said.

DOC.HEAD: UCLA Math Program Cited For Asian Discrimination
DOC.TEXT:
The Education Department says an investigation has determined that a graduate mathematics program at the University of California at Los Angeles discriminated against Asian Americans. Michael Williams, assistant secretary for civil rights, said Monday that the 30-month inquiry found ``a statistical disparity in the rates of admission to the mathematics department on the basis of race'' and ``an inconsistency in how Asian and white applicants who received the same evaluation ratings were treated.'' Seventy-five other departments were cleared of discrimination allegations, while eight departments were found to have inconclusive records, Williams said. The Office of Civil Rights also is investigating undergraduate admission practices at UCLA and at Harvard. As a result of the findings, Williams said UCLA must offer admission to five Asian-American students who had been ``discriminatorily denied admission.'' The university also must establish a uniform system of admission and improve recordkeeping ``to allow us to determine whether or not it is observing the civil rights laws.'' UCLA Chancellor Charles Young said the university will appeal the violation finding because ``we firmly believe that racially neutral criteria were used to make these decisions and that the OCR has no basis to conclude that discrimination exists at UCLA.''
---
DOC.HEAD: House Sends Decoder Provision to President
DOC.TEXT:
New television sets with 13-inch screens or larger would have to include built-in decoders for displaying closed captions for the deaf under legislation awaiting President Bush's signature. The House gave final approval to the bill Monday by voice vote. The Senate passed it in July. The measure requires TV sets sold after July 1993 to be equipped with circuitry for converting audio portions of a TV program into subtitles on the screen. Decoders are available now but they sell for $160 to $200 separately. The House Energy and Commerce Committee estimated that including the chips at manufacture would add no more than $15 to the retail price. In addition to the estimated 20 million to 24 million Americans who are deaf or hearing impaired, backers said the decoders also would benefit millions of children and functionally illiterate adults in learning to read as wells as immigrants trying to learn English. All prime-time television shows broadcast by the three major networks now carry closed captions, as do most national news shows and sports events.
---
DOC.HEAD: National Arboretum Opens Bonsai Museum
DOC.TEXT:
The National Arboretum has unveiled the official North American Bonsai Museum and paid tribute to the man called the father of that horticultural art in America. John Naka, after whom the pavilion was named, called the honor the most significant of his career. ``This is an honor that I never dreamed would come to me,'' he said Monday at dedication of the museum. ``People all over the world have embraced the art of the bonsai, and by doing that have embraced one another to their customs.'' Bonsai is the art of shaping trees and shrubs in shallow pots through pruning and controlled fertilization. The technique originated in Japan centuries ago.
---
DOC.HEAD: House Approves Limiting TV Commercials On Kids' Shows
DOC.TEXT: The House has sent legislation to President Bush that would reinstate limits on commercial advertising on children's television shows. The bill was approved on voice vote without dissent despite oposition from the Bush administration, which says the restrictions would ``create new and extremely serious First Amendment problems'' involving free speech. Also approved without opposition by the Senate, the legislation would effectively reverse the Reagan administration's deregulation of the commercial content of children's TV programming in 1984. Similar legislation was passed by both the House and Senate two years ago, but it was vetoed by President Reagan after Congress had adjourned. But with opposition from the television networks and the National Association of Broadcasters defused, sponsors of the bill said they hope the overwhelming congressional support it enjoys will persuade Bush not to veto it. ``The limits which we propose are reasonable,'' said Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas. ``I trust the support of various groups will persuade our president that this bill fits into his program as a kinder and gentler president who responds to family concerns.'' The legislation would limit commercial advertising during children's programming to 10{ minutes an hour on weekends an 12 minutes an hour on weekdays. It also would require the Federal Communications Commission - in renewing the licenses of television stations - to weigh how well broadcasters are serving the educational and informational needs of children. The House Energy and Commerce Committee estimates that the average child spends 10,000 to 15,000 hours in front of a television - more time than in school - and is exposed to more than 200,000 TV commercials by the time he or she reaches age 18.

DOC.HEAD: Gen. Curtis LeMay, Architect of Strategic Air Command, Dies
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Retired Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, the gruff, cigar-chomping ``Iron Eagle'' who built the nation's global nuclear strike force and suggested the United States threaten to bomb North Vietnam ``back into the Stone Age,'' is dead at 83. The four-star Air Force general died of a heart attack Monday at the base hospital. In addition to transforming the war-weary Strategic Air Command into a force that could deliver nuclear weapons anywhere in the world, LeMay relayed the order to drop the A-bomb on Japan and directed the Berlin Airlift in 1948. In 1968 he ran for vice president as George Wallace's running mate. During World War II, LeMay was instrumental in pressing the daylight bombing offensive against the Nazis. He led missions personally, demanding bombers not use evasive maneuvers over target areas thick with anti-aircraft fire. Transferred to the Pacific, he organized the B-29 bombing campaign against Japan. His planes dropped the atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. But he said later that Japan had already been beaten by incendiary bombing. ``We went ahead and droppped the bombs because President Truman told me to do it,'' he said in a 1985 interview. LeMay was in charge of the Air Force in Europe in 1948 when the Soviet Union cut off access to West Berlin. His management of the Berlin Airlift kept West Berlin supplied and dismayed Stalin. He became Air Force vice chief of staff in 1957 and chief of staff in 1961. Contending strategic air power held the key to U.S. security, LeMay pushed for a modern bomber force. He ushered in the B-52, still part of the nation's nuclear deterrent. LeMay retired as chief of staff in 1965, frustrated by Robert S. McNamara, defense secretary under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. McNamara had subordinated LeMay's coveted bombers to the new ballistic missiles and put restraints on U.S. air power in Vietnam, a sore point for LeMay, who believed in all-out war. In his 1965 autobiography, ``Mission with LeMay,'' he wrote that a solution to the Vietnam War might be to warn the North Vietnamese that they must ``draw in their horns and stop their aggression, or we are going to bomb them back into the Stone Age.'' Born in Columbus, Ohio, LeMay graduated from Ohio State University. Charles Lindbergh's flight to Paris led him to enlist as a cadet in the Army Air Corps in 1928. Tough on himself and subordinates, he was unable to distinguish between the unfortunate and the incompetent. But he would do any job he demanded of his followers. He was as comfortable in a machine gun turret as he was in the cockpit. The 1955 Jimmy Stewart movie ``Strategic Air Command'' provided a glimpse of the strike force LeMay built. A cigar-chomping Frank Lovejoy played a character with LeMay's tough, demanding persona. One story about LeMay was that he once found a SAC sentry who had put down his weapon to eat a sandwich. ``This afternoon I found a man guarding a hangar with a ham sandwich. There will be no more of that,'' LeMay said in a memo. LeMay was a gun collector, big-game hunter and ham radio operator. His nicknames included ``Iron Eagle'' and ``Iron Pants.'' In his autobiography, he said he had ``blood on my hands ... not because I preferred to bathe in blood. It was because I was part of a primitive world where men still had to kill in order to avoid being killed, or in order to avoid having their loved nation stricken and emasculated.'' A memorial service is scheduled for Wednesday at the air base chapel. Burial will be at the U.S. Air Force Academy on Thursday. Survivors include his wife, Helen, and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter's Notebook Seized by Police, Newspaper Threatens to Sue
DOC.TEXT: A detective got a search warrant and seized a reporter's notebook from her desk for an investigation of a slaying, shocking First Amendment experts. Police later backed down and returned the notes. ``It was a case of an aggressive, young, sometimes overzealous detective who felt the notes would help the case. We hope to put it to rest,'' said Paul Pash, police commissioner in suburban Warren. Detective Richard Van Hulle seized the notebook Saturday from Macomb Daily reporter Cindy Mooty, 27, while she was alone in the newsroom of the 55,000-circulation newspaper in Macomb County. He returned it on Monday. Herschel Fink, chairman of the State Bar of Michigan Law and Media Committee, called the seizure a violation of the First Amendment. ``It's so frankly abhorrent to freedom of speech maybe we all felt comfortable it couldn't happen,'' he said. ``I don't think it's a matter that we can allow to pass.'' Fink said his committee will discuss recommendations to the Michigan Supreme Court for a rule to prevent a similar incident. Mooty said the notes were of interviews with Elizabeth Schultz on the Sept. 21 slaying of Roy Smith III. Smith, 17, was shot from a passing car as he stood on Schultz's porch. Deputy Chief Carl Muschong said the notebook was held in an evidence locker until it was returned. He said police did not make copies. Ben Burns, editor and publisher of the Macomb Daily, said the newspaper may sue for damages. But he added, ``I'm not interested in pounding on some officer's head who was trying to do what he thought was a thorough investigation. ``We've had a very good relationship with the Warren police and we'd like to maintain that,'' he said. The search warrant was issued Friday by District Judge Dawnn Gruenberg, who said police told her Mooty had agreed to turn over the notes. ``Under the particular facts I had, I do not believe this was in any way connected to the First Amendment or a free press,'' the judge said. The police commissioner and deputy chief said they were not aware a judge had issued a search warrant until it was executed. Mooty said she told police last week that if they wanted her notes, they would have to subpoena them and that the newspaper would probably fight it. She said she never expected a search warrant. Dawn Phillips, general counsel for the Michigan Press Association, said Michigan law does not protect a reporter's notes. At least 26 states have some form of shield law that protects published or unpublished information and sources or bars a contempt ruling for refusing to submit material, she said. ``Reporters shouldn't be afraid on a Saturday morning when they go in to do a story that the police are going to show up,'' Phillips said.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Slams Into Another After Hijacking, Dozens Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with official confirmation of hijacking and crash, two planes hit on the ground. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese passenger jet that was hijacked on a domestic flight slammed into two other planes at Canton's international airport on Tuesday, and hospital officials said dozens of people were killed. The Boeing 737 was carrying about 90 passengers and all three planes exploded after the collision on the airport tarmac, according to Western diplomats a reporter at the Canton People's Broadcasting Station. About seven hours after the crash, China's official Xinhua News Agency reported only that a ``passenger plane of the Xiamen Airline company was hijacked'' and ``landed in accident at the Canton airport.'' Xiamen is a subsidiary of China's national carrier, CAAC. The news agency did not say who hijacked the plane or why. The reporter said all three planes belonged to CAAC. One, a Boeing 757, was believed to be Flight 3523, which had already begun boarding passengers for Shanghai. Casualties were rushed to at least five area hospitals. Officials said they closed the airport soon after the 8 a.m. accident in the southern city, capital of Guangdong province. ``Altogether several tens were killed,'' said an official at the Chinese Traditional Medicine Univesity in Canton. Like other officials, he spoke on condition of anonymity. A Taiwanese man was pronounced dead at his hospital, one of many in the provincial capital to receive casualties. An official at the No. 1 People's Hospital said it had received five victims and that one, a Chinese man, had died. ``We're right in the middle of emergency rescue procedures,'' the official said, declining to give her name. At the Red Cross Hospital, a nurse who only identified herself as Huang, said a 43-year-old Chinese man was being treated. The city health department refused to comment on the death toll. At least five flights between Canton and the nearby British colony, Hong Kong, were postponed. Six hours later, the airport reopened for international flights but no domestic flights were taking off. The hijacked flight originated in the Fujian city of Xiamen, north of Guangdong province, and was heading toward Canton when someone on board attempted to hijack it, a Western diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity from Canton. In Hong Kong, government-owned radio quoted Hong Kong air traffic controllers as saying they had been informed of a hijacking early Tuesday. Richard Stites, a spokesman at the U.S. Consulate in Canton, said the consulate had not been notified about any Americans on board. In Taipei, Taiwan, state-run television reported that at least two Taiwanese citizens had been on board the plane. Many Taiwanese originally come from Fujian province and Taiwanese businesses have invested millions of dollars there over the past few years.

DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Subsidiary Joins Doctors' Groups to Promote Health
DOC.TEXT: Two leading doctors' organizations are under fire from members for joining with a subsidiary of a tobacco conglomerate on a campaign to lower Americans' cholesterol and reduce their risk of heart attack. ``It's a pathetic use of a medical organization for the commercial ends of a tobacco and food conglomerate,'' said Dr. Alan Blum, a family physician and chairman and founder of the anti-smoking group DOC, or Doctors Ought to Care. Blum is a member of the two doctors' organizations, the American Medical Association and the American Academy of Family Physicians. ``Basically the American Medical Association and the American Academy of Family Physicians are associating with people who murder 400,000 Americans a year, in order to save a possible 35,000 or 40,000 because of lowering cholesterol,'' said Dr. Brent Blue of Jackson, Wyo., a member of the family physicians' academy. Smoking is a leading cause of heart disease. Cigarettes kill an estimated 390,000 Americans each year, according to the U.S. Office on Smoking and Health. The doctors' organizations have allowed their names and symbols to appear in newspaper and magazine supplements supported by Fleischmann's, a maker of margarine and a cholesterol-free egg substitute. Fleischmann's products are made by the Nabisco Foods Co., part of the RJR Nabisco tobacco conglomerate. Fifty-five percent of the conglomerate's net sales in 1989 came from tobacco products, according to RJR. In a separate campaign, Fleischmann's paid the AMA $250,000 to become a sponsor of its Campaign Against Cholesterol. Three years ago, Doctors Ought to Care successfully fought to prevent the American Academy of Family Physicians from joining Fleischmann's in a cholesterol screening program. At that time, the academy decided it ``would not deal directly with tobacco companies, but that this proscription did not extend to subsidiaries with no involvement with tobacco products,'' the academy said in a statement Monday. Asked about the tobacco company link, Larry Joyce, an AMA spokesman, said, ``The only concern we would have is if any company tried to influence the public health messages that are part of the program.'' He said the campaign includes anti-smoking messages. Academy members opposed to the earlier Fleischmann's proposal said they were distressed at the new alliance. ``This is what we worked on, and this is what they said they weren't going to do,'' said Blum. ``We're shocked and disappointed. We're in disbelief.'' Fleischmann's is an advertiser in the academy's supplement in the current issue of Reader's Digest. Fleischmann's ads appear on the same double, fold-out page with the academy's low-cholesterol message. Supplements advertising Fleischmann's and featuring the AMA name and symbol appeared in Sunday's newspapers. The academy has several links with Fleischmann's in addition to the public health campaign, and its medical journal, the American Family Physician, accepts Fleischmann's advertising, said academy spokesman William DeLay. Discussion of the RJR Nabisco link is likely to come up at the academy's meeting, said Blue. The Maine chapter has proposed that the academy stop interweaving its public health messages with commercial advertising, for fear that will damage the reputation of family physicians.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Losing Public Support
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The comic Woody Allen once wrote, ``In perpetrating a revolution, there are two requirements: someone or something to revolt against and someone to actually show up and do the revolting.'' On Monday, in what the leftist Sandinista Front had predicted would be the most violent anti-government action yet, the second factor - someone to show up - was largely missing. The result was nothing to laugh about for the Sandinistas. It was a stark public display of the dwinding popularity of the party of revolution that had ruled Nicaragua for a decade. A handful of burning tires scattered around some street intersections and a demonstration by about 500 Sandinista supporters at the government complex were the only signs in Managua that it wasn't a Monday morning like any other. The demonstration was supposed to kick off a round of mass civil disobedience over the government's economic policies. Nicaraguans interviewed expressed weariness with the Sandinistas' violent tactics and a desire to give Violeta Chamorro's U.S.-backed government a chance to work. Just a few months ago, the Sandinistas could whip up impressive throngs for anti-government marches and party celebrations. But on Monday, people went to work and children to their schools, while traffic and pedestrians skirted the piles of burning rubber. Sandinista party and labor leaders had been announcing the protest for weeks. Former President Daniel Ortega, who lost Feb. 25 elections to Mrs. Chamorro, had issued dire warnings that ``this situation is practically reaching the point of no return.'' Lucio Jiminez, secretary-general of the National Workers Front, the umbrella group for Sandinista labor unions, had said Monday's protests would mobilize large numbers of supporters. Jiminez' organization alone claims to represent 200,000 people. After a government-Sandinista meeting last week, the government announced a set of measures to alleviate hunger and misery. The program addressed Sandinista demands that the government cushion the poorest sectors against a drastic economic recovery program. But the Sandinistas, apparently sure of their popular appeal, persisted in their plans for what Ortega called a ``social explosion.'' According to Ortega, it would be much bigger than two Sandinista-led strikes in May and July that paralyzed the country. The last one, in which six people were killed and hundreds left injured, nearly deteriorated into civil war. Political observers have noted that the Sandinistas seemed to start losing support in the first strike, which occurred barely two weeks after Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration. Government supporters chided the Sandinistas for not living up to their promise to be a loyal opposition. Aftr the second strike, people interviewed in the streets expressed anger at the government's apparent inability to put down the demonstrations, which caused millions of dollars in damage and lost production and left Managua's streets nearly impassable for days. For Monday's action, however, Mrs. Chamorro's young government has shown it is learning how to take control. After announcing the cushioning measures Friday, state-run television repeatedly ran clips from street interviews showing people who agreed with the steps. Many Nicaraguans who watched a live television interview with Ortega on Friday night saw the former president as unreasonable. The interview was conducted by the deputy minister of the presidency, Antonio Ibarra. While Ibarra tried to have Ortega admit the need for government-Sandinista talks to work out a consensus on social and economic reform, Ortega fell back on time-worn Sandinista accusations and slogans. Despite this, Ortega has in the last few days begun to sound somewhat conciliatory. And even Jimenez seems to be softening his stance, agreeing to hold talks with government officials today.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Doralisa Pilarte has been AP correspondent in Managua since 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Launches Presidential Campaign in Poland
DOC.TEXT: Presidential candidate Lech Walesa has told his first campaign rally that he opposes abortion, and attacked the anti-Semitism that has tainted politics in his overwhelmingly Roman Catholic nation. At the rally Monday, the Solidarity chairman also stressed that no alternative exists to the painful ``shock'' economic reforms now pinching the Polish people. Walesa, 47, said it was too early to present his program but he took questions for 45 minutes from the crowd of 5,000 assembled in a cold, windswept market square of the northern-central city of Torun. One Pole drew scattered murmurs of support from some in the crowd when he asked Walesa to remove all the ``Communists and Jews'' from the government. The union leader replied, ``Look at America and other countries - many ethnic groups are existing there in a pluralistic way and they are doing well. ... I am not a Jew, but I am not anti-Semitic, and I will always be against such slogans.'' He was applauded, and said to the questioner, ``I won.'' Walesa also said he supported a controversial ban on abortion approved by one house of Parliament on Saturday. ``You know that I am a practicing Catholic, and my opinion here cannot be different from that of the church,'' he said. It was Walesa's first rally since declaring his candidacy Sept. 16, and he struck a populist note, declaring, ``I am one of you and want to remain one of you.'' Walesa's likely chief rival, one-time ally Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, has not yet formally declared. Poland's first popular presidential vote in more than 50 years could take place as early as Nov. 25 under a newly passed election law signed Monday by President Wojciech Jaruzelski. The exact date is to be announced shortly. Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader, asked Parliament on Sept. 19 to shorten his term because of increasing demands for him to step down as an unwanted symbol of Poland's old order. Parliament elected him to a six-year term in July 1989. When Walesa appeared on the red-brick balcony of the medieval town hall in Torun, he flashed V-for-victory signs. The brass band struck up a tune instantly recognizable to Poles as the anthem of prewar strongman Marshal Jozef Pilsudski. A banner read ``Torun welcomes Lech'' and two posters said, ``We will elect Lech Walesa president.'' Walesa received a warm, but not thunderous welcome. Evoking the spirit that made Solidarity endure after it was created as the East bloc's first independent trade union in 1980, Walesa said: ``We succeeded 10 years ago. Ten million people joined us in the search for new chances for Poland. Today I have a similar job.'' Walesa said, ``Poland is really free but ... we need new minds'' in government. He said repeatedly that the economic reforms were crucial, but he did not appear to win over the audience. The labor leader has accused the Mazowiecki government of being too slow to privatize the state-dominated economy and to dismiss former Communists from positions of authority in government and industry. Mazowiecki supporters accuse Walesa of personal ambition and demagoguery.

DOC.HEAD: Fog in South; Clouds in East
DOC.TEXT: Fog hovered over the South early today. Skies were partly cloudy in the East and clear in the Midwest. Today's forecast called for temperatures in the 60s from the Northeast, across the Great Lakes region and into the Pacific Northwest. Highs in the 70s were expected in the mid-Atlantic region and the Midwest. The South and Southwest were likely to see temperatures in the 80s and 90s. Showers were forecast in the Northeast and in parts of Kansas, New Mexico and Arizona. Thundershowers were expected in portions of Texas, Oklahoma and Missouri. More sun was due in the Charleston, S.C., area, where last month was the driest September since record-keeping began in 1738. Total rainfall for the month was 0.18 inch. Last month was a wet one in Anchorage, Alaska, with 6.64 inches of rain, nearly triple the normal amount and the most since the area began keeping records 73 years ago. The high Monday in the Lower 48 states was 101 degrees in Taft, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Impeached Judge Attempts Political Comeback in Florida
DOC.TEXT: Impeached federal Judge Alcee Hastings attempted to turn his ouster to his political advantage today in a runoff for the Democratic nomination for Florida secretary of state. Turnout was expected to be a low 20 percent. The runoff between Hastings and ex-newspaperman Jim Minter was the only statewide race on the ballot. Hastings, who was Florida's first black federal judge when appointed in 1979, was removed by Congress last year over bribery allegations on which he was acquitted in court. He claims to be a victim of political persecution. ``A lot of people really do know that I took a political hatchet in the face,'' he said. ``I will not be made into a clown.'' The 53-year-old former judge finished second to Minter in a three-way primary in which a former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon got more than a quarter-million votes. Minter, a 52-year-old former speechwriter for former Gov. Reubin Askew, covered the Capitol for years as a newsman. He resigned as an editorial writer for the Tallahassee Democrat to enter politics. The winner faces Republican incumbent Jim Smith in the Nov. 6 election. Independent polls recently gave Minter a lead of about 11 points, but more than a third of the voters surveyed said they hadn't yet made up their minds. Minter pinned his hopes on good government types such as environentalists and political activists. Hastings was said to be strong among unions and minorities. ``I will get 90 percent of the black vote, but I can't win with just the black vote,'' he said. ``I have to get broad-based support, and I have it.'' In other runoffs today, former state Sen. John Vogt and ex-defense industry lobbyist Bill Tolley vied for the GOP nomination for the congressional seat now held by Bill Nelson. Nelson, a Democrat, decided not to seek re-election and made an unsuccessful run for governor. Democrat Jim Bacchus, a lawyer, awaits the winner. Hastings has proposed abolishing the independently elected state Cabinet as too cumbersome, even though he seeks a seat on it. And he has suggested that casino gambling might help solve the state's budget problems. The secretary of state is Florida's top elections official and oversees corporate charters and state records. Minter and Hastings have called for campaign finance reform and both have outlined positions on the environment, education and other issues.

DOC.HEAD: As Storm Clouds Gather, Bush Throws Saddam a Line
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 12 graf, ``Butros Ghali to CORRECT spelling and title of Ghali
DOC.TEXT: Should Iraqi President Saddam Hussein choose to grab it, there now is a lifeline in the turbulent Persian Gulf waters to pull him free from an ultimate military showdown with the United States. It was cast out Monday by President Bush in a United Nations speech that blended condemnation of the Iraqi leader as a plunderer of Kuwait with the option of a diplomatic solution. If Saddam wants to save face, if he takes seriously the recent war-talk of senior administration officials, the Iraqi can rationalize a withdrawal from the small oil-rich emirate as a means to Arab ends. After all, Bush said Iraq's unconditional departure from Kuwait could create new opportunities: a permanent settlement between Iraq and Kuwait, new but undefined arrangements for stability in the Persian Gulf and a settlement between the Arabs and Israel. Later, Bush told reporters ``there is no flexibility here.'' He said his policy had not changed and they should not look for nuances - hidden meanings - in his speech. And yet, mixed in with the denunciation of Saddam Hussein and even the threat of a war crimes trial, the president offered more in the way of a diplomatic alternative than at any point in the two-month crisis. In effect, Bush said withdraw, then negotiate. Implicit is an opportunity for Saddam to take up his territorial demands with the ousted rulers of Kuwait, provided they are restored to power. The Iraqi leader, feeling the pressure of an international trade cutoff, has complained that Iraq is being singled out while other countries' actions are not checked by the United Nations. Saddam has pointed an accusing finger at Israel, seeking to swing other Arabs to his side by projecting Iraq as the bearer of the banner for an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza, which Jordan and Syria lost in the 1967 Mideast war. But at least one major Arab nation, Egypt, reportedly took exception to any gesture to the Iraqi leader. Butros Ghali, the Egyptian minister of state for foreign affairs, discussed Bush's speech with David Levy, the Israeli foreign minister. Afterward, diplomatic sources reported that Ghali said Saddam should not be given any chance ``to claim a bonus'' for his takeover of Kuwait and that the Arab-Israeli dispute should not be linked to it. Just as Bush took a cue from Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in raising the spectre of a war crimes trial for Saddam, the president followed the lead of French President Francois Mitterrand in offering Saddam a way to avert confrontation. Mitterrand's four-step proposal before the U.N. General Assembly last week also held out to Saddam the potential of an Arab-Israeli settlement if Iraq gives up Kuwait. Senior U.S. officials, who had dismissed any linking of the two disputes, showed little interest in the French proposal at the time. But on Sunday, the birthday of the Muslim prophet Mohammed, Saddam said Iraq was prepared for a dialogue with France ``so that everything is based on clear ideas and actions.'' Mitterrand said one of his objectives was to ensure Israel's security. Bush, of course, would do nothing less for America's best friend in the Middle East. And yet, Saddam and other Arab leaders also are aware that U.S. policy seeks Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and the Golan Heights. Bush's script for the area in the event of an Iraqi withdrawal holds promise of realizing that goal. Whether it entices Saddam to execute a complete turnabout, only the Iraqi leader can say. The president is providing a way out short of war for Saddam. And yet he also is prepared to take the ultimate military step if scorned. There are 165,000 U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf region and more arriving daily. Brent Scowcroft, the president's assistant for national security affairs, and other senior officials have been warning that U.S. patience is running out. ``We're still giving sanctions the time to work, the time to be effective,'' Bush told reporters Monday. ``And I'm a little encouraged that perhaps they are having a strong effect.'' The choice, evidently, is Saddam Hussein's. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is The Associated Press' chief diplomatic writer.

DOC.HEAD: CBS News' Answer to `Nightline' Has a Way to Go
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The 30-minute ...' to CORRECT `Engame' to `Endgame.'
DOC.TEXT: ``America Tonight,'' CBS' answer to ``Nightline,'' has a way to go before it's more than an insomniac's edition of morning talk. Monday night's premiere proved a once-over-lightly exercise, with too much crammed into too little time. The 30-minute premiere included a 40th anniversary story on ``Peanuts'' cartoonist Charles Schulz and a promising segment called ``The Endgame.'' The creators will mercifully shun interviews with actors hawking movies. ``We hope to have some insights, to have some arguments and have some fun,'' said folksy Charles Kuralt, the show's anchorman in New York. Crisp, efficient Lesley Stahl is the program's anchor in Washington. The show, which began at 11:35 p.m. EDT, could have dispensed with analyses that added little to the world's knowledge, one on prospects for war in the Persian Gulf, the other economic reporter Robert Krulwich's light-hearted, although knowledgeable, look at the federal budget compromise. ``The Endgame'' is an occasional segment in which visiting experts and analysts discuss the day's hot topics. That can be dreary, but the first matchup of two former Reagan administration officials discussing the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 proved an inspired, different sort of Washington forum. Former Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard Perle and former Navy Secretary James Webb made war, or the prospect of one, more than just a TV abstraction.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Falls Sharply, Dollar Strengthens
DOC.TEXT: Gold fell more than $6 an ounce in Europe today, but it traded higher than the New York low. The dollar strengthened in early trading. The drop in the gold price followed a $16 tumble in New York on Monday to $386.60. The fall in bullion was prompted by a lowering of oil prices on a belief there is a better chance of a negotiated settlement in the Persian Gulf. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $389.25 an ounce at midmorning, compared with $395.25 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $388.80 at midday, down from $396.60 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $10.82 to close at a bid $387.25. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.42 yen to a closing 136.73 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 136.85 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: -1.5578 German marks, up from 1.5520 -1.2973 Swiss francs, up from 1.2885 -5.2205 French francs, up from 5.1985 -1.7575 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7495 -1,1665.50 Itaiian lire, up from 1,163.50 -1.1540 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1526. In London, the dollar also rose against the pound, which was quoted at $1.8832, cheaper than $1.8890 late Monday. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.67 a troy ounce, down from Monday's $4.72 dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Backers of Rebel Lebanese General Are Fired On, 30 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with one graf to UPDATE with higher casualty toll. Picks up 2nd pvs, `Aoun blamed...'
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen raked supporters of rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun with automatic weapons fire as they rallied at a candlelight vigil and police said today that 30 people were killed and 100 wounded. Aoun blamed the Lebanese Forces militia of rival Christian warlord Samir Geagea, calling Monday's killings a ``horrific massacre.'' He said President Elias Hrawi's Syrian-backed government was ``equally responsible.'' For his part, Geagea accused Aoun of engineering the bloodbath to win international sympathy as government troops tighten a siege around the general's enclave. The rival forces of Aoun and Geagea battled for control of Lebanan's Christian communities earlier this year. Hrawi is besieging Aoun's strongholds in an effort to make him yield to government authority. In a new attack today, snipers fired at pedestrians in the same spot as Monday's shooting, killing a civilian and wounding four, police said. The earlier carnage occurred shortly before midnight at the coastal highway bridge spanning Nahr el-Maut, or Death River, five miles north of Beirut, police said. They said about 5,000 Aoun supporters carrying candles demonstrated at the crossing to protest the weeklong siege of Aoun's enclave, where his 15,000 soldiers are headquartered. ``As they shouted slogans condemning the president and Mr. Geagea for the starvation blockade, gunfire suddenly erupted and the crowd panicked in a stampede,'' said a police spokesman. ``Some of the victims were trampled to death, but at least 22 died of gunshot wounds,'' said the spokesman, who cannot be identified in line with standing rules. In his statement, Aoun said Hrawi, Geagea, Prime Minister Salim Hoss, Defense Minister Albert Mansour and Hrawi's army commander Gen. Emile Lahoud are ``equally responsible for carrying out the massacre.'' He called on the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France to withdraw their recognition of Hrawi's government. He said forces of Geagea and Lahoud had fired at his supporters from the north side of the crossing. Aoun said Geagea's militiamen and units of Lahoud's army fired on the demonstrators from the northern tip of the river crossing. However, a statement from Geagea's command in the Christian port of Jounieh, 12 miles north of Beirut, said Aoun's ``planted intelligence agents fired at the demonstrators from behind.'' It said the incident was designed ``to try to win some international sympathy and acclaim and to prolong his stay in the presidential palace a few more days.'' Aoun is headquartered at the presidential palace in suburban Baabda, the traditional seat of heads of state. He and Geagea fought a four-month war this year for control of the Christian enclave that covers 310 square miles of coastal and mountainous territory north of Beirut. By police count, 1,046 people have been killed and 2,799 wounded in that confrontation. Aoun's forces were left trapped in parts of east Beirut and neighboring mountains with no air or sea outlets. Geagea's 6,000-member militia, which ended the fighting in control of more than 80 percent of the Christian enclave, has pledged allegiance to Hrawi. He was elected president by Parliament on Nov. 24 under an Arab League peace plan designed to give equal power to the Moslems in the government, which was long dominated by Christians. But Aoun, who had been appointed a caretaker leader before the peace plan, has rejected Hrawi's presidency. He has tried to oust the estimated 40,000 Syrian troops from Lebanon. The president, in turn, has threatened to attack to dislodge Aoun if the blockade fails.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0471 to CORRECT category code.
DOC.HEAD: World War II Powers Give Up German Rights
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With the flick of a pen, thefour victorious powers of World War II have signed away the rights they won over Germany by pounding Hitler's army into submission 45 years ago. Ministers from the two Germanys joined in signing Monday's declaration and toasting it with champagne. They pledged that the reunited Germany being created this week will be dedicated to peace and good neighborliness. The two German officials spoke at a 35-nation ministerial conference on European security and cooperation, the first such official meeting in North America. President Bush and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze congratulated the German people during the session. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany and East German Science-Education Minister Hans-Joachim Meyer addressed the conference minutes after the four World War II Allies signed away the special rights they have exercised in the Germanys and Berlin since the end of the war in 1945. The declaration suspends allied rights from the moment the two countries formally merge at midnight Tuesday. The suspension is a stopgap measure to allow the united Germany to be a fully sovereign country. A Sept. 12 treaty must be ratified by the U.S. Senate and legislative bodies of the Soviet Union, Britain and France. Meyer's participation marked one of the final appearances on the international stage for East Germany. ``United Germany wants to set a good example. The Germans commit themselves to their duty to keep the peace, and they bindingly declare that never again will Germany raise territorial claims and that it recognizes existing borders as final,'' Meyer said. As a member of the NATO alliance and the Western European community, united Germany ``is in a good position to substantially promote the process of Europe's growing together,'' Meyer said. In an emotional speech, Genscher said unification day ``marks the fulfillment of a desire cherished by the German people for 45 years: to unite in peace and freedom.'' Genscher, who was raised in what became East Germany, also vowed that a united Germany will dedicate itself to peace. ``We are uniting in happiness and gratitude, not in nationalistic euphoria,'' he said. ``The dark chapters of our history are a cause for reflection ... on what was done in Germany's name. That will not be repeated.'' In his remarks, Bush said he had watched on television on Sept. 12 as U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Shevardnadze, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas and the two Germans signed the document suspending postwar allied rights. ``Those strokes of a pen bring to an end an era of discord and division,'' he said a few minutes later as he opened the two-day meeting of 33 European countries, the United States and Canada. ``We rejoice with the German people that their nation is united once more, and we will soon welcome a united Germany into the community of states,'' Bush said. The Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, known as CSCE, began with the 1975 Helsinki East-West conference. With the crumbling of the Soviet bloc's Warsaw Pact, many countries count on using the CSCE framework for a new all-European security system, Provided negotiators at Vienna agree in time on a treaty reducing European conventional forces, Baker said the United States would agree to a CSCE summit in Paris in November.

DOC.HEAD: Inquiry Postponed After U.S. Families' Lawyer Killed in Car Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to CORRECT American lawyer's name from Kriendler to Kreindler. Pickup 9th, `Oh God...'
DOC.TEXT: The inquiry into the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 was adjourned today after a Scottish lawyer representing the families of 90 American victims was killed in a car crash. ``It's like a curse that keeps following this thing,'' said George Williams, whose 24-year-old son, Geordie, was one of the 270 victims of the plane crash over the nearby town of Lockerbie. ``What a terrible, terrible tragedy.'' Lawyer Michael Hughes, 37, was working with U.S. attorney Lee S. Kreindler representing the American families. The judge, Sheriff Principal John S. Mowat, postponed until Thursday the inquiry into the Dec. 21, 1988 disaster. Hughes, who left a widow and five young children, was killed Monday evening on the M74 highway as the drove home to Glasgow, 70 miles north of Dumfries. Police said an oncoming truck spun out of control, hit a van and plunged through the motorway's central divider into Hughes' car. No one else was injured. Kreindler arrived in Glasgow on Monday night and was due in Dumfries today. American attorney Frank Granito Jr., who represents the families of 60 British and American victims, said Hughes' death ``will pose a great hardship'' since he was the key Scottish member of Kreindler's team. ``Oh God, we are in shock,'' said Granito. ``We relied very much on Michael. He extended to us the utmost courtesy and was of invaluable help to our firm ... it will be very difficult for us to continue.'' But Granito said the American attorneys representing the victims' families had been granted the right to question witnesses and will go ahead. Frank Rosenkrantz, a German whose Spanish wife, Maria Nieves Larracoechea, was a stewardess on the plane, said: ``It's just a nightmare. Everything that can happen in human terms has happened.'' Hughes was a partner in a family law firm, Hughes Dowdall, in Glasgow. The inquiry, expected to last three months, is due to focus on ways of preventing a similar disaster. It will not take evidence on the key question of criminal responsibility for the bombing. Police have said the bomb hidden in a radio-cassette recorder in a suitcase was probably put aboard the New York-bound flight in Frankfurt. The flight changed from a Boeing 727 to a Boeing 747 at London's Heathrow Airport. Scottish officials have said they are investigating Ahmed Jibril's radical Palestinian group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, and Mohammed Abu Talb of the Popular Struggle Front, who was convicted of bombings in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Buthelezi Declines To Meet With Mandela To Discuss Violence
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi has refused to meet Nelson Mandela to discuss ways to end savage factional fighting that has claimed hundreds of lives, officials said today. The African National Congress said Buthelezi, leader of the Inkatha Party, declined an invitation to attend a meeting Friday of black homeland leaders at Mandela's home in Soweto outside Johannesburg. ``The ANC would have preferred if Mr. Buthelezi would have attended the consultative meeting on Friday,'' said ANC spokesman Abba Omar. Inkatha officials said Buthelezi was visiting Switzerland and they had no immediate comment. ANC officials said they hoped Buthelezi's refusal to attend the meeting would not derail efforts to end fighting between the two groups. The meeting was called last month when dozens of people were being killed daily in black townships around Johannesburg. ``The ANC feels the peace initiatives that we have begun on the ground, and which involved Inkatha members, will continue,'' Omar said. It was not clear how the ANC could have any meaningful dialogue with Inkatha without Buthelezi playing a role. Buthelezi had expressed reservations about attending the meeting because he was invited as leader of the KwaZulu homeland. He said he would attend as head of Inkatha and asked for a preliminary meeting with Mandela. Government officials, meanwhile, said today they were still considering a call from Mandela for an emergency meeting on political violence. An official spokesman, who declined to be identified, said the government thought such a meeting would not be ``worthwhile'' at this time. Some 800 people have been killed since August in black townships around Johannesburg in bloody battles pitting Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the ANC against Zulus linked to Inkatha. Similar fighting has claimed about 5,000 lives in recent years in Natal province. ANC officials said Mandela would meet Friday with five other black homeland leaders. Homelands were set up by the South African government as separate states for blacks under the apartheid system. The ANC's proposal to include Buthelezi among the weak homeland leaders was seen by many observers as an attempt to sideline the Inkatha leader. Buthelezi, who heads Inkatha and the KwaZulu homeland, has demanded a one-on-one meeting with Mandela to prove they are the country's two top black leaders. Mandela has declined such a meeting, mainly because of pressure from other ANC leaders who refuse to have anything to do with Buthelezi. Buthelezi has accused the ANC of attempting to monopolize political power and excluding other black political groups from talks on ending white minority rule. President F.W. de Klerk has promised to end apartheid and share power with the black majority. The ANC and Inkatha both oppose apartheid, but differ over plans for a future South Africa. Inkatha wants a free-market economy and appeals to Zulu nationalism, while the ANC is more leftist and pan tribal. In other developments, police said a man was killed today in Durban on the east coast when a bomb exploded at a computer company. The company is owned by a white member of the ANC and one of his workers was killed and two women workers injured, they said. No group claimed responsibility for the blast, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Seek Help in Search for Rapist Who Carves Cross, Cuts Hair
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Police are looking for a ``clean-cut'' rapist who calls himself St. Peter, chops off his victims' hair as a sacrifice to God and carves crosses in their backs. The man raped three women he picked up in his car last month, said police Sgt. C. Roberson. He identified himself as ``St. Peter, the messenger of the Lord,'' and cut off the victims' hair, saying he would present it to God in order to cleanse their souls. After raping two of the women, the man carved an upside down cross into their backs with a knife. He was about to mark the third woman, but she was able to flee, Roberson said. ``Everyone tells us he's clean cut, fairly good looking, articulate and real meticulous,'' said Roberson. ``He seems to be real nice on the onset.'' The rapes occurred Sept. 16, 21 and 28. Two were in Long Beach and the other in the Harbor area of Los Angeles. Two victims had been hitchhiking and the third entered the man's beige Volvo after he offered her a ride, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Torching Abortion Clinic Apparently Acted Alone
DOC.TEXT: An abortion clinic fire that pro-choice supporters blamed on the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue apparently was started by a man accused of burglarizing a nearby veterans center, authorities said. ``He said he had no reason. He is not an activist. He has no opinion on abortion, pro or con,'' said police Detective Cleve Palmer. ``He may have done it to throw suspicion back on the protesters,'' Palmer said. Authorities on Friday arrested David Brian Martin, 31, after recovering plants, a computer and some typewriters stolen from the Veterans Counseling Center the night of the Sept. 4 blaze. Investigators also found at Martin's home wooden matches similar to ones found at the Planned Parenthood office, police said. Martin lives across the street from both the clinic and the veterans center. Martin told investigators he was drinking and doesn't recall setting fire to the clinic, Palmer said. He was being held on $5,400 bail. The fire did about $100,000 in damage to the clinic's waiting room, file room and laboratory. Immediately after the fire, Planned Parenthood supporters said they suspected anti-abortion activists who had been picketing the clinic two to three days a week. Operation Rescue denied involvement and spokeswoman Judie Hockel said the arrest vindicates the organization.

DOC.HEAD: Police Open Fire During Riots, Two Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs, police confirming 3 deaths, other details. Pickup 7th graf pvs ``I have...''
DOC.TEXT: Police opened fire on a stone-throwing mob today, killing two people, as thousands of villagers rampaged through the government district of the capital. One policeman also was killed. The riot followed a student-led rally of more than 100,000 people to protest a federal policy to reserve up to half of public jobs for low-caste Indians. There were indications the rally was exploited by politicians seeking to destablize the government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh. Police used gunfire when tear gas failed to disperse the mob. A police spokesman said two people were killed, and news agencies reported seven people were wounded.
