One policeman was killed by an unknown gunman in the crowd, said a police inspector who declined to be identified. At least two other policemen were injured, apparently by stones, news agencies reported. The violence ended four days of relative calm in the Indian capital following riots that crippled parts of New Delhi last week and affected supplies of gasoline, water and basic foodstuffs. Near the rally site, mobs set fire to a five-story government building, damaging the ground floor of the Ministry of Food and Civil Supplies, fire officials said. ``I have never seen such a dirty crowd,'' said Kanwaljit Deol, commander of the 3,000 police deployed in a two-mile stretch of the lawn where the rally was held. Brigades of paramilitary forces were called in assist police. New Delhi police Chief Vijan Karan said mobs set ablaze two fire engines, hurled stones at police patrols and government buildings and smashed windows. The rally was the largest yet in the student-led movement fighting Singh's job policy, which he announced Aug. 7. Since then, 70 people have died in protests and riots, including about 20 youths who set themselves on fire or ate poison. Today's violence began after fiery speeches from student leaders, social activists and farmers lambasting Singh. The speeches were punctuated by chants of ``Death to V.P. Singh!'' and ``Whoever lives like Hitler, dies like Hitler!'' Offices and most shops were closed for a national holiday. It was the 121st anniversary of the birth of India's independence leader Mohandas K. Gandhi, the prophet of non-violence. Police and some students claimed many participants in today's rally were bused in from the neighboring largely rural Haryana state to create turmoil that could destablize the government. A political rival of Singh, Devi Lal, has resigned from Parliament to protest Singh's handling of the job-quota issue. He has a substantial following in the countryside and is a senior leader of Singh's Janata Dal party. ``The students have been outmaneuvered by the politicians,'' said Rajev Awasthi, who said he quit the student committee that helped organize the rally when he saw it lose control. The rally went ahead despite a Supreme Court injunction Monday ordering the government to halt the job quota program until the court rules on its legality. The disputed policy reserves 27 percent of government jobs for lower classes, in addition to a 22 percent quota previously set aside for the most deprived castes. Upper-caste students claim they are victims of reverse discrimination and would lose prized jobs to less qualified people. Singh's 10-month-old coalition won office largely on the strength of the middle classes and intellectuals protesting alleged corruption of Rajiv Gandhi's government. The new prime minister has said he endorsed the quotas to give social justice to Indians deprived because of their caste. The caste system assigns social status of Hindus according to birth, and it often determines educational and professional opportunities. Modern India, which is 82 percent Hindu, professes secularism and has outlawed discrimination by caste, but the system persists.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead, 15 Injured as Truck Rams Disabled Bus Near Nashville
DOC.TEXT: A tractor-trailer rammed a disabled Greyhound bus on the side of Interstate 65 and set it afire today, killing one person and injuring 15, authorities said. Liz Dunn, public relations manager for Greyhound Lines, said the truck hit the left rear of the bus and knocked it into a relief bus as passengers were transferring to the new bus. The accident occurred about 5:15 a.m. on the southern edge of the city, about 15 miles south of downtown Nashville. Passengers had been heading from Birmingham, Ala., to Detroit. The disabled bus caught fire in its engine compartment, but it was quickly extinguished, Dunn said. The truck, which carried produce, came to rest 100 yards up the highway and also burned. Dunn said the person killed was a bus passenger. ``They could have been outside, I'm not sure if they were on the bus or walking from the disabled bus to the relief bus,'' Dunn said. ``Both buses had four- way flashers on and were parked on the shoulder,'' she said. Five people were critically injured, and 10 others also were taken to hospitals, authorities said. Rescue workers had to pull some people from the windows of the disabled bus. The truck was en route from Tipton, Ga., to Nashville, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Compton, Calif., Mayor Walter Tucker Dies at 66
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Walter R. Tucker, a gun control advocate who made Compton the first city in California to outlaw automatic weapons, has died of cancer at age 66. Tucker died Monday at Kaiser Hospital in the Los Angeles suburb of Bellflower. First elected mayor in 1981, he was serving his third term. ``It is one of the most tragic losses Compton has ever had,'' said Councilwoman Patricia A. Moore. ``He was so important to this community - to Compton's history. We loved him dearly.'' A member of the Board of Directors of the National Conference of Black Mayors, Tucker championed federally funded urban redevelopment and job training. He was an early and vigorous advocate of gun control. In 1989, Compton banned the sale and possession of automatic weapons after the slayings of five schoolchildren in Stockton. Born in Oklahoma, Tucker became active in civic affairs shortly after he moved to Compton in 1957. He started his political career as a school board trustee in 1967 and was a city councilman for four years before becoming mayor. A dentist by profession, Tucker also was a past board president of the National Dental Association. Tucker is survived by his wife, Martha; two daughters; and two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Critics Include Challengers Bush Backs
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Tauke opposing budget plan and Bush summoning GOP lawmakers to White House; DELETES pvs grafs 13-14, bgng Rep. Tom... now redundant earlier reference to Tauke
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has a ``tough job selling'' the budget compromise he negotiated with Congress, a Republican dissenter said today as the president began an arm-twisting drive to win support. ``People are very skeptical about this kind of solution coming from Washington,'' said Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa., who has declared his opposition to the package of tax increases and spending cuts. Tauke is in a tough Senate race as he tries to unseat Democrat Tom Harkin, and like other Republican challengers Bush hopes are victorious in November, Tauke was quick to break with the president on the budget agreement. Harkin complained that ``senior citizens and our family farmers will suffer disproportionately'' under the agreement and said he would spend the next couple of days studying it carefully. Bush summoned nearly 60 skeptical Republican members of Congress to the White House to urge them to back the agreement. ``He's going to be twisting arms and cajoling and telling people that if you are not supportive of this, we ask you to take another look and think anew,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``He's got a tough job selling it,'' said Tauke. ``Muggers in pinstriped suits,'' cried Rep. Lynn Martin, the Republican trying to unseat Democratic Sen. Paul Simon. ``They're back at your pocketbook again.'' ``Throw out the leadership of Congress,'' said Martin, apparently excluding Bush from the gang of ``muggers.'' Simon left himself a little more room to maneuver, saying, ``The more I see of it, the less willing I am to support it.'' The plan would enact permanent tax increases while leaving spending cuts up to Congress to enact in the future, complained Rep. Newt Gingrich, one of Congress' leading conservatives. Gingrich, R-Ga., also was upset that the plan did not contain enough measures to help businesses. ``We can do better for America,'' said Gingrich, the No. 2 House Republican. ``This package will lose jobs, raise taxes and deepen the recession.'' The cries of outrage over the compromise were bipartisan on Monday and came with certain swiftness from politicians running for higher office or suspected of harboring such ambitions. ``I'm opposed to it,'' said Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, who could be Bush's Democratic opponent in 1992. ``Every middle-class person will be forced to pay more for tobacco, gasoline, alcohol while the rich go free because President Bush promised the conservatives we wouldn't tax the rich people.'' ``Fiscal irresponsibility,'' said Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, another Democrat. Only last week, Bush campaigned in Illinois for Martin and in Michigan for Rep. Bill Schuette, who is challenging Democratic Sen. Carl Levin. ``My inclinations and leanings are that this is a bad agreement,'' said Schuette, who defended the president as having ``gone the last mile'' before being forced into the deal by ``liberal Democrats.'' An aide to Rep. Claudine Schneider, the Rhode Island Republican challenging Sen. Claiborne Pell, said Schneider was ``evaluating it, studying it, trying to ascertain that no one group is being singled out.'' On his campaign swing, Bush threatened to put the blame squarely on the Democrats if negotiators failed to reach an agreement and the government ground to a halt. ``I will take that message to every state in the Union,'' he said. But an agreement was reached and this week found the president switching from bashing Democrats to trying to persuade Republicans. ``I think this hurts the Republicans,'' said Lyn Nofziger, White House political director during President Reagan's first two years in office. ``I think it's going to hurt our election chances next month.'' Nofziger said the agreement ``takes an issue away from the Republicans. How can they go out and say, by golly, we're not going to raise taxes.'' Vice President Dan Quayle said that if an incumbent votes against the package, ``there will be a lot of heavy water to carry on the campaign trail.'' Political operatives involved in 1990 campaigns were more cautious in their assessment. ``I don't know what is going to happen,'' said Anita Dunn of the Democratic Senate Campaign committee. ``I don't know who is going to vote for what and I don't know what the final vote is going to look like.'' ``Today is really a day of assessing and studying,'' said Wendy Burnley, spokeswoman for the Republican campaign committee.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Urged To Use Caution in Travel To India
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said today that Americans traveling in northern and eastern India, especially in the New Delhi area, should exercise extreme caution because of political unrest. Travel by road in many areas can be hazardous, the department said. It noted that train travel has been disrupted because of disturbances at railway stations and sabotage of tracks and trains. The notice also reaffirmed a prior advisory urging Americans to postpone travel to Jammu and Kashmir province because of disturbances there.

DOC.HEAD: Escaped Convict Acquitted of Rape in Sexual Fantasy Defense
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: An escaped convict was acquitted of a rape charge after claiming that a woman whose home he broke into in the middle of the night was living out a fantasy when she had sex with him. Gilbert Stevens Diamond was convicted of burglary, assault and escape charges Monday but found innocent of rape in the Dec. 17 incident. His attorney, public defender Richard Reinhart, had called the sex encounter ``something she did to him'' and said the 48-year-old woman reported it only because she felt guilty afterward. Neither the woman nor jurors would discuss the case after the verdict was announced. The woman testified last week that she awakened to find Diamond sitting on top of her, with one hand on her throat and a knife in the other hand. She said she submitted to sex - and even suggested one sex act to Diamond - after he threatened to kill her. Moments after Diamond left the home, the hysterical woman called Manatee County's emergency telephone number. The jury twice heard a tape recording of the call. ``I can't believe this is happening,'' the woman sobbed over and over on the tape. Circuit Judge Robert Boylston had forbidden the public defender to ask the woman questions about her sexual conduct. But Reinhart stated his fantasy theory in his argument to the jury, without objection from prosecutors. Assistant State Attorney James Parker described the woman's submission as a question of life or death. ``Knowing that rape was inevitable, she had nothing to do but save her life,'' Parker told the jury. ``She had to do what was necessary in order to survive.'' The judge set sentencing on the assault, burglary and escape convictions for Nov. 1. Diamond, 31, was convicted in January 1989 of burglary and assault. He had been assigned to a work-release program, and testified he escaped by walking away from his dishwasher's job at a restaurant.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq To U.S.: Tell Israel to Dispose Of Nuclear Weapons
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT:
Iraq challenged President Bush today to demand that Israel dispose of its nuclear weapons arsenal in return for the removal of other weapons of mass destruction in the hands of the Arabs. An Iraqi government spokesman, reacting to Bush's speech at the United Nations on Monday, said: ``We support the removal of all mass destruction weapons from the region, provided this applies not only to chemical or other weapons the Arabs possess but also the nuclear weapons Israel has... ``And we challenge Bush, who is ever so careful not to anger Israel, to declare a clear-cut position regarding this issue and make the suggestion to Israel,'' the spokesman said. His statement was carried by the official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia. He said, ``Bush should prove he is sincere in his call for peace and security in the region and worldwide. ``Or is he again using the flowery calls for peace and for the removal of the threat of mass destruction weapons as a camouflage for ill intentions he harbors against the Arab people, their wealth and sanctities?'' Israel has never responded directly to allegations it has nuclear weapons, saying only that it will not be the first country in the region to introduce such weapons. Western intelligence reports say that Israel possesses up to 100 atomic bombs and nuclear warheads. In 1981, Israeli warplanes destroyed an Iraqi nuclear reactor believed to be developing an atomic bomb.
Iraq has been condemned by the United Nations for using chemical weapons, banned under a 1925 Geneva protocol, in its 1980-88 war with Iran. Baghdad also has been widely criticized for using mustard gas and other chemicals in a crackdown on rebellious Kurds, becoming the first country to use such weapons against its own people. Iran claimed the Iraqis killed some 4,000 Kurds in the March 1988 attack on the Iraqi Kurds, who allied themselves with Iran during the war. U.N. teams who inspected victims hospitalized in Iran found traces of the outlawed weapons, including blisters, severe burns and darkened skin. Iraq also was reported to be developing biological weapons, including toxins that spread lethal diseases.

DOC.HEAD: Mob Forces Postponement Of Benazir Bhutto's Hearing
DOC.TEXT: An unruly mob today broke down police barricades and stormed the courtroom where ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto was to stand trial for corruption. Dozens of people, including policemen and journalists, were injured in the stampede, apparently aimed at delaying the court proceedings until after the Oct. 24 parliamentary elections. Hundreds of police, armed with steel-tipped batons and automatic rifles stood by, prohibited by law from using force around the Punjab High Court. Ms. Bhutto, pale and visibly shaken by the outburst, waited with her lawyers and bodyguards in a room adjacent to the courtroom. After more than two hours of pandemonium, Justice Rashid Aziz Khan adjourned the hearing until Oct. 9, the day Ms. Bhutto is to stand trial before him on another corruption charge. Police blamed Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party for the melee. Ms. Bhutto's lawyers accused police commandos of triggering the violence to deliberately discredit the former prime minister and her Pakistan People's Party. The party seems to be gaining strength since the army-backed caretaker government resurrected the one-judge special tribunals to try members of her ousted government for corruption. Ms. Bhutto's political opponets were expected to try to capitalize on the violence, portraying it as an example of her party's disrespect for law and order. Ms. Bhutto's government was dismissed after only 20 months by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, who cited charges ranging from corruption and nepotism to abuse of power. Ms. Bhutto and half a dozen former Cabinet ministers have been charged with corruption before the tribunals. The charge before Aziz Khan today accused her of selling government-protected land to a London-based firm owned by a cousin. The land reportedly sold at below market value. Other charges to e heard before tribunals in her hometown of Karachi allege she illegally used an Asia Development Bank loan to hire a foreign consulting firm to oversee a Karachi power project and allowed a British-based firm to export cotton at rates far below the international market rate. She is also accused of giving lucrative contracts for the distribution of liquified gas to family and friends. Ms. Bhuutto has said she does not recognize the jurisdiction of the special tribunals, which were orginally set up in 1977 during the days of martial law. But she has said she is appearing in protest to show the hollowness and maliciousness of the caretaker government, which is comprised of former allies and bitter critics. She has vehemently denied any wrongdoing. If she is convicted of any of the four charges she could be disqualified from the Oct. 24 polls and banned from politics for up to seven years.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Announces Drug Recall
DOC.TEXT: Two lots of a prescription antihistamine are being recalled because the packages may contain a blood pressure medication, the Fod and Drug Administration said today. The antihistamine is Bioline brand hydroxyzine pamoate in 50 milligram capsules. The blood pressure medication, 2 mg clonidine hydrochloride, comes in scored, peach-colored tablets, with a ``dp'' logo above the scoreline and ``02'' below the line. If a consumer finds that a bottle that is supposed to contain the Bioline capsules instead contains the tablets, they should return it to the pharmacy where they got it, the FDA advised. Someone who takes the blood pressure drug in the amounts directed for the antihistamine could become dizzy and fall, the agency said. Both drugs are made by Duramed Pharmaceuticals of Cincinnati, Ohio. Labels are supplied by the distributor, Bioline Laboratries of Ft. Lauderdale, Fla. Bioline is asking pharmacists to examine lots 91009 and 91240. About 237 bottles from these lots were distributed nationally, the FDA said.

DOC.HEAD: President Hopes Saddam Will Reverse Course
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf with 3 grafs to include reference to Gorbachev, Aylwin meeting
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, heartened by unbroken support he heard from world leaders for standing up to Saddam Hussein, says he hopes the Iraqi leader will reverse course and withdraw from Kuwait. Bush met today with the Soviet Union's military chief, Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, who applauded the steps Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev have taken in arranging high-level exchanges between superpower military officials. ``We cherish what is uniting our two nations today, and we fully understand the contribution you both made to the improvement of our ties,'' the general told Bush. Bush also met today with Chile President Patricio Aylwin, and was meeting later with Angolan rebel leader Jonas Savimbi. In their first meeting since Aylwin's inauguration returned democratic rule to Chile last March, Bush told the Chilean president that relations between the two countries ``are moving in the right direction.'' The president, who faces a hard sales job to both the public and politicians on his $500 billion deficit-cutting deal, was keeping the emphasis on foreign affairs after returning late Monday from a weekend whirlwind of diplomacy in New York. Bush held one-on-one talks with nearly two dozen world leaders and renewed his indictment of Iraq in an address to the U.N. General Assembly that held out the possibility of ``opportunities'' for settling Saddam's quarrels with Kuwait once Iraq withdraws unconditionally. At a news conference after signing a stopgap resolution keeping the government running until Friday, Bush said he felt optimistic both that the tough U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq are holding fast and that the message is getting through to Saddam that he stands alone. ``Let's hope that that, coupled with the economic sanctions, will cause him to do what he's done in the past: do a 180 (-degree turn) and get out,'' said Bush. He said the Iraqi president had executed a turnabout in dealing with his old war adversary, Iran. Bush said ``there's no flexibility'' on the demand for a complete Iraqi withdrawal and restoration of the government of Kuwait. But he said he was not pressing at this point for a new U.N. resolution to unleash force against Iraq. Bush said he shares British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's view that the multilateral force in the gulf already has that authority. He said he found ``totally solid support for the U.N. position and the U.S. position'' among the world leaders. ``What I'm optimistic about is that there isn't one single breach in the armor'' of worldwide condemnation of Iraq, he said. The stopgap funding resolution also frees more money for Operation Desert Shield, in which the United States has dispatched some 165,000 troops to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. The president's 23rd and last meeting in New York was with President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador, who assured Bush that he will push the murder investigation ``in the ugly case of the Jesuits ... until the end.'' Six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter were killed during Cristiani's election campaign last November, and the military has been accused of obstructing the investigation, in which government troops have been implicated. Earlier, the White House announced the United States is sending two batteries of Patriot air-defense missiles to Israel to defend against an increased threat from Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: French Fire Warning Shots To Halt North Korean Freighter
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A French warship fired warning shots today to halt a North Korean freighter near Djibouti, the first use of naval firepower by France to help enforce the trade embargo against Iraq. Military officials in Paris said the corvette Doudart de Lagree opened fire after the freighter Sam Il Po defied an order to stop for inspection. The warship set off in pursuit, firing blank warning shots from more than 300 yards away before a third shot from closer range prompted the freighter to halt, officials said. A French search party then boarded the freighter, officials said. The vessel was allowed to resume its passage after searchers determined it did not appear to be violating the U.N. embargo imposed on Iraq and occupied Kuwait. The incident occurred in the Bab al Mandab strait, linking the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden. French officials did not say where the freighter began its journey or where it was headed. It was the fifth interception in which warning shots were fired since the blockade was imposed Aug. 6, four days after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The earlier incidents involved U.S. warships and an Australian frigate. It was the 16th time French search teams have boarded vessels in connection with the blockade. The Foreign Ministry said today that 332 French citizens remained trapped in Iraq or Kuwait, including 67 held at strategic sites in Iraq to deter possible military attacks. The ministry said Iraq's decision this week to free nine French hostages was good news for their families, but would in no way soften France's insistence that all foreign hostages be freed by Iraq. The nine, expected back in France by Wednesday night, apparently were chosen at random and were not among those held at strategic sites, the ministry said. The release was announced by Iraq on Monday, a day after Saddam Hussein said he would like to launch a dialogue with France based on remarks by President Francois Mitterrand at the United Nations last week. Mitterrand apparently piqued Saddam's interest by suggesting that resolution of the crisis caused by the Iraqi invasion might be followed by initiatives to solve the problems of Lebanon and the Palestinians. But Mitterrand reiterated the West's insistence that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait and free all hostages before any negotiations take place. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas has suggested that Saddam is attempting to drive a wedge between France and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Hears Oklahoma City School Desegration Case
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 11 news grafs court arguments; picks up 4th graf pvs, A federal...; DELETES 7th graf pvs, That decision..., now redundant
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration urged the Supreme Court today to let Oklahoma City children attend the schools nearest to their homes even if that results in racial imbalance. ``The school board has no realistic control over where people choose to live,'' Solicitor General Kenneth Starr, the administration's top courtroom lawyer, said in arguing that Oklahoma City's schools should be freed from a court-ordered desegregation plan. But Julius Chambers, the New York City lawyer representing those black parents who challenged the neighborhood school plan, said the court should not turn back the clock. He opposed the plan adopted by the city school board in 1985 for students in kindergarten through fourth grade. ``You should not let the school district in Oklahoma City, or in any other city, reinstate the same assignment practices that caused segregation in the past,'' Chambers argued. How the justices resolve the Oklahoma City dispute - a decision is expected by July - could determine the future racial makeup of public schools in hundreds of American cities. At issue is what once-segregated school districts can do after achieving racial balance under court-ordered plans. The court must decide whether school districts like Oklahoma City's may abandon forced busing and other desegregation tactics once a federal court rules they have become fully integrated. Ronald Day, representing the city's school board, said residential segregation of the races ``is a phenomenon over which this school board, indeed no school board, has control.'' Starr, representing the federal government, warned the court against ``placing undue emphasis on the numbers.'' He added, ``No one is assigned on the grounds of race.'' Justice Thurgood Marshall, the court's only black member and the winning lawyer in the 1954 Supreme Court case that outlawed racially segregated public schools, challenged Starr's assertions. ``The poor Afro-American kid is still in the same school,'' Marshall said. ``It remains a segregated school.'' A federal judge ruled in 1977 that Oklahoma City schools had achieved full integration, and eight years later city school officials returned to a neighborhood schools plan for children in kindergarten through fourth grade. The racial balance that had been achieved through busing disappeared, and some parents called the result ``resegregation.'' Hundreds of school districts, including those in most major cities, operate court-ordered busing plans for racial desegregation. Only a few have persuaded courts to declare their once-segregated systems fully integrated, but the potential impact of the high court's ruling in the Oklahoma City case is enormous nevertheless. A federal appeals court disapproved the Oklahoma City neighborhood schools plan last year, ruling that federal court supervision in such cases ``extends beyond the termination of the wrongdoing.'' The city's schools once were racially segregated by law. Black parents sued in 1961 to end the last effects of such segregation, and in 1972 a court-ordered desegregation plan was put into place. U.S. District Judge Luther Bohanon ruled in 1977 that the school district had become fully integrated, and ended his supervision. School officials continued the crosstown busing, however, until 1985 when children in kindergarten through fourth grade were allowed to attend the school nearest their home. By 1986, 33 of the school district's 64 elementary schools were 90 percent black or white. After some black parents challenged the new racial makeup, Bohanon ruled that the 1972 desegregation plan no longer had to be enforced. But the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in reversing Bohanon's ruling, said the Oklahoma City school board has a continuing duty to refrain from any action that could weaken racial balance in the public schools. Other federal appeals courts have ruled - in cases from Norfolk, Va., and Austin, Texas - that a local school board's obligation to promote racial balance ends when the school district is declared ``unitary'' or fully integrated. The justices opened the court's 1990-91 term with a flurry of activity Monday. The court: -Agreed to decide in an Ohio case whether juries may impose stiffer sentences because of a crime's impact on the victims or their families. -Said it will consider letting states outlaw all barroom-style nude dancing. The court will review a ruling that struck down such an Indiana ban. -Refused to free a Southern Baptist seminary in New Orleans from having to grant a divinity degree to a man the seminary says is unfit for Christian ministry. -Voted to consider reinstating a libel suit against Janet Malcolm, a writer for The New Yorker magazine. A lower court threw out a suit against her by a psychologist who said she made up quotes attributed to him. -Rejected an appeal by an Ohio woman who gave birth to a healthy boy after she underwent an unsuccessful abortion. The woman tried to sue a doctor and hospital for the costs of rearing the child.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Boosts Forces in Kuwait, U.S. Aircraft Carrier Enters Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with French ship firing warning shots, faulty air siren in Jerusalem, Iraqi challenge to Bush. Minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has strengthened its forces in southern Iraq and Kuwait and has now deployed nearly half its 1 million-man army to defend the occupied territory, U.S. military sources said today. In the Persian Gulf, meanwhile, the aircraft carrier USS Independence arrived on a visit intended partly as a ``show of force'' against Iraq, a Navy officer said in Saudi Arabia. The 79,000-ton carrier and several ships of its battle group passed through the Strait of Hormuz, the only gateway to the gulf, today and are now operating in the waterway, a statement from the Pentagon said. ``The Independence and its escorts will remain in the Persian Gulf for a short period to conduct normal operations,'' the Pentagon said. A French warship today fired warning shots to halt a North Korean freighter near Djibouti in the Bab al Mandab strait linking the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden. It was the first use of naval firepower by France to help enforce the trade embargo against Iraq. Military officials in Paris said the corvette Doudart de Lagree opened fire after the freighter Sam Il Po defied an order to stop for inspection. A French search party then boarded the freighter, officials said. The vessel was allowed to resume its passage after searchers determined it did not appear to be violating the U.N. embargo on Iraq. French officials did not say where the freigther began its journey or where it was headed. It was the fifth interception in which warning shots were fired since the naval blockade was imposed Aug. 6, four days after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The earlier incidents involved U.S. warships and an Australian frigate. More Egyptian soldiers were headed to Saudi Arabia today. Two ships passed through the Suez Canal headed for the Saudi Red Sea port of Yanbu. Canal officials said they carried troops and military hardware but gave no details. At the United Nations, Iraq unexpectedly postponed its speech to the General Assembly on Monday just hours after President Bush hinted that an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait could help resolve Arab-Israeli tensions. Iraq's U.N. Mission gave no explanation for rescheduling the address to Wednesday. Diplomats speculated, however, that Baghdad wanted time to evaluate Bush's message. Earlier Monday, Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari praised Bush for saying he preferred ``a diplomatic outcome.'' In his speech, Bush said Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait could create ``opportunities: for Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences permanently; for the states of the gulf themselves to build new arrangements for stability; and for all the states and peoples of the region to settle the conflict that divides the Arabs from Israel.'' The U.S. military sources in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, said analysts estimate there are well over 400,000 Iraqi troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait, compared to 360,000 a week ago. The numbers of tanks, artillery pieces and other heavy weapons have also been increased, the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. They gave no figures. The Pentagon said last week there were about 3,500 Iraqi tanks in the ``Kuwait theater.'' Most are believed to be in defensive positions, many dug-in behind earthworks. The buildup of recent weeks is concentrated in areas inland from the Persian Gulf and in a crescent around Kuwait. The Iraqis were also said to have reinforced their defenses along the supply lifeline from the southern Iraq city of Basra into Kuwait. The highway runs about 20 miles to the border and another 50 miles to Kuwait City. U.S. and Saudi officials have stressed that the allied forces are in defensive positions to protect against an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia. But many analysts have discounted the possibility of an invasion in view of the buildup of U.S. troops, now around 165,000, in the kingdom. The Saudi government says it will not allow the United States to initiate offensive action against the Iraqis from Saudi soil without their consent. The offensive capabilities of U.S. forces have been underscored in recent days by ship-borne U.S. Marine units conducting amphibious landing exercises in Oman, and by the arrival in the gulf of the USS Independence. In Paris today, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas dismissed Iraq's order Monday to release nine French hostages as insignificant, but suggested Baghdad may be softening its line in the gulf crisis. On Sunday, Saddam complimented President Francois Mitterrand for offering positive ideas to resolve the crisis and called for replacing the language of ``threats and warnings'' with dialogue. In an interview from the United Nations, Dumas told the French television network La Cinq: ``We are obliged to say that no gesture has yet come from Iraq that modifies the basic problems. We simply note a change in tone.'' In other developments today: -Iraq challenged President Bush to demand that Israel dispose of its nuclear weapons arsenal in return for the removal of other mass destruction weapons in the hands of the Arabs. The statement was carried by the official Iraqi News Agency. -In Jerusalem, a faulty siren signaled ``air attack,'' sending Israelis scurrying into bomb shelters less than 24 hours after the government decided to distribute gas masks to the public. It took a half hour before radio announcers broke into regular programs to calm hundreds of anxious callers with the news that the siren system went off by accident. Israel announced Monday it would start distributing gas masks to its 4.7 million citizens. -A European Community official said the trading bloc has agreed to give $2 billion in aid to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey to help offset the impact of the Persian Gulf crisis. -Prime Minister Toshiku Kaifu of Japan began a Middle East tour after promising the United Nations in New York to contribute nonmilitary personnel and material to the international effort to end the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Carrier Independence Enters Persian Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Navy sent the aircraft carrier Independence into the Persian Gulf today as a show of strength in the continuing military buildup against the forces of Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein. The Pentagon said in a statement that the Independence and the carrier battle group accompanying it will have an opportunity to become familiar with the ``unique operating conditions'' in the restricted waters of the Gulf between Saudi Arabia and Iran. But it said the presence of the Independence will also ``provide a visible demonstration of the operational capabilities of a carrier battle group to our friends and allies in the region.'' No U.S. carrier has entered the Gulf since the USS Constellation sailed there in 1974. ``Although the movement of one of our carrier battle groups into the Persian Gulf is unusual, it is not unprecedented and is not meant in any way to increase regional tensions,'' the Pentagon said. The Independence carries some 75 aircraft, including F-14 Tomcat fighters, F/A-18 Hornet strike fighters, A-6 Intruder attack aircraft, S-3 Viking anti-submarine warfare aircraft, EA-6B Prowler electronic warfare aircraft, E-2C Hawkeye airborne early warning aircraft, and SH-3 Sea King helicopters. The Independence approached the Gulf through the Straits of Hormuz Monday night. It had been positioned in the Gulf of Oman which connects to the Persian Gulf through the straits.

DOC.HEAD: West African Force Bombs Taylor Rebels
DOC.TEXT: West African soldiers backed by government troops and a rebel faction advanced behind a barrage of heavy artillery against Charles Taylor's rebels early today, forcing them to retreat. The French news agency Agence France-Presse reported the joined forces launched the offensive Monday night, and forced Taylor's army to retreat several hundred yards from strategic positions near the presidential mansion. To the north of the besieged city, the five-nation West African task force was led across swamps by rebels of rival guerrilla leader Prince Johnson for an attack in which they seized Taylor's front line facing Monrovia port, the French agency reported. The West African army has its headquarters in the port. Hundreds of civilians fled fighting in the two-pronged attack that followed a weeklong cease-fire called by Taylor. Agence France-Press quoted rebels as saying the West Africans had pushed Taylor's forces back nearly four miles from northern Monrovia, and were threatening to encirle the rebel army. The task force of 5,000 soldiers from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Gambia and Sierra Leone has been under pressure to act from Johnson's faction. Johnson said he would launch an all-out assault on Taylor's forces and on remnants of Samuel K. Doe's army holed up in the mansion if the task force did not intervene. Johnson and Doe's officers support a West African plan to impose a cease-fire and install an interim government of non-combatants to organize fair elections. Taylor has opposed the transitional government, and has declared himself president of his own temporary government. The West African army had been widely criticized for failing to end the 9-month-old tribal war in which the three Liberian armies have slaughtered at least 5,000 civilians. Most were killed because of tribal affiliations. The task force went into action Monday, opening fire on Taylor's positions with warplanes and heavy artillery. Their offensive follows the arrival last week of a new field commander, Gen. Joshua Dogonyaro of Nigeria. Johnson on Sunday said Taylor's men had attacked him and the cease-fire had failed. He demanded action from the West Africans. Johnson told reporters: ``If I do not see them (the task force) out there, there will be trouble. I am ready to mount my missiles and attack the mansion. If they don't get them out, we will bomb the mansion. I am also ready to move against Charles Taylor.'' Johnson killed Doe, then Liberia's president, on Sept. 10 after taking him prisoner at the task force headquarters in a surprise attack. The West African force evacuated 1,000 people from Doe's mansion after he died, mainly women and children. Some 1,000 soldiers now trapped in the mansion and nearby Barclary Training Center barracks refused to be evacuated, saying they did not trust assurances of safe conduct.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian and Soviet Officials Meet in Moscow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with details of the talks. Pickup 2nd graf pvs ``Our political...''
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania and the Soviet Union agreed today to maintain economic ties through 1991 and set up working groups to prepare for negotiations, news agencies reported. The agreement came at a meeting between Lithuanian and Soviet officials in the Kremlin after months of delays to try to settle the standoff over the Baltic state's independence drive. The Lithuanian news agency ELTA reported the delegations agreed to maintain trade and economic relations for 1991, clearing away uncertainty about supplies to and from the republic. The Baltic News Service reported a joint communique said the next meeting would be held in two weeks. Expert groups were told to prepare proposals on providing pensions to World War II veterans living in Lithaunia and other issues of social welfare of Soviet citizens, ELTA reported. ``Our political position since the founding of (the independence movement) Sajudis has been frank and clear, and today we will be able to check out the position of the other side,'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis told a Lithuanian news service on his way into the meeting. The seven-member Lithuanian delegation, headed by Landsbergis, includes Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene and other top officials of the republic's government. The Soviet delegation is headed by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzkhov and includes Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin and Justice Minister Veniamin Yakovlev. Lithuania declared independence March 11, setting the pace for other Soviet republics seeking more autonomy from the Kremlin. All but two of the 15 republics have since declared some form of independence or sovereignty. Lithuania agreed to suspend its declaration in July in exchange for talks with the national government and the lifting of an economic embargo imposed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in April. Mrs. Prunskiene said Monday that she expected Gorbachev would participate in the talks, although he is not a member of the Soviet delegation, the Estonian News Service reported. It said Gorbachev did not attend this morning's session. Neither side has called the talks ``negotiations.'' The official Tass news agency referred to the session as a ``consultative meeting.'' The Estonian News Service referred to the meeting as ``consultations on negotiations.'' The news agency quoted Landsbergis as saying he hoped the Soviets would negotiate with an ``open hand'' and that the initial meeting would produce a concluding general statement and a date for future talks. Lithuania and the other two Baltic republics, Latvia and Estonia, are refusing to participate in negotiations for a new treaty linking the republics with the central government. All three have accused Moscow of dragging its feet in dealing with their independence claims.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska to Pay Every Resident $952 From Oil Fund
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that payouts began in 1982, sted fund created that year.
DOC.TEXT: Alaskans will get more than $950 each from the state this year as their annual share of earnings from the $11.2 billion oil-wealth savings account. The $952.63 dividend announced Monday is the second-largest since the state began payouts from the Alaska Permanent Fund in 1982. It is $79 more than the 1989 dividend. For a family of four, this year's dividends will total about $3,810. They are paid to virtually every man, woman and child residing in Alaska, regardless of income. The amount is based on a complex formula that considers the fund's earnings over the previous five years. The recent doubling of oil prices because of the Persian Gulf crisis did not affect this year's dividend. Announcement of the dividend amount is widely anticipated in Alaska, where merchants hold ``dividend sales'' and car dealers accept the checks as down payments. In the state's poor, rural areas the dividend is a major source of personal income. ``The annual distribution of Permanent Fund dividends is widely recognized as an important element of the Alaska economy,'' said state Revenue Commissioner Hugh Malone. ``When the 1990 payout is complete, over $3 billion will have been put into the hands of Alaskans since 1982.'' The 1990 checks will be mailed starting Oct. 9. State officials said they expected more first-time applicants to be rejected because the residency period for eligibility was extended this year from six months to a year. But the state's rising population over the past two years was adding to the number of applications, offseting most of the decline attributed to the eligiblity change. The total amount of earnings made available for dividends this year was $482.51 million. The state estimated there would be 506,511 eligible applicants. The Permanent Fund is a state trust created by voters in 1976 to ensure Alaskans benefit from the state's oil wealth long after the oil is gone. It has saved 20 percent of the $33.2 billion in oil taxes and royalties received by the state since the huge Prudhoe Bay field went into production.

DOC.HEAD: New Owner of City Hall Could Find Taxes Tarnish Silver Lining
DOC.TEXT: Property taxes in the thousands could turn City Hall into a white elephant for the man who won the building in a court settlement. Governments pay no taxes on their buildings. But Walter DeBow, as a private owner of City Hall, could face a tax billue of the three-story brick building, said St. Clair County Assessor Sam Flood. DeBow will not be taxed for the building this year, Flood said. A court awarded City Hall to DeBow last week as payment on more than $1 million the financially strapped city owed him from a $4 million damage award. The earlier award was set in 1985 for injuries he suffered in the city jail. DeBow's attorney, Clyde Kuehn, said his client wants to seel the property, long before the property taxes are due.

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Erupts on Uninhabited Island
DOC.TEXT: A volcano on an uninhabited island off New Zealand's North Island erupted Tuesday, sending ash clouds about 10,000 feet in the air, scientists said. ``Seismically, it doesn't look like anything unusual, and it's unclear what changes have taken place on the island,'' a spokesman from the New Zealand department of scientific and industrial research's Rotorua office said. The eruption, on White Island in the Bay of Plenty area, lasted about 45 minutes and started at 11:45 a.m. The last major eruption in early June doubled the size of the island's main crater and blew out a new one. The volcanic island is about 3.6 miles in circumference, with three mountains rising above the crater. It is home to large colonies of birds and is a designated bird sanctuary.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Laboratory Blows Up, Killing 8 People, Destroying Houses
DOC.TEXT: A cocaine laboratory blew up today in a house next to a school in Medellin, killing eight people and leveling several buildings, police said. Three of the victims were children, the radio network RCN said. Twenty people were injured and several buildings and cars were destroyed, RCN said. Gasoline and other explosive chemicals are used in the processing of cocaine. The explosion appeared to be the result of a bomb placed in the laboratory, the office of Mayor Omar Flores said in a statement. Two Colombian cocaine cartels have been at war for almost two years in a battle for control of the cocaine smuggling into the New York City area. About 200 people have been killed in the war between the Medellin cartel and the Cali cartel. The two groups are named after major Colombian cities where the drug gangs have their headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: Last Diesel Attack Sub Retired; U.S. Undersea Force Now All Nuclear
DOC.TEXT: Taps and near-tears marked the retirement of the last U.S. diesel-powered attack submarine and the launch of a new era for the Navy, which now has an all-nuclear underwater attack fleet. Past and present officers and crew of the USS Blueback said farewell to the vessel Monday during the ceremony at the submarine base on Point Loma. ``We are here to close, with honor, the active life of the Blueback,'' said a choked-up Cmdr. Thomas A. Grassi. ``It's time to say farewell to an era and to a gallant lady.'' The Blueback, which was commissioned in 1959, never saw battle and most of the time it patrolled the Pacific. But it did its part for posterity. It made the first underwater voyage from Japan to San Diego in 23 days. In 1989, the Blueback was used as a Soviet submarine in the film, ``The Hunt for Red October.'' It's final trip will be to the Navy's submarine graveyard in Bremerton, Wash. Grassi was the last of 15 Blueback skippers. The 215-foot submarine is ``a floating hunk of cold, black metal,'' he said. ``It has been her crew which made her alive.'' Taps sounded as the crew lowered the vessel's commissioning pennant. The banner was given to Grassi, who is retiring along with the sub. The ceremony ended an era that began in 1912 when the Navy launched its first diesel-powered submarine, the Skipjack. The Navy's only diesel submarine still in service, the Dolphin, is a non-combatant research ship. The transition to a nuclear sub fleet began in 1954 with the Nautilus. Defenders of diesel submarines contend they are quieter, harder for an enemy to find and cheaper than their nuclear-powered counterparts. Navy officials argue that the newer nuclear models are faster and more efficient. ``Nuclear submarines offer the ability and the endurance to deploy on station for many days as opposed to the diesel, which is less capable in a forward-deployed role,'' said Navy spokesman Lt. Greg Smith. Diesel engines drove the Blueback on the surface, and high-capacity storage batteries powered electric motors when it was submerged.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Temple U. Faculty Back to Work
DOC.TEXT: A judge today ordered striking Temple University professors back to work, saying that education is so critical that the right to strike must yield. ``Education is vital to the health, safety and welfare of this nation and this community,'' said Common Pleas Judge Samuel Lehrer in issuing the back-to-work order sought by the university. The walkout began Sept. 4, the first day of classes. The order, which the union said would be appealed, is to become effective at 8 a.m. Wednesday. Temple officials had said they would have to cancel 1,900 classes, or more than 40 percent of those offered, for the entire semester if professors weren't back by this morning. Arthur Hoskner, the president of the union representing the 1,100 teachers, librarians and others, said last week a back-to-work order would be honored. Today, he said it would be appealed. ``I'm sorry the judge made the wrong decision, but we will appeal it,'' Hockner said. The next step would be Commonwealth Court, which may or not grant a stay to the order if the case is appealed. The union represents 1,100 teachers, librarians and others; its officials would not say how many of them are taking part. A state mediator called both sides for a bargaining session Monday night to see if something could be done before the courts stepped in. But talks broke off just before 8 a.m. today and Robert Harrington, Temple's chief negotiator, said there was no progress made during the night. On Sunday, the union had overwhelmingly rejected the school's latest offer. University officials have testified during hearings that the four-week strike poses a threat to the public, including the school's 30,000 students. ``Without an injunction the cancellation of classes will affect 6,000 students now without any classes and 23,000 other who have lost one, two or three classes,'' said Temple lawyer John Langel. More than 250 students withdrew from the university Monday, school officials said. Union attorney Alaine Williams had argued unsuccessfully that there is no constitutional right to a college education, and urged the judge to order both sides to the bargaining table. The union presented witnesses who said that even if the strike goes on, it would be possible for professors to make up for lost time.

DOC.HEAD: Former KGB General Wins Round in Court in Battle for Pension
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Tuesday ordered the government to provide a fuller explanation of its decision to strip a former KGB general of his officer's pension in retribution for his public criticism of the intelligence agency. ``I hope to achieve one thing: that other people, based on this precedent, will act more boldly and courageously in their attempts to restore justice and their human rights,'' former spy Oleg D. Kalugin told reporters after the court's decision, which he called a victory. ``I am satisfied. This gives us a chance to dig deeper, to find out something more'' about how the decision was made, Kalugin told reporters. Nikolai Romanenkov, presiding over a three-judge panel, adjourned the proceedings until Oct. 23 and said the court would ask the Council of Ministers - the Soviet Cabinet - and the chief military prosecutor to explain their actions in Kalugin's case. If the court meets Kalugin's request to restore his rank, pension and honors, it would be a landmark for citizens challenging official secrecy about government decisions. ``I am sure there are thousands of these people in the Soviet Union. I simply set an example for them,'' Kalugin said. He said the case had no precedent in Soviet law. Under reforms President Mikhail S. Gorbachev introduced, the Soviet parliament has asserted greater control over the government. But Kalugin and other reformers argue that many officials continue to follow secret orders. Kalugin said after the hearing that the court, by seeking further information from the government, was pushing Soviet society toward ``the stage where all secret acts, illegal acts, will be slowly, gradually be done away with.'' Officials in the KGB, whose predecessors in the 1930s arrested, incarcerated and executed millions of citizens with impunity, have told the Soviet people that the days of terror are over. But the KGB and the Soviet leadership reacted harshly last summer after Kalugin went public with his criticism of the agency, which gathers intelligence abroad and is responsible for state security at home. Kalugin accused the KGB of tapping telephones and spying on free trade unionists, clergymen and others who challenge Communist authorities. KGB spokesmen have denied the charges. Publicity surrounding the case helped Kalugin win a seat representing the southern Russian city of Krasnodar in the Soviet parliament last month. Shortly after Kalugin began his public campaign against the KGB, the Council of Ministers headed by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov issued an order stripping Kalugin ofhis rank of major-general. Gorbachev issued a decree revoking honors that Kalugin won during a career that including a stint from 1958-70 in the United States. Kalugin has filed a separate civil suit against Gorbachev. Viktor Alexeyev, chief of the KGB legal department, told the court that the agency revoked Kalugin's military pension after he was demoted, in accordance with a Soviet law. Alexeyev said Kalugin could receive a normal old-age pension when he becomes eligible, in five years. The judge rejected a motion by Alexeyev to dismiss the case, and the KGB attorney appeared shaken, breaking into a sweat. His hands shook as he read aloud from his legal papers before a bank of Soviet photographers and television cameramen crowded into the courtroom. Kalugin and his attorney, Boris Kuznetsov, told the court that the KGB action was ``inhumane and a gross violation of the constitution and of human rights.'' Alexeyev told the court the KGB decision was based on a order the Council of Ministers issued June 29. Kalugin's attorney requested and received a copy of the order, noted that it was not signed by Ryzhkov, then asked, ``Is this a secret order?'' Alexeyev acknowledged that it was an internal order, and shouts of ``Good Work!'' rang out in the courtroom. The judge, rather than asking for silence, broke into a grin. Alexeyev appeared angry as the judge and then a state prosecutor began to question him for details about KGB's actions in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Study Links Drinking to Death Before Age 65
DOC.TEXT: Men who habitually drank at least two alcoholic drinks a day were nearly twice as likely than abstainers to die before age 65, and the difference for women was three-fold, a study found. Even people who drank at lower levels than such ``heavier'' drinkers showed higher death rates than abstainers. The study was based on a national sample of people who died in 1986. For women, 40.7 percent of so-called heavier drinkers died before age 65 versus 13.2 percent of abstainers. For men, the figures were 42.3 percent versus 22.4 percent. The numbers cannot be interpreted as indicating risks of early death because of the way the study was done, cautioned study co-author Darryl Bertolucci. The study began with people who already were dead, and worked backward in time to classify them on their drinking habits, rather than starting with people of known habits and following them to find their risk of early death. Nonetheless, the study ``does show a relationship that needs to be looked into,'' he said. Bertolucci, a statistician at the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, presented the results oonday at the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association. The study used data on the drinking habits during adulthood of 8,303 men and 7,158 women, ages 25 or older. The data was obtained several months after their deaths from next-of-kin or other knowledgeable informants. Those who had drunk fewer than 12 drinks a year were classified as abstainers. Light drinkers were those who had averaged up to three drinks a week, moderate drinkers were those taking four to 13 drinks a week, and heavier drinkers were those who took two or more drinks a day. Among men, 33 percent of moderate drinkers and 32 percent of light drinkers died before age 65. For women, the figures were 29 percent and 26 percent respectively. As expected, cirrhosis of the liver was a more frequent cause of death in men for heavier drinkers than lighter drinkers or abstainers. Cancers of the trachea, bronchus, lung and esophagus increased with greater drinking levels for men and women. Similar increases were seen for suicide among women. But deaths from traffic accidents were not related to drinking levels in either sex. Bertolucci stressed that the study focused on long-term drinking behavior, while traffic deaths might be more related to how much a person was drinking just before the accident. Bertolucci said 25.2 percent of the men and 7.6 percent of the women in the study were classified as heavier drinkers, 17.1 percent of the men and 8.3 percent of the women were ranked as moderate drinkers, 27.2 percent of the men and 23.1 percent of the women were light drinkers, and 30.6 percent of the men and 61 percent of the women were called abstainers. The percentages of heavier drinking were higher than those found in a 1987 national survey that put 14 percent of men and 3.1 percent of women in that category, he said. Ian Rockett, an associate professor of public health at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville, called the study ``valuable in an exploratory sense.'' He cautioned that the drinking levels reported by the next-of-kin may have been underestimates.

DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously on Sept. 30 that two U.S. Air Force pilots killed when their F-15 fighter plane crashed were the first Air Force personnel reported killed in Saudi Arabia since the beginning of operation Desert Shield. The first killed was Air Force Staff Sgt. John Campisi on Aug. 12 when he was hit by a military truck on a darkened runway in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Mayor Proposes New Taxes For New Cops
DOC.TEXT: The mayor said today he wants to hire more than 7,900 more police officers over the next 19 months as part of the effort to curb the city's escalating crime. The officers would be part of a four-year, $1.9 billion anti-crime program which would include 2,950 new jail beds at the Rikers Island prison, improvement of security at 150 schools and more officers on subway trains. Mayor David Dinkins' plan was released after Police Commissioner Lee Brown issued a report saying that by hiring more patrolmen, redeploying other officers and hiring more civilians, there would be an overall increase in the number of officers on patrol daily from 6,640 to 10,227, a hike of 54 percent. The number of police on street beats would triple. Dinkins said the beefed-up force would reduce the average response time to crimes by more than 50 percent to 90 seconds. A rash of high-profile crimes riveted the city's attention this summer. Among the more noteworthy were a number of children hit by stray bullets, the Zodiac gunman who apparently picked his victims by birthdates, repeated killings of cab drivers, the killing of a prosecutor near the Bonx courthouse and the fatal stabbing of a tourist who was defending his mother during a subway mugging. The mayor's program would be financed in part by a property tax increase that would cost the average single family homeowner $20 more per year, and a payroll tax that would cost a worker making $50,000 about $1 per week the first year, $1.50 a week later. The new officers won't be on the streets for some time. The Police Academy can handle 2,600 students at a time by splitting classes into two shifts. Each class lasts six months. Dinkins' program also calls for $420 million over four years for the Board of Education to provide services to students at risk of dropping out, in the hope of preventing crimes. The mayor said he also wants the state to add five new prisons to house additional criminals expected to be arrested by the extra police officers.

DOC.HEAD: Rhetoric Calmer, But No Indication Bush or Saddam Will Blink
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Saddam Hussein have toned down their rhetoric, but private Mideast specialists said Tuesday there's no evidence either man is prepared to make significant concessions in the Persian Gulf. ``I am marginally encouraged by what Saddam and the president have to say, but I don't think it would change my bets very much,'' said Geoffrey Kemp of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a research group. ``The rhetoric had dropped slightly, but we may be moving closer to war because there is no evidence that anyone is prepared to give,'' he said. Saddam has given no indication he'll pull his forces out of Kuwait. In fact, U.S. military sources say he has deployed about 430,000 troops to southern Iraq and Kuwait to defend the occupied territory. And Bush is a long way from cutting a deal with the Iraqi leader he's repeatedly condemned, several experts said. Even though tensions remain high - the aircraft carrier USS Independence and its battle group entered the Persian Gulf Tuesday - analysts said recent statements by Saddam and Bush underscore the caution with which they are proceeding to avoid what would surely be a bloody conflict. They also appear to be keeping the doors open for some face-saving diplomacy, although Bush has insisted there's no flexibility in his policy. Saddam may be feeling the pressure of the U.N. economic sanctions. Bush, in a Monday address to the U.N. General Assembly, reiterated that Iraq's Aug. 2 occupation of Kuwait ``will not be allowed to stand.'' But he said if Saddam withdraws from Kuwait, that could help speed resolution of the Iraq-Kuwait conflict and the dispute over Israel's seizure of Arab lands during the 1967 war. ``Bush was less confrontational, but the substance was the same,'' said Richard Murphy, a former assistant secretary of State for the Middle East. The United States, he said, has long pushed for a solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict. Bush may have appeared to soften his tone to play to his international audience, as well as to underline the U.S. commitment to follow the U.N. lead in isolating Iraq, Murphy said. He may also be sensitive to recent polls that show Americans support Bush's goals in the gulf so far, but aren't prepared for war. Some Republicans have expressed jitters over the effect of the gulf policy on the Nov. 6 elections, analysts said. ``If we get involved in some interminable landlocked police action, there are going to be some second thoughts,'' said Lance Tarrance, a Republican political pollster. One survey, conducted for American Talk Security, a bipartisan group of polling and consulting companies, said nine out of 10 Americans don't want the United States involved in war. Murphy said Saddam ``appears to be nibbling'' at a proposal French President Francois Mitterrand offered at the U.N. last week. Mitterrand said if Saddam withdraws from Kuwait and meets other U.N. demands, the Palestinian and Lebanon questions can be discussed. Saddam has praised Mitterrand for offering positive ideas to resolve the crisis and has said he'll be in contact with the French. Since his annexation of Kuwait, Saddam has repeatedly called for a broad-based resolution of Arab problems. He wants a peace conference to deal with Israel's 23-year annexation of Palestinian lands, including the West Bank and the Golan Heights, and Syria's 14-year occupation of Lebanon. Allen Gerson, a former U.N. official who is now a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, said no one knows what Saddam is thinking, but that the Iraqi president must realize the foolishness of provoking the United States and its U.N. allies. The United States has about 170,000 troops based in Saudi Arabia. ``If he were rational, he would go for a deal,'' Gerson said. ``Otherwise he will get wrecked. The overwhelming odds are that if he doesn't, then he is going to get destroyed.'' Hans Binnendijk, deputy director of London's prestigious International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, said in a recent article that Saddam might withdraw from most of Kuwait except for the southern part of the Rumaila oil fields and the gulf islands of Bubiyan and Warbah. Saddam might try to declare Kuwait a homeland for Palestinians in a bid to garner support from other Arab leaders who don't uniformly look with sympathy on the Kuwait's wealthy ruling clan, the al-Sabahs. Alexander George, a Stanford University professor now at the U.S. Institute of Peace, offered a scenario in which the al-Sabahs or their representatives return Kuwait City, but the Iraqis would then hold onto the oil fields and offshore islands as a bargaining chip. ``I am not advocating appeasement, but these are important carrots,'' he said. But Kemp said he doubts the United States would yield on the demand that the al-Sabahs, who have been driven into exile in Saudi Arabia, return to the emirate.

DOC.HEAD: Disabled Protesters Withdraw After 24-Hour Takeover of College Building
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with protest ending.
DOC.TEXT: Disabled activists ended their occupation of an administration building at Morehouse College today, leaving the building with a statement from the college saying it sympathized with the group's concerns. The protest by members of ADAPT, or Americans Disabled for Attendant Programs Today, had shut down some vital offices in the administration building, but classes continued as scheduled. About 200 activists seized the building Monday and barricaded themselves in the office of President Leroy Keith. They vowed at first to remain until Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan agreed to meet with them. But they modified their demands today, asking instead that Keith write a letter to Sullivan, the former president of the Morehouse School of Medicine, supporting their cause. Keith said he would not write or sign such a letter. ``We have no business intervening in this situation where we have no authority,'' he said. Later, about 50 remaining members of ADAPT left the building carrying a statement written on Keith's stationery. But the statement was not signed and college officials refused to comment on whether they had anything to do with it or come out of the building. Even though they failed in their demand to get Keith to write Sullivan, the demonstrators termed the protest a victory. College students applauded the protesters as they left the building. Earlier today, Campbell Gardett, a spokesman for Sullivan in Washington, said the Department of Health and Human Services had offered to have its regional director in Atlanta meet with the protesters ``as Dr. Sullivan's representative.'' The demonstrators said they felt the late Martin Luther King Jr., a Morehouse alumnus, would have approved of their protest. ``This is a college that has always valued human rights,'' said Michael Auberger, a founder of ADAPT. ``This is another minority that is trying to gain its human rights.'' On Monday, the group expressed dissatisfaction that Sullivan did not respond to their invitation to meet with them although he agreed to speak at an AIDS symposium at Morehouse last week. Auberger said the problems of the disabled are ``as serious as AIDS. He chose to ignore the issue.'' Georgia is one of 13 states that offers no state-funded care for disabled people outside of nursing homes. It is one of eight states that provides no matching supplements for federal disability benefits, said Mark Johnson of Alpharetta, a spokesman of the Georgia branch of ADAPT.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion, Pay Raise at Issue in Close Louisiana Race
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Foster Campbell is attacking GOP Rep. Jim McCrery's strong anti-abortion stance and support for a congressional pay raise as he seeks to put a new ending on a rerun of a tight 1988 race. McCrery acknowledges that Saturday's open primary ``could be close'' and has stepped up campaign advertising in the final days of the race. But he makes no apologies for his views on abortion and accuses Campbell of twisting the facts on the pay raise. Since McCrery and Campbell are the only two candidates on the ballot, the weekend voting will decide the winner of the congressional seat. ``I'm gonna beat this guy,'' says Campbell, a 43-year-old state senator, cattleman and insurance agent. ``His positions are indefensible on abortion. The voters view it as extremist. And, people who work for a living can't handle a vote for a $30,000 pay raise and a vote against a $1.20-an-hour minimum wage increase.'' McCrery, 41, is completing his first full term. He defeated Campbell by just 1,300 votes in an April 1988 special election to complete the term of Buddy Roemer, who became governor. Campbell, who was severely injured in an auto accident in the final month of the special election race, didn't run in the fall election for the full term. In that race, McCrery handily beat Adeline Roemer, the governor's mother. But now Campbell, 43, has fully recovered and is back on the attack. Campbell himself supported a bill prohibiting abortion except in cases of rape and incest and to save the life of the mother. But he says McCrery goes too far in his opposition to abortion. In a recent debate, he called McCrery's vote for a measure prohibiting use of federal funds for abortions ``cold and callous.'' Campbell's less restrictive views on abortion have brought him support from a large group of Shreveport women in business and professions. ``It was just time for us to take a stand on an issue that is going to be involved in next year's state elections,'' said Judy Williams, a public relations and advertising executive. ``A large number of women would have otherwise voted for Jim McCrery.'' McCrery responds that abortion is largely a state issue and defends his vote in Congress against federally financed abortions. ``I have voted against spending your tax dollars to perform abortions and will continue to vote against it,'' he said in a recent debate. ``Go a step further, Jim,'' Campbell countered. ``If a poor woman was raped, you are saying she should not be able to have an abortion if she can't afford one even if she's a victim of rape. I have two daughters. I don't want the government coming into my living room making decisions about them.'' McCrery says Campbell isn't telling the whole story about the congressman's vote in support of a congressional pay raise. ``He doesn't tell you I voted to take away $30,000 of other income from special interests, that I voted to restrict almost all other forms of outside earned income,'' McCrery said. ``It was an important bill to preserve the integrity of the country. ``He says I voted against minimum wage but he doesn't tell you I voted for a 90-cent increase and that is now the law, not the higher wage he wanted. Throughout this campaign, Foster has milled you.'' Campbell responded: `You voted for the $30,000 pay raise, Jim. Why not just vote for a stronger code of ethics?'' Campbell pledged that if he is elected, ``I'll give the $30,000 pay raise to charity each year and document it.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Stocks Rebound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Following the...', to CORRECT to `margin trading limits' sted `... deposits.' Version moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Encouraged by confidence-building measures announced by the Finance Ministry, share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded today in a record single-day surge. The closely watched Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues climbed 2,676.55 points, or 13.24 percent, to 22,898.41. The index had lost 3,555.97 points in the previous five sessions to close at 20,221.86 on Monday, its lowest level in 3{ years. The previous record advance was posted a day after the Black Monday global stock market crash, when the Nikkei rose 2,037.32 points, or 9.3 percent, to 23,947.40 on Oct. 21, 1987. Following the Nikkei's fall below the 20,000-point level at one point Monday, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto announced his ministry would take steps to raise margin trading limits and cut futures and options trading hours in an attempt to support the market. ``The support from the Finance Ministry boosted the market's sentiment. I believe institutional investors as well as individual buyers now can't resist investing at the current low levels,'' said Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, a trader with Daiwa Securities. The market today roared with ``panic buying,'' said Amy Yip, manager of equity sales at Baring Securities Ltd. ``Customers were worried about missing the boat. They're afraid the market's going to pull back tomorrow ... and yet their hands and mouth can't function together. They're moving entirely differently from logic,'' she said. While market participants predicted Monday that the Nikkei would continue downward to 15,000 points, views are now calling for a pulling back to 23,000 points, or even to 25,000 points, Yip said. ``This just shows how very fragile investor sentiment is,'' she said. The Foreign Ministry's measures themselves weren't what prompted buying today, traders said. They said the bullish mood resulted more from the psychological impact of the ministry's stance on ``supporting'' the market. Volume on the market's first section was estimated at 550 million shares, up from 428 million shares Monday. Hashimoto's show of support came after the Nikkei index had shed 10,616.13 points, or 34.4 percent, from its closing of 30,837.99 on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait. Japan is highly vulnerable to unrest in the Persian Gulf because it imports 99 percent of its oil, with 70 percent coming from the Middle East. ``In addition to the psychological effect of Hashimoto's measure, the market, weary of selling, was prepared for an upturn,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, a dealer with Nomura Securities. Diplomatic efforts by countries to settle the gulf crisis, slipping oil prices, a surge in the Dow Jones Industrial Average on Wall Street overnight and a stronger bond market in Japan were among the positive factors, he said. ``We believe today's rebound is an indication of sustained recovery as long as the Middle East remains calm,'' Inoue said. The dollar, meanwhile, declined against the Japanese yen. The dollar began the day at 136.55 yen, down 0.60 yen from Monday's close. After ranging between 136.53 yen and 137.10 yen, it closed at 136.73 yen, down 0.42 yen. The yen's strength reflected overnight gains in New York and other overseas markets amid growing expectations of an easing of U.S. credit, said Minori Takeuchi of Chemical Bank. In bond dealings, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 8.185 percent, down sharply from 8.475 percent the previous day. Their price rose to 82.81 points from 81.68. North Sea Brent crude oil for November delivery fell to about $35.50-35.65 a barrel, well under the $37.40 level late Monday in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Home Sales Decline For Sixth Time In Eight Months
DOC.TEXT: Sales of new homes fell 1.4 percent in August, the government reported Tuesday. Analysts said sales would have fallen further but for buyers who signed contracts before the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis were felt. Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said buyers often rush to ``lock in'' on lower-cost mortgages when they fear rates will rise following an event such as the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But David F. Seiders, economist for the National Association of Home Builders, suggested that September sales will be adversely affected by those made in August and by the rising rates that accompanied the oil-price shock. TheCommerce Department said new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 550,000 after edging down a revised 0.2 percent in July. However, the July fall was much softer than the 2.3 percent first reported last month. The August decline was the sixth in eight months and more evidence of weakness in the housing industry. Sales during the first eight months of the year have plunged 13.6 percent below the same period of 1989. Many analysts expect sales to remain weak because of high mortgage rates, consumer caution over adverse economic news and the Persian Gulf crisis and overbuilding in some areas. Seiders said the Home Builders now are forecasting 500,000 sales this year, compared to 650,000 in 1989. But he said that forecast is contingent upon the Federal Reserve permitting interest rates to fall. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. said fixed-rate mortgage rates, which fell to 9.84 percent during the first week in August, began spiraling after the Iraqi invasion and ended the month at 10.24 percent. They remained at 10.22 percent at the end of September. The weak sales have contributed to sluggishness in the construction industry. The Commerce Department reported on Monday that overall spending was unchanged in August while residential spending fell 1.2 percent from July.
