Sales of less-expensive existing homes, on the other hand, have been moving up for three months, including a 2.1 percent advance in August, according to surveys by the National Association of Realtors. The Commerce Department said the median price of a new home edged up 0.2 percent to $120,200 in August while the Realtors said the median price of an existing home was $97,000. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. Inventories of new homes in August were unchanged from July's 7.7-month backlog, the department said. The West posted the only increase in sales, up 0.7 percent to 139,000 units after falling 3.5 percent a month earlier. Sales were unchanged in the Northeast at 77,000 units following a 7.2 percent decline in July. Sales fell elsewhere. They were down 3.2 percent to 91,000 units in the Midwest after a 2.1 percent drop the previous month, and off 2.0 percent to 244,000 units in the South which had registered a 5.1 percent gain in July.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacist Leader Faces $10 Million Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer who bankrupted a Ku Klux Klan faction with a $7 million civil judgment is going after another white supremacist group with a lawsuit on behalf of the family of an Ethiopian who was beaten to death. The $10 million wrongful death suit goes to trial Oct. 8 in another test of the idea of attacking racist groups through their wallets. Three skinheads confessed to bludgeoning Mulugeta Seraw to death with baseball bats. The lawsuit contends Tom Metzger, the founder of White Aryan Resistance, incited the killing by sending agents to a Portland skinhead group with a message of hate for blacks and Jews. Metzger denies the charge. The lawsuit will be argued by Morris Dees, a lawyer for the Alabama-based Southern Poverty Law Center. He won a $7 million civil judgment three years ago against the United Klans of America after two Klansmen from Mobile, Ala., killed a 19-year-old black man. Metzger, a former KKK grand dragon from Fallbrook, Calif., and White Aryan Resistance are named as defendants, along with Metzger's son, John, and two of the men who confessed to killing Seraw. The case has drawn threats from a white supremacist group suspected in the Sept. 15 bombing of the federal courthouse in San Diego. The FBI is investigating the previously unknown group, the Holy Church of the White Fighting Machine of the Cross. No one was injured in the explosion. But a letter the group sent to KNSD-TV of San Diego said it could not guarantee there would not be injuries in the future. And it warned ``all concerned to drop the lawsuit in Portland, Ore.'' Metzger said he had never heard of the group, but added that other supporters would be in Portland for a fund-raising event during the trial. Civil rights groups also plan rallies and a march during the trial. ``Metzger symbolizes the rise of white hate groups in this country over the last 10 years,'' said Ron Herndon, a black activist in Portland. ``The trial and what happens to him will send a strong message one way or the other to the country.'' The lawsuit claims that, hours before Seraw was slain, two of Metzger's agents spoke to the attackers and other members of a neo-Nazi gang, East Side White Pride. ``Dave Mazzella and I told these skinheads that blacks and Jews were the enemy of the white Aryan race,'' Michael Barrett said in an affidavit for the lawsuit. ``We told them to use violence if they got the opportunity and to be sure and beat the hell out of the enemy. We were telling them what Tom and John Metzger told us to say to skinheads we were organizing.'' Barrett said he had since quit the white supremacist movement. In a telephone interview from California, Metzger denied he sent Barrett and Mazzella to Portland. Seraw, 27, was attacked Nov. 18, 1988, by Kenneth Mieske, Kyle Brewster and Steven Strasser, members of East Side White Pride. The three men and their girlfriends drove up as Seraw was being dropped off by friends. ``They deliberately went up there for the purpose of starting a fight,'' police Detective Tom Nelson said. ``Seraw was defending himself against Brewster when Mieske came up and blindsided Seraw with a baseball bat.'' The blow to the head knocked Seraw to the pavement. Mieske smashed Seraw's head twice more, splitting the bat lengthwise, police said. Mieske admitted he killed Seraw because he was black. He pleaded guilty to murder and racial intimidation, Brewster pleaded guilty to manslaughter and racial intimidation, and Strasser pleaded guilty to manslaughter. Mieske was sentenced to life with a 20-year minimum, Brewster to 10 to 20 years and Strasser to 20 years. Despite the confessions, Metzger contends the killing was in self-defense. ``We've been saying from the beginning that it was mutual combat provoked by the Ethiopians,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Aboard Cruise Ship Off Panama, No Injuries Reported
DOC.TEXT: A cruise ship with 1,463 people on board caught fire in the Atlantic Ocean off Panama, but the blaze was quickly brought under control and no injuries were reported, sources said today. The fire broke out aboard the Crystal Harmony on Monday night, said the sources at Norton Lily of Panama City, the local agents for the ship. The vessel carried 938 passengers and a crew of 525, said the sources, who spoke with The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. ``They're all well,'' one source said of the passengers and crew. The source said the ship was heading for Cristobal, a port at the north entrance of the Panama Canal, and had been expected to arrive there Thursday. The sources refused to give further details. It was not known whether the fire had disabled the ship or whether a rescue operation was under way. The ship's route, owner, and the nationality of its passengers and crew also were not immediately known. The sources said they demanded anonymity because the unidentified company that owns the Crystal Harmony had forbidden them to talk to reporters.

DOC.HEAD: American Companies Plan To Increase Overseas Spending
DOC.TEXT: American companies surveyed before the Persian Gulf crisis said they planned to boost their overseas spending by 1 percent in 1991, the government said Tuesday. The Commerce Department said a survey conducted in June showed that majority-owned foreign affiliates of U.S. companies planned $56.6 billion in capital spending next year, up from $56 billion in planned expenditures in 1990. But the department said ``the 1991 plans should be viewed with particular caution because the most recent survey was conducted ... before the (Aug. 2) Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``Developments in the Middle East following the invasion may influence worldwide economic conditions, investment opportunities and oil prices, which may significantly change firms' capital spending plans,'' it said. The 17 percent increase in 1990 spending plans was up from a 13 percent planned increase reported in a survey last December. Actual capital expenditures in 1989 totaled $47.9 billion. ``The level of capital expenditures indicates that U.S. parent companies plan to maintain their recent emphasis on overseas operations,'' the report said. The largest increases were planned in Germany, up 18 percent to $6.3 billion, and Japan, up 15 percent to $2.6 billion. Even before the energy disruption of the Persian Gulf crisis, the report said petroleum affiliates planned to increase spending by 2 percent, to $15.9 billion, in 1991. The increases include oil tanker construction and oil and gas extraction in Canada, Norway, Nigeria and Southeast Asia. ``Petroleum firms - attracted by host government incentives and potentially larger exploitable oil and gas reserves than those in the United States - have been increasing their overseas spending, relative to their domestic spending, for exploration and development,'' it added. At the same time, it said completed projects will result in spending declines in Australia, Britain and the Caribbean. Manufacturing affiliates plan to increase spending by 1 percent, to $28.2 billion. Increases are planned in non-electrical machinery, transportation equipment and chemicals. ``Manufacturers have been attracted by several favorable conditions abroad: increasing economic integration in the European communities, movement toward market-oriented economic systems in Eastern Europe, an improved investment climate in Latin America and rapid economic growth in East Asia,'' it continued. Large investments in the European communities account for the bulk of the planned increase in spending on non-electrical machinery, mainly computers, and transportation equipment. ``Computer manufacturing affiliates in the European communities plan to build facilities to produce a new generation of high-speed semiconductors and to meet rising demand for personal computers,'' the department said. ``Automotive manufacturing affiliates in the European communities are planning extensive projects to reduce production costs and introduce product improvements in response to rising competition from Japanese-owned firms and growing consumer demand,'' it added. ``In chemicals, sizable investments are planned in Japan, where an affiliate is building a product development center,'' it said. Spending declines, related to project completions, are planned in primary and fabricated metals, ``other manufacturing'' (mainly rubber and paper products), electrical machinery and food products, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Commander Nunez Dies After Long Illness
DOC.TEXT: Carlos Nunez Tellez, a government leader in Nicaragua during the decade when it was ruled by the leftist Sandinistas, has died in Cuba, a Sandinista radio station said today. He was 39. Nunez died of ``an illness for which he was undergoing treatment in Cuba,'' said Radio Ya, the main Sandinista radio station. It did not say when Nunez died. It has been rumored for some time that he had leukemia or some other form of cancer. Nunez was one of the nine commanders that made up the National Directorate of the Sandinista National Liberation Front, and was president of the National Assembly when the Sandinistas controlled it. He was known for his relatively moderate positions on key issues. The Sandinistas lost control of the Assembly in elections on Feb. 25, but Nunez was re-elected. He was seen only at the opening session after the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro took office April 25 after defeating President Daniel Ortega and ending a decade of leftist Sandinista rule. Nunez joined the then-underground Sandinista National Liberation Front in 1969 with his brother, Rene, and received guerrilla training abroad. He became part of the Sandinista directorate in March, 1979, four months before the front toppled the dictatorship of the late Gen. Anastasio Somoza. Information about his survivors and funeral plans were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Ready to Begin Counting Down for Discovery
DOC.TEXT: NASA completed final preparations Tuesday for the countdown of space shuttle Discovery, due to lift off this week with five astronauts and a plutonium-powered sun probe. The countdown clock was to start ticking at 3:30 a.m. Wednesday. Liftoff is scheduled for Saturday morning. A generator containing 23.7 pounds of plutonium-238 was installed Tuesday in the satellite, tucked inside Discovery's cargo bay. The satellite, called Ulysses, will use electricity generated from the decaying plutonium during its five-year journey in space. Technicians also repaired a broken wire in Discovery's engine compartment that was preventing a liquid oxygen valve from opening. Environmental activists opposed to NASA's use of plutonium have gone to court in an attempt to halt the launch. A hearing is scheduled for Thursday in Washington, D.C., before U.S. District Oliver Gasch, who refused to stop Atlantis from lifting off last year with a plutonium-powered satellite bound for Jupiter. The activists fear a Challenger-like accident would scatter the deadly plutonium over Florida and result in untold cancer fatalities. They say NASA's inability to fix the shuttle Columbia's hydrogen leaks calls into question the space agency's competency. NASA tried four times in four months to launch Columbia before stopping two weeks ago to turn its attention to Discovery. Columbia is expected to remain grounded until late this year or early next year. A newly repaired Atlantis, grounded by hydrogen leaks in June, is scheduled to carry a secret military satellite into orbit in early November. NASA officials insist the chances of plutonium being released into the atmosphere are extremely small and would pose little health risk even if it did. There is no other way to get Ulysses into an unprecedented orbit over the sun's poles, they said. ``We've done everything we can'' to ensure safety, said Willis Meeks, NASA's project manager for Ulysses. ``We're ready, and I'm optimistic we're going to launch on the 6th.'' After being released from Discovery, Ulysses is to speed toward Jupiter and use the giant planet's gravity to be whipped into the proper solar orbit. If Discovery does not lift off by Oct. 23, the $750 million mission will have to wait until late 1991 for the proper planetary alignment. The four-day mission would be NASA's first shuttle flight in nearly half a year. Discovery was the last spaceship to be launched; its cargo was the Hubble Space Telescope, which later was found to have a flawed mirror. Meeks, like everyone else at National Aeronautics and Space Administration, is counting on a successful flight by Discovery to help get the beleaguered agency back on track. ``It will be a boost for morale and a boost for NASA,'' Meeks said.

DOC.HEAD: Pillsbury Makes Limited Recall of Brownie Mix
DOC.TEXT: Pillsbury Co. on Tuesday recalled a limited number of its Great Additions brand Double Chocolate Brownie Mix because some boxes were inadvertently filled with Great Additions brand Walnut Brownie Mix. The mix could be a problem to people allergic to walnuts, but it poses no other danger, the company said. The mislabeled batch was distributed in Ohio, Kentucky, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Indiana. The recall covers about 6,000 cases filled June 12-23 at a plant in North Lake, Ill., said Jennifer O'Neill, a spokeswoman for Minneapolis-based Pillsbury. Only a small number of boxes in those cases were filled with the wrong mix, she said. Thirteen consumers in Kentucky, Indiana and Ohio complained about the mistake in August and September, O'Neill said. Pillsbury is recalling packages with a production code of ``FOK'' followed by any number from 12 to 23. The codes are printed on the top flap of the mix box. The ingredients pouch inside the box is correctly labeled. Consumers who want a refund or replacement can return the product to their grocer or contact Pillsbury. Pillsbury has established a toll-free telephone number for consumers who want more information: 1-800-767-4466. The line is open Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. CDT.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested for Blimp Damage Meant No Harm, Lawyer Says
DOC.TEXT: A model-airplane buff arrested after his radio-controlled craft punctured a Goodyear blimp didn't mean to disable the giant airship, his lawyer said. ``He had no desire to shoot the blimp. He knows the blimp flies there,'' said William J. MacCabe, attorney for John W. Moyer, 28, of Redondo Beach. Moyer was arrested after the Columbia, one of three Goodyear blimps, was ripped Sunday when a model plane struck it at 1,000 feet above Carson. The blimp, which was carrying seven Goodyear corporate customers on a promotional flight, made a hasty but safe landing at its base 10 miles south of Los Angeles. No one was injured, but the blimp's tail section and gondola were slightly damaged and there was a 3-by-3-foot gash in the blimp's skin. Moyer was booked for investigation of assault with intent to do bodily harm, and was being held in lieu of $5,000 bail, authorities said. Image-conscious hobbyists in the area were outraged by the incident. ``This is a real black eye,'' complained Larry Wolfe, owner of the Jet Hangar hobby shop in Carson. The Columbia was scheduled to fly with a temporary patch to the Marine Corps Air Station at El Toro on Thursday for repairs expected to take nearly a week, Goodyear spokesman Bob Urhausen said. Urhausen said Monday the blimp may not be repaired in time to serve as a television camera platform for the American League baseball playoffs next week. But it will be on hand when the World Series opens Oct. 16, he said. Goodyear's other blimps are based in Pompano Beach, Fla., and Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Say Rich, Big Business Should Bear More of Budget Brunt
With AM-Budget Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eighty-seven-year-old Charlotte Brooder likes having an occasional glass of wine with dinner and wouldn't mind having to pay slightly more for it. But when it comes to Medicare, she has a message for President Bush and Congress: Don't mess with the rates. Trying to rein in the mushrooming budget deficit, Bush and congressional leaders have tentatively agreed to increase the Medicare premium for 34 million Americans, many of whom like Brooder rely on fixed incomes. Taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, alcohol and other luxury items also would rise. But it is the provision raising the Medicare premium that most bothers Brooder, a retired schoolteacher and librarian who moved to San Diego from Sheridan, Wyo., in 1973. Brooder and other low-income elderly living in the Green Manor high-rise complex said in interviews Monday that the burden of balancing the federal budget always seems to fall heavily on the poor and the elderly. Often they are one in the same. ``I just don't like it,'' said Brooder, who pays $240 a month for the one-bedroom apartment. ``I know they are trying to balance the budget, but I just don't like the way they are trying to balance it. I could probably get along fine, but there are many who could not. ``I like to go out to dinner and have a glass of wine every once in a while and I wouldn't mind paying the tax on it, but that's my business and I'm probably going to have to keep my entertainment down,'' said Brooder, a widow since 1961. According to the budget plan, Medicare beneficiaries would pay more for the coverage that helps pay doctor bills. An annual $75 deductible would rise to $100 in 1991 and to $150 by 1993. Medicare insurance premiums would rise from $28.60 per month to $33.50 next year and to $54.30 by 1995, the American Association of Retired Persons estimates. The budget plan aims to save $60 billion in Medicare outlays in the next five years. Half would be in reduced payments to doctors and hospitals, the rest by taxing beneficiaries. As in other places with a large elderly population, talk around Green Manor is all about the budget and its impact on Medicare. From the crowd chatting on the lobby couch, to the laundry room, to the lounge, the topic was the proposed changes in benefits. Many said the effects would be severe. ``It's going to hit people hard,'' said Irene Hawkinson, 69, who has lived in Green Manor the past four years with her husband, Eugene, a retired meteorologist. ``I just hope they keep the Social Security Cost of Living Adjustments. We don't need the jewelry or the liquor or the cigarettes.'' Green Manor has 180 residents. To live there, they must be able to fend for teemselves and have an annual income of no more than $20,500 if single or $23,000 if a couple. The 13-story high-rise is owned and subsidized by a nearby congregational church. Rent is scaled to income. There is a three-year waiting list. Bob Woodbridge, 64, a retired drapery maker who moved from El Paso, Texas, in February, said he supplements his $602 monthly Social Security check by washing cars and driving other residents to grocery stores, the doctor and the hospital. ``Some people can't afford to go out, but those who can, why can't it just be a 10 percent increase for them? ``If they are used to spending $20 on entertainment, $22 wouldn't hurt them. So, for people who can afford it, travel a lot and entertain, let them pay the taxes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Executive Testifies About Proposal To Hire Tribal Chairman's Son
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony.
DOC.TEXT: A former coal company executive testified today that suspended Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald and his son sought a $4,500-a-month consulting contract for the son while the company was negotiating a coal lease. The testimony by Kenneth R. Moore, former vice president of St. Louis-based Peabody's western division, came one day after attorneys made opening statements in tribal court in the bribery and kickback trial of MacDonald and son Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr. Moore, who retired from Peabody in 1988, said the contract, which Peabody ultimately rejected, was suggested on at least three occasions in late 1987. It was also mentioned in a letter that gave the amount of the payment at $4,500 a month, he said. Moore said he talked to a Peabody attorney about the proposal who ``basically said, `It smells.' ... We decided not to do it.'' During questioning by the defense attorney Val Jolley, Moore said he was not threatened by the elder MacDonald in relation to Peabody leases to mine coal on Navajo land, nor did MacDonald express any bitterness or hostility when the proposal was rejected. Moore quoted MacDonald as responding: ``Fine, I understand.'' On Monday, Jolley had argued that the prosecution of the Navajos' suspended chairman is flawed because officials do not understand the traditional Indian practice of a chief accepting gifts. Jolley said the prosecution was trying to apply non-Indian notions of political decorum to MacDonald's behavior. ``They've made a bunch of mud balls, hoping that some of them would stick,'' Jolley said in his opening statement. Jolley said tribal ethics permit gifts based on a social relationship, as well as campaign contributions. He did not deny that MacDonald had received loans and gifts from contractors doing business with the tribe, but he did deny such acceptance violated any tribal laws. ``ot a single vendor that gave money to Peter MacDonald Sr. ever received any agreement or understanding that Peter MacDonald Sr. would do anything on behalf of that contractor,'' said Jolley. MacDonald, 61, said his political enemies had delayed the start of the trial in an attempt to worsen his chances at winning election to the new position of tribal president next month. MacDonald had previously accused the interim tribal government of using the trial to remove him from the Nov. 6 ballot and give the job of president to his opponent, former chairman Peterson Zah. In his opening statement, prosecutor Mark Donatelli said MacDonald had violated a public trust. ``Mr. MacDonald retreated into his outside world of cash, condominiums, and corrupt compromise. He alienated the business community through a pattern of corrupt government,'' said Donatelli, whose Santa Fe, N.M., law firm was hired to investigate and prosecute corruption in tribal government. Clint Hartwell, manager of the Citibank Arizona branch here, was the first prosecution witness. Hartwell verified microfilm copies of deposits into the bank account of Denay Inc., owned by MacDonald. Hartwell testified that checks were written to Mrs. MacDonald from the Denay account totaling nearly $104,000 since 1986. MacDonald also received $20,000 from the account, but there are no bank records showing that Denay paid anything to the Internal Revenue Service or the Arizona Department of Revenue, Hartwell said. If convicted in tribal District Court on all 45 counts of bribery, conspiracy and ethics violations, MacDonald could be jailed for 23 years, fined up to $22,500 and barred from serving in tribal office for four years. Monday's was the seventh trial date set for MacDonald and his son, Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr. Legal maneuvering and other roadblocks had forced Judge Robert Yazzie to abandon the previous dates. The younger MacDonald, an unemployed lawyer who lives in San Jose, Calif., faces 11 counts of bribery and one of conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Say Negative Ads Should Identify Their Source
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs top two grafs to CORRECT that petition does not seek to outlaw ads, only to tighten regulations on identification of sponsors.
DOC.TEXT: Two activist groups asked the government Tuesday to tighten regulations to make sure negative political ads clearly identify the candidate making the attack. People for the American Way and the Media Access Project said many attack ads fail to adequately identify their sponsors in a concerted attempt to confuse and deceive voters. ``The American public by and large does not like negative television commercials,'' said Art Kropp, president of People for the American Way. ``On the other hand, they are effective ... if there is no connection made to the candidate who is paying for them.'' Candidates' pictures should appear for at least four seconds and cover at least 20 percent of the TV screen, the two groups said in a petition to the Federal Communications Commission. They also said text identifying the sponsor should appear for at least four seconds and measure at least 4 percent of the vertical height of the TV screen. Currently, special discounted advertising rates are available to candidates whose commercials contain identifications that are readily legible and on screen long enough to be read by the average viewer. But the two groups that filed the FCC complaint showed a tape of political commercials they say show that broadcasters are not meeting those standards. The ads, including some from hot governors' races in California and Texas, feature tiny pictures and text identifying the source of the ads. Sometimes the sponsorship information appears for only a second or two; often it appears against a backdrop of newspaper clips or alongside distractions such as a moving dog or moving text. Andrew Jay Schwartzman, an attorney with the Media Access Project, said the current vague standards make broadcasters reluctant to reject ads. ``As soon as one broadcaster in a community accepts a given ad ... the pressure becomes insurmountable,'' he said. Both groups stressed that they are not promoting censorship or regulation of ad content. ``Negative ads will be a part of campaigns forever. What we're aiming for is basically truth in advertising,'' Kropp said. He and Schwartzman said the abuse is bipartisan and occurs at all levels, with some of the worst cases occurring in local or primary races involving inexperienced and unknown candidates. They said the problems arise mainly in negative spots because they work best with voters when the sponsoring candidate is not associated with the attack. In positive commercials, on the other hand, ``the candidates happily appear standing in their Air Force uniform, bouncing children on their knee or holding the hand of a senior citizen,'' Schwartzman said. The two said they do not expect the FCC to decide on their petition before next month's election, but they want the agency to issue an interim notice reminding broadcasters of their responsibilities under current rules. Milton Gross, chief of the FCC's political branch, said the last such notice was issued in September 1977. He said the agency advises individual broadcasters of their obligations when specific complaints arise, but has never received a broad complaint like the one filed Tuesday. People for the American Way describes itself as a non-partisan constitutional liberties group with 290,000 members. The Media Access Project is a public interest telecommunications law firm.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actress Mimi Rogers says she's been so busy lately she doesn't know if her divorce from Tom Cruise has been finalized. ``As far as I know, we're divorced, but I've been so busy on this new film that I haven't had time to check, so I'm not sure,'' she said recently. ``I bet that sounds pretty silly, huh?'' The actress put her personal life on hold while she worked in the desert from early morning to late at night on her new film ``The Rapture,'' in which she plays a woman facing the end of the world. She also appears in Oliver Stone's ``The Doors'' and stars opposite Mickey Rourke in the thriller ``Desperate Hours,'' which opens this weekend. The Michael Cimino film is a remake of the 1955 Humphrey Bogart movie ``The Desperate Hours,'' which is about an escaped felon who takes a family hostage in their suburban home. Miss Rogers plays the woman whose house is invaded. --- LANSING, Mich. (AP) - June Lockhart says life's a ``hoot and a giggle,'' and she's too busy to settle down like Timmy's mother, the character she played on the 1950s television series ``Lassie.'' The twice-divorced grandmother of two recounted adventures from flying gliders to paddling down the Amazon while speaking to a Town Hall audience Monday. ``I'm not married, and this question sort of goes with how come I look so good,'' said Lockhart, 65. ``There is nothing like a rich, full romantic life to keep you looking great.'' While she has played mothers on television's ``Lost in Space'' series and ``Lassie,'' she said she's anything but a homebody. ``I know so many wonderful men that I date and they are bright, intelligent and young,'' she said. ``And they are sort of all over the country, because I travel a lot so I just phone and say, `Hey, I'm coming in, do you want to play?' ``I hit the ground in the morning running. For me, life is a hoot and a giggle,'' Lockhart said. ``You can't take the stuff seriously.'' ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Baltimore Orioles are thinking about asking one of America's comeback kings, Richard Nixon, to throw out their first pitch next year - the team's last in Memorial Stadium. The invitation hasn't been extended yet, but the team may ask Nixon to do the honors, said Martin B. Conway, the team's vice president for marketing. ``I'm sure it's something he'd look at and consider,'' said Kathy O'Connor, an aide to the former president. ``He has not done this kind of thing in a long time.'' Nixon staged one of the greatest turnarounds in modern political history when he was elected president in 1968 after vowing six years earlier to leave politics forever. His current status as sometimes-adviser to Republican presidents has some political experts saying he's made another comeback since his resignation in disgrace after the Watergate scandal in 1974. If the impending invitation from the Orioles to throw the first pitch raises eyebrows, Conway says it's all part of plans for a nostalgic commemoration of Memorial's first year. It was Vice President Richard Nixon who threw out the first ball on April 15, 1954, when the team played its first game at the stadium. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Doris Day is returning to acting, 17 years after she left television. Miss Day, 66, is signing a multipicture deal with ABC Productions to star in television movies for ABC-TV, the studio said this week. The contract calls for her to be in three TV films a year as a recurring character. The character is still in the planning stages. Production is expected to begin at the end of the year, with three movies to be televised during the 1991-92 season. Miss Day has appeared in more than 40 motion pictures, the last being the comedy ``With Six You Get Egg Roll'' in 1968. Her last TV series was the comedy ``The Doris Day Show'' from 1968-73. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Jazz and soul singer Nancy Wilson's name has been added to Hollywood's Walk of Fame, more than 30 years after she began her career as a vocalist. A party in Wilson's honor was held Monday at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel following the installment ceremony on Hollywood Boulevard. Wilson earned her first hit in 1963 with ``Tell me the Truth.'' Her other hits included, ``I Wanna Be With You,'' ``Peace of Mind,'' and ``Can't Take My Eyes Off of You.'' She received an Emmy for her 1975 television special ``The Nancy Wilson Show.'' Wilson, 53, lives on a 640-acre ranch outside Palm Springs with her husband, the Rev. Wiley Burton. --- MALINDI, Kenya (AP) - Eduardo Agnelli, heir to the Fiat auto fortune, was acquitted Tuesday on a charge of heroin possession. Magistrate Martin Muya freed Agnelli and two Kenyans accused with him, saying the prosecution failed to prove its case. Agnelli called it a set up. The prosecution claimed Agnelli and his co-defendants threw a sachet of heroin into an adjoining room when police raided a home in the nearby village of Watamu on Aug. 21. But Muya noted that the heroin could not have been tossed over the wall separating the rooms, as police claimed, because the rooms had ceilings of woven mats. ``I swear upon God I did not have the drug,'' Agnelli said later outside the courtroom. ``The whole thing was a plant and the judgment was very fair. God bless this country.'' Agnelli, 36, is the only son of Giovanni Agnelli, chairman of the Fiat auto company. The family is one of the world's wealthiest. --- JERUSALEM (AP) - Defense Minister Moshe Arens was in good condition after prostate surgery Tuesday, an aide said. ``The doctors say he is doing well and there are no complications,'' said Arens spokesman Dan Naveh. He added Arens is expected to be released from the Tel Hashomer hospital in Tel Aviv in several days.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Face A New Reality: Gas Masks In Their Closets
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Among the warnings broadcast to Israelis on the radio Tuesday was: Don't let the children play with the gas masks. It was one of many reminders to Israelis - long used to air raid shelters in their basements and sonic booms from air force jets overhead - that they now must face the possibility of an Iraqi chemical attack. In announcing Monday that masks would be distributed to the entire population of 4.7 million, the army was at pains to make it sound like a routine, unhurried operation and not an emergency. But the next morning, sirens in Jerusalem and a suburb of Haifa sent some people in search of shelters while others made worried phone calls to authorities. They were told the sirens went off by accident. Israelis woke up to a barrage of radio talk shows and newspaper articles on how to deal with the masks. To those who wondered whether Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's threat was serious, the reply from the experts was: Iraq probably will not attack Israel, but it's best to be ready. Most callers to Israel radio focused on what people should do with the sealed box containing a mask and syringe with a nerve gas antidote. The answer was: Keep it in the closet, away from the kids, and don't open it except when ordered. How, they asked, can we be sure the masks will work? What about asthma sufferers, and babies? How does one protect the rest of the body? ``In principle, the gas only causes damage when it is breathed in through the lungs. It should not hurt the skin,'' said Col. David Klivansky, answering a question on Israel radio. Klivansky added that in the sealed rooms that Israelis have already been told to prepare for a possible gas attack, ``you need only the mask.'' The kits will be distributed at schools and notices mailed to citizens telling them where to pick them up. Yitzhak Samuel, who lives in the Tel Aviv suburb of Ramat Hasharon, said his family already had received masks and felt safe. ``We have them high up in the closet far from the kids,'' he said on army radio. ``We received lectures on a video and we are not afraid.'' The daily Yediot Ahronot devoted three pages to the gas masks. A picture showed a young woman demonstrating their use in the manner of an airline stewardess. Other photos showed protective tents for infants and special children's masks. A cartoon depicted Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir unwrapping a gas mask and advising a menacing-looking Saddam: ``Don't panic.'' One concern voiced by Israeli officials has been that a decision to distribute gas masks might be read by Saddam as a warlike move. Another fear is that it will scare the Israeli public. ``We can expect the public to behave in an adult manner now, although the announcement about distribution, in our view, will raise the level of anxiety,'' reserve Brig. Gen. Aharon Vardi, a civil defense official, said on Israel television. Indeed, signs of nervousness already are apparent. In the past weeks, while officials debated how to prepare for a chemical attack, people rushed to buy sealing tape for their rooms and baking soda for homemade gas masks. Still, officials are trying to make the gas masks a part of everyday life, just like the constant appeals to be alert for suspicious packages that could be bombs. As army spokesman Brig. Gen. Nachman Shai put it, the public should accept the gas masks simply as ``another way of living in the Holy Land.''

DOC.HEAD: Large-Scale Landing Exercises Underway in Arabian Sea
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Large-scale Navy and Marine Corps amphibious landing exercises are underway in the northern Arabian Sea involving 18 ships and 90 aircraft, the Pentagon said Tuesday. Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams said the exercise, involving elements of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade and Amphibious Task Group III, will continue through Friday. He would not say where the exercises are taking place, specifically refusing to comment on reports that the landings are in the sultanate of Oman. ``I can't confirm the name of the country involved,'' Williams said. No U.S. reporters have been allowed to observe the exercises and Williams said that is the wish of the unnamed host government. He also declined to say how many U.S. troops are involved in the exercise, which he said is intended to sharpen the skills necessary for a successful amphibious landing and to give those involved experience at ``working in a desert environment.'' The Pentagon, meanwhile, announced that U.S. troop strength in the Persian Gulf region now tops 170,000 and is at its highest level since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A total of 26,806 U.S. military reserve personnel have been alerted since the crisis began, Williams said. These include 18,136 Army reservists, 4,062 from the Navy, 3,930 from the Air Force and 678 from the Coast Guard. All are in combat support roles. No Marine reservists are been alerted. Iraqi troop strength in and near Kuwait remains at about 430,000, with 3,500 tanks, 2,500 armored vehicles and 1,700 artillery pieces, Williams said. He said Iraqi forces remain in an essentially defensive posture with infantry forward and armored vehicles toward the rear of the zone.

DOC.HEAD: Opera Diva Joan Sutherland Makes Last Performance
DOC.TEXT: The curtain calls and accolades lasted nearly 45 minutes Tuesday night after Dame Joan Sutherland, acclaimed as the greatest coloratura soprano of her day, gave the final performance of her brillant career. Miss Sutherland, the 63-year-old soprano known as La Stupenda, chose to make her last performance in her hometown, appearing as Marguerite de Valois in Giacomo Meyerbeer's ``Les Huguenots.'' Resplendent in a black floor-length gown, Miss Sutherland was drowned in thunderous applause, cheers and foot-stomping when a single spotlight illuminated her after the rest of the cast members took their bows. They clapped from the wings before gathering behind her as brightly colored streamers and flowers cascaded ankle-deep onto the stage from the audience. Miss Sutherland tossed two of the bouquets into the orchestra pit before rendering a last solo - a haunting, understated version of ``Home Sweet Home.'' Her husband, Richard Bonynge, who conducted the performance, then came on stage to give her a kiss. Moffatt Oxenbould, the opera company's artistic director, gave Miss Sutherland a trophy, saying: ``Trophies are for winners, and you are one of the most gracious winners of all time.'' Later, a 12-man cadre of bagpipers and drummers greeted Miss Sutherland at the Regent Hotel. Fans and guests lined the balcony as her every move was greeted by a barrage of camera flashes. Even photographers assigned to the event lined up for autographs. Tickets for the Opera House performance ranged up to $500 ($415 U.S.). More than 400 patrons in tuxedoes and furs also attended a post-performance dinner that carried the same price tag. But the enthusiastic crowd, which included Prime Minister Bob Hawke and Treasurer Paul Keating, seemed to feel they got their money's worth, chatting excitedly about ``a once-in-a-lifetime'' event as they lingered after the performance. In a toast to Miss Sutherland, Hawke praised her ``hard work, disciplined dedication and single-minded application.'' ``In some ways tonight could be considered a sad occasion, because we have seen the curtain come down on one of the greatest careers in the history of opera,'' he said. ``But in fact tonight should be an occasion for happiness and shared pride in the achievements of a truly great Australian.'' Miss Sutherland was a member of the Royal Opera in London's Covent Garden in 1952-59. In 1959, her performance in ``Lucia di Lammermoor'' won widespread acclaim. Miss Sutherland, with her extraordinarily strong and pure high notes and amazing dexterity in trills and runs, quickly became an international sensation. She specialized in the tragic heroines of the bel canto repertory, from Donizetti's Lucia to Bellini's ``Norma,'' although her spunky Marie in Donizetti's ``Daughter of the Regiment'' was among her most-admired portrayals.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Joins House in Voicing Support for Bush on Gulf Policy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing thruout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Senate today endorsed President Bush's efforts to ``deter Iraqi aggression'' despite some members' concerns that the move could be seen as giving Bush broad authority to wage war. The resolution of support passed by a 96 to 3 margin. It followed an overwhelming House vote Monday expressing similar sentiments. ``This resolution is not an authorization for the use of force, now or in the future,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, told his colleagues before the vote. ``This resolution is not a blank check.'' Senators voting on the prevailing side said they believed it was important to send a signal of unity around the world by giving legislative support to Bush's moves so far. The resolution ``strongly approves the president's leadership'' in winning approval of eight resolutions in the United Nations Security Council, which imposed a global trade embargo on Iraq and called for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait. It states: ``The Congress supports continued action by the president in accordance with the decisions of the United Nations Security Council and in accordance with United States constitutional and statutory processes ... to deter Iraqi aggression and to protect American lives and vital interests in the region.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., joined Sens. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., and Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., in voting against the resolution. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., was not present. Kennedy called the language of the endorsement ``a blank check endorsement for future actions'' which abdicates Congress' war-declaring power. The House resolution, adopted on a 380-29 vote Monday, avoids any mention of future steps in the crisis. ``This resolution most assuredly does not represent a blank check,'' said Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the Foreign Affairs Middle East subcommittee. ``It does not support future actions except those actions that continue present policy.'' Hamilton and committee chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla., said it is the responsibility of lawmakers to demonstrate formally how they feel about Bush's policies in the Middle East. ``This is the most significant decision of the Bush administration with regard to foreign policy, and Congress ought to speak its mind on it,'' Hamilton said. Opponents said the resolution abdicates Congress' responsibility and gives Bush to many loopholes to wage a war. ``I'm very concerned ... this will only provide a congressional public relations mandate for the president to accentuate a military resolution of this crisis rather than sustained diplomatic negotiations with all parties concerned,'' said Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif. The House version puts Congress on record in support of diplomacy, international sanctions and negotiations through the United Nations to achieve Bush's policy goals: Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, restoration of the legitimate Kuwaiti government, freedom for hostages and stability for the gulf region. ``The United States shall continue to emphasize the use of diplomatic and other nonmilitary means in order to achieve those objectives and policies, while maintaining credible United States and multinational deterrent military force,'' the resolution stated. Like the House measure, the Senate resolution applauds Bush's use of the United Nations as a forum for international diplomacy in the crisis. But it appears to further limit Bush's future options by linking them to approval by the United Nations. Congress ``supports continued action by the president in accordance with the decisions of the United Nations Security Council and in accordance with United States constitutional and statutory processes ... to deter Iraqi aggression and to protect American lives and vital interests in the region,'' the Senate version states.

DOC.HEAD: German Democratic Republic Slips into History
DOC.TEXT: East Germany spent a melancholy last day as a nation Tuesday before passing into history, leaving behind 40 years of communism and one brief, dizzy fling as a free country. Bureaucrats emptied their desks and clasped hands in farewell, the first freely chosen Parliament held a wistful last meeting, and the chief government spokesman said he was looking for work. The museum devoted to the former nation's history laid off some workers and began closing departments. West Germany shut its embassy in a country now part of its own. East Germany's once-sacred Communist flag, a red, gold and black banner emblazoned with a hammer and drafting compass, was spread on sidewalks and sold as souvenirs. Lawyers and bureaucrats, once among the powerful elite, stood in the last unemployment lines of an autonomous East Germany. East Germany would have been 41 years old on Sunday, but instead acceded to West Germany and transformed itself into just another five states of the mighty Federal Republic of Germany, or West Germany. Phones rang at government offices Tuesday, but there was nobody home. ``I hope for a new chance in the new Germany. I'm deeply moved by what has happened here,'' said Franz Jahsnowsky, a top Foreign Ministry official. Jahsnowsky, who spoke in the ministry parking lot, was the former chief of diplomatic protocol for ousted Communist boss Erich Honecker. He said he is not optimistic about a role in the new German government. About 220,000 government workers nationwide automatically went into employment limbo. They will receive about 70 percent of their pay while West German officials decide how many to keep. Chief East German government spokesman Matthias Gehler would not hazard an estimate. ``I know I'm out of work,'' Gehler said. Some government workers may get jobs after the new East German state governments are elected on Oct. 14. But tens of thousands are expected to be shut out. Very few people in the Foreign Ministry are expected to get jobs. ``Everyone thinks everyone in the Foreign Ministry had contact with state security (secret police),'' said Eckhard Trenck, 40, who works in the press department. Many East Germans said they welcomed unity, but felt sad at the imminent end of their national identity and the only homeland they knew. The Soviet Union carved the German Democratic Republic from the rubble of World War II on Oct. 7, 1949. The nation was ruled by a succession of iron-fisted Stalinist governments until the protests that swept the East bloc toppled the old regime on Oct. 18, 1989. On Nov. 9, the Berlin Wall was opened. A Communist caretaker government ran the nation until the first free elections of March 18, when the Christian Democrats of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere were elected on the promise of quick German unity. The 400-member Parliament held an emotional final sitting Tuesday after a rocky, six-month tenure during which legislators battled West Germany and among themselves over the terms and timing of unity. Only 144 lawmakers are to be added to the West German Parliament that convenes for the first time on Thursday. The rest are out of work. ``We have fulfilled our duties,'' said Sabine-Bergmann Pohl, a physician and president of Parliament. It was a sad time at East Berlin's Museum for German History, where 25 pensioners were laid off and about half of the 160 other workers were put on indefinite status. The museum - once a shrine to the old regime - was turned over last month to the German History Museum in West Berlin, which permanently closed some sections on Tuesday. It plans to empty the building by year's end and move its artifacts to a wing of a new museum in the western side of the city. A small group of employees was talking to a reporter Tuesday when a woman came by with their layoff notices. ``That's what democracy is to us,'' snapped Gerta Kirchner, 70. ``I need this salary to survive.'' West Berliner Christoph Stoelzl, the new head of the museum, said pensioners are being laid off because West German law regulates how much outside income they can receive. Peter Wensszlaw is a bit of a museum piece himself. He was a lawyer in an East German legal system that no longer exists because East Germany now has West German laws. The nattily dressed Wensszlaw, 38, stood in an unemployment line. He said he has no bitterness about the changes that moved him from a position of privilege to one of desperation. ``I was a lawyer for 19 years and a (Communist Party) member,'' he said. ``My wife was a teacher and she's also out of work. But there is a good thing happening here. I'm optimistic.'' Wensszlaw said an employment counselor mentioned the possiblity of working as a tax adviser. ``From a Communist lawyer to a (West German) tax expert,'' he said. ``You can't think about ideology any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Battle-Scarred Reichstag, a Symbol of Turbulent Past
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The battle scars on the Reichstag testify to Germany's turbulent past and the old parliament building's place in German history. With the hoisting of Germany's flag and the singing of the national anthem in front of the Reichstag at midnight Tuesday, the old parliament building becomes the focal point of unification ceremonies. On Thursday, the Reichstag will be host to the first session of German lawmakers in nearly six decades as legislators from the West and East come together for the first time in the new united Germany. The sandstone edifice was heavily damaged in the last days of World War II as German troops and Soviet soldiers engaged in fierce fighting for the capital. After hand-to-hand combat, Red Army soldiers raised a red Soviet flag atop the Reichstag, in a famous World War II photograph that symbolized the crushing of Adolf Hitler's Third Reich. After the war, the West German parliament met occasionally at the Reichstag, but never convened in full. Restoration of the building was completed in 1971, but the main hall, where Thursday's session will be held, was deliberately left empty as a reminder of the unresolved German question. Germany got its first parliament in 1871 after Kaiser Wilhelm I unified the country and Berlin became the capital. The building and the parliament were called Reichstag, meaning imperial legislature. The present Reichstag building was completed in 1894 after 10 years of construction. A mysterious fire on Feb. 27, 1933, just a month after Hitler became chancellor, gutted the building. The blaze served as Hitler's pretext to force passage of an act that allowed his government to make laws without Reichstag approval. The inscription ``Dem Deutschen Volke'' (To the German People) was added to the building during World War I and is still visible over the main portal.

DOC.HEAD: Gift From Americans Bears Prophetic Inscription
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Among the thousands of bells ringing in the new united Germany is one with a fitting inscription: a 23,000-pound Liberty Bell given to Berlin by millions of Americans. The Liberty Bell, which hangs in the tower of Berlin's Schoeneberg city hall, about three miles from the Brandenburg Gate, was presented to Berlin on Oct. 24, 1950, by the then-military governor of Germany, U.S. Gen. Lucius D. Clay. Records show 17 million Americans donated money to give the bell to Berlin after the Berlin airlift. The nine-month airlift kept West Berliners from starving and broke a Soviet blockade of the city that ended in May 1949. The Liberty Bell bears this inscription, in English: ``That this world under God shall have a new birth of freedom.'' The Berlin Liberty Bell, which is electronically controlled, rings out over the city each noon and during special celebrations.

DOC.HEAD: Hijacked Plane Crashes, Killing 127 People
LaserPhoto HK1
DOC.TEXT: A hijacked Chinese jetliner cartwheeled into two parked jets at Canton airport Tuesday, setting off a fiery explosion, killing at least 127 people and seriously injuring 46 others, officials said. ``The plane split the jets into pieces,'' said a Chinese man who witnessed the crash. ``It was a horrible explosion. The whole sky went red and the airport shook like an earthquake.'' Money, passports, watches and clothes were scattered along the tarmac. The crash occurred at 9 a.m., but ambulances wailed late into the night. Chinese officials, Western diplomats and witnesses provided conflicting accounts of the disaster and the resulting casualties. A Western survivor said there was a struggle in the cockpit of the hijacked Boeing 737 as it landed at Baiyun International Airport, causing the plane to careen into an empty Boeing 707 and a Boeing 757 full of passengers bound for Shanghai. Other unconfirmed reports said two hijackers, Chinese men who wanted to force the plane to Hong Kong or Taiwan, exploded a bomb on the jet. A CAAC spokesman, Wang Chunfu, said only one Chinese man was responsible for the hijacking. Wang told a news conference 127 people died in the crash and 46 people were seriously injured. He said 100 people, including the injured, survived. Among those killed, he said, were foreigners and Chinese from Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan. He declined to release further details. Premier Li Peng went to the crash site near China's main southeast city and visited survivors at hospitals. The accident was the worst publicly acknowledged air disaster in China. Previously, in 1982, a CAAC Trident crashed in the southern city of Guilin, killing 112 people. China rarely disclosed air disasters before the 1980s. Although it was a domestic flight from Ziamen to Canton, at least two Americans were on the hijacked plane, U.S. Embassy spokesman Sheridan Bell said. Erin Lynne Thomas of Oklahoma City, Okla., was hospitalized in good condition with a broken limb, he said. She reported a second American woman had been sitting next to her, but Bell said the second woman was missing. An airport security officer, who only identified himself as Chen, said the pilot tricked the hijackers into believing they were leaving China, but the hijackers realized the truth as the jet approached Canton. As the hijackers argued with the pilot, Chen said, the plane circled the airport for about 40 minutes. Then it crashed. Witnesses said the 737 spun out of control down the tarmac, sideswiping the empty plane before hitting the 757. ``The plane was snapped in half like a match stick,'' said a Westerner who saw the crash scene. ``All that was left of the fuselage was charred metal. It looked like a crematorium.'' The conflicting reports on the number of people killed or injured could not be reconciled immediately. Western diplomats said 104 people, including 10 crew members, were aboard the hijacked plane. Diplomats said they learned of only nine survivors, including the American woman. At least 150 people were aboard the Boeing 757, the airport security official said. He said he believed ``a large number'' of people were also killed aboard that flight. Tomohide Yamamoto, a businessman from Japan, said he was sitting in the 12th row of the Boeing 757. ``I think those who were sitting behind the 14th row couldn't have escaped from the plane,'' he told Japanese television. ``Only those who were sitting in the front were rescued. After I got out of the plane, no one came out.'' The security official said that among the three planes, only five people - an airplane mechanic, an air hostess, an elderly woman, a young woman and a man - escaped unscathed. ``We have at least 200 people dead or injured,'' he said. He said he believed the casualty tolls were higher than reported by the Chinese media. The security official said two hijackers exploded a bomb as the jet landed, causing the accident. Officials from the Boeing Co., which has an office at the airport, also told U.S. diplomats in Guangzhou, that a bomb was detonated in the plane, diplomats said. But a survivor, speaking on condition of anonymity, denied the report and said the crash was caused by a scuffle in the cockpit. The hijacking and crash occurred as China was playing host to its first major international sporting event, the Asian Games. Security forces nationwide have been on alert to prevent any incidents that might embarrass the government. Several hijackings, once unheard of in Communist China, have taken place in recent years. In April 1989, a hijacker blew himself up after he failed to force a domestic flight to Taiwan.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Explosion Destroys Two Homes, Damages Three
DOC.TEXT: A fiery natural gas explosion destroyed two houses and heavily damaged three Tuesday in this community across Boston Harbor from Logan International Airport. Firefighters were hampered by low water pressure and winds up to 35 mph that whipped the flames, officials said. No injuries were reported. Neighbors said the homes were empty because their occupants were at work. ``There was just a massive explosion,'' said Dan Wall, who was watching television at home at the time. ``Pictures came crashing off the wall. It knocked me out of my chair.'' Boston Gas spokesme said that justan Frank Arrical before the noontime explosion, a utility crew had been about half a block away digging in search of a reported leak. It was unclear whether the digging was related to the explosion, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Says Coast Guard Should Be Able to Shoot Down Drug Planes
DOC.TEXT: If Rep. Lawrence Coughlin has his way, the Coast Guard would have the authority to shoot down aircraft suspected of carrying illegal narcotics. On Tuesday, the Pennsylvania Republican presented the House Merchant Marines subcommittee with this scenario in which his legislation wmunist Party official lashed out Tuesday at a proposed law to limit the party's influence in the Soviet military and police, calling it a ``step toward lawlessness.'' The national legislature approved the law in principle Monday and began considering amendments Tuesday. Final approval could come as early as Wednesday. The bill would establish procedures for forming new political parties and guarantee them equal rights with the Communist Party, which agreed earlier this year to give up its constitutional monopoly on power. Yuri A. Manayenkov, a member of the legislature and the party's Central Committee, told reporters during a break in the legislative debate that the law would usher in ``the real transition to a multiparty system'' and create ``a good foundation for further democratization.'' But, he added: ``I would like to say that not all the provisions in the draft law please us, as Communists.'' In particular, he objected to a clause that would require soldiers, police officers and KGB agents to ``suspend active political participation'' in political parties, including the Communist Party. ``What does `active political participation' mean?'' Manayenkov said. ``What are the exact, concrete parameters? There aren't any. So this would be, in fact, a step toward lawlessness.'' The Communist Party's power and influence have waned in the past year as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev created a powerful presidency and appointed a presidential council that assumed much of the authority formerly wielded by the party's Politburo. But the party has kept a strong hold on the military, KGB security police and law enforcement agencies, and Manayenkov's comments indicated that Communists are reluctant to give up that control. Manayenkov also said the party plans to hold onto most of its property, officially valued at $7.8 billion. There have been calls by local authorities in some cities for the party to turn over its buildings to the government. Maj. Gen. Mikhail S. Surkov, a legislator and head of the political section of the Soviet army in the Transcaucasian region, told reporters that soldiers could remain party members under the proposed law. But he said all party meetings and other political activities would have to take place during ``non-working hours.'' Surkov denied allegations that officers who have quit the party in recent months have been drummed out of the military. Of 480,000 Communists in the military, he said, only 680 have voluntarily left the party this year, ``and not one of them was forced out of the army afterward.'' Nikolai Sazonov, a leader of the Democratic Socialist faction in the legislature, called for stronger measures to depoliticize the armed forces and law enforcement agencies. He said his faction would propose an amendment to prohibit any party from giving orders to officials in the military, police and KGB. ``The current proposal is too vague,'' he said. ``The party won't give up control of the military and the KGB unless it has to.''

DOC.HEAD: Official Rules Out Debate on Celibacy, Women Priests
DOC.TEXT: The moderator at the worldwide synod of bishops said Tuesday there should be no debate on rules requiring priests to be celibate and forbidding the ordination of women. The synod, an advisory body attended by more than 200 bishops, was called by Pope John Paul II to discuss the formation of Roman Catholic priests. The monthlong assembly, which opened Sunday with a Mass in St. Peter's Basilica, began its official working sessions Tuesday. The pope has made it clear he has no intention of changing the church position mandating priestly celibacy and an all-male priesthood. Brazilian Cardinal Lucas Moreira Neves, the synod moderator appointed by the pope, emphasized that these issues would not be up for debate at the meeting. ``Time is not sufficient to deal with certain questions, such as celibacy of priests, women priests, priesthood for married men,'' he told the assembly. ``These issues have already been dealt with in a definite way in other forums.'' Some bishops, however, are expected to raise the question of how they can persuade more men to become priests without abandoning the celibacy rule. One of the reasons cited for the decline in the number of priests is the requirement that they be celibate and forsake marriage. Earlier Tuesday, the International Federation of Married Catholic Priests held a news conference in Rome to complain that the ``opinion of an important minority has no voice'' at the synod. The organization's president, Bert Peeters of Belgium, said the group had sent letters to all the bishops' conferences represented at the synod to press for changes allowing ordination of women and married men. Peeters said his federation is represented in 26 countries. Of the 400,000 priests in the world, about 90,000 are married, he said. The highest number is in the United States, with 17,000, followed by France with 10,000, Peeters said. The church does not permit members of the organization to celebrate the sacraments. In his speech, Moreira Neves, who is archbishop of Sao Salvador of Bahia, said a greater effort must be made to prepare candidates for the priesthood. ``The springtime of vocations experienced in many parts of the world could turn into a cold winter if proper formation is lacking,'' he said. If young candidates do not receive the proper training in seminaries, the bishops who ordain them ``risk laying their hands on good and nice pagans.'' Young priests should be psychologically balanced and spiritually motivated, and must dedicate their work to the good of the church, Moreira Neves said. ``Otherwise they run the risk of throwing themselves into social work in the role of militants, revolutionaries and labor leaders,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Hears School `Resegregation' Case
DOC.TEXT:
The Supreme Court was urged Tuesday to let Oklahoma City children attend neighborhood schools even though that has brought back racial imbalance. Continued desegregation of public schools in hundreds of other American cities could be at stake as well. Lawyers for the Bush administration and the Oklahoma City school board said formerly segregated school districts should be allowed to escape court-ordered integration plans once they achieve racial balance. But a lawyer for some black parents in Oklahoma City said returning to neighborhood schools in a city where whites and blacks live in different areas had turned back the clock to a time when blacks and whites were required to attend separate schools. In an animated, hour-long session, all eight justices asked questions. Solicitor General Kenneth Starr, the administration's top courtroom lawyer, acknowledged that many of Oklahoma City's neighborhoods are predominantly black or white, but said, ``The school board has no realistic control over where people choose to live.'' School board lawyer Ronald Day argued that a federal judge's finding in 1977 that the city's schools were fully integrated - or ``unitary'' - freed the board from continuing forced busing and other court-ordered remedies until all city neighborhoods are integrated. Such residential segregation, Day said, ``is a phenomenon over which this school board, indeed no school board, has control.''
Julius Chambers, the New York City lawyer challenging the neighborhood school plan, told the court, ``You should not let the school district in Oklahoma City, or in any other city, reinstate the same assignment practices that caused segregation in the past.'' At issue is whether once-segregated school districts are under any continuing obligation to maintain racial balance in their schools once a federal court says they have achieved total integration. But the high court also may have to say for the first time, in a decision expected by July, just what constitutes total integration. Justices Harry A. Blackmun and Anthony M. Kennedy posed questions about the definition of ``unitary,'' and showed no indication that they agreed with the definitions offered. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Antonin Scalia and Sandra Day O'Connor grilled Chambers on his assertion that school desegregation should last as long as residential segregation exists. At one point, O'Connor asked whether Oklahoma City school officials would be required to comply with some kind of desegregation plan ``100 years from now'' if blacks and whites still lived in predominantly one-race neighborhoods. Chambers said they would be. Justice Thurgood Marshall, the court's only black member and the winning lawyer in the 1954 case that outlawed racial segregation in public schools, engaged both Starr and Day in spirited exchanges. Referring to that landmark case, Marshall asked Day, ``What assurance do I have that the school board will continue to honor the Constitution?'' And the justice challenged an assertion by Starr by stating, ``The poor Afro-American kid is still in the same school. It remains a segregated school.'' Before the court's 1954 ruling, Oklahoma City's public schools were racially segregated by law. The school board was sued in 1961 for continuing to operate a dual system, and in 1972 massive busing was ordered. But the same federal judge who had ordered the busing and other desegregation tactics ruled in 1977 that Oklahoma City schools had achieved full integration. Eight years later, city school officials returned to a neighborhood schools plan for children in kindergarten through fourth grade. The racial balance that had been achieved through busing disappeared, and some parents called the result ``resegregation.'' The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals disapproved the Oklahoma City neighborhood schools plan last year, ruling that federal court supervision in such cases ``extends beyond the termination of the wrongdoing.'' Other federal appeals courts have ruled - in cases from Norfolk, Va., and Austin, Texas - that a local school board's obligation to promote racial balance ends when the school district is declared fully integrated.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Chile's President, U.S. Moves To Improve Relations
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration took another step Tuesday to strengthen relations with Chile's new democratic government by allowing the Overseas Private Investment Corp. to resume operations there. The announcement came during the first Washington visit of President Patricio Aylwin since his March inauguration brought democratic rule back to Chile. Aylwin met President Bush at the White House Tuesday. OPIC is a quasi-governmental organization that facilitates investment by U.S. firms in foreign countries. The White House also disclosed that Bush will travel to Chile during a tour of five South American countries Dec. 2 to Dec. 8. The United States barred OPIC activities with Chile under Aylwin's predecessor, military dictator Gen. Augosto Pinochet, because of concerns about labor rights violations. Union leaders during the early Pinochet years claimed that many labor organizers were killed by government factions. ``Following a review process, it has been determined that these abuses have been eliminated,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. Relations between the United States and Chile now are moving ahead and making the transition from the Pinochet era, said Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson. ``There's a lot of baggage from the past from the Pinochet days that we're trying to clean out. This is a government we feel very strongly about and we want to make that clear in deed as well as word,'' he said of the decision to let OPIC resume operations with Chile. Pinochet remains head of the nation's 60,000-strong military, and Aylwin recently ordered the general to cease his renewed involvement in politics. Bush ``expressed the United States' strong support for Chile's return to democracy, and our commitment to close and cooperative relations with Chile,'' Fitzwater said in a statement. Aylwin told reporters after their Oval Office meeting that he and Bush also discussed the newly signed agreement to set up a U.S.-Chile Council on Trade and Investment, to lay the groundwork for a future free trade agreement. The administration currently has a proposal pending in Congress for a free trade pact with Mexico, like the one the United States has with Canada. U.S. officials want to conclude the agreement with Mexico, which would come at the end of 1991 at the earliest, before moving ahead with stated intentions to open free trade with Chile or other countries in the hemisphere, officials said. However, the trade council and the OPIC decision are seen as a way the United States can encourage Chile's return to democracy and pledge to end years of human rights abuses. ``We would like to reward that both for our sake and theirs,'' said Timothy O'Leary, spokesman for the U.S. Trade Representative's office. ``This is an important step toward enhancing our relationship.'' Bush announced in June in his Enterprise for the Americas initiative that he wanted eventually to see free trade throughout the hemisphere. Accords similar to the one reached with Chile also have been signed with Colombia and Ecuador. The accord sets up a bilateral council that would include private sector and government members to resolve trade disputes and questions relating to investment. Aylwin also pressed Bush for inclusion of Chile in the Generalized System of Preferences, a system in which Third World countries can get special trade benefits. The Chilean government is working on the remaining obstacles to obtaining GSP benefits, which center chiefly on U.S. industry's complaints regarding the lack of patent protection for U.S. products. Aylwin told reporters outside the White House that he had also expressed to Bush his commitment to human rights and to seeing justice done in the case of former Chilean diplomat Orlando Letelier and an associate, who were murdered in a car bombing in Washington in 1976. U.S. authorities blame agents of the military government then in power.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Kill 17, Set 400 Houses on Fire
DOC.TEXT: Paramilitary troops shot and killed 17 civilians and set 400 houses on fire in the troubled Kashmir valley after an ambush attempt by Moslem separatists, witnesses and a local official said Tuesday. United News of India said 20 people died. The government said 11 civilians, one policeman, one soldier and two rebels died in a gunbattle between the troops and the militants. It said a court of inquiry has been ordered. The shootings broke out around noon Monday in Handwara, an apple trading town about 46 miles from the Jammu-Kashmir state capital of Srinagar. The government said Moslem militants hurled a grenade at Border Security Force troops patrolling the town market. The grenade missed the troops, but ignited a fire in a shop that killed four people, it said. A full-scale battle between the troops and about 50 militants ensued, in which many civilians got caught in cross-fire, state police chief Jyotindra Nath Saxena told reporters in Srinagar. The Kashmir valley has been wracked since January by a Moslem movement for secession from Hindu-majority India. At least 1,300 people have been killed in battles between security forces and the insurgents. Indian security forces have often been accused of human rights abuses in trying to control the insurrection. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people follow Islam, making it the only Moslem-majority state in India. Nationwide, Moslems account for 12 percent of India's 880 million people. Phansung, a Handwara town official who uses one name, and other residents said troops set fire to about 400 houses after the grenade was thrown and raked the town with rifle fire. Many victims were dragged from their homes and shot at point-blank range, and others died in the fire which gutted the market, witnesses said. A shopkeeper, Mohammad Anwar, said he saw a government official being stopped by the troops in the street and made to sit down on the pavement. ``Then they just shot him in the head and threw him into a burning shop,'' Anwar said. A senior state government official of the district, Mushtaq Ahmed Gannai, said many of the 1,500 people inhabiting the shopping neighborhood were missing. There were reports that 200 schoolchildren had not returned home, he said. Handwara has a population of about 30,000. Among the dead was a former Kashmiri lawmaker, Malik Ghulam Rassol, who was dragged out of his home and shot, his neighbor Jana Begum said. She said her brother's wife and her son were also were shot to death when they ran out of their blazing home. Four people were hit by bullets as they traveled in a taxi. On Tuesday, the taxi was seen crashed into a wall, its windshield punctured by bullet holes and the upholstery covered with dried blood. The smell of burned flesh emanated from the smoking debris of the buildings that housed shops on the ground floor and houses on the upper stories.

DOC.HEAD: Brooklyn Museum Displays NEA-Funded Collection of `Objectionable Art'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 9th and 10th grafs, `The exhibit includes ...'
DOC.TEXT: While a Cincinnati art gallery and its director stand trial for obscenity, the Brooklyn Museum is showing deliberately ``objectionable'' artworks funded in part by the National Endowment for the Arts. Museum officials culled the display of nude children, embracing lesbians and homo-erotic paintings from their own collection, in response to what they call the current climate of censorship. The exhibit, ``The Brooklyn Museum Collection: The Play of the Unmentionable,'' also includes three Robert Mapplethorpe photographs, including a study of a nude black man. Twenty percent of the funding came from the NEA and the rest from donations, museum officials said. ``The really mind-bending discovery is that museums and private collections throughout the land are already replete of art which would send certain politicians and certain public pronouncers crazy,'' said Robert Buck, the museum's director. ``It's already been this way for thousands of years. Art is a reflection of life.'' NEA spokeswoman Virginia Falck said Tuesday the endowment was not aware of the nature of the exhibit and was ``looking into it.'' The endowment has come under attack from conservatives for using government money to fund art projects they believe is obscene. Joseph Kosuth, considered one of the leaders in the conceptual art movement that began in the 1960s, received an NEA grant last spring for an unspecified exhibition, giving just the briefest details of the kind of art that would be displayed. He decided to comb the Brooklyn Museum for art that would illustrate what he believes is th fallacy of artistic censorship. Kosuth said he asked the curators of the museum's six major departments to come up with artwork that could be considered objectionable by some. ``It really shows the history of the culture of intolerance,'' said Kosuth. ``We're only organizing what's already there. We're showing that this is endemic to the whole cultural context and that a country shouldn't assault itself this way with this kind of debate.'' The exhibit includes a broad range of paintings, photographs and sculpture. Among the artwork displayed are Rodin's bronzes of lesbians embracing, 19th century paintings of nude children, and an 18th century Hindu painting of a man urinating into another man's mouth called ``Intoxicated Ascetics.'' One of the seven photographs at issue in the obscenity trial of a Cincinnati art gallery and its director shows a man urinating into another man's mouth. The prosecution rested its case Monday after jurors took their first look at the explicit pictures. The Brooklyn Museum exhibit also includes a series by the contemporary photographer Larry Clark whose series ``Teen-age Lust'' shows explicit photographs of sex acts, as well as a photo of a nude brother and sister. The boy is pointing a pistol at his sister, who is tied up. ``Mapplethorpe would be considered mild compared with some of the work,' said Kosuth. The exhibit, which opened Sept. 27 and runs until Dec. 4, is on display in the grand lobby. ``It hits you right when you walk in,'' said Kosuth. ``But there are signs up letting people know if they don't want to see it or if they don't want their children to see it.'' Juxtaposed between the artwork are quotations about art and censorship by historical figures such as Adolf Hitler, Joseph Goebbels and George Bernard Shaw.
