The quote from Hitler reads: ``Artist does not create for the artist; he creates for the people and we will see to it henceforth that people will be called in to judge its art.'' Shaw's quote reads ``Assassination is the extreme form of censorship.''

DOC.HEAD: VOA Tapes `Radio Postcards' from Families of Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This stands for AM-Gulf-Hostages Messages, listed as with to AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt, on the noon digest.
DOC.TEXT: ``Hi Johnny ... we're having three grandchildren, not two - Michelle is having twins,'' was the joyful message to one of more than 900 American hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. ``You're in my thoughts constantly, constantly, constantly.'' Families of those trapped in the Mideast began sending messages to their loved ones Tuesday, taping them on a hotline set up by the Voice of America. ``These are radio postcards,'' said VOA Director Richard Carlson. The families have been told to keep their messages personal, to refrain from expressing political views and to avoid using last names so they don't tip off Iraqi authorities searching for Americans in hiding. A State Department task force has started calling the families and giving them the hotline number, along with instructions on what type of messages to prepare. The first calls to the hotline were poignant. One, to Sergio ``from the west coast of Mississippi,'' said: ``Missy will be coming home for Thanksgiving. I pray you'll be here, too. Love, Mickey.'' Another was to Bob ``from his loving wife Sue.'' Assuring him the family was doing well, she added: ``We're praying for your safe return. We miss you very, very much. Come home soon.'' There were also some humorously cryptic messages. This one, to Mike from Jeff, said the caller had spoken to ``Mrs. W. in New York. Notre Dame has won its first three games. We think about you every day.'' The 30-second greetings will be aired starting Thursday on the government-owned radio network. VOA, which since the gulf crisis began has increased its English and Arabic-language programs to 24 hours a day, will broadcast the messages in three five-minute segments during each hour of the station's morning news program. On the first day, the messages may be aired in a 15-minute segment. An estimated 600 to 700 Americans - mostly men - are believed trapped in Kuwait, with another 300 to 350 in Iraq. Most of their families were allowed to leave. Iraqi authorities have rounded up about 100 Americans and moved them to industrial and military facilities as ``human shields'' to guard against U.S. bombings. The rest of the Americans in Kuwait are hiding from house-to-house searches by Iraqi security forces. State Department officials say many of those captured were fingered by informants who led security forces to their hideouts. In many cases, Iraqi troops broke down doors to get into apartments where Americans were hiding in cramped quarters and suffering food shortages and uncertainty about their fate. A special round-the-clock task force at the State Department has been keeping in touch with the families in the United States, relaying information about the hostages if they have it and providing moral support. It has also begun referring families to support groups. VOA, which broadcasts news and entertainment in 43 languages around the globe, said this was a first-of-its-kind operation. The only comparable project was a program of messages in Pashto and Urdu, the languages spoken in Afghanistan and Pakistan, to refugee families after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979. Within hours of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the Iraqis began jamming VOA's Arabic language service, along with the British BBC's Arabic service. But the jamming has eased considerably in recent days and the English-language broadcasts have not been disrupted at all. The VOA recently received permission from Bahrain, off the coast of Saudi Arabia, to use medium-wave transmitters for its English-language service, providing the closest facility to Iraq and occupied Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus-Desegregation
Court Hears Case On Restoring Man To Sanity So He Can Be Executed
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana officials should be barred from giving a mass murderer mind-altering drugs to restore his sanity so he can be executed, the Supreme Court was told Tuesday. ``It's fundamentally wrong,'' Baton Rouge, La., lawyer Keith Nordyke argued in behalf of death row inmate Michael Owen Perry. ``The medications don't cure Mr. Perry. They may mask his insanity for a period of time so we can feel better about executing him,'' Nordyke contended. But Rene Salomon, an assistant state attorney general, said the powerful drugs being given to Perry are beneficial. And Salomon emphasized that Louisiana has a strong interest in seeing Perry cured - so he can be executed. At one point, Justice Harry A. Blackmun said, ``It doesn't seem to make much sense to cure a man only to execute him.'' But Justices Antonin Scalia and Byron R. White suggested that Louisiana officials are doing nothing more than administering drugs routinely given to people suffering from Perry's mental illness. Why is it outrageous, Scalia asked Nordyke, to say Perry cannot turn down normal, beneficial treatment solely to avoid execution? Nordyke said such treatment, because of its punitive aim, violates the Constitution's ban on cruel and unusual punishment, and that administering it against Perry's will violates his rights as well. ``There is a fundamental right bottomed on human dignity,'' Nordyke contended. He said no other state uses medication for punitive purposes. But Salomon said Perry's ``right to some sort of self-determination has been greatly diminished'' by his status as a convicted criminal. Perry was convicted of killing his parents and three other relatives in their Lake Arthur home in 1983. He was judged to be sane when he committed the crimes and mentally competent to stand trial. He lost his sanity while on the state's death row. Tradition and a 1986 Supreme Court decision bar states from executing anyone who is insane. When Justice Anthony M. Kennedy asked Nordyke whether it is against Perry's ``medical interests'' to forcibly inject him with such drugs, the inmate's lawyer answered, ``Ultimately, it will kill him.'' ``I was talking about his interests prior to execution,'' Kennedy said. Justice Thurgood Marshall, the only member of the court opposed to capital punishment under all circumstances, asked Salomon why state officials simply did not give Perry enough mind-altering drugs to kill him. ``It would be cheaper,'' Marshall suggested caustically.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Submarine Finds Second Half of United Jet's Cargo Door
DOC.TEXT: A submarine has retrieved the top half of the cargo door that ripped away from a United Airlines jetliner last year, sweeping nine people to their deaths, a Navy spokeswoman said Tuesday. The discovery ends a needle-in-a-haystack search of the Pacific Ocean floor. The Sea Cliff submarine recovered the bottom half of the door last week. The Sea Cliff located and recovered the top half Monday evening from 14,100 feet of water 90 miles south of Honolulu, lifting the wreckage to the surface with its hydraulic jaws, said Pacific Fleet spokeswoman Sandy Stairs. Stairs did not know how far the door's top half was found from the bottom half. The three-man Navy mini-sub and its support ship were expected to return to Pearl Harbor on Tuesday. The door will be turned over to the National Transportation Safety Board, which wants to know why it tore away from United Flight 811 shortly after takeoff from Honolulu International Airport on Feb. 24. The Boeing 747 carried 355 passengers and was bound for New Zealand. Shortly after takeoff, the cargo door opened at 22,000 feet, sweeping nine passengers from the plane. The crew managed to return the disabled jet to Honolulu. After investigators examine the recovered debris, parts of it will be sent to the Boeing Co. in Seattle for a more detailed review under board direction, NTSB officials said. A preliminary examination of the door's lower half showed the door had fractured lengthwise near the midspan latch. The eight sectors of the latch lock were all in the locked position and were deformed. The NTSB determined that faulty design of a locking mechanism probably caused a cockpit light to falsely indicate the door was locked, but wants to examine the door to confirm its findings. The agency blamed United, Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration for failing to corect problems with the door. It asked the Navy to find the cargo door in hopes that examination could lead to better aviation safety rules.

DOC.HEAD: Trade School Officials Seek Budget Alternatives
With AM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Trade school officials, upset by budget cut proposals that would eliminate many of their institutions from the student loan program, began to search Tuesday for other ways to save money. The $500 billion deficit-reduction agreement between the White House and congressional leaders calls for cutting $2 billion from the student loan program, mainly by reducing loan defaults. ``I'm pleased with the approach they took - assigning the savings over the next five years,'' said Dallas Martin, president of the National Association for Student Financial Aid Administrators. ``It certainly is a much more manageable and realistic way to approach the problem.'' The total of student loan defaults is $7.8 billion. To trim $2 billion, the budget negotiators would eliminate from the student loan program correspondence or home study programs and schools with default rates of 30 percent or more. Eligible students would be required to have a high school diploma or the equivalent, and credit checks on students aged 21 or older would be required as a condition of a loan, the negotiators proposed. ``There clearly is going to be more scrutiny applied to'' the student loan program, Martin said of the recommendations. ``There certainly are going to be needy students who are not going to be able to get loans. It's just going to require everyone to tighten up a little bit.'' Officials of the National Home Study Council and the National Association of Trade and Technical Schools have been working on alternative budget-cutting strategies. The trade school association plans to send a ``reform package'' to Capitol Hill on Wednesday that will help reach the dollar goals ``with minimum damage being done to students,'' said President Stephen Blair. ``The guaranteed student loan program was established to make sure people who are unable to get bank loans still can get a loan,'' said Blair. He said about half of the 650,000 students attending the association's 13,000 trade and technical schools are over age 21. The Education Department last month called for close scrutiny of 60 schools with high loan default rates - ranging from 20.4 percent to 81.5 percent. Blair said the ``reform'' proposal will focus on improved student admission testing, stronger refund requirements and delayed disbursements of student loans. The National Home Study Council sent a letter to the Office of Management and Budget on Tuesday, saying that eliminating home study schools from the student loan program ``would not result in any significant default savings in the coming years.'' The council's four-point plan includes requiring that 15 percent of a school's students not use the federal aid program and not granting financial aid that exceeds the tuition amount.

DOC.HEAD: Allison Atlas Stable After Transplant Complications
DOC.TEXT: A leukemia patient whose quest for a bone-marrow donor found perfect matches for 10 people but none for herself is having complications from a transplant from her mother. Allison Atlas was in stable condition and improving Tuesday, and could be released in two to three weeks, said Susan Edmonds, a spokeswoman for the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center. The 20-year-old native of Bethesda, Md. received a bone marrow transplant from her mother in August. She was readmitted to the hospital Sept. 18 after suffering a negative reaction, including skin rash, nausea and vomiting, Ms. Edmonds said. The complications did not mean she was rejecting the marrow, Ms. Edmonds said. Before the transplant, donors were sought throughout the United States and Israel for the former New York University student. A group called Friends of Allison Atlas obtained 50,000 blood samples. None was a perfect match for Miss Atlas, but for 10 other patients they were. In the absence of a transplant, the condition is fatal.

DOC.HEAD: Rwandese Refugees in Uganda Attack Their Homeland
DOC.TEXT: Rwandese refugees, some who have lived in Uganda for over a half-century, crossed into their homeland and attacked several villages, state Radio Uganda said Tuesday. The radio mentioned no casualties in the raid Sunday by armed civilians and uniformed gunmen serving in Uganda's National Resistance Army. Haji Moses Kigongo, the vice chairman of the ruling National Resistance Movement, condemned the raid in a statement and denied Uganda knew of it in advance. Kigongo said Ugandan authorities had repeatedly asked Rwanda to repatriate the refugees, pointing out inherent dangers in the continued permament exile of thousands of them in Uganda. Ugandan officials say there are about 87,000 Rwandese refugees camped near Rwanda's border in southwestern Uganda. Other refugees have moved elsewhere in Uganda and some occupy senior positions in President Yoweri Museveni's government, especially the army. Kigongo said Rwanda's government had pointed out the problems involved in resettling the refugees in the tiny and crowded central Africa nation. Rwanda is among the world's most densely populated countries with an average of 566 people per square mile. Justice Bahunga, a Rwandese diplomat in Kampala, said it was unfortunate the raid occured when the two government were seeking a solution to the refugees' continued stay in Uganda. ``In fact, we had wanted to know how many wanted to stay here or to go back to Rwanda, but these people could not wait for the outcome,'' Bahunga said. The refugees are remnants of Rwandese who fled communnal fighting in their homeland late 1950s and early '60s.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Money Launderer Gets 12-Year Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian convicted of funneling cocaine profits into a $32 million global money laundering case was sentenced Tuesday to more than 12 years in prison. Gonzalo Mora Jr. was considered a key player in a complex ring involving the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and six men associated with it. One was Manuel Noriega's one-time personal banker. ``Everybody had a role to play,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Jackowski. ``Mr. Mora's role was to secure the funds to be laundered - he controlled the pickups of cash.'' Mora, who pleaded guilty in January to money laundering conspiracy and 33 specific money laundering acts, was sentenced to 12 years and seven months in prison to be followed by three years probation. ``For stupid errors I have committed, I see myself separated from my home and my family,'' a teary-eyed Mora told the judge. ``I ask for your mercy and leniency.'' U.S. District Judge William Terrell Hodges said he would credit Mora for the two years he has already spent behind bars. Although Mora also pleaded guilty to drug trafficking, which carries a possible life sentence, the judge agreed to dismiss that charge as he did with the other defendants since there was little evidence to support it. Prosecutors portrayed Mora as a launderer with ties to the Medellin cartel who organized pickups of cocaine profits from the streets of U.S. cities and funneled them from smugglers to undercover agents posing as high-stakes launderers. Mora, 35, and the other defendants were accused of scheming to use fake corporations and complex wire transfers to launder $14 million. During the two-year investigation, the government said some $32 million in drug profits was processed. Defense attorney Joel Rosenthal argued that Mora was nothing more than a ``small-time, journeyman money washer'' used as a pawn in the government's undercover operation. ``Government agents sought him out, took advantage of him and set him up in this scheme,'' Rosenthal said, adding that other defendants in the case heaped their wrongdoing on Mora. A six-month trial ended in July, with five former BCCI bankers and a Colombian businessman convicted of conspiracy and various money laundering charges. Among the defendants was Amjad Awan, Miami-based assistant director of BCCI's Latin American division, who once told a U.S. Senate committee that he was Noriega's personal banker and controlled some $25 million the fallen Panamanian leader kept at BCCI banks. When sentenced Nov. 30, Awan and the others face between 10 and 30 years in prison under federal sentencing guidelines. Before the trial began in January, two divisions of the Luxembourg-based BCCI pleaded guilty to participating in the money laundering conspiracy and agreed to the biggest penalty ever slapped against a bank. BCCI, one of the world's largest financial institutions with 72 offices worldwide, forfeited $14 million it was accused of helping to launder plus another $1 million in interest. In addition to the hefty fine, BCCI was put on five years probation under the Federal Reserve System and agreed to open the books to prosecutors investigating Noriega.

DOC.HEAD: Snipers Fire on Area of Demonstration Massacre in Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Snipers fired at pedestrians Tuesday as church bells tolled along the Death River for at least 30 supporters of rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun who were killed during a candlelight march. Aoun and rival Christian warlord Samir Geagea blamed each other for the sniper attacks and the slaying Monday of demonstrators protesting a government blockade keeping food and other supplies from entering Aoun-held territory. Aoun said Geagea and his Lebanese Forces militia were responsible for the ``horrific massacre,'' and said President Elias Hrawi's government was ``equally responsible.'' Geagea, however, accused Aoun of engineering the bloodbath among his own supporters to win international sympathy. At least 22 of those killed were shot and some others were trampled to death by frightened crowds, said a police spokesman who requested anonymity. At least 100 people were wounded in the gunfire. Snipers, firing at pedestrians in the same spot of Monday's carnage, killed at least one civilian and wounded four, police reported. Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente issued a radio appeal to Aoun and Hrawi for a temporary truce pending a Vatican effort to negotiate a compromise. ``I ask for a 48-hour respite to be able to meet the president and the general to mediate an accord, which might not be ideal but will probably halt this deadly, destructive madness,'' Puente said. Following Puente's plea, Aoun proposed forming a national unity government to ``hold free general elections, disband all militias and normalize conditions in Lebanon.'' ``We give the papal nuncio the 48 hours he requested. ... Our doors are open. Let him come forth and do what he wants,'' Aoun said. There was no direct response from Hrawi. But a statement issued by his Cabinet said the government ``remains determined to pursue efforts to smother Gen. Aoun's mutiny.'' Hrawi, Aoun and Geagea are Maronite Catholics, which has allegiance to the Vatican and has dominated power in Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. The shootings on the demonstrators occurred on a highway bridge spanning Nahr Al-Maut, or Death River, five miles north of Beirut. About 5,000 Aoun supporters gathered to protest Hrawi's weeklong blockade of gateways into Aoun's enclave, home for 150,000 Chrisians. The government troops hope to pressure Aoun and his 15,000 mainly Christian soldiers into surrender. In a radio address to the army, Aoun appealed for an uprising to overthrow Hrawi's government. ``They call us mutineers. You and I pride ourselves for rebelling against a government that starves its own people and squanders state wealth,'' Aoun said in the 10-minute speech. Aoun and Geagea fought a four-month war this year for mastery of the Christian enclave that covers 310 square miles orth of Beirut. By police count, 1,046 people were killed and 2,799 wounded in that confronation that left Aoun and his troops trapped in parts of east Beirut and the adjoining Metn mountains with no air or sea outlets. Geagea's 6,000-strong militia, which gained control of more than 80 percent of the Christian area, has joined with Hrawi, elected president by Parliament Nov. 24. Aoun has rejected Hrawi's presidency. Syria has 40,000 troops controlling 70 percent of Lebanon under a 1976 mandate from the Arab League to end the Moslem-Christian civil war, now in its 16th year.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov to Defend Title Against His Nemesis
LaserPhoto NY17
DOC.TEXT: A long-festering feud between the world's two best chess players, both from the Soviet Union, has erupted on American soil. There's more at stake than pride and $3 million in prizes. Garri Kasparov, 27, ended Anatoly Karpov's 10-year world chess reign in 1985. On Monday, Karpov, 39, will try to wrest it back as the two meet for the first time in three years. They warmed up for the battle at a news conference Tuesday, exchanging verbal jabs over the politics of chess and their nation. Kasparov, founder of a democratic political party, said he will play under the flag of the Russian Republic - not the Soviet Union. Karpov often has been quoted as saying: ``I have two loves: communism and chess.'' ``Karpov represents the power authorities,'' Kasparov said in an interview published Monday. ``He was Brezhnev's boy when Brezhnev was in power and now is Gorbachev's boy when Gorbachev is in power.'' ``I am indifferent ... under which flag he wants to play,'' Karpov replied Tuesday, insisting that his beliefs are independent of any party or leader. ``Probably somebody will try to make politics of this. I came here to play chess.'' Years ago, a chess analyst likened Kasparov's agile, bold demeanor to the dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov, and Karpov's methodical, rigid style to former Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev. ``Normally, chess is a battle between two individuals: a brutal, intellectual battle,'' Kasparov said. ``But in my case, with Karpov, it's a fight between two different mentalities in Russia. I identify him with the system I've been fighting.'' The two are as different in personality as they are in political leanings. Kasparov, who beat ``Deep Thought,'' a chess-playing computer, in New York last January, is talkative, flamboyant and fluent in English - a media darling who tirelessly publicizes chess. Karpov often is portrayed as a colorless introvert who tunes out the audience while playing with surgical precision. But on Tuesday, he fluctuated between shy and outgoing. He even hammed it up once, presenting a copy of his book to Kasparov. ``I consider for this match, the situation is very ...'' Karpov said through an interpreter, who couldn't think of the right word in English to finish his sentence. ``Unusual!'' Karpov interjected in English, prompting laughter and applause. Kasparov won the world championship in 1985 and defended it against Karpov in 1986. In 1987, their championship match ended in a tie; under the rules, Kasparov retained his title. The latest match will comprise 12 games in New York and 12 games in Lyon, France, the latter beginning Nov. 24. The winner will receive $1.7 million and the loser $1.3 million. Kasparov said his earnings will fund ``my private interests and the political interests of the world.'' Karpov said he will help victims of the Chernobyl nuclear plant fire and promote chess in schools. Despite his outer confidence, Kasparov conceded that he's nervous. ``It's like a new mountain,'' he said. ``You have to climb this mountain. You presume you will win. If you lose, it's very painful.'' He equates chess with creativity, decisiveness and even athletic ability. ``I can analyze a situation and find a solution with a minimum of information,'' he said. ``I think I have a strong will to fight. Very often, you're dealing with your intuition.'' Kasparov, a prolific author, also plays soccer and tennis, swims, bicycles and jogs. Karpov favors billiards, cards and brisk walks. ``I believe it's my brain's rest if I do something else apart from chess,'' said Kasparov. Now, back to the juicy stuff. It's written, often, that they despise each other. How, they're asked, do they REALLY feel? Long pause. Nervous smiles. ``They need an answer, or what?'' replied Karpov. ``Do the Yankees like the Red Sox?'' offered Kasparov.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets: Iraqis Slow in Processing Exit Visas for Soviet Workers
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi authorities have slowed processing of exit visas for some of the 5,000 Soviet workers caught there, including 870 oil workers and 372 builders of a thermal power station near Baghdad, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Tuesday. Spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh told a regular news briefing that Iraq has promised to let all the Soviets leave, but an increasing number have ``asked to accelerate their return.'' Gremitskikh said 2,617 Soviets, mainly women and children, have been evacuated since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, but 5,174 remain. That includes about 150 military experts training Iraqi soldiers how to use and maintain Soviet-built weapons. ``Regrettably, the Iraqi authorities clearly show tardiness in considering the documents submitted by the Soviet side to issue an exit permit for several groups of specialists,'' Gremitskikh said. He said Iraqi authorities have been withholding for one week exit visas for 870 oilmen working in southern Iraq and 372 workers at the Yusifia thermal power station near the capital city. ``It is a genuine concern,'' he said. ``More and more specialists demand that they be evacuated.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Sen. Hugh Scott Honored For 90th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Former Senate Republican leader Hugh Scott returned to the Capitol Tuesday as he approaches his 90th birthday to be honored by senators in a reception room that bears his name. Scott, who represented Pennsylvania in the Senate for 18 years, was given a plaque, a birthday cake and a book on Chinese art. An art collector, he has written a book on art in the Tang Dynasty. ``There's Sen. Scott, in the middle again,'' said Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., as Scott's wheelchair was encircled by Republican Leader Robert Dole, R-Kan., and by Sens. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., Paul Simon, D-Ill., and John Danforth, R-Mo. Scott turns 90 on Nov. 11, but his former colleagues are celebrating now because the Senate will be in recess on that date. Scott was presented a framed, Senate-passed resolution extending the chamber's ``best wishes.'' Then, a dozen senators sang ``Happy Birthday'' and several shouted ``hip, hip hooray!'' On the wall was a portrait of Scott with his trademark pipe and walrus-like mustache.

DOC.HEAD: Flood Threat For Southern Plains; Strong Winds Buffet North-Central Plains
DOC.TEXT: Showers were scattered over the Southwest and much of the Plains on Tuesday, and strong winds buffeted parts of Montana and Wyoming. In Texas, flooding on the Rio Grande River closed Highway 170 between Lajitas and Presidio. Normally dry Cibolo Creek measured 4 feet deep at Shafter, near Presidio. Flash-flood watches were posted over southeast New Mexico and southwest Texas west of the Pecos River after heavy rainfall, and more downpours were predicted. Showers dampened western Texas, western Oklahoma, eastern New Mexico, eastern Colorado, the Nebraska Panhandle, parts of Wyoming and Montana, southeast Utah, southwest Colorado and central Arizona. Rainshowers were fell in central and northern New England and southern Florida. Strong, gusty winds rolled across the northern half of the Rockies on Tuesday afternoon. Wind gusted to 44 mph at Lewistown, Mont., and to 40 mph at Billings and Livington, Mont., as well as Watertown, S.D. and Rawlins, Wyo. Tuesday's low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 29 at Hibbing, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 42 at Caribou, Maine, to 94 at both Beeville and Harlingen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Strikers Back to Classrooms
DOC.TEXT: A judge Tuesday ordered striking Temple University professors to return to their classrooms, saying their 29-day walkout threatened the nation's most precious commodity - education. Union leaders appealed the ruling to state Commonwealth Court. Common Pleas Judge Samuel Lehrer said the strike by members of the Temple Association of University Professionals damaged the education of some 29,000 students and also harmed the public. The walkout began Sept. 4, the first day of classes. ``Education is vital to the health, safety and welfare of this nation and this community,'' said Lehrer, who ordered the faculty to return Wednesday. Temple had threatened to cancel 1,900 of its 4,700 classes that haven't met since the strike began, leaving 6,000 students without any classes and 23,000 others minus one or more classes. Union officials estimated that about 600 members joined the strike. The union, which represents 1,100 teachers, librarians and other academic professionals, were meeting Tuesday afternoon to decide whether to defy the order. ``The strike is going to continue until our members decide to end it,'' the association's president, Arthur Hochner, said before the meeting. Lehrer ordered the union officers, defendants in the lawsuit filed by the university, ``to make no statements or encourage any person to violate this order.'' The judge said his decision was ``a tremendous responsibility'' but necessary ``in promoting, safeguarding and nurturing our most precious commodity - education.'' Temple lawyer John Langel said he was ``pleased with the judge's decision but dispeased they'd rather appeal than negotiate.'' Lehrer also ordered both sides to resume negotiations. The university has told striking teachers that they will not be paid for the fall semester if they do not return to work. It also had planned to cancel those classes Tuesday. The cancellation was delayed a day, by the judge's order, so strikers could obey the injunction. About 1,500 of the private university's students have withdrawn because of the strike. There have been student rallies and sit-ins on campus. The union on Sunday rejected the university's latest offer, which included a 5 percent salary hike in a four-year contract. It also would have required members to contribute $260 a year toward health insurance. The professors, whose salaries average about $45,500, want 7 percent raises and do not want to pay for health care. Temple put its last offer into effect for those on the job, prompting the union to file an unfair labor practice with the state labor board.

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Gubernatorial Candidates Trade Barbs
DOC.TEXT: Republican John G. Rowland called Lowell Weicker a ``hypocrite'' during a heated debate in the Connecticut governor's race. At one point Monday night, Rowland handed Weicker an empty soda can, representing Weicker's proposal to have the state seize unredeemed can and bottle deposits, which Weicker estimates at $20 million. They would underwrite bonds to pay for clean-water projects. But with the state facing a deficit approaching $400 million ``you only need 8 billion more cans to get rid of ... the deficit,'' said Rowland. Weicker glared at him. Connecticut Party contender Weicker criticized Rowland and Democrat Bruce Morrison because the two congressmen missed votes on the floor of the U.S. House on Sunday night. Only 10 of the 435 congressmen missed the vote on a budget resolution and money for American troops in the Middle East. Rowland acted shocked that Weicker would criticize him and Morrison for missing votes, noting that Weicker, a millionaire, missed hundreds of votes as a U.S. senator, sometimes while ``crisscrossing the country collecting honoraria.'' ``You're the biggest hypocrite in the entire United States Senate,'' Rowland said. Morrison tried to capitalize on Rowland's youth - his colleague is 33 - and said Connecticut wasn't ready for ``a governor who's 10 years younger than Dan Quayle.''
DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Hunt Leading Hubbert; Demos Ahead in All Other Races
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Guy Hunt leads Democratic challenger Paul Hubbert by 13 percentage points, according to a new poll. Hunt has 52 percent of the vote to Hubbert's 39 percent, says the poll, conducted Sept. 23-26 and commissioned by The Anniston Star. Another 9 percent of those responding said they were undecided. But Hunt's support does not appear to be helping other GOP candidates. In six other races - U.S. Senate, attorney general, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state auditor and agriculture commissioner - Democrats led Republicans. Mason-Dixon Opinion Research Inc., of Columbia, Md., based its results on telephone interviews with 811 randomly selected residents who said they plan to vote in the general election Nov. 6. The poll had a margin of error of 3.5 percent.
DOC.HEAD: $80,000 in Wirth Contributions Came From Cable TV
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Tim Wirth has received at least $80,000 in campaign contributions since 1987 from cable television interests, according to a report published Tuesday. The Colorado Democrat last week derailed a bill opposed by the cable industry. Telecommunications Inc. of Denver, the nation's largest cable company, its executives and the company's political action committee gave Wirth $12,300, the Rocky Mountain News said. During the 1986 Senate race, when Wirth faced Republican Ken Kramer, TCI pumped $25,000 into the Colorado Democratic Party. All Democratic candidates, including Wirth, benefited. Wirth has denied the contributions had any influence on his actions last week regarding the cable industry. ``I get contributions from the ski industry, and I defend them too,'' Wirth said. ``I get contributions from teachers and I am supportive of education. I am supportive of environmental issues and environmentalists helped get me elected, he said.
DOC.HEAD: New Group To Try To Buff Image Of Liberal Democrats
DOC.TEXT: Ohio Sen. Howard Metzenbaum declared Tuesday that the Democratic Party has strayed from its roots and launched an organization to promote liberal values. ``No longer are we going to sit by and watch our party by steered toward a more conservative and less confrontational path,'' said Metzenbaum, president of the new Coalition for Democratic Values. ``We will have an impact. We will make our voice heard,'' he told a news conference. Metzenbaum said the issues initially targeted are tax fairness, health care for American workers, campaign finance reform and defense spending. The group intends to promote what it calls progressive ideals through newspaper, television and radio advertisements, as well as by distributing position papers. More than 50 members of Congress signed on as original members of the organization, as did former Democratic Party chair Paul Kirk and representatives of unions, business interests and other interest groups. The group's roster also includeda sprinkling of celebrities, including actress Joanne Woodward, actors Tony Randall and Walter Matthau and singer Harry Belafonte.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, Lithuanians Agree to Bilateral Economic Relations
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania and the Soviet Union agreed Tuesday to conduct their economic and trade relations for 1991 as equal partners, in a further stride toward independence for the Baltic republic. ``The first step has been taken, and it was a major step, and we did not lose our bearings,'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis told a news conference after the Kremlin meeting. The talks, headed on the Soviet side by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, were the first at such a high level since Lithuania suspended its March 11 declaration of independence following the Kremlin's economic embargo against the republic. A communique issued afterward also mentioned preparations for future ``negotiations.'' That is a significant concession by the Soviet side, because President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has maintained bilateral ``negotiations'' can occur only between two nations and not between the Kremlin and a republic. Asked whether the Kremlin has changed its view on independence for Lithuania and is now willing to negotiate, Landsbergis replied: ``We'd like to think it is so, yet further meetings will show if it really is so.'' On the Lithuanian side, the communique said the republic will discuss ``addressing the opinions of various groups of residents'' - a reference to the interests of the large Russian population of the Baltic republic who oppose independence. The Kremlin has alleged that Lithuania's Russian population has been the object of discrimination during the republic's independence drive. According to the communique, the delegations ``agreed that their further activities will be conducted according to bilateral trade and economic relations for the year 1991.'' Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene explained the agreement would mean ``closer economic cooperation'' with the Soviet Union, based on more of a partnership principle, rather than the previous practice of a republic's rigid subordination to the central government. The content of Lithuania's trade agreements with the Soviet Union will depend on what functions the other republics delegate to the central government, she said. ``This does not mean that the Lithuanian Republic will delegate any functions of the governing of its economy to the Soviet Union,'' she said. ``And it does not mean that Lithuania is going to sign the union treaty or be a part of the Soviet economy.'' The union treaty, which is still being negotiated, will define the relationship between the Kremlin and the republics. Gorbachev has proposed a loose confederation, with strong economic links, but republics such as the Baltics who are seeking independence say it does not go far enough. The agreement reached Tuesday would not affect any other bilateral pacts Lithuania has struck with any of the other 14 Soviet republics, she said. Mrs. Prunskiene said experts would soon begin work on Lithuania's economic cooperation with the Soviet Union in 1991 in matters of foreign economic trade, customs and tariffs, and other issues. Landsbergis, who led the republic's delegation, said that although the four-hour Kremlin meeting was ``100 times better than could be reflected in the communique,'' he did not foresee rapid political independence. ``Probably we'll have to cover a long path of other such meetings before we can commence official negotiations and sign an appropriate protocol,'' Landsbergis said. The agreement might not meet with universal approval in Lithuania, where sentiment is strong for complete independence, one Western diplomatic expert said. ``Moscow hopes it if it gets an agreement without territorial concessions, it will be to its advantage,'' said the diplomat, speaking on condition he not be further identified. But Mrs. Prunskiene and Landsbergis ``feel the negotiations convey legitimacy'' to the republic's independence declaration of March 11, he said. When Mrs. Prunskiene and Landsbergis report back to the pro-independence Lithuanian parliament, they can expect reaction divided into three camps, he said. The most sympathetic group of Lithuanian lawmakers ``believes in a step-by-step process,'' and that an agreement for bilateral economic cooperation ``is useful, and lends momentum for further negotiations.'' The middle camp believes in the necessity for a political agreement, but is generally sympathetic to the economic talks. The third group, the most radical, says ``don't negotiate at all. The Soviet Union is falling apart, and all we have to do is wait.'' Lithuania and the Soviet Union agreed to set up a working group headed by Soviet Deputy Prime Minister Vitaly Doguzhiyev and Lithuanian Deputy Prime Minister Romualdas Ozolas, who will draft proposals in two weeks to prepare for official negotiations, the communique said. The Soviet Union also agreed to increase pension payments to World War II veterans in Lithuania as of Oct. 1, he said. Commenting on the reunification of Germany and its meaning for the Baltic republics, which were annexed by the Soviet Union following a secret pact between Josef Stalin and Adolf Hitler, Landsbergis said: ``We hope that our independence, also the independence of Latvia and Estonia, would be the last steps of the Second World War.''

DOC.HEAD: Texans Have 20 Choices Besides Richards and Williams
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Daiell in 4th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A write-in candidate for Texas governor says widespread disappointment with this year's ballot inspired him to run on the slogan: ``A vote for me is a vote for none of the above.'' Tyler Pierson, owner of Tyler's Fine Dry Cleaners in Arlington, says he's trying to increase political participation in a year when many people don't want to vote for either major-party candidate. ``I guess the reason I'm running is the choices we have,'' Pierson said. ``Nine of 10 people just flat weren't going to vote (because of) the mudslinging and it being the costliest contest in U.S. history.'' Pierson's name and 18 others will be posted in the voting booth, not as part of the official ballot but close at hand for easy Election Day reference. On Nov. 6, Libertarian Jeff Daiell will join Democrat Ann Richards and Republican Clayton Williams on the ballot. Among the 19 write-in candidates are a former stripper, a street-corner flower vendor and a man who has hedged his bets by filing as a write-in for every office possible. The write-ins also include Jim Wright (not the former U.S. House speaker), ``Alamo'' Scott, three ministers, two lawyers, a cooking teacher and a grocery store manager. ``I think I'm going to beat out the other write-ins,'' predicted Bubbles Cash, a former stripper who owns a jewelry store. Her bumper stickers say, ``Texas needs Cash.'' Another write-in is Carl ``Crazy'' Hickerson-Bull, a 46-year-old flower vendor from Austin who wants to legalize marijuana. The perennial Austin City Council candidate has called for the construction of horseshoe pits for cab drivers waiting to pick up passengers at the airport. His fans drive beat-up vans with bumper stickers that say, ``I'm Crazy Too Carl.''

DOC.HEAD: West African Task Force Drives Back Liberian Rebels
DOC.TEXT: The five-nation West African army sent to enforce peace in Liberia attacked rebel forces led by Charles Taylor on Tuesday and forced them to retreat toward this capital city's eastern suburbs. The French news agency Agence France-Press quoted Taylor's rebels as saying their forces were pushed back nearly four miles and that the guerrilla army was threatened with encirclement. Task force soldiers advanced behind a barrage of heavy artillery, backed by government troops and by a rival rebel faction under Prince Johnson, who broke with Taylor last February. The force began the two-pronged offensive Monday night after Taylor's rebels attacked Johnson's fighters and lobbed rockets at remnants of slain President Samuel Doe's army holed up in his presidential mansion. The multinational army, joined by Doe's soldiers, forced the rebels back from strategic positions near the mansion, starting a retreat. To the north of besieged Monrovia, task force soldiers were led across swamps by Johnson rebels for an attack in which they seized Taylor's front line facing Monrovia port. The West African army has its headquarters in the port. Hundreds of civilians fled fighting that followed a weeklong cease-fire called by Taylor. The 5,000-member task force is the strongest in Monrovia, armed with fighter-bombers, tanks and armored cars. Johnson has pressed the force to take action, saying he would launch an all-out assault on the forces of Taylor and Doe unless it intervened. Similar threats led the task force to evacuate about 1,000 people from Doe's mansion after Johnson's men killed Doe on Sept. 10. The Economic Community of West African States sent soldiers from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Gambia and Sierra Leone to Monrovia on Aug. 24 to enforce a truce in the civil and tribal war, in which at least 5,000 civilians have been killed. Refugees said in Lagos, Nigeria, that rebels from both factions in Monrovia are merciless and seem to enjoy murdering civilians. They said people in the capital are dying of starvation, while others are slaughtered without reason. George Matey, 28, of Ghana, said: ``I have never seen human beings being killed as they are being killed in Liberia. They were just slashing people's throats and it was fun to them. All the streets were littered with bodies.'' Matey was among 7,000 hungry and penniless nationals of Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea and Liberia who arrived Monday from Monrovia aboard the Nigerian cargo ship River Majidun. An additional 10,000 refugees, mainly Ghanaians and Nigerians, left Monrovia by sea Monday, headed for Takoradi, in Ghana, and Lagos. Task force soldiers initially said their role ruled out taking the offensive, to the extent they did not fire a shot when Johnson captured and wounded Doe in a surprise attack on the West African force's headquarters. Johnson's men nightly watch a film of Doe's last tortured hours, the French newspaper Liberation reported Tuesday. Its Africa editor, Stephen Smith, wrote he was among guests invited to view ``scenes bristling with horror . . . blood clots from the torture; zoom shots of a face disfigured by fear, an anguished, gaping grin twisted onto a mouth murmuring pitiable calls for mercy.'' Many in the audience had seen the film before and called for the operator to hurry over ``boring episodes,'' Smith wrote. Doe died at about 3.30 a.m. on Sept. 10, and for two weeks his body was on display before it was taken to Johnson's headquarters, according to the film. ``My men threw it in a hole, back there, behind the house,'' Smith quoted Johnson as telling him. Johnson and Doe's officers support a West African plan to impose a cease-fire and install an interim government of non-combatants to organize fair elections in this West African nation of more than 1.7 million people. Taylor has opposed the transitional administration, and declared himself president. Nigerian Brig. Gen. Joshua Dogonyaro, the new task force commander, asked the United States to persuade Taylor to agree to talks, a task force statement said Tuesday. It said Dogonyaro made the appeal when he called on U.S. Ambassador Peter de Vos last Friday. De Vos told reporters Tuesday the United States was continuing its role of passing messages between the warring sides, but would not otherwise intervene.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Traffic Forces Postal Service to Try BART
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 4th to include time of BART trip
DOC.TEXT: Neither rain, nor sleet, nor hail should keep the postman from delivering the mail, and now not even traffic since the U.S. Postal Service started using the rail. Traffic is so congested along a portion of Interstate 880 that the Postal Service is moving its overnight Express Mail on the Bay Area Rapid Transit system. The mail was transported on BART from Fremont to the West Oakland mail-sorting center on a trial basis last month, said spokesman Dan DeMiglio. The 25-mile stretch of roadway takes 45 minutes to travel in typical commuter traffic and can take twice that on a bad day, according to the California Highway Patrol. The trip on BART averages 41 minutes. Although the Postal Service hadn't yet missed an overnight delivery, a quality control team started to worry that the heavy traffic would cause problems, DeMiglio said Tuesday. Several hundred pieces of mail are moved on BART each day. DeMiglio called the rail service ``an incredibly reliable system'' that helps reduce pollution. In addition, he said the postal worker who moves the mail is far less likely to be involved in an accident on BART.

DOC.HEAD: Uncle And Nephew Battle For House Seat
DOC.TEXT: State House Minority Leader William R. Strong is running against his uncle, but neither candidate is pulling any punches. ``I love him, but ... what am I supposed to do?'' Strong, a Republican, said of his Democratic opponent, Pearl Strong. The incumbent's radio advertisements portray Pearl Strong - a former state reresentative himself - as a tax-raising pawn of the Frankfort Democratic establishment. The elder Strong, 68, describes his nephew as a political careerist who has turned his back on the mountains and their needs. ``Uncle Pearl refuses to debate me on the issues,'' begins one William Strong ad. ``Maybe he's afraid, because he knows the people don't approve of his past record, which is why he lost the 1986 primary by nearly 500 votes.'' ``I'm sorry, `Little Bill,''' Pearl Strong responds in another ad. ``You have been debating for four years in Frankfort and the people in the 39th District have not seen anything yet.'' Pearl Strong said he decided to run because he thought his nephew was giving up the seat. The elder Strong - who served as state representative from 1985 to 1986 and state senator from 1968 to 1971 - said he thought it would be best to keep the seat in the family. But the younger Strong, 47, denies ever giving his uncle the impression that he would not run. The campaign has already driven a wedge between the two. Until this fall, the uncle used to stop by William Strong's insurance office in Hazard for a daily chat. Now, he mails his insurance payments from his home. William Strong says nasty things about his uncle in his ads, but when it comes to questions about their past, he turns into the teen-ager who used to play baseball with his uncle in the former coal camp of Darfork. ``Oh, God, yeah,'' said William Strong, reminiscing. ``That stuff was great. That has nothing to do with this race.'' What does, he said, is his opposition to tax increases - and his uncle's support of them. The elder Strong said his nephew's vote against the $1.3 billion school-reform tax increase cost the district several million dollars in state projects. Pearl Strong said his nephew's vote was in exchange for the Republican leadership's support of an eventual bid for lieutenant governor. William Strong denies any deal was made. But both men said that, after November, the election won't come between them, no matter who wins. ``When I played baseball, everybody in a different uniform was my enemy until the game was over,'' said Pearl Strong. ``Then we were friends.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Against Chic Nightclub Over Entry Policy Goes to Court
DOC.TEXT: It may be the revenge of the nerds, but four people suing a chic nightclub because they were allegedly denied admittance for not wearing trendy togs would prefer to think of it as justice for all. The four argued Tuesday in small claims court that they were rejected by a doorman at the Mayan, a former porno theater lately reopened as a club, in a manner that violated state civil rights law. They want damages of $250 apiece. ``I think we were met at the door by a flippant and arrogant doorman,'' plaintiff Jeff Stolzer told the court. ``They just looked you over like you were scum.'' Municipal Court Commissioner Diana Wheatley took the case under advisement and said she would issue a ruling later. Sammy Chao, president of the company that owns the Mayan, denied discrimination and asserted that doormen choose from the crowd at the entrance to keep out troublemakers. He denied there was a dress code. The plaintiffs claim the problem is that the decisions are arbitrary. If there had been a posted dress code, they argued, they would have been able to comply. The plaintiffs are Kenneth Lipton, 36, a personal injury lawyer specializing in dog bites; Tess Dubrall, 34, an accounting manager; Stephen Ambrosini, 33, an accountant; and Stolzer, 35, who runs a termite company. All waited in vain to get in the club when they tried to rendezvous there on May 19. The San Fernando Valley residents claim a violation of the Unruh Civil Rights Act, a state law passed in 1959 to end discrimination by businesses. The commissioner was mostly interested in the mechanics of the entry process, which was described as the doorman choosing from the crowd. ``The places I go you can just walk in,'' the commissioner remarked. ``Obviously this is a more popular spot.'' Chao said he hires doormen sensitive enough to ``see through a person'' and screen out people who are intoxicated, dangerous or appear to have a dangerous attitude. He said there was no discrimination on the basis of race or sex, but that the number of people who could get in was limited for safety. Additionally, room must be saved for private parties and people with reservations, he said. ``It's not Disneyland,'' he said. ``We have a limited time to provide the service .... If we run a first-come, first-serve we will soon be filled.'' He also said the club was in a bad area. ``It is not a particularly safe environment,'' he said. ``If a bum shows up you're not going to let him in.'' The owner of Vertigo, another club, came as an interested spectator. Jim Colachis' club is facing action by the state Alcoholic Beverage Control Department because its undercover officers were denied entry. The ABC has recommended a 30-day suspension of its liquor license. A hearing is pending. Colachis said his club never set out to be egalitarian, and if it was first-come, first-served, loyal customers would be treated unfairly. The state inspectors were not dressed properly, he said. ``It might have been nice for the beach, but I don't think it would be appropriate for President Reagan's home, or my establishment. I want to encourage anything but mediocrity,'' he said. ``Haven't we become casual enough in America?''

DOC.HEAD: Activists March at Ag Department
DOC.TEXT: A small group of animal rights demonstrators marched Tuesday in front of the Agriculture Department and several were arrested when they tried to force their way into the building. ``We'll take care of 'em,'' protest organizer Sandra Behm said about those taken into custody. ``We'll get 'em out.'' Members of the Farm Animal Reform Movement, or FARM, were criticizing the department's refusal to back legislation that would provide for more humane treatment of farm animals. About two dozen protesters had been marching on the sidewalk in front of the building when some ran toward the entrance, which was guarded by federal police. Five members of the group were taken into custody. Two were released but three were taken away to be charged with trespass, one officer said. The protesters were wrestled to the pavement and handcuffed. There were no visible injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Eighteen Arrested For Protesting Lack of Benefits For Women AIDS Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, Officials can, to CORRECT title of benefits to Supplemental Security Income
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen demonstrators were arrested Tuesday when they blocked traffic on a busy street to protest rules they say unfairly deny disability benefits to many women infected with the AIDS virus. The AIDS activists said the Social Security Administration, in determining eligibility for disability benefits, is ignoring many of the diseases and infections that are common in women infected with the virus. The result is that many women with disabling conditions including gynecological disorders like pelvic inflammatory disease and chronic vaginal infections are denied benefits, the protesters said. These disorders are not on a list of infections and diseases used by the Centers for Disease Control to define AIDS. Much of the list was compiled in the early days of the epidemic when most AIDS victims were white, middle-class, homosexual men. But this definition misses the ailments and conditions common to women infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, the activists said. ``It's time they stopped denying women'' said Phyllis Sharpe, 39, of New York, who marched in the demonstration led by the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, known as ACT UP. Sharpe, who is infected with HIV and suffers from diarrhea, shortness of breath and chronic vaginal infections, is also one of several plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed in New York Monday on behalf of people disabled by HIV but denied disability benefits. In addition to women, others with HIV - children, drug addicts and poor people - also have been unable to get benefits despite repeated hospitalizations for diseases not on CDC's list such as tuberculosis, heart infections and kidney failure, the lawsuit says. Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King said officials awarding disability benefits are not limited by the CDC definition of AIDS. Officials can award up to three months of Supplemental Security Income payments immediately upon request to people who have any of the AIDS-related conditions on CDC's list, pending a final decision on the claim, she said. But Social Security officials also ``can and do'' give this three-month presumptive disability status to people who are sick with HIV infection but have not progressed into AIDS, she said in a statement. ``We recognize our responsibility to continue to revise our procedures, seek broader flexibilit,, improve our guidelines and instructions to insure that we and the State Disability Determination Services eliminate all artificial barriers'' to assistance, King said. About 100 AIDS activists marched outside the Department of Health and Human Services headquarters building near Capitol Hill, chanting slogans such as ``How many women have to die, before you say they qualify,'' and ``Health care is a right, not just for the male and white.'' Police arrested 12 men and six women who blocked traffic on Independence Avenue and 3rd Street, near the U.S. Capitol. They were charged with demonstrating without a permit and obstructing traffic on Capitol grounds.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor's Response to Crime: 7,931 Cops
DOC.TEXT: The mayor proposed a $1.8 billion ``battle plan against fear'' Tuesday, asserting that his plan to confront street and subway crime with nearly 8,000 new police officers would reclaim the city from criminals. But footing the bill for the ``Safe Streets, Safe City'' program would mean a hike in property taxes, a payroll tax and a 25-cent surcharge on lottery tickets sold in the city, Mayor David Dinkins said. ``We will flood the streets with an army of police officers. ... Our war against fear will return peace to our communities, leaving us with safe streets, in a safe city,'' Dinkins said in a City Hall speech. The plan follows a summer of bad publicity and stinging criticism about the city's escalating violence. If approved, it would put the most officers on the force in the city's history. Among the more noteworthy cases were a number of children hit by stray bullets, the Zodiac gunman who apparently picked his victims by birthdates, repeated killings of cab drivers, the killing of a prosecutor near the Bronx courthouse and the fatal stabbing of a tourist who was defending his mother during a subway mugging. The proposal would need approval from the City Council and the state Legislature. In Albany, Republican opposition threatened the payroll tax part of the package, which would apply to out-of-town commuters who work in the city, as well as residents. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller said he had some doubts about the constitutionality of the proposed surcharge on lottery tickets. If given the legislative go-ahead, the plan would not kick in for at least another six months while potential new police officers were trained. And with the Police Academy operating at top volume, it would take 18 months to get the proposed 7,931 new officers walking a beat or riding a subway car. Key elements of the Dinkins proposal include 2,950 new jail beds at Rikers Island, $420 million for educational programs to prevent pupils from dropping out and turning to crime, assignment of a cop to every train at night, and a 54 percent increase in the number of police on patrol each day. ``Fear is the ugliest of emotions,'' Dinkins said. ``Unchecked, it may become the greatest criminal of all.'' The plan would mean more cops walking beats. Dinkins wants the hiring of 1,626 civilians to free officers from desk duty, elimination of certain units, and assignment of other agencies to certain emergencies, such as heart attacks. The plan calls for a property tax hike that would cost the average single family homeowner $20 more per year, and a payroll tax that would cost a taxpayer who earned $50,000 annually about $1 per week the first year and $1.50 the next.

DOC.HEAD: Nunez, a Leader of Nicaragua's Sandinistas, Dies in Cuba
DOC.TEXT: Former National Assembly speaker Carlos Nunez Tellez, who helped plot and direct the Sandinista revolution that overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza, died Tuesday in Havana of heart trouble. He was 39. Nunez was a senior leader of the opposition leftist Sandinista party. Party spokesman Dionisio Marenco said Nunez died of heart failure in the Cuban capital, where he went in January for radiation treatment of an undisclosed illness, said to have been leukemia. ``He had been ill for a long time,'' Marenco said, but declined to give details. Friends said Nunez, a tall, thin man, looked gaunt when he left for Cuba. Nunez gained fame as one of the nine Commanders of the Revolution of the Sandinista National Liberation Front, the masterminds who led the July 1979 overthrow of rightist President Somoza. The Somoza dynasty had ruled Nicaragua with an iron fist for 42 years. The dictatorship was overthrown after a year of fighting in which human rights groups said more than 42,000 people were killed. The nine became Commanders of the Revolution - an honorary, lifetime title -and formed the National Directorate, the party's top-echelon inner core. Born on July 26, 1951, to a humble family in the northern city of Leon, Nunez and his older brother Rene joined the underground Sandinista movement in 1969. Carlos Nunez was immediately placed in charge of the Sandinista political front in Leon. He was shifted to Managua, where he rose steadily through the ranks. He was ecretly sent out of the country to receive military and guerrilla training. He returned in June 1979 to direct Sandinista sabotage and agitation during the Battle of Managua that sealed the Somoza regime's fate. Nunez was on the Council of State, a temporary ruling body set up by the Sandinistas, and in 1984 was elected speaker of the National Assembly, Nicaragua's single-house legislature. He steered through most of the revolutionary legislation, including measures that gave Nicaragua greater literacy and an improved health care system. The Sandinistas lost in general elections last February to a 14-party coalition led by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. But Nunez and his wife Milu Vargas were re-elected deputies in the assembly. He leaves his wife and four children, two by an earlier marriage.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Concerned About Possible Heating Oil Shortages
DOC.TEXT: State energy officials and industry representatives were told Tuesday there are adequate supplies of heating oil for this winter, but some worried about possible shortages if there is a glitch in the system or increased tensions in the Mideast. ``We don't think there is going to be a supply problem this winter,'' Calvin Kemp, director of the Energy Information Administration, said at a conference on this winter's fuel outlook. But Kemp and other Energy Department officials cautioned that the supply picture could change if there are additional interruptions of crude oil supplies or a major problem at a refinery. ``We see very, very tight refinery capacity, which leaves you vulnerable if a refinery should go down for some reason,'' Kemp said. Kemp and industry experts said that the supply of propane continues to be precarious because of demands for the fuel from the petrochemical industry and supply problems that could develop during the winter. Lawrence Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, which sponsored the conference, also acknowledged the potential for heating oil supply problems. ``The sytem is in a very tenuous balance. We're betting that everything that can go right will go right,'' Goldstein said at a news conference. Many of the scores of participants in the forum, including state energy officials and heating oil retailers, expressed worry about what might happen if there are problems at refineries or if oil supplies are further disrupted because of a flareup in the Persian Gulf. ``We assume the system will work perfectly under the stress that it has been under and we're just worried about a stressed-out system not working,'' Charles Guinn of the New York Energy Office said during a break in the proceedings. George Sterzinger of the Vermont Energy Office said there is concern that if President Bush draws on the Strategic Petroleum Reserve some regions needing oil the most might not get it. Many of the state officials sought clarification from Energy Department officials on what the federal government might do to assure adequate supplies should a shooting war erupt in the Middle East. In a ``worst case'' scenario, said Julian Wright, deputy assistant secretary for energy emergencies, oil would be drawn from the petroleum reserve and both the federal government and states would be expected to impose ``very strong conservation measures.'' Wright did not elaborate on what measures might be needed, but he and other federal officials, as well as most industry representatives, rejected the possibility of either price controls or an allocation of supplies. Although crude oil prices have edged to within $40 a barrel in recent days, industry experts said that much higher prices can be expected if hostilities erupt in the Persian Gulf. ``If there's a shooting war, prices would go up substantially,'' said John Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. He said he would not be surprises at prices in the $60-a-barrel range and noted that some estimates have been as high as $100 a barrel. ``It would depend how long a war would last and if (Saudi) oil installations were damaged,'' said Lichtblau.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises German Unification
With AM-German, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday congratulated Germans on the historic unification of their country and said that ``45 years of conflict and confrontation between East and West are now behind us.'' ``At long last the day has come,'' Bush said. ``Germany is united. Germany is fully free.'' Bush issued a written statement just hours before the formal merger of East Germany with West Germany. He called his remarks a statement in celebration of German unification and addressed them to ``the people of the united Germany.'' Bush said the 4{ decades since World War II ``were a time of tension and turmoil'' for the world. ``For your nation, fate was particularly cruel,'' he said. ``For 45 years, at the heart of a divided continent stood a divided Germany. On the fault line of the East-West conflict, one people split between two worlds. ``No more,'' Bush said. ``Today begins a new chapter in the history of your nation. Forty-five years of conflict and confrontation between East and West are now behind us.'' Bush said the United States had been ``a steady partner in the quest for one Germany'' and shares common bonds. ``Even as Germany celebrates this new beginning,'' Bush said, ``there is no doubt that the future holds new challenges, new responsibilities. I'm certain that our two nations will meet these challenges, as we have in the past, united by a common love of freedom.'' He called the Berlin Wall ``the stark and searing symbol of conflict and Cold War. ... Today the wall lies in ruins. And our eyes open on a new world of hope. ``The last remnants of the wall remain, there at the heart of a free Berlin, a ragged monument in brick and barbed wire, proof that no wall is ever strong enough to strangle the human spirit; that no wall can ever crush a nation's soul.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Soldiers Shoot and Kill Three Palestinians in Riots
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers on Tuesday shot and killed a Palestinian youth as he fled arrest and troops fatally wounded two other Arabs during ensuing riots, Arab reports said. At the West Bank's Vatican-sponsored Bethlehem University, classes resumed, ending a nearly three-year closure by the army that had kept 1,600 students out of school. It was the second Arab campus shut during the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising that was permitted to reopen The violence broke out in the northern West Bank town of Jenin, as soldiers opened fire on a youth who tried to flee detention, Arab reports said. Troops later clamped a curfew on the town and nearby refugee camp, they added. The victim, Maher Akel, 21, was shot twice in the chest and died, Palestinian reports said. Akel had reportedly been wanted for escaping an army prison three months ago. News of Akel's death sparked rioting in the town, and soldiers opened fire to disperse stone-throwing protesters, killing two other youths, Arab reports said. One victim, 16-year-old Tawfik Rajee, was struck in the chest and died. The other, Omar Amer, 21, suffered a gunshot wound to the abdomen and died on the way to Rafidiyeh Hospital in Nablus, the reports added. The army confirmed Akel's death and the circumstances and said it was checking the other reports. The fatalities raised to 1,007 the number of Palestinian victims of the uprising against Israeli rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Of those, 735 have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians and 272 by fellow Palestinians on suspicion of cooperating with Israeli authorities. In the unrest, 52 Israelis and foreigners have been killed by Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Details Iraqi Killings om Kuwait, Torture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed until 8:01 p.m. EDT. Time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International in a report Wednesday said Iraqi troops in Kuwait have tortured and executed scores of people, some for refusing to display pictures of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``Iraqi forces have arrested not only people suspected of armed attacks against them but men, women and children found with opposition literature, the Kuwaiti flag or photographs of the Emir of Kuwait,'' the London-based human rights organization said. The report said troops have forced some doctors to sign false death certificates saying bullet-riddled corpses brought into hospitals died after admission. Amnesty said the report was based on information gathered by two representatives who interviewed witnesses and victims in Bahrain. ``Their testimony builds up a horrifying picture of widespread arrests, torture under interrogation, summary executions and mass extra judicial killings,'' Amnesty said. Since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion, possessing the Kuwaiti flag or a picture of the emir has been punishable by death, said Amnesty International. Other Kuwaitis have been arrested or killed for not putting up a picture of Saddam. Amnesty said detainees are being held in police stations, schools and other public buildings in Kuwait. ``Those who have been released say the Iraqi military and intelligence routinely torture detainees,'' the report said. Torture of victims included electric shocks, prolonged beatings, broken limbs and threats of sexual assault. Some victims had their hair plucked out with pincers or their finger and toe nails pulled out, the group reported. It said doctors who worked in Kuwait hospitals at the time of the invasion told Amnesty investigators that Iraqi soldiers brought in ``scores'' of bodies of young men who had been shot at close range. Doctors were forced to issue certificates saying the young men died after admission to hospital, the report said. Iraqi troops carried out executions at Kuwait University, said the report. ``We cannot even publish more details on former torture victims in case they or their families are identified and suffer further reprisals,'' said Amnesty.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Fails To Assure Disinfectants Kill Germs As Claimed, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency fails to monitor the effectiveness of disinfectants and up to 20 percent of the products sold to kill disease-causing germs may not work, a government study says. In a report released to Congress on Tuesday, the General Accounting Office said the EPA has not inspected the majority of laboratories that test disinfectants and that the agency ``lacks assurance'' methods to prove the germ-killers are valid. ``EPA's policy of `let the buyer beware' for disinfectants may be compromising public health and wasting consumer dollars,'' the GAO's Richard L. Hembra said in a statement released with the report. The GAO report said estimates by the EPA's own experts are that an estimated 20 percent of all disinfectants fail to kill germs or viruses as they are supposed to, and that tests in some states show that more than 40 percent of the compounds are ineffective. Americans spend about $1 billion a year on disinfectants to kill disease-killing germs, sterilize food preparation areas, surgical tools and bathrooms and prevent infectious disease. There are about 4,100 such products registered by the government. The EPA is directed by law to register disinfectants and to assure that they are effective. But the GAO said the agency depends on test data submitted by manufacturers and that the EPA ``lacks assurance that the test methods and performance standards used... are valid.'' The report said it found the EPA had inspected only a small percentage of the labs that test disinfectants and ``in fact...was aware of only 12 of the 92 labs that had performed these studies.'' After labs have been inspected, the study said, it takes the EPA from five months to more than 2{ years to process the reports. Even the methods of conducting disinfectant tests, the report said, are uncertain. ``Almost all of the EPA-recommended efficacy test methods and performance standards have been embroiled in scientific controversy for over a decade,'' the report said. The agency has done little to resolve these uncertainties and it ``inadequately managed'' a $384,000 study of the issue at the University of North Carolina. Anne Lindsay, te EPA official who supervises the disinfectant registration, said her agency has monitored labs that do about 40 percent of the testing. She also said the agency is developing a ``re-enforcement strategy'' to assure that manufacturers accurately report test data. The GAO report said that from 1977 to 1982, the EPA's own lab found that 42 percent of all disinfectant samples failed efficacy tests. In 1982 the agency closed its lab and since then the EPA has depended on industry self-testing. Lindsay said only one manufacturer has reported a batch of disinfectant that failed to pass the tests. She said the EPA ``generally agreed'' with the issues raised in the GAO report and is attempting to improve the system.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Honors Math, Science Teachers
DOC.TEXT: President Bush urged top math and science teachers Tuesday to ``take children, lift them up, inspire them, broaden their horizons and aim them'' toward careers as scientists and engineers. ``You discovered how to bring out the fun in science,'' Bush told 107 elementary teachers who gathered in the Rose Garden after receiving Presidential Awards for Excellence in Science and Mathematics Teaching. ``You provide a model and an inspiration for elementary teachers everywhere.'' ``You're also helping to meet a crucial national need,'' said Bush, noting that three of the national education goals involve boosting student achievement in math and science by the year 2000. Statistics show that by 1995, eight of the 10 fastest growing professions will be based on science. Skills in mathematics and a college education will be needed for a majority of the 21 million new jobs created by the U.S. economy by the year 2000, says the National Research Council. By the year 2010, U.S. industry will face a shortage of 560,000 scientists and engineers, other statistics show. ``For many students you represent their very first exposure to science and math, which gives you a vital responsibility,'' Bush continued. ``Most kids who go on to become scientists or engineers first became interested in those subjects in elementary school or junior high. Most often the reason they do is because they become exposed to a teacher like you.'' ``You are able to take children and lift them up, inspire them and broaden their horizons and aim them ...,'' he said. The presidential awards program, sponsored by the National Science Foundation and managed by the National Science Teachers Association, began eight years ago. Each teacher receives a $7,500 grant. Elementary teachers are included for the first time this year in the program. Middle and senior high school science and mathematics teachers will be honored in mid-October.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Claim Some Credit for German Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Gorbachev's statement, details. No pickup. ADDS byline
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union claimed some of the credit Tuesday for German unification and said it hopes the merger will bring prosperity, peace and stability to the former adversaries and Europe as a whole. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev said ``profound internal democratic changes'' in the Soviet Union and East Germany set the foundation for unification. At a news briefing, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said ``German unification took place, not in the least, as a result of many changes initiated largely by perestroika in the Soviet Union. The unification of Germany took place according to the aspirations of the German people, taking into consideration legitimate interests of other states.'' The Soviet Union initially balked at the idea of a united Germany being part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Gorbachev and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed this summer to eliminate nuclear missiles and weapons capable of carrying nuclear warheads from East Germany. West Germany also promised to arrange longterm financial aid to help rebuild the Soviet economy as well as generous payments to cover the withdrawal of Red Army troops in East Germany. The agreements paved the way for East and West Germany and the four victorious World War II Allies to sign a treaty in Moscow on Sept. 12 signifying there were no external obstacles to unification. In a message Tuesday to Kohl and President Richard von Weizsaecker, Gorbachev congratulated the leaders and the German people on unification, which he described as a ``great event,'' the Tass news agency reported. ``Unification could not have taken place if there had not been profound internal democratic changes in our countries, if the right conclusions from the tragedy of the most horrible war had not been reflected in real life,'' Tass quoted the message as saying. ``On this remarkable day, I want to pay tribute to all those in my country and in your country who, overcoming sorrows, remembering losses and honoring the dead, did not yield to prejudice and fears, but persistently worked for the future, making this peaceful and worthy solution of the `German issue' possible,'' it said. Foreign Minister Eduard A.
