Shevardnadze said the treaty provides adequate guarantees for Soviet security by limiting the size of Germany's army, forbidding offensive nuclear weapons on German soil, forfeiting any German claims to territory it lost during World War II, and banning any revival of Nazism. ``Thus an end has been put to the past and the ground has been laid for Germany's future,'' Gremitskikh said Tuesday. ``Let us hope that the German unification will be an integral part of European development.'' Gremitskikh said the Soviet Union and the united Germany will enter a new phase of relations ``which we are hopeful will bring to both peoples and to the entire community a prosperous peace, stability and well being.'' Tass noted some Soviets are wary of a united Germany, but it put that concern in a new light. ``There are quite a few people in the Soviet Union who feel bitterness about the loss of an ally, the GDR. But this is the choice of citizens of the GDR,'' Tass said. ``We believe that we are not losing our ally, but gaining a friend,'' the news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: St. Louis Encephalitis Outbreak Reported in Florida
By JACKIE HALLIFAX
DOC.TEXT: St. Louis encephalitis, a sometimes fatal viral infection spread by mosquitoes, has struck at least 26 people in Florida, the largest outbreak in the state since 1977, health officials said Tuesday. Tourists and residents were warned to wear long-sleeved shirts and pants or stay inside at dusk, when the mosquitoes are most likely to bite. Boy Scout troops have canceled overnight camping trips and schools are being sprayed with mosquito killer. Fifteen of those infected have been hospitalized and two are in comas, state health officials said Tuesday. ``It's not enough for people not to come to Florida for vacation, but when they come I want them to know they should follow precautions,'' said Dr. Diana Wells, assistant state epidemiologist. Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. St. Louis encephalitis, so named because it was identified there in 1933, is the most common type and belongs to a family of viruses known as arboviruses. Symptoms range from headaches and fevers to coma and death. Other symptoms include stiffness of the neck, irritability, extreme lethargy, tremors and seizures. The death rate is usually about 7 percent but no deaths have been reported with the latest outbreak, Wells said. Last month, the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta reported high levels of St. Louis encephalitis in Texas and Florida and high levels of Eastern equine encephalitis - a more deadly arbovirus - in Massachusetts, New York and New Jersey. Federal health officials reported 108 cases of various arboviral encephalitis last year. Eight people died during Florida's last severe outbreak in 1977, when 110 cases were reported. The last major outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis struck nearly 3,000 people 15 years ago, the CDC said. There are usually about three cases a year in Florida, said Ernie Dufree, a spokesman for the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. Since late July, 26 cases have been documented in central and southern Florida and preliminary blood tests show that another seven are infected, Wells said. About 35 more possible cases are being investigated, the CDC said. The youngest person to be afflicted is 14 and both of the comatose victims are over 55, Wells said, adding that older people are most likely to show symptoms. The state health department recommends that people stay inside for an hour before sunset and two or three hours afterward. If they do go outside, they should wear long pants and sleeves and use insect repellant, Wells said. Boy Scout troops in southern and central Florida have canceled overnight camping troops, some high school are playing football games during the day rather than at night and several schools have sprayed mosquito killer on campus. The Florida outbreak is expected to peak early this month and the mosquitoes will disappear when twilight temperatures fall into the 60s.

DOC.HEAD: Broadway Musical Version of `The Thin Man' Postponed
DOC.TEXT: ``Nick and Nora,'' a musical version of ``The Thin Man,'' has been postponed until next spring because the producers have not been able to completely finance the $5.6 million production. The musical, starring Barry Bostwick and Joanna Gleason as Dashiell Hammett's famous detective couple, was to have opened in February at the St. James Theater. It is one of the most highly touted musicals of the season, one of the few big American shows expected to compete with ``Miss Saigon,'' the British blockbuster. Rehearsals for the musical are now expected to begin on Jan. 2, 1991, in New York with an out-of-town engagement beginning Feb. 26 at the Mechanic Theater in Baltimore, a spokesman for producers James Pentecost and Charles Suisman said Tuesday. The show now will open at the St. James in New York on April 25 after three weeks of previews. ``Nick and Nora,'' which has a book by Arthur Laurents, music by Charles Strouse and lyrics by Richard Maltby Jr., has been in the works for more than five years. It has been plagued by money troubles. A last-minute backers audition, with Bostwick, Gleason and other cast members, was held Sept. 18 at the Dramatists Guild for potential investors. Variety quoted Pentecost and Susiman as saying they needed to raise some $2.5 million to make the musical's initial October rehearsal date. The audition was held, Variety said, because a three-performance workshop of the show in August didn't raise the required amount of capitalization from prospective backers. ``Nick and Nora'' was to have started a pre-Broadway tryout in Baltimore on Dec. 20 at the Mechanic Theater and run there through Jan. 19. The Mechanic will fill part of those dates with the touring company of ``M. Butterfly,'' said Hope Quackenbush, managing director of the Baltimore Center for the Performing Arts.

DOC.HEAD: Florida A&M Wins $350,000 Award From British Petroleum
DOC.TEXT: Florida's only historically black public university will get $350,000 from a subsidiary of British Petroleum Co., a company that does business in South Africa. Frederick Humphries, president of Florida A&M University, defended the gift Tuesday, saying the school was abiding by the same standards as other schools. Thirty schools applied for the grants, which will mostly go to provide scholarships for minority engineering students. Florida A&M was one of four schools that got the $350,000 grants. The other schools were Tuskegee University in Alabama, North Carolina A&T State University, two other historically black schools. The fourth school was Ohio State. Charles Taylor, a spokesman for Cleveland-based BP America Inc., said he saw no contradiction in his company making donations to encourage minority education in the United States while its parent company does business in South Africa. ``We have had a long interest in what transpires in South Africa,'' Taylor said from Cleveland. ``We share with all of the opponents of apartheid an abhorrence of that system and we have been aggressively opposing that system.'' ``I wish that all American companies would get out of South Africa,'' Humphries said. ``But some do and some don't.'' Humphries said London-headquartered BP Co. abides by the Sullivan Principles, a code of ethics established in 1977 by a Philadelphia minister who has now backed away from the guidelines as inadequate to dismantling apartheid. The Sullivan Principles called on companies operating in South Africa to, among other thingts, use fair employment practices and to train blacks and other nonwhites for management positions. ``The minimum is the Sullivan code and the maximum is I wish they were all out,'' Humphries said. In 1986, the U.S. Anti-Apartheid Act banned most new investment by American companies in South Africa and put more restrictions on certain industries, like computers. Since South Africa has no oil reserves, it is dependent on foreign companies for oil. In 1988, BP sales in South Africa were estimated at $90 million and its assets were estimated at $400 million, said Donna Katzin, director of South Africa programs for the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility in New York. Companies wholly owned by British Petroleum in South Africa employ some 5,000 workers. Companies in which BP has some interest employ 23,000 workers, Katzin said. ``I would say that BP is right up there at the top of the list with other oversea corporations that do substantial and strategic business in South Africa,'' Katzin said. British Petroleum supports education of blacks in South Africa and works to improve living conditions, Taylor said. ``Our position is simply that we believe that we can have more impact inside that system than a total withdrawal from it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Vote Against Souter
DOC.NOTE: EDs: The following information is also used in AM-Souter a0723
DOC.TEXT: Here are the senators who voted against the confirmation of David Souter to be a justice of the Supreme Court. All nine are Democrats. Souter was confirmed by a 90-9 vote of the Senate early Tuesday evening. Daniel Akaka of Hawaii, Brock Adams of Washington, Alan Cranston of California, Bill Bradley and Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, Quentin Burdick of North Dakota, John Kerry and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, and Barbara Mikulski of Maryland. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., did not vote.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
BERLIN: united Germany.
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl and other leaders stood in the glare of floodlights at the Reichstag building and joined in singing the national anthem. Millions of Germans and a watching world joined the ceremony by television. The ceremony marked return of a united Germany built on the ruins of Adolf itler's defeat in World War II and the end of Cold War antagonism that split Europe into competing blocs led by the United States and the Soviet Union. It came less than 11 months after the Berlin Wall was opened Nov. 9, 1989, by a tide of democracy that swept away Communist regimes across Eastern Europe. Pick up 15th pvs, `The unification...'

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Okays Treaty, Sends to Full Senate for Quick Action
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday unanimously approved the treaty ending the post-World War II division of Germany and sent it to the full Senate. The committee had hoped the Senate could act before the 7 p.m. EDT unification of West Germany and East Germany, but the Senate recessed for the evening without action. President Bush congratulated Germans on the historic unification of their country and said that ``45 years of conflict and confrontation between East and West are now behind us.'' ``At long last the day has come,'' Bush said in a written statement. ``Germany is united. Germany is fully free.'' The committee voted 19-0 in favor of the treaty, signed in Moscow last Sept. 12 by Britain, France, the Soviet Union, the United States and East and West Germany. After Senate approval, President Bush was to sign the treaty on Wednesday. Members of the committee said that, even though they voted for the treaty, they still had reservations about a united Germany. ``Nothing should stand in the way of the treaty, but these sentiments need to be said, and we will have to watch Germany,'' said Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., who was born in Berlin and fled Nazi Germany at age 2. Boschwitz noted Germany's involvement in wars and the Holocaust. ``Germany is Germany from the standpoint of its history, and I think we need to have some recognition of that fact,'' Boschwitz said. ``I have a mixed emotion about seeing it get back together again. Hopefully the feelings and mentality of the people have changed.'' Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., committee chairman, said he shared Boschwitz's thoughts. ``I agree with him that we should all keep our eye on how things progress in Germany,'' said Pell, whose father, former Rep. Herbert C. Pell, helped prepare for the Nazi war crimes trials in Nuremberg after World War II. The committee turned back an attempt by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., to amend the treaty uniting the two Germanys with a statement reaffirming U.S. rejection of the Soviet Union's annexation of the Baltic states. Committee members agreed, however, to submit a parallel resolution saying the same thing rather than trying to put it in the treaty and delaying its ratification. ``The State Department doesn't want this due to the fact that it might offend the Soviet Union, but I don't care about that,'' Helms said, pointing out that it simply reasserts a position held by the United States for 50 years. ``I don't think we ought to renege now,'' he said, adding that the Soviets have been touting the treaty as a confirmation of Soviet jurisdiction over the Baltic states of Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia. Pell said the administration fears the amendment might serve as an example to the Soviet Union to add its own language to the treaty. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., said he and other committee members had written the president on Friday expressing concern about any impact the treaty might have on the Baltic states. He said the president is expected during the signing ceremonies on Wednesday to say that nothing in the treaty alters the U.S. policy of rejecting the Soviet Union's annexations.

DOC.HEAD: The Dartmouth Review President Resigns Over Anti-Semitic Quote
DOC.TEXT: The president of The Dartmouth Review resigned Tuesday after the conservative off-campus weekly drew fire for quoting Hitler in its masthead on a Jewish holiday. ``I will not be a part of this newspaper anymore - I am not an anti-Semite,'' said C. Tyler White, who is also a student at Dartmouth College. The newspaper is not funded by the college. Student officials of the newspaper, which has previously been decried as sexist, racist and homophobic, said the quote was put in by an unknown staffer without the authorization or knowledge of editors. One called it ``sabotage.'' But White said the newspaper's official response failed to express the staff's regret or to assume responsibility for letting the quote be printed. ``The editor-in-chief has failed in his job, and now we all must wear the albatross of anti-Semitism because he won't take responsibility for the issue's contents,'' White said in a statement. He is the third of the weekly's 24 members to resign because of the incident. The edition distributed Saturday on Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement and Judaism's most solemn day, carried a quotation from Adolf Hitler's ``Mein Kampf.'' The passage inserted without attribution in The Review's masthead said: ``Therefore, I believe today that I am acting in the sense of the Almighty Creator: By warding off the Jews, I am fighting for the Lord's work.'' Cheers and congratulations greeted the resignations at the Student Assembly office, where students stacked petitions bearing more than 2,000 signatures and planned a protest rally Thursday. ``The main message we're trying to get across ... to the nation and the national media is that The Dartmouth Review in no way represents the campus,'' said Brian Ellner, president of the assembly, which represents 3,200 undergraduates. In a statement, Editor-in-chief Kevin Pritchett blamed the mess on a ``tasteless prankster.'' Pritchett has said staffers were investigating how the quote got into print. The Review attacked administrators, saying ``it is unfair and wrong to confuse our arguments with what is clearly a case of sabotage.'' College officials also condemned the weekly. President James Freedman and other top administrators were to speak at the rally. The newspaper, which has been published since 1980 with backing from some of the nation's most prominent conservatives, has been vilified over the years for its views on women, homosexuals and blacks. William Cole, a black music professor, resigned in August after The Review had belittled him in print for seven years. Cole said his effectiveness was compromised by the attacks. He filed a $600,000 libel suit against the newspaper that was later settled out of court for no money. Review staffers also were involved several years ago in a sledgehammer attack on shanties erected on campus as part of a protest against enforced segregation in South Africa. Several staffers were suspended.

DOC.HEAD: UNICEF Says Sudan Drought May Kill Million
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. Children's Fund official said Tuesday that advancing drought in Sudan could kill up to 1 million people, and donor countries have not responded to calls for help. ``I think we have the makings of a major humanitarian disaster, a bombshell disaster, that hasn't caught the attention of the world,'' Richard Reid, UNICEF's regional director for the Middle East and North Africa, said. He said 4 million to 5 million southern Sudanese are threatened by drought worse than that which killed more than 250,000 Sudanese in 1988. ``It is probable that unless there is focused and solid and rapid intervention, we could lose at least 250,000, and it could go up to the estimated 1 million that died in 1984,'' Reid warned. With UNICEF as the lead agency, Operation Lifeline Sudan saved more than 200,000 lives last year when drought gripped Sudan, a Red Sea nation with a population of more than 25 million. This year few donor countries have been offering help. UNICEF collected about $67 million for the 1989 relief campaign. ``This year we have received practically nothing, less than $5 million,'' Reid reported. ``Frankly, there is, up to now, on the part of everyone involved in addressing this humanitarian need, a hesitancy, a semiparalysis, a disarray, and a lack of focus. We certainly hope that will change.'' Diplomats said privately that distaste for the military junta of Lt.Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, which seized power from the elected government of Sadek el-Mahdi last year, is a major reason donations dried up. U.S. laws bar foreign aid to military juntas that oust elected governments. ``And so that assistance was lost,'' Reid said, ``and one by one, donors have fallen off. But we're faced with a situation that really shouldn't have political markings, and that is a situation in which the children are going to be the most affected.'' The major crop-growing areas have had no rain for more than two months, he said. The drought leaves vast areas of the country without food; people weakened by starvation lose their resistance to disease and die, particularly children under age of 5. ``A disease like measles can spread through a village like wildfire, and you have a mortality rate of up to 20 percent,'' the UNICEF official said. ``I remember that . . . just before we began Operation Lifeline Sudan, we would go into huge districts in which we couldn't find a trace of children under age 5. They had all died.'' A civil war between the Islamic government in Khartoum in the north and the Sudan People's Liberation Army in the mostly Christian and animist southern three provinces has cut off relief deliveries in half of Sudan. Reid said railroad engineers, barge boatmen, and truck drivers were afraid to carry grain shipments through the southern provinces without security guarantees that relief agencies can't provide. El-Bashir's takeover added to the bureaucratic problems because new officials were named in key ministries, such as transportation. El-Bashir announced a cease-fire with the SPLA through the end of the year so children can be vaccinated, but he said Tuesday no reply has come from the rebels. He is to meet Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Wednesday to discuss the situation. The Secretariat is the organizing agency this year for Operation Lifeline Sudan.

DOC.HEAD: Clashes Reported in Kiev During Nationalist Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Police on Tuesday clashed with nationalist demonstrators defying a ban on rallies in front of the Ukrainian Parliament in Kiev, according to press reports. One official predicted more violence unless the ban is lifted. Several people were injured in the third consecutive day of pro-secessionist rallies in Kiev, about 400 miles southwest of Moscow. It was first time any violence was reported. On Monday, the conservative majority in Parliament voted to uphold a decree prohibiting rallies in front of the building. Opposition members of the Parliament walked out following the decision. On Tuesday, hundreds of people gathered to urge the dissolution of Parliament and the Ukraine's secession from the Soviet Union, the official Tass news agency reported. Many in the crowd carried the nationalist blue-and-gold flags. Tass did not elaborate the clash, but the nationalist Rukh movement reported fights began after several dozen demonstrators tried to break through police barricades. ``Several old women were beaten,'' and one policeman also was injured, it said. Rukh blamed the violence on unidentified ``provocateurs,'' but it also quoted an unidentified nationalist sympathizer as saying, ``There was fault on both sides.'' Some members of Parliament demanded a commission be formed to investigate the violence outside, Tass reported. Deputy Pavlo Movchan was quoted as saying the decision to limit access to the square outside Parliament ``will only increase tensions and lead to further confrontation.'' On Monday, tens of thousands of Ukrainian nationalists marched and chanted slogans against the Communist Party and the republic's leaders. One-day warning strikes idled factories in the more radical western Ukraine, but many enterprises in Kiev and eastern parts of the republic did not close. The Ukraine is the second most populous of the Soviet republics, after Russia, and is an important grain-growing area. Its Parliament has declared sovereignty from Moscow and claims the right to overrule national law. Rukh and other nationalist groups want it to go further and take rapid moves toward secession.

DOC.HEAD: In `Little Berlin,' Germans Dance in Streets
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: People in this little farming village in the Thuringian forest - once divided by a concrete wall and a death strip of communist patrols and guard dogs - began ``dancing into unity'' late Tuesday on the eve of East Germany's demise. President Bush visited Moedlareuth's western section while vice president and dubbed the village ``little Berlin'' because of the dividing wall. The whole village of about a dozen homes and 60 people celebrated German unification smack in the center of the border that for 45 years kept them apart. More than 2,000 people from dozens of surrounding communities and even farther away jammed the narrow streets as Germans officially united Wednesday. Those from the eastern section of Moedlareuth reckoned they had every reason to celebrate. ``My cousins lived just 100 meters (330 feet) away, and I wasn't even allowed to wave to them from here,'' recalled Rudolf Richter, a 62-year-old farmer whose house overlooks the remains of the wall. Moedlareuth was divided from 1945 until November 1989. In 1952, border fortifications were installed. The mill was torn down to prevent its being used as a hiding place for would-be escapees to the West. Vehicle and pedestrian traffic between east and west Moedlareuth was halted. A concrete wall 2,160 feet long was added 1966, with an observation tower containing guards with shoot-to-kill-orders. Eastern residents were forbidden to wave to relatives on the western side. Two brothers who lived on opposite hillsides sometimes gazed at each other through binoculars, although that also was banned by the communists. Visits might be permitted once a year for elderly people, less for others. But not to eastern Moedlareuth, a forbidden zone for non-residents including East Germans. Contact was so controlled Moedlareuth residents had to ride three hours by train to visit relatives who lived within shouting distance. At least two people escaped into the West despite the border fortificaton. There is no record of anyone being shot trying to flee through Moedlareuth. On Tuesday night, laughter peeled through the night air, firecrackers popped and beer flowed. A rock band was brought in for the festival, which was called ``dancing into unity.'' Many celebrants gazed at the nearly 1,000-foot section that remains of the wall. Officials want to keep it as a reminder. Other revelers inspected the abandoned observation tower or strolled down the death strip. ``It's unbelievable that this could happen to a village, to people who love one another,'' said Bernhard Lerch, 33, an East German who fled with his wife and two children to West Germany last fall before the revolution. Asked what unity means to him, Lerch's son, 8-year-old Daniel, replied, ``Freedom. That's all.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Kills 85 Guerrillas in Peruvian Jungle
DOC.TEXT: The army killed 85 Maoist Shining Path guerrillas in three attacks in a remote, coca-rich jungle region north of Lima, Col. Juan Rivero, military commander for the region, said Tuesday. He said six soldiers were wounded in the clashes Thursday in the Upper Huallaga River valley, 280 miles northeast of Lima. According to military reports, heavy fighting in the area the past two weeks now has left at least 155 dead on both sides, with guerrillas suffering most of the losses. Rivero said the army was pursuing a rebel column that attacked a police station Wednesday, killing four police agents. A failed guerrilla ambush Friday left 15 rebels and two soldiers dead, he said. Rivero's headquarters are in Huanuco, a departmental capital 155 miles northeast of Lima. The Upper Huallaga is the world's main supplier of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine. Shining Path guerrillas provide protection for drug traffickers in exchange for money and arms.

DOC.HEAD: Resolution Praising Gulf Action Passed by Senate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf on congressional delegation going to gulf region
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a resolution praising President Bush's actions in the Persian Gulf and supporting continued deployment of U.S. troops to deter Iraqi aggression. But the debate leading up to the 96-3 vote had nervous echoes of 25 years ago, when a similar act opened the way to escalation of the Vietnam War. Senator after senator rose to say Bush could not use the resolution as justification for future military moves. In fact, debate seemed aimed more at stating what the document was not than what it was. ``This resolution is not an authorization for the use of force, now or in the future,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``This resolution is not a blank check. This resolution is not a Gulf of Tonkin Resolution.'' In 1964, Congress approved a resolution giving President Johnson the authority to retaliate for an attack on two vessels in Vietnam's Gulf of Tonkin. The resolution later was used as authorization for a widening of the U.S. war effort. Tuesday's vote came a day after the House approved a similar resolution on a 380-29 vote. Senators said they thought it was important to send a signal of U.S. unity by giving legislative support to Bush's moves so far. Voting against the measure were Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., and Bob Kerrey, D-Neb. Not voting was Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif. The resolution ``strongly approves the president's leadership'' in winning approval of eight resolutions in the United Nations Security Council that impose a global trade embargo on Iraq and call for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait. It also states: ``The Congress supports continued action by the president in accordance with the decisions of the United Nations Security Council and in accordance with United States constitutional and statutory processes ... to deter Iraqi aggression and to protect American lives and vital interests in the region.'' Kennedy called that language ``a blank check endorsement for future actions. ... It is, in effect, a Tonkin Gulf Resolution for the Persian Gulf'' that abdicates Congress' war-declaring power. Kennedy said he was voting against the measure because it could ``easily be used by President Bush as approval in advance by Congress of military action against Iraq, up to and including the launching of an all-out war.'' But Mitchell said the resolution speaks only to actions already taken. ``Future actions must be judged on their own merits, in view of the circumstances at the time,'' he said. ``The Constitution makes plain that only Congress can provide a declaration of war. The president of the United States has no legal authority to commit the United States to war,'' Mitchell said. ``The Senate, then, will be involved in future grave decisions should the crisis expand and the shadow of war approach.'' But Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, noted there had not been a declaration of war since World War II. ``There was none for Korea, none for Vietnam, none for Grenada, none for Panama,'' he said. ``We are somewhat in a no-man's-land'' in the Persian Gulf under the War Powers Act, which requires presidential consultation and congressional assent for deployment of troops in an area of imminent hostilities, he said. Cohen said the Gulf situation, in which the ``most massive military forces'' of Iraq and a multinational force are faced off, is ``clearly a situation involving imminent hostilities.'' A slight miscalculation by either side could lead to war, he said. And Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., noted the crisis involves the United Nations, a situation not envisioned by those who ambiguously divided up the powers to make war in the Constitution. But there appeared to be a broad consensus that for any military action that goes beyond defensive and deterrent moves, Bush must come to Capitol Hill. ``If the president decides he must (attack Iraq), and risk tens of thousands of American casualties, then he must do so with the approval of Congress - in advance, in specific terms,'' Kennedy said. The Senate resolution was a non-binding document that would not need to be signed into law by the president. The version the House approved Monday is one that would need White House approval and would become law. Meanwhile, House Speaker Thomas Foley said a 25-member bipartisan House delegation would leave Friday for a visit to the Persian Gulf. The group will be in the region three or four days to oversee the multinational military buildup, Foley, D-Wash., said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Says He Acted Hastily in Complaining About Puppet Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with comment from Robertson spokesman, and moves up festival official's denial that NEA funds went to puppeteer.
DOC.TEXT: A minister who complained about simulated oral sex in an art festival puppet show said Tuesday he had met with the puppeteer and festival officials and was satisfied future shows won't be open to children. In a joint appearance with puppeteer Jon Ludwig and officials of Arts Festival of Atlanta, the Rev. John Norton said he acted hastily in contacting news organizations to complain about the Sept. 21 performance of ``Zeitgeist,'' a show for adults that included puppets simulating oral sex. ``My complaint was not with the performance itself, but with unaccompanied children having access to a performance with adult material,'' said the Methodist minister from Marietta. Patricia Gann, executive director of the festival, said she appreciated Norton's suggestions for the future, ``which will ensure that unaccompanied children will not have access to all arts festival activities.'' TV evangelist Pat Robertson fueled the controversy last week by complaining that the National Endowment for the Arts, which is under attack by conservatives in Congress, had funded the show. Frankie Abourjilie, vice president for public relations at Robertson's Christian Broadcasting Network in Virginia Beach, Va., contended Tuesday that ``the NEA funded the puppeteer directly'' through funding of the Center for Puppetry Arts. Ms. Gann denied Robertson's assertions. The festival did receive money from the Georgia Arts Council, which itself receives NEA funds, but the council's grant for theatrical products was spent entirely on other works and none went to Ludwig's performance, she said. Festival officials said the puppet show, staged as a ``surrealistic morality play'' for adult audiences only, was financed entirely by ticket sales and concession receipts, without support from any government source. Norton, without mentioning Robertson by name, complained Tuesday that others had misconstrued his concerns. ``We do not feel it is appropriate for us to be placed in the position of being connected with the greater issues others have attempted to draw us into,'' he said. Norton, Ms. Gann and Ludwig read statements at Tuesday's news conference, but refused to answer questions.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Asks Extradition of Former Argentine President, 4 Officers
DOC.TEXT: A Rome court has asked that former president and general Jorge Videla and four ex-officers be extradited to face charges of human rights abuse, a federal court disclosed Tuesday. The others were former navy chief Emilio Massera; former air force commander Orlando Agosti; cashiered Gen. Carlos Suarez Mason and retired Gen. Roberto Bocalandro. Justice and Foreign Ministry spokesman made no immediate comment on the extradition request. Approval, however, was unlikely. The charges stem from the disappearance of four Argentine citizens of Italian descent during the 1976-83 ``dirty war'' crackdown on suspected leftist subversives by the military regime. Relatives of Silvia Roncoroni, Maria D'Amico, Maria Ferrando and Dora Greco filed the suit. The four young women were last seen in 1978 in coastal Mar del Plata, 250 miles south of Buenos Aires, the government news agency Telam reported, citing court and Foreign Ministry sources. During the crackdown, at least 9,000 Argentines vanished after being arrested and were presumed executed, according to a presidential commission. It said many were tortured, and that most were innocent of any crime. Human rights groups contend up to 30,000 ``disappeared'' and are presumed dead. Videla was convicted by Argentine courts in 1985 of human rights abuses, cashiered and sentenced to life in prison. Massera and Agosti were convicted with Videla and cashiered. Massera was sentenced to life in prison. Agosti served a term of three years, nine months and was released. Suarez Mason, also cashiered, is in jail facing 39 charges of murder.

DOC.HEAD: Europeans Approve $1.5 Billion in Aid for Turkey, Egypt, Jordan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede and 3rd graf to CORRECT figures from $1.5 billion, $500 million and $1 billion to almost $2 billion, $690 million, $1.32 billion and $1.96 billion. FYI, figures in a0710 were European currency units sted dollars as stated; following translates to dollars
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The European Community will provide almost $2 billion in aid to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey as compensation for economic hardships stemming from the Persian Gulf crisis, the Italian foreign minister said Tuesday. ``The cohesion and the unity in the international community is stronger than before,'' Gianni De Michelis said about opposition to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait. De Michelis said the European Community would contribute $660 million as a group, with individual members providing a total of $1.32 billion for a grand total of $1.98 billion. Turkey lost substantial revenue with by the shutdown of an Iraqi oil pipeline through its territory, Jordan is burdened by an influx of refugees and Egypt with the cost of keeping troops in Saudi Arabia to deter an Iraqi attack. Most of the aid will be in the form of grants, and some in loans. De Michelis said the European Community also would consider assisting countries in Eastern and Central Europe and elsewhere that are beset economically. Italy is chair of the 12-nation group, whose foreign ministers approved the assistance while attending a European Security Conference meeting here to prepare for a 35-nation summit in Paris Nov. 19-21. The 35 ministers who attended the preparatory session condemned Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait. ``These actions jeopardize the just and peaceful world order to which more cooperative European relations are making an important contribution,'' they said in a resolution introduced by the United States that called for an immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Two tentative decisions to help Egypt, Jordan and Turkey were made last month. De Michelis cautioned Iraqi President Saddam Hussein not to attack Israel, saying there would be ``a strong reaction'' from the international community. ``It is difficult not to foresee a military reaction in that case,'' he said, adding that his country would participate in any military action against Iraq approved by the U.N. Security Council. But De Michelis said more time should be taken to see if the curbs on trade approved by the Security Council produce an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. He said he concurred with President Bush's statement to the U.N. General Assembly on Monday that a pullout could set the stage for addressing the Arab-Israeli dispute. ``We cannot accept Saddam Hussein's attempt to link the problems,'' De Michelis said. ``And we cannot reward aggression and invasion.'' But, he said, ``we have always stated the fact that there are problems in the region'' that need solutions. He listed them, without elaboration, as Palestinian, Israeli and Lebanese problems. Saddam insists he's being singled out for harsh treatment and that Israel's retention of territory lost by defeated Arab nations in 1967 should be taken up simultaneously with Iraq's territorial dispute with Kuwait. De Michelis said Bush's approach was ``rational and right'' and didn't reflect ``more flexibility'' toward Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: Cocaine Lab Blast near Colombian School Kills 9, Hurts 57
DOC.TEXT: A cocaine-processing laboratory blew up Tuesday in a house next to a school in Medellin, killing nine people and injuring 57, including 20 children at the school, officials said. A police communique said four children were among those killed, none of them pupils at the school. A mushroom-shaped cloud rose after the explosion, and odors of gasoline, ether and other chemicals filled the air, witnesses said in broadcast reports from the scene. More than 20 vehicles were destroyed. The explosion came at 9:45 a.m., when the school was filled with hundreds of pupils. In a communique, Mayor Omar Flores' office blamed the explosion on a bomb containing an estimated 35 pounds of dynamite in the basement of the house. It said it could not be determined if the bomb went off accidentally. The Medellin and Cali cocaine cartels have been at war in Colombia for almost two years in a battle for control of the cocaine smuggling into the New York City area. Before Tuesday, about 190 people had been killed in the war.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with initial, unofficial returns; pick up dash matter.
DOC.HEAD: Hastings Falls Behind For Democratic Secretary of State Nod
DOC.TEXT: Former newspaperman Jim Minter jumped to an early lead Tuesday against impeached former federal judge Alcee Hastings in a runoff for the Democratic secretary of state nomination. With 347 of 4,528 precincts, or 8 percent, reporting unofficial returns, Minter had 23,871 votes, or 71 percent, to Hastings' 9,804 votes, or 29 percent. Preliminary counts Tuesday indicated just 13 percent of the state's 5.9 million registered voters cast ballots, elections officials said. That translates to just 7.5 percent of the state's voting-age population of 10.3 million. In the lone, U.S. House runoff, former Harris Corp. space-defense lobbyist William Tolley opposed former state Senate president John Vogt for the GOP nomination to face Jim Bacchus, an Orlando attorney who captured the Democratic nomination without opposition. The winner of the secretary of state race will face well-financed Republican incumbent Jim Smith, who served two terms as a Democratic attorney general, in the Nov. 6 election.
DOC.HEAD: Pickup at dash
Rebel Rocket Barrage Kills 25: Radio Kabul
DOC.TEXT: A barrage of rockets battered the Afghan capital on Tuesday, killing 25 people and wounding 22 others, Radio Kabul said. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack but the radio broadcast, monitored in Islamabad, blamed U.S.-backed insurgents. For more than a dozen years, Moslem rebels, called mujahedeen or Islamic holy warriors, have been fighting to topple successive communist-style governments in Afghanistan. From their headquarters in neighboring Pakistan, insurgents have been waging a bloody war that has left an estimated 1.5 million people dead. Another 3.5 million Afghan war refugees have fled to Pakistan since December 1979 when more than 115,000 Soviet troops intervened to crush a burgeoning Moslem insurgency and install a friendly government. Moscow withdrew its soldiers in February 1989 in line with a United Nations-negotiated agreement. Most of the people were killed when a rocket hit a central coal distribution center where people were stocking up with fuel for the winter, the radio said. The radio report could not be independently confirmed. Hundreds of people have died in rocket attacks on the Afghan capital in the last two years.

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Drummer Freddie Kohlman Dies, Aged 75
DOC.TEXT: Louis Freddie Kohlman, a jazz drummer who backed such greats as Billie Holiday and Diana Ross with a powerful beat, has died of cancer at the age of 75. Kohlman died Saturday at his home in New Orleans. Kohlman, who was known only by his last name, began playing professionally in his teens when he appeared with such musicians as Oscar ``Papa'' Celestin, Sam Morgan and Joe Robichaux. A native of New Orleans, he moved to Chicago in 1956 to play at Jazz Ltd. He stayed 11 years before returning to his hometown, where he performed at clubs and hotels and later at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. As a member of the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, Kohlman traveled widely in the United States and overseas. Kohlman appeared in several movies, including ``Pete Kelly's Blues,'' ``Pretty Baby'' and ``Angel Heart.'' Among the performers he worked with were Marian McPartland, Leslie Uggams, Perry Como and Dolly Parton.

DOC.HEAD: New Device Gives Amputees Sensation Through Artificial Limb
DOC.TEXT: Amputees who wear artificial feet can sense the floor with a new electronic device that was developed by a company here and made its national debut Tuesday. The Sabolich Sense-of-Feel System was developed by John Sabolich, president of the Sabolich Prosthetic & Research Center. It was demonstrated on the ABC-TV program ``Good Morning, America.'' The system uses small pressure transducers implanted in the artificial foot to signal electrodes in the socket of the prosthesis. The electrodes in turn stimulate the skin of the limb stump and transmit sensation to the brain. The $1,400 electronic system is powered by a standard 9-volt battery and can be used by any lower-limb amputee, Sabolich said. ``It's the most incredible thing,'' said Holly Howard, an above-the-knee amputee from Tyler, Texas, who is one of 20 people testing the device so far. ``For the first time in 10 years, I can feel my foot and know where it is.'' Sabolich said the invention he first conceived of eight years ago might also have the potential to reduce, and even eliminate, so-called phantom pain for amputees who feel discomfort as if from the missing limb. ``The brain really likes to have information from the floor,'' Sabolich said. ``When it doesn't have information from the floor, the nerves sort of dangle, and that increases phantom pain and doesn't let the person know where their foot is on the ground.'' Dr. William N. Harsha, an Oklahoma City orthopedic surgeon, asked to comment on the system, said he had not known of it ``except in the research stage, and John Sabolich has been in the forefront of that.'' ``I would think it would be of great benefit,'' Harsha said. ``It would enable the patient to know where his foot iswhen he is walking, going up and down the stairs. Each of these movements is different and requires different control.''

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand Rules Out French Military Presence in Germany
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand on Tuesday ruled out a longterm French military presence in unified Germany unless it comes within a new, overall European defense framework. The French leader made his comments in interviews with the German television networks ARD and ZDF hours before East and West Germany formally unified on Wednesday. ``A big country like yours, does it need foreign troops on its soil, even friendly troops?'' Mitterrand asked. At a Sept. 18 summit in Munich with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Mitterrand announced France will withdraw half its 50,000 troops stationed in Germany over the next two years. The World War II Allied powers - the United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain - give up their occupying rights in East and West Germany with the unification. But Kohl has suggested he would like the Western allies to continue a military role after unification, even though all have announced intentions to quickly reduce troop levels. ``If it's judged necessary in the framework of European defense, that's something else,'' Mitterrand said. ``A new accord would be necessary. We must speak clearly'' on this. The 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe will meet in Paris next month to consider the future shape of Europe since the democratic revolutions that swept Eastern Europe last year. Meanwhile, European Affairs Minister Edith Cresson said France should launch an economic offensive to establish markets in post-unification East Germany. ``We count on Germany to play the game (of competition) fairly,'' she said in a report to be presented to the government Wednesday. The report was made public hours before Mitterrand replaced the outspoken Cresson with Elisabeth Guigou, a close adviser, in a Cabinet shakeup marking the start of a new legislative term. Cresson, who caused an uproar last spring when she said Japan was ``out to conquer the world'' with exports, said she had asked to quit the government. In the report on Germany, Cresson said France has ``proved its good will and its solidarity'' by supporting German unification. Now, she said, France should be vigilant in ensuring that European Community measures aimed at helping East Germany do not provide West German businesses with unfair advantages. Cresson said French companies has encountered difficulties as they tried to move into East Germany in recent months, because of disorganization there and also because of ``abuses'' by West German firms. She said some West German firms had found ways to pressure the East German government to their advantage.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav Leaders Reject Republic's Move for Independent Army
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Slovenian response, order for Croatia to remove riot police. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `Tension between...'
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslav leaders Tuesday blocked Slovenia's move for a self-sufficient defense force and ordered the federal army to remain in the defiant region. The presidency said the nation's stability was treatened by the constitutional amendment passed Friday by the Slovenia Parliament saying the republic was solely responsible for its defense. In a statement, the presidency said the Slovenian move was designed to ``destroy the constitutional competence of the federation'' of Yugoslavia, which is beset by widening ideological and ethnic rifts among various groups. ``This, the presidency ... cannot and shall not permit,'' said the statement, carried by the state Tanjug news agency. In response to the decision, Slovenian President Milan Kucan said his republic's military will ``fulfill only decisions and commands of the presidency of Slovenia.'' But in a speech on Slovenian television, he said the army would ``fully discharge its obligations ... as part of the armed forces of Yugoslavia'' in case of war. The collective presidency, formed of representatives from each of the country's six republics and two provinces, is the highest body in the land. It is also in charge of the armed forces. The development sharpened the already intense conflict between federal officials and the westernmost republic, seeking to make decisions independent of the central government in Belgrade. Slovenia and Croatia are the only republics led by democratically elected governments, following elections earlier this year. Both want the nation changed into a loose confederation of sovereign states. The meeting by the federal presidency was called to discuss the heightened tensions between Communist-ruled Serbia and Croatia, Yugoslavia's largest republics. Many of the estimated 500,000 Serbs in Croatia claim to be victims of discrimination and harassment. The presidency early Wednesday demanded Croatia withdraw special riot police from towns where members of the Serb minority seized large amounts of automatic weapons from police armories last week. The presidency also ordered Croatia to release ``illegally detained Serbs.'' At least 27 people have been arrested and one Croatian policeman was wounded in clashes with Serb protesters since the arms were taken. Federal officials said the seized arms must be returned and barricades removed. ``The situation in many area with mixed national population has seriously deteriorated,'' the presidency's statement said. President Borisav Jovic, a Serb now holding the annual rotating chairmanship of the presidency, cut short his visit to the United Nations to attend the session in Belgrade. Tension between Serbs and Croats, dating to the birth of Yugoslavia in 1918, intensified this year after the first free elections in Croatia since 1945. Center-right parties trounced the Communists in those elections. Croatia's non-Communist leaders claim the unrest in their republic has been orchestrated by Serbia to destabilize their republic and gain support for Serbia's hard-line policies. Road and rail traffic was blocked Tuesday in eastern sections of Croatia. Barricades were set up by Serbs across roads and railway lines to Knin, a Serbian-dominated city of 10,000 people near the Adriatic coast, witnesses said. The Serb minority, which makes up about 10 percent of Croatia's population, proclaimed autonomy within the republic on Monday and staged anti-government rallies. Tanjug quoted the Croatian Interior Ministry as saying its units were beginning to withdraw from Serbian-dominated areas of the republic.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Celebrates Unity With Large-Than-Life Party
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Germany united with a burst of color under a clear moonlit sky Wednesday to close out the most festive chapter of a remarkable year. The two sides of Berlin were linked by a river of people that stretched from Alexanderplatz, East Berlin's central square, to the historic Branderburg Gate more than a half-mile away. Crowds estimated at more than 1 million swarmed down Unter den Linden, East Berlin's main avenue, and spilled onto the broad plaza at the base of the gate. Floodlights and fireworks lighted the sky as German unification took effect at midnight to a stirring chorus of the national anthem. Masses gathered from every vantage point to watch the center of the celebration at the Reichstag, the old German Parliament building near Brandenburg Gate. Germans draped themselves in the red, gold and black flag, threw firecrackers and shimmied to the rock, swing, and jazz bands that lined Unter den Linden. The gigantic party was heavily orchestrated - and commercially sponsored - compared to the mass demonstrations that brought down the Communist government last year and the jubilant euphoria that followed the Nov. 9 opening of the Berlin Wall. ``This was overdone, all of this money,'' said East German Hartmut Giese, 46, from a place where the Wall once stood in view of the Brandenburg Gate celebration. ``But we need things like this to help bring us together, to give us something to share,'' he said. On Unter den Linden, a West Berlin school teacher drew gawks as she leaned on the railing overlooking the Spree River, smartly dressed in black tights and a tailored Soviet major's jacket and hat. ``I wanted to see what it felt like to be an occupying power in East Germany,'' she said. Nearby, a huge crane suspended an East German-made Trabant, a tiny, two-cylinder car that was one of the first products spurned by East Germans when their borders opened to Western commerce. West German youths fired at it with flareguns, shredding the now-obsolete East German flag that hanged below it. Leftist radicals held small rallies throughout the city to protest unification. About 200 blew whistles outside a police barrier at the Schauspielhaus, jeering arriving dignitaries.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Confirms Souter
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS one graf; no ticket for Souter
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus-Desegregaton
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted 90-9 Tuesday to confirm the nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court. The only dissenting votes came from liberals who fear he will oppose abortion rights. The New Hampshire jurist was approved less than 2{ months after he was tapped as President Bush's first nominee to the high court. It was too late to put him on the court for the start of its session this week but, age 51, he'll probably participate in its rulings well into the next century. The Supreme Court announced that Souter would be sworn in as the first item of business next Tuesday morning, before the court begins the second week of its session. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``We're obviously very pleased that Congress confirmed this nomination. We think Judge Souter will be an outstanding justice for many years.'' Fitzwater said Bush hoped to attend Souter's swearing-in. Souter watched the proceedings from a friend's law office in Concord, N.H. ``He's just exactly the kind of person with a broad background that we need on the Supreme Court,'' Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said as debate on the nomination began. ``I think he showed that he is a person of fairness. He's willing to listen. He's a person of independence.'' Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., said he supported Souter, but warned Bush that the path of the next nominee might not be so smooth if the president moves further to the right wing. ``I want to express the hope that the administration will not learn the wrong lesson'' from the lopsided Senate vote on Souter, Biden said. A more doctrinaire conservative ``could well fall outside the sphere of acceptability,'' he said. Souter becomes the 105th justice of the Supreme Court, filling the seat vacated last summer by the retirement of Justice William Brennan. In Concord, Souter toasted the vote with champagne and friends, and pledged to return the nation's confidence in him. ``I have been given much and much will be expected of me in return, and I will make that return to you and I will make it in the fullest measure that I can,'' Souter said. The court's spokeswoman, Toni House, said Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist would administer the oath of office in private at 9 a.m., and would administer the oath in a public ceremony in the court's ornate courtroom 15 minutes later. The first major case in which he will participate will be a sex-bias dispute that will be argued before the justices Wednesday, Oct. 10. At issue is whether employers may exclude all women of child-bearing age - perhaps 20 million - from some hazardous jobs. There was little doubt Souter would be a more conservative justice than Brennan, especially on matters of criminal law. But Souter's position on social issues, including abortion, would be harder to predict. During three days of testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Souter declined to say whether he believed the court should overturn its 1973 ruling in Roe vs. Wade, which legalized abortion. He said he was open-minded. On issues including civil rights and religious liberty, his testimony indicated a far more moderate viewpoint than his record would suggest. Sen. Herb Kohl, D-Wis., a committee member, said there appeared to be ``two Judge Souters.'' ``Fortunately, the Judge Souter who testified before our committee did not seem locked to the past,'' said Kohl, saying he was voting for that one and hoping the Senate had not been deceived. Biden said he was troubled by Souter's refusal to declare support for abortion rights and by the judge's mixed record on civil rights. But Biden joined the majority when his committee approved the nomination 13-1, and said Tuesday he would do so again in the full Senate. ``He's about the best we can expect, from my perspective, from this administration,'' said Biden, reflecting the outlook of many Democrats. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, waited until just before the vote to announce his support. ``Judge Souter reflected a reasoned approach and a sound understanding of the Constitution,'' he said. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said he was unwilling to give Souter the benefit of the doubt. ``The Senate is still in the dark about this nomination,'' Kennedy said. Souter, he said, has not met the test of a ``good faith, in-depth, abiding commitment to the core constitutional values of the kind so obviously at stake at this turning point in our history.'' Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., the Senate Majority Whip, said if because of Souter the court overturned Roe vs. Wade, he would move legislation to create a federal statute legalizing abortion. Hatch, an abortion foe, said opponents were applying single-issue politics to their decisions. ``I hope that the litmus test mentality is not used in the future,'' Hatch said. It would make it ``almost impossible for any great nominee to make it on to the court. And Judge Souter is a great nominee.'' All nine voting against Souter were Democrats: Daniel Akaka of Hawaii, Brock Adams of Washington, Cranston, Bill Bradley and Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, Quentin Burdick of North Dakota, Kennedy, John Kerry of Massachusetts and Barbara Mikulski of Maryland. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., did not vote. Souter, of rural Weare, N.H., is a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School and a former Rhodes Scholar. He spent most of his adult life working in the judicial system of his home state in jobs including attorney general, trial judge and member of the state supreme court. Last April, he was confirmed by the Senate to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston. He served only until July before being tapped by the president to succeed Brennan. The debate Tuesday was interrupted at one point when a protester who shouted, ``You murderers.'' The protester was charged with disrupting an orderly session of Congress, according to U.S. Capitol Police. Souter, meanwhile, underwent a brush with the law on his way to his friend's law office - the parking meter accepted his quarters but wouldn't drop the red flag. ``If I get a ticket, you guys are witnesses,'' he joked after giving up on the meter. Souter did not get a ticket.

DOC.HEAD: At New Dividing Line: German Cheers, Polish Fears
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: On the western side of the Oder River, fireworks exploded and Germans cheered Wednesday as the flag of the united nation was hoisted. But on the eastern bank, Poles were more subdued, watching with a mixture of fear and resentment at new German attitudes and policies. The ceremony marking the unification of Germany was preceded by stone-throwing attacks by German youths on two Polish buses picking up factory workers in Frankfurt on Oder, the German city across the river from Slubice. Two Polish cars waiting to cross the border back into Poland also were pounded by youths wielding sticks. ``To me, it seems horrifying,'' said one passenger, Halina Gawronska. ``They come to us and we welcome them with open arms and then this. We live together, we know each other. How could they?'' ``There was always great friendship, but now we don't know what is going on,'' said a companion, Genewa Kowalska. The stone-throwers, who appeared to be teen-agers, shouted pro-German slogans, shattered the windows of the buses and injured the two drivers. Some of the many Poles who work in former East Germany cities have expressed concerns they could lose their jobs due to new visa restrictions, the deteriorating economic situation and pro-German sentiments. There has been hostility and suspicion along the border, formed by the Oder and Neisse rivers, since it was created after World War II. One-third of Poland is land forfeited by defeated Germany, settled largely by Poles thrown out of Polish territory to the east annexed by the Soviet Union. Some Germans have never relinquished claims to the former lands. Some Poles, with memories of German aggression and the 6 million of their countrymen killed during World War II, have eyed a resurgent German neighbor with distrust. ``History has taught us to have some fears,'' said Leszek Korczak, of Glogow, waiting at the border to return to Poland. The western border of Germany was a crucial issue for Poland during the unification talks. Poland secured promises from the parliaments of the two Germanys that the border would be made final in a treaty between Poland and the united Germany's new government. At midnight, fireworks began to explode over Frankfurt on Oder and the commanders of the Polish and German border stations saluted the flag of the German Federal Republic. Earlier, the German border guards had changed out of their grey uniforms into the dark green uniforms of the West German units. The ranking Polish official present, Slubice Major Wieslaw Wrzosek, called unification ``a new chapter in he history of Europe, a new chapter in relations between Poles and Germans.'' Some of the Poles returning from Germany expressed resentment at a policy requiring visas for Poles visiting what had been East Germany and Berlin. No visas had been needed for Berlin, and only an invitation for East Germany. ``Poles always find some way to manage but this difficulty was not needed at all,'' said Korczak. The new commander of the German border station, Ultun Topp, defended the visa policy, which took effect Wednesday. The German-Polish line is now the new ``outer border'' between Eastern and Western Europe, he said. ``We have to control it for all the people in the European Community. But I believe there will come a time when all the visas will fall away. ... I hope so.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: spending cuts.
DOC.TEXT: This agreement will also raise revenue. I'm not - and I know you're not - a fan of tax increases. But if there have to be tax measures, they should allow the economy to grow, they should not turn us back to higher income tax rates and they should be fair. Everyone who can should contribute something and no one should have to contribute beyond their fair share. Our bipartisan agreement meets these tests. And through specific new incentives it will help create more jobs. It's a little known fact. But America's best job creators and greatest innovators tend to be our smaller companies. So our budget plan will small-and medium-size companies a needed shot in the arm. Just as important, I am convinced that this agreement will help lower interest rates and lower interest rates means savings for consumers, lower mortgage payments for new homeowners, and more investment to produce more jobs. And that's what this agreement will do. And now let me tell you what this agreement will not do. It will not raise income tax rates, personal or corporate. It will not mess with Social Security in any way. It will not put America's national security at risk. And most of all, it will not let our economy slip out of control. Clearly each and every one of us can find fault with something in this agreement. In fact, that is a burden that any truly fair solution must carry. Any workable solution must be judged as a whole, not piece by piece. Those who dislike one part or another may pick our agreement apart. But if they do, believe me, the political reality is, no one can put a better one back together again. Everyone will bear a small burden. But if we succeed, every American will have a large burden lifted. If we fail to enact this agreement, our economy will falter, markets may tumble and recession will follow. In just a moment the Democratic majority leader, Senator Mitchell, will offer what is known as the Democratic response - often a rebuttal, but not tonight. Tonight, the Democratic and Republican leadership and I all speak with one voice in support of this agreement. Tonight, we ask you to help us move this agreement forward. The congressional leadership and I both have a job to do in getting it enacted, and tonight I ask for your help. First, I ask you to understand how important, and, for some, how difficult this vote is, for your congressmen and senators. Many worry about your reaction to one part or another. But I know you know the importance of the whole. And so second, I ask you to take this initiative: Tell your congressmen and senatorsyou support this deficit reduction agreement. If they are Republicans, urge them to stand with the president. Urge them to do what the bipartisan leadership has done, come together in the spirit of compromise to solve this national problem. If they're Democrats, urge them to stand with their congressional leaders. Ask them to fight for the future of your kids by supporting this budget agreement. Now is the time for you, the American people, to have a real impact. Your senators and congressmen need to know that you want this deficit brought down. That the time for politics and posturing is over and the time to come together is now. This deficit reduction agreement is tough and so are the times. The agreement is fair, and so is the American spirit. The agreement is bipartisan, and so is the vote. The agreement is real, and so is this crisis. This is the first time in my presidency that I have made an appeal like this to you, the American people. With your help we can at last put this budget crisis behind us and face the other challenges that lie ahead. If we do, the long-term result will be a healthier nation and something more. We will have once again put ourselves on the path of economic growth and we will have demonstrated that no challenge is greater than the determination of the American people. Thank you, God bless you and good night.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Accepts United Germany With a Heavy Heart
DOC.TEXT: Israel on Tuesday accepted Germany's unification with some hesitancy, tainted by the memory of the slayings of 6 million Jews by the Germans a half-century ago. ``As Jews we have mixed feelings. We cannot forget our scars from the past, what happened to our people during the Second World War,'' said Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's spokesman, Avi Pazner. ``On the other hand, there is a new reality now with which we have to live,'' Pazner said in a telephone interview. Pazner called on the new united Germany to ``remember its debt to the Jewish people ... and do all it can to act favorably toward the state of Israel, in bilateral ties and in the European and international arenas.'' Shamir, leader of the right-wing Likud bloc, was born in Poland and lost his parents and other close family in the Holocaust. He emigrated to British Mandatory Palestine before the war. Some Israeli leaders were more negative about the festivities in Berlin. Parliament speaker Dov Shilansky, a concentration camp survivor, said in a statement read on state television: ``On the day of united Germany the people of Israel should wear sackcloth, douse their heads with ashes, mourn and chant lamentations.'' Eliahu Ben-Elissar, chairman of Parliament's Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee said: ``The unification of Germany is happening too soon. We should have raised our voices, the voice of conscience against unification. This we didn't do and it is too bad.'' Leaders of the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial museum called on Germany to fight anti-Semitism, neo-Nazism and refrain from supplying arms to Israel's Arab enemies.

DOC.HEAD: Witness: Mapplethorpe Took Photos to Come to Grips With Life
DOC.TEXT: Robert Mapplethorpe took sexually explicit photographs to come to terms with his own troubled life, an art historia testified Tuesday at the nation's first obscenity trial of a gallery and its director. Robert Sobieszek, curator of a New York photo museum, said in videotaped testimony played for the jury that seven Mapplethorpe photos at issue have as much artistic merit as others in his 175-picture retrospective. ``The story was of a very full and rich artist who was interested in documenting what was beautiful and elegant on the one hand and tortured and troubled on the other,'' said Sobieszek, from the George Eastman House museum in Rochester, N.Y. Mapplethorpe, who was homosexual, began work on the show, ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment,'' after he was diagnosed with AIDS. He died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in March 1989 at age 42. ``They reveal in a very strong, forceful way a major part of his life,'' said Sobieszek. ``A troubled portion of his life he was trying to come to grips with.'' The Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, are on trial on misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. Barrie may testify Wednesday, defense attorneys said. The charges stem from the seven photos Sobieszek referred to showing the exposed genitals of two children, a man urinating in another man's mouth and anal penetration involving various objects. The Cincinnati gallery hosted the show for seven weeks ending in May. If convicted of both charges, Barrie could be sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000. The gallery could be fined $10,000 for conviction on both counts. Jurors heard depositions from Beatrix Mary Nevill of London and Claryssa Dalrymple of New York City, mothers of the girl and the boy in the photos. They testified that Mapplethorpe took the pictures in 1976 with their approval and exhibited them with their consent. At issue is whether the seven Mapplethorpe photos violated community standards of obscenity. Prosecutors, who have completed their case, sought to establish that contemporary community standards provide one criterion for defining obscenity. Defense attorneys said the exhibit drew more than 80,000 people in Cincinnati. They want that considered as an indicator of community standards. Jerry Stein, an arts critic at The Cincinnati Post who gave the exhibit a favorable review, testified that the photographs of the children are an ``innocent or non-sexual presentation.'' Judge David Albanese refused to set aside a defense subpoena seeking testimony from Owen Findsen, arts reviewer for The Cincinnati Enquirer. The newspaper fought the subpoena. Defense attorneys said Findsen would be called to testify Wednesday. Jurors might begin deliberations Wednesday. The trial in its second week. Meanwhile, police said Tuesday they began issuing misdemeanor disorderly conduct citations for at least 30 people who participated in a Sept. 24 protest of the city's prosecution of Barrie and the gallery. Most of the citations were issued anonymously in the names of ``Jane Doe'' or ``John Doe'' as police attempt to identify protesters through police films. Police said protesters unlawfully blocked streets and tied up traffic without a parade permit.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Asks Taxpayers to Share Burden; Tries to Sell $500 Billion Budget Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds quotes, editing
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Americans Tuesday night to support a demanding $500 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts. ``Everyone who can should contribute something,'' the president said. Claiming rare unity with leaders of the Democratic-controlled Congress, Bush said in a 10-minute televised speech from the Oval Office that the package was written in ``eight months of blood, sweat and fears - fears of the economic chaos that would follow if we fail to reduce the deficit.'' ``It is the best agreement that can be legislated now,'' Bush said of the compromise. Bush's address from the Oval Office was nationally televised, but his message was primarily aimed 16 blocks away: at Congress, where an initial vote on the plan may be held as early as Thursday. Although the package generally has support among Democrats, lawmakers from Bush's own party - particularly in the House - have balked at its tax provisions. Bush himself had to abandon his ``no new taxes'' pledge in the face of the growing deficit. ``I'm not, and I know you're not, a fan of tax increases,'' Bush said. ``But if there have to be tax measures, they should allow the economy to grow, they should not turn us back to higher income tax rates and they should be fair. ``Everyone who can should contribute something. And no one should have to contribute beyond their fair share.'' Bush pointed out that the agreement had been hammered out by a bipartisan group. ``The Democratic and Republican leadership tonight all speak with once voice,'' he said, and urged people to tell their congressmen they support the package. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, joined Bush in urging passage of the fragile package, saying the future of the nation ``is more important than partisan differences.'' In a televised response, Mitchell acknowledged that Democrats and Republicans had ``deep differences over values and priorities'' that delayed an agreement for months. The Democratic leader called the agreement ``imperfect,'' and warned that the compromise budget cuts and tax increases will demand ``sacrifice from all Americans.'' ``But, if enacted, it holds the promise of restoring a sound economy, from which all Americans will benefit,'' Mitchell said. ``Everybody who can should contribute something,'' Bush said. ``Everybody will bear a small burden. But if we succeed, everybody will have small burden lifted.'' The alternative, Bush said, is recession. Wavering Republican lawmakers had told Bush earlier in the day that the plan was in trouble, and that a presidential address to the nation endorsing the package might be helpful if he expected GOP support for the package with congressional elections just a month away. Bush also planned to push for the three-day-old package, which the White House negotiated with congressional leaders, in a series of upcoming speeches around the nation. The budget package would raise taxes on gasoline, alcohol, cigarettes, boats and furs while trimming benefits to farmers and Medicare recipients. It also would reduce tax deductions for people who earn more than $100,000. Bush earlier Tuesday had pressed his case with skeptical and wavering House Republicans. He seemed to be making some headway and by late Tuesday, House GOP leaders were beginning to feel more optimistic about their chances of rounding up support from most of their members. ``We've made significant progress,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. One opponent, Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., agreed, saying, ``I'd guess right now it would be narrowly defeated. By tomorrow, it would be narrowly passed. ... People are being moved, one-by-one.'' Bush said the budget deficit was ``a problem that has lingered and dogged and vexed this country for far too long.'' Likening the budget crisis to the Persian Gulf stalemate, Bush said ``our nation is standing together against Saddam Hussein's aggression ' while at home ``another threat, a cancer, is gnawing away at our nation's health.'' The president said that ending deficit spending was simple ``common sense.'' ``No nation can continue to do business the way the federal government has been operating and survive,'' he said. ``When you get a bill, that bill must be paid,'' he said. Bush said that the plan was not ``a magic act'' but contained true deficit savings and would put the nation on the path toward lower interest rates and a balanced budget. ``Everyone will bear a small burden but if we succeed, every American will have a large burden lifted,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Meanwhile even: a0777
Princeton Scientists Report Fusion Reactor Can Break `Break-Even' Milestone
DOC.TEXT: Physicists at Princeton University say they have reached a milestone toward commercial use of the power packed in a hydrogen bomb - a fusion reactor capable of producing as much energy as it consumes. Scientists say the breakthrough allows them to move toward developing fusion as an alternative energy to coal and nuclear power plants. However, they cautioned that the project, which has already spanned 15 years and cost $1 billion, faces several major hurdles, including determining how to extract the energy from the reactor. Scientists said Tuesday that the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor in Princeton could reach the ``break even'' point sometime after 1993, but warned that commercial use remains decades away. The researchers, at the Princeton Plasma Physics Research Laboratory, have combined atoms of a heavy form of hydrogen called deuterium to form helium and energy. The next step, which the researchers hope to achieve in 1993, would use deuterium and a radioactive form of hydrogen called tritium to generate large amounts of energy in the Tokamak reactor. A hydrogen bomb uses the same reaction to cause mass destruction. Dennis Manos, principle research physicist at the Princeton labs, said the reactor would eventually be able to generate 10 million watts of power a day. Tokamak has attained 50,000 watts and a record temperature of 400 million degrees centigrade with the deuterium mixture, he said. ``It's step one, the first real threshold you have to get across to get an engineering device whose ultimate objective is to produce much more energy than you put in,'' said Robert Sachs, a physics professor at the University of Chicago. The Atomic Age began at the University of Chicago in 1942 with the creation of the first self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction. Fusion creates energy by combining two hydrogen atoms into a heavier helium atom. It differs from nuclear fission, which powers conventional nuclear plants by splitting heavy atoms into smaller pieces. Proponents say fusion eliminates the danger of reacto meltdowns, produces less radioactive waste and is produced from a readily available source - hydrogen. ``It is a potentially safer technology, but it has a long way to go when you compare it with existing commercial fission technology,'' Manos said. The Soviet Union, the United States, Japan and the European Economic Community hope to develop a test reactor sometime after the year 2000, he said. But there are other obstacles. ``How to extract the energy from the reactor in a useful way is an engineering question no one has yet answered,'' Sachs said.
Here is the text of the Democratic response to President Bush's televised address to the nation Tuesday night, delivered by Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine.

I speak tonight not for the Democratic Party but for America's future. For more than a decade the United States has endured budget deficits that sap our economic strength. When you have a deficit there are only two things you can do; cut spending or increase revenue. This agreement does both. It cuts spending, military and domestic. It raises taxes.
