DOC.HEAD: Finding Plants that Thrive without Much Water
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Corrects spelling to drought-resistant, sted drought-resistent.
DOC.TEXT: By choice or necessity, plants that use little water are growing enormously in popularity in the Southwest, where drought and soaring water costs drive home the message of current or potential water shortages. But be warned: They don't become drought-resistant until they've become established in your landscape, which may take a couple of years. So while their reputation for needing little care and little water is well justified, you can't just bring one home from the nursery, dig a hole, put it in, and you and the plant live happily ever after. Start by doing some research. For long-term satisfaction, check first the vast amount of shade and color possible. Then be sure the plant is suited for the location being considered. Will it eventually become too large for available space? If it sheds leaves, seed pods and other litter, will this be a problem, such as around a pool or patio? Can it reasonably be expected to handle environmental stress - sun, wind, heat or cold - it must tolerate in the contemplated site? Take your time in this. Study reference books. Talk to experts. A species ideal in one part of your landscape may prove a nightmare elsewhere. Unlike some clothes, one size definitely doesn't fit all situations. Fall normally is the best time to plant most trees and shrubs in warm-arid areas, strange as this may sound to newcomers accustomed to snow and freezing temperatures. Not too much top growth may show initially, but the root growth will get the plant ready for the triple-digit temperatures and drying winds of the following summer. Early spring is the next best time for planting, especially for cold-tender ones. A newly installed plant should be watered about every other week in cooler weather and once or twice a week through the warmest months for the first year or two. If it's making satisfactory growth and looks healthy, back off to determine whether supplemental watering still is required. If the plant seems to start suffering, apply an inch or two of water and see if this helps. If it does, wait about a month to see if another watering is needed. Once drought-resistant plants are established, watering can be reduced dramatically. In general, over-watering is a serious problem for drought-resistant plants. Once established, they simply can't handle constantly moist soil. But natural rainfall may not be sufficient in some years, either. Wilted foliage usually is a good indication of too little water. Sometimes the leaf color becomes dull. It takes practice to determine such nuances. New plants should be watered before they reach this stage. A good rule to remember: Established plants probably won't die from lack of irrigation; they just won't grow very fast or look as well. Make sure to apply water slowly and deeply. As a rough rule of thumb, one inch of water on the surface will wet the soil one foot deep. Thus deep, slow watering promotes root development at lower soil levels, which helps minimize plant problems in hot weather. Deep watering also works to flush soil salts from the root zone. This is important since salt content of arid-region soils normally is quite high. Once drought-resistant plants are established, do you automatically turn off the water? In certain cases, yes. For example, if a tree has reached its desired size and can get by on natural rainfall, stop watering it. When fertilizing, remember that nitrogen is the one element consistently missing in most arid region soils. Most drought-resistant plants, once established, need little, if any fertilizer. As in watering, ``once established'' are the key words. A small amount of slow-release fertilizer, following label directions, helps at planting time. Then, if the plants are putting on the growth and providing the landscaping effect you want, they probably don't need any. After all, many are native to areas where soil nitrogen is low, owing to sparse vegetation where little organic matter is recycled into the soil. Many experts believe that stimulating growth through fertilizer reduces the lifespan of many arid-adapted plants. And as plants increase their growth rate, they require more water and more maintenance, such as pruning. Ammonium sulfate is an inexpensive, readily available fertilizer containing 21 percent nitrogen and 24 percent sulfur. As a general rule, 2 ounces of ammonium sulfate a year is sufficient nitrogen for even a good-sized shrub under warm-arid conditions. The sulfur also lowers the pH, a most important consideration in areas with alkaline soil, such as much of the Southwest. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: James Walters worked for the AP as a reporter and editor from 1947 until he retired in 1984.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday, Oct. 4

DOC.TEXT: A sigh of relief sounded on Wall Street after the Bush administration and leaders of Congress finally compromised on a budget, but the best thing many observers could say of the accord was that it exists. ``I think the financial markets are grateful that the issue is going to be put behind us for a while,'' said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International Inc. ``Regardless of whether people like or dislike the compromise, there is some feeling that an albatross has been removed from around the market's neck.'' A stalemate in the negotiations over a package of tax increases and spending cuts had added to the worries weighing down the stock market in recent weeks. Markets on Monday welcomed the break in the deadlock as a sign that interest rates could be header lower. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The volatile price of oil took its second-sharpest fall of the Persian Gulf crisis, tumbling more than $2 per barrel as traders thought they saw glimmers of peace. Light sweet crude for November delivery dropped $2.42 to $37.09 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange Monday. Oil's largest one-day fall since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 was $4 per barrel on Aug. 27. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Former Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said the savings and loan industry would have plunged ``into the tank'' deeper and faster without the deregulatory policies of the Reagan administration. When asked by Rep. Chalmers Wylie, R-Ohio, whether the thrift debacle discredited deregulation, Regan replied ``absolutely not.'' Regan appeared Monday before the House Banking Committee in the first of a series of hearings examining the causes of the S&L mess. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The nation's manufacturing economy last month hit its lowest level since the end of the previous recession in late 1982, according to a key business survey. The third straight monthly drop in the National Association of Purchasing Management index provided more evidence of an imminent recession and reflected increased prices from the oil crisis. The group said Monday its indexes for production, new orders, imports, inventories and employment all dropped sharply last month. Meanwhile, its price index shot up to its highest level since September 1988. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Construction spending stalled in August following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait after posting its first gain in four months in July, the government said. Only an increase in government projects kept overall spending from declining, according to a Commerce Department report released Monday. ``Confidence is the major problem we have across the board right now,'' said Daryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Falling prices and mortgage rates combined with rising incomes in August to improve the typical American family's ability to buy a home, a real estate trade group said. But the National Association of Realtors said Monday that the improvement was curtailed by the Mideast crisis and weakness in the overall economy. The Realtors group said its housing affordability index rose from 102.4 in July to 105.6 in August. That meant a family with a median income of $34,467 had 105.6 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced existing home costing $97,000. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Federal Reserve will move quickly to lower interest rates now that negotiators have reached agreement on a deficit-cutting plan, many economists predict. But these analysts said Monday the interest rate relief will be too little and too late to avert a recession. Their forecasts were made before today's key meeting of the Fed's top policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee. --- DETROIT (AP) - Workers at General Motors Corp. overwhelmingly ratified a new three-year contract. United Auto Workers union President Owen Bieber plans to resume negotiations Tuesday with Ford Motor Co., which had been placed on hold for over a month during the GM talks. The union said Monday that the rank and file had ratified the GM pact. --- ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP) - Exxon Corp. and its shipping subsidiary have filed notices of claims against the U.S. Coast Guard totalling more than $2 billion in connection with the Exxon Valdez shipwreck. Exxon spokesman Les Rogers said the Sept. 21 filings preserve options for Exxon and Exxon Shipping Co. to sue the Coast Guard over the spill. Exxon declined to offer an explanation for why company officials think the Coast Guard should share responsibility for the March 24, 1989, oil spill that dumped nearly 11 million gallons of crude into Prince William Sound. ---

The stock market recouped some of its summer losses with a sharp rally Monday, encouraged by falling oil prices and hopes for lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 63.36 points to 2,515.84, for its largest point gain since it rose 78.71 points on Aug. 27. Gold prices fell nearly $16 an ounce. The dollar was lower against major foreign currencies. Grains fell sharply. Silver and platinum continued their slide. Meat was sharply higher. Soybeans were lower. Treasury bond prices moved higher.

DOC.HEAD: Gannett Foundation Rejects $540 Million Stock Offer
DOC.TEXT: The Gannett Foundation has rejected a $540 million bid from the Gannett Co. to buy its 10 percent block of the media giant's stock. Martin F. Birmingham, chairman of the foundation's finance and investment committee, said Monday that the foundation, Gannett's largest shareholder, had authorized the investment firm of Salomon Brothers to seek other offers. ``The current depressed market price of Gannett stock does not represent the true value of the company,'' Birmingham said. ``It would be irresponsible for the trustees to accept this unsatisfactory `at the market' bid.'' The bid, dated Sept. 14, was $33.87{ per share for a total value of about $540 million. The foundation had told the company that no substantive talks with interested third parties would take place as long as serious negotiations were going on with the company. Douglas H. McCorkindale, Gannett Co.'s chief financial officer, agreed the company's stock was undervalued because of the recent downturn in advertising revenue. Despite the foundation's rejection, Gannett Co. was still ``a ready, willing and able buyer of the stock,'' he said. McCorkindale said Gannett was not worried that having such a large block of stock up for grabs could make the company a potential takeover target because ``financing a takeover in today's market is much, much more difficult than it was two, three or four years ago.'' He cited the decline of the junk bond market that financed a number of takeovers in the 1980s. He also noted that Gannett has a shareholder rights offering plan that would kick in after somebody acquires 15 percent of the stock. The plan would make it prohibitively expensive for a suitor to acquire more shares. John Morton, a newspaper analysts with Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington, agreed, that Gannett Co. was the most likely buyer to pay a premium over market price. ``If they (the foundation) couldn't get the price they wanted from Gannett, I think it's unlikely they're going to get it from anybody else,'' said Morton. ``It's not as though Gannett is a company that's considered a prime candidate for a takeover. Takeover-prone companies, normally are those that have not satisfied their shareholders with financial performance over the years. You cannot say that about Gannett,'' he said. Gannett stock closed at $32.87{ Monday, up $2 on the New York Stock Exchange. The foundation had told the company that no substantive talks with interested third parties would take place as long as serious negotiations were going on with the company. Birmingham said the company made its bid for the foundation's block of nearly 16 million shares after foundation officials asked for its best offer in writing. He said the market value of the stock was about $800 million at the third-quarter high a year earlier. ``Since last year, many factors have contributed to the decline of Gannett stock, including the company's first down quarter since it went public in 1967 and its gloomy predictions about 1990 earnings overall,'' Birmingham said. The foundation was established in 1935 as an independent entity with controlling ownership of the company. Since the company went public, the percentage of ownership by the foundation has declined to its current 10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Enforcement Bill Increasing SEC Powers
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission will get new powers to curb penny stock abuse and fine lawbreakers under a reform bill passed unanimously by the House. The same bill was passed by the Senate last week, paving the way for it to be signed into law by President Bush. The House also unanimously passed another bill Monday that would enhance the SEC's ability to cooperate with foreign securities regulators in the investigation of international fraud cases. ``We have begun to reverse the rapacious and deregulatory 1980s with proper legislative protections for the small investor,'' said Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the SEC. Markey was one of the penny stock bill's sponsors. ``While these bill's won't make us forget the 1980s were the decade of greed, they will at least begin the process of making the 1990s a safer decade for the small investor,'' he added. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden, who lobbied hard for the reform bills, said he was pleased they passed because they help the SEC protect the markets' stability and deter fraud by providing more flexibile enforcement. An earlier Senate version did not contain a penny stock provision, but was similar in most other ways to the Securities Enforcement and Penny Stock Reform Act passed by the House on July 23. A compromise bill including penny stock provisions was passed unanimously by the Senate last week after a month of negotiations between House and Senate staffers. The new bill will give the SEC the authority to bar crooked promoters and consultants from selling penny stocks, highly speculative securities that sell for a few dollars or less. While not illegal, penny stocks are prone to fraud and are considered to be very risky at best. They are usually not traded on any stock exchange and, thus, information amount them is hard to come by. The bill also would tighten disclosure requirements for some types of penny stocks. It also would: - give the SEC the power to order alleged wrongdoers to ``cease and desist'' illegal activities without first having to go to court and obtain a restraining order; - widen SEC authority to seek court orders barring convicted securities law violators from serving as officers or directors of companies with publicly-traded stock; - enact numerous reforms in the selling of penny stocks; - authorize new civil penalties for securities violators of up to $100,000 per violation for an individual and up to $500,000 for companies and other entities. Previously, the SEC had the power to impose fines only in insider trading cases. For other violations such as fraudulent sales techniques, the agency had no mid-level sanction. It could only enjoin violators from repeating their activities or revoke their license, which some have called the regulatory equivalent of the death penalty. Monday's vote follows House and Senate approval of another reform bill last week that will allow the SEC to regulate the controversial computerized strategy of program trading in times of extreme market turbulence. That bill also would give the SEC authority to monitor large stock trades and the parent holding companies of brokerages. It would also allow the agency to close the markets - with the president's approval - in market emergencies.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Budget Proposal Has Some Crying Foul
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The jeweler Cartier is crying foul, the elderly are worried and a liquor distributor says bootleggers are apt to move in on his territory because of the new taxes and cutbacks in the proposed $500 billion deficit-reduction plan. ``Bush sure made a big deal about reading his lips, didn't he?'' grumbled Curtis Sine, a barber in Ottumwa, Iowa. The plan unveiled Sunday calls for $134 billion in new taxes on gasoline, alcohol, tobacco, airline tickets and other luxury items and includes $105 billion in spending reductions for benefit programs such as Medicare. Some around the country shrugged off higher taxes Monday, saying the deficit must be brought under control. Sine wasn't one of them. ``It sounds terrible, but frankly, I'd like the other guy to pay for it. I think generally that's how people think,'' he said. Mark Sherman, owner of Spirit World liquor store in Omaha, Neb., said, ``People are going to drink less and drink better. The actual gallonage we sell is going to go down.'' And Jack Hooper, president of the Tennessee Wine and Spirits Co., a major distributor, said bootleggers will benefit from the higher alcohol tax. ``We run the risk of making legitimate businesses more expensive,'' he said. The taxes would be used to dig politicians in Washington out of ``a hole which they dug through fiscal irresponsibility,'' said Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder. ``The individuals who will bear overwhelmingly the burden of this `agreement' are the majority of Americans - the hard-working middle class - and Americans in need, the poor among us,'' he said. Joe Crosby, 71, of El Paso, Texas, said he's one of those people. ``I'm a disabled. I'm on Social Security and Medicare. They're hurting me when they do all of that,'' he said. Ralph Destino, chairman of swanky Cartier, said smaller jewelry makers and retailers will be hurt. ``This notion that somehow or other taxing jewelry is in the `soak the rich' category just isn't borne out by the facts in this country,'' he said. Bernard Hargrove, who sells boats at his Red River Marine in Heber Springs, Ark., complained of new fees on boats. ``That's ridiculous. Let's charge them an annual fee to play golf or go watch a football game or whatever,'' he said. Mando Guerra, a patron at Midtown Lounge in El Paso, Texas, wasn't concerned about the higher alcohol taxes but said his grandmother receives Medicare benefits. ``It's going to hurt a whole lot of old people,'' he said. The agreement would boost the federal gasoline tax from 9 cents per gallon to 21 cents by next summer. ``Look at this - I'm already paying $1.66,'' said Richard Coleman, a printer from West Haven, Conn., who was pumping premium unleaded at a station. The state has the nation's highest state tax at 22 cents a gallon. ``They're hitting the middle class again.'' Truckers cried foul.``A lot of these truck drivers operate just down to the bare teeth now, as far as profit margin is concerned. This is gonna hurt 'em,'' Bill Gussett said from the Flying J truck stop in La Grande, Ore. Higher gas taxes don't worry Bob Muscatell, who sells motor homes and recreational vehicles in Santa Clara, Calif. ``I've always taken the position the RV buyers are not concerned about the cost of the gasoline,'' he said. ``Even if (gas) costs $2 a gallon and you want to go on a trip with your family, it's still cheaper than flying and other means of transportation.'' Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said the gasoline-tax increase is difficult, but good for the country. ``The nation needs a meaningful budget-reduction package,'' said Susan Shackson, Ford director of public policy development. ``Is this the best one? Probably not. But we are where we are. I would say at this point let's get on with it.''

DOC.HEAD: UAW Heading to Ford Next; Chrysler Third
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UAW not expected at Ford before 12:30 p.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers turned their attention to Ford Motor Co. today after the union's contract with General Motors Corp. won overwhelming approval from the UAW rank and file. The UAW hopes to get Ford to adopt the contract with little or no change. Negotiations with Ford were to resume today for the first time since Aug. 28, when the union chose to focus on GM to set a pattern contract for the industry. ``We want to get on with this thing,'' Ford spokesman Dick Routh said Monday. Workers at GM factories and offices in 29 states ratified the three-year pact 86,032 votes to 21,461, the union said Monday. Only a third of the 300,000 members eligible to vote cast ballots last week and Sunday. The light turnout reflected satisfaction with the agreement, former UAW vice president Irving Bluestone said. ``When people are upset, that's when they come out to vote in droves,'' he said. It's expected that Ford will be able to sign a parallel contract, perhaps within a couple of weeks. Under the GM-UAW agreement, GM will spend up to $4.1 billion to guarantee the income of laid-off workers. The contract also calls for a 3 percent raise the first year and lump-sum payments of 3 percent in the following years. Reports have said that if the income-guarantee provision is carried over to Ford, it could cost that company about $1.4 billion. Ford, however, streamlined its work force several years before GM and might have smaller obligations. The story might be significantly different when the talks shift to Chrysler Corp., possibly by the end of the month. Chrysler is in the worst financial shape by far of the Big Three and has said the GM agreement seems expensive. Later this month, Chrysler is expected to report what could be a third-quarter loss of more than $200 million. The Big Three contracts cover about 463,000 workers in all. The contracts expired Sept. 14, but their terms were extended while talks continued.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Interest Rate Cut Won't Avert Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires; should stand.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve will cut interest rates in support of the deficit-reduction package, but the amount of the decline is likely to disappoint the Bush administration and not be enough to keep the country out of a recession, private economists predict. These analysts said rising inflationary pressures from a doubling of oil prices will severely limit the Fed's maneuvering room despite administration contentions that interest rates need to fall swiftly in order to stave off an economic slump. The Fed's top policymakers gathered in Washington today for a key meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, or FOMC. The panel, composed of Fed board members in Washington and Fed regional presidents, meets eight times a year to map the course of interest rates. While the results of the closed-door deliberations are not released for six weeks, many economists said they expected a vote by the FOMC to nudge short-term interest rates down by one-fourth of a percentage point. For his part, President Bush on Monday reminded the Federal Reserve of his keen interest in seeing lower interest rates and he predicted that the weekend budget deal, once enacted by Congress, would trigger rate declines. ``I would look to the Federal Reserve to lower the rates ... once they see that a sound budget agreement has been put into effect,'' Bush told reporters in New York. Both the administration and congressional negotiators are hoping to complete action on the budget cuts and tax increases by Oct. 19, although the legislative outcome was far from certain. Many analysts said final passage of the deficit-cutting package would likely be the trigger for Fed rate cuts, although some said the reduction could come sooner, especially if Friday's report on the unemployment situation for September shows widespread weakness. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan has pledged several times to support a credible deficit reduction package, indicating that the central bank would move to offset the negative effects of lower government spending and higher taxes by reducing interest rates. ``Greenspan has got to ease. If he doesn't, he is telling the financial markets that he doesn't view the deficit agreement as credible,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI-McGraw Hill. But Wyss and other economists said they were not looking for much more than a 0.25 percentage point drop in the federal funds rate. The rate, now 8 percent, is the interest that banks charge each other on overnight loans. Some economists said that while small, a 0.25 percentage point drop would likely prod commercial banks to lower their benchmark prime lending rate to 9.5 percent. The prime rate, which is used as the base for setting many consumer and business loans, has been at 10 percent since January. Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co., said markets should not expect anything beyond a small easing move on the Fed's part because of the rising inflationary pressures buffeting the U.S. economy. ``The Fed is being tossed back and forth by the Iraqi event,'' Sinai said. ``It wants to ease because of an impending recession, but aggressive easing is very hard to do as long as the inflation threat is as great as it is.'' Sinai and other economists said they viewed a recession starting this year as all but inevitable despite the Fed's belated move to lower interest rates. ``The handwriting is on the wall. The Fed has already waited too long if it had hoped to avoid a recession,'' said David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. Jones said he was looking for the first downturn since the 1981-82 slump to begin in the next three months and to last for a full year. Many analysts said they looked for further rate cuts by the Fed early next year as the extent and severity of the recession become known. An economic downturn would call into question the economic assumptions underlying the new budget agreement and make the agreement's deficit=cutting goals that much harder to obtain. The administration's new forecast predicts the overall economy, as measured by the gross national product, will grow by 1.3 percent in 1991, nearly double the 0.7 percent GNP rate forecast for this year. But economists noted that the economic outlook was based on an assumption that oil prices will average $24.15 per barrel in 1991, far lower than current average of nearly $40 per barrel.

DOC.HEAD: Global Economies Would Be Casualty With Direct Hit on Oilfields
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to reflect market rebounds of last two days. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `So what...'. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: For global economies, an empty barrel of oil can be as scary as the loaded barrel of a gun. No shots have been exchanged yet in the Persian Gulf, but war jitters have nearly doubled the price of crude oil to almost $40 a barrel since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. In New York, the stock market fell 15 percent to its lowest point in 16 months before rebounding somewhat Monday after the federal budget compromise was reached. The Tokyo market is even worse, plummeting about one-third and reaching a level below that of the 1987 crash before regaining part of the loss today. In London, stocks are down about more than 10 percent. So what happens if the real thing breaks out and bullets start flying in the world's richest oilfields? What if Iraqi missiles strike pipelines, pumping stations, oil ports or tankers in Saudi Arabia? What if poison gas or germ warfare scatters oilfield workers? ``It is not just thousands of lives that are at stake in a shooting war. There is a risk of a real cataclysm for the global economy,'' said Christopher Flavin, vice president of research at Worldwatch Institute, a policy research organization. Worldwatch's projected casualty list means worldwide gas rationing, the financial collapse of developing countries, outright failure of the economic reforms in Eastern Europe and a severe shock to the world banking system. Many experts believe doomsday anxieties are unfounded because Iraq is unlikely to knock out Saudi exports. The Iraqis repeatedly tried but failed to cripple Iran's Kharg Island loading terminal in an eight-year war, and Iran had nothing resembling the U.S.-led, high-tech shield protecting Saudi Arabia. But Iraq has vowed to fight ``the mother of all battles.'' The Strait of Hormuz could become choked with mines, terrorists could unleash hit squads and kamikaze pilots could fly missions against oil terminals or tankers. And even though Iran fought a bloody war with Iraq, Iranians are again shouting ``Death to America,'' so who knows what they might do? Grab the financial flak jackets. The World Bank estimates a shooting war would boost oil prices to $65 a barrel. Worldwatch said war could bring $80 prices, and the former Saudi oil minister among others said it might even hit $100. Superexpensive oil would trigger a financial chain reaction. The immediate spike could mean gas pump prices of $2.50 a gallon or higher, soaring electric bills and higher airline fares. Prices would climb on oil-based products such as plastics, pharmaceuticals, synthetic clothing and asphalt. There would also be the likely double whammy of recession. The United States, the world's biggest oil user, has 6 percent of the world's population and 3 percent of its oil reserves but consumes 26 percent of its oil. In a pinch, people are less likely to make major purchases such as cars, houses, major appliances and discretionary clothing. ``A shooting war hits the consumer section very hard,'' said Roger Brinner, chief economist for DRI-McGraw Hill. ``There's a double blow to the economy from oil price shocks: the direct hit of weaker purchasing power and a confidence shock. ``We were near a recession. We didn't need another shove in that direcion,'' Brinner said. One other nasty effect of recession is joblessness. ``Saddam Hussein is going to throw a lot of people out of work,'' said Joel Popkin, a consultant and inflation expert in Washington. Popkin figures that every $10 increase in the price of a barrel of oil means a 1 percent increase in the consumer price index just in higher fuel costs, plus another 1 percent over six to nine months in ripple effects. ``If the conflict is protracted without a definite conclusion, oil prices are likely to stay around $40 for a year,'' Popkin said. ``The country would definitely be cast into a recession of some magnitude, not just a shallow dip.'' Complicating matters are budget and trade deficits, the savings and loan bailout and shaky banking. Edwin Rothchild of Citizen Action, a Washington consumer group, said of the aftershocks of a shooting war: ``You're talking about stag-flation of enormous proportions. It's going to be a disaster worldwide.'' Two oil shocks in the 1970s caused gas lines, hoarding, limited rationing and trucker discontent. But the United States is more dependent than ever on foreign oil. It imports half its daily consumption of 16 million barrels a day. One-fourth of the imports come from the Persian Gulf, a powderkeg atop two-thirds of the world's oil reserves. Sixty-four percent of Japan's oil and 42 percent of Europe's oil, excluding Great Britain, comes from there. There is one buffer: a 590 million barrel reserve in salt caverns of Louisiana and Texas, which President Bush has tapped to calm jitters. The reserve equals 73 days of all imports. Japan also has an oil reserve and has done a much better job since the 1973 embargo. Virtually all the country's energy is imported, but it has reduced its dependency on oil for energy from 77 percent to 57 percent by developing nuclear power and conserving. Japan is the most efficient energy user among developed countries, according to one Western analyst. The United States uses 2.5 times the commercial energy per person than Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Apple, Sony Discuss Expanding Ties
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer and Sony Corp. are discussing ways to expand their business ties, a move which analysts expect will lead to a strong alliance between the two divergent high-tech companies. Officials from the two firms, however, refused Tuesday to confirm reports that they are negotiating an agreement for Sony to make personal computers in Japan to be marketed under Apple's name. A Sony official confirmed that the companies were engaged in talks but said final details on the products and production volumes were not yet decided. Sony now produces computer disk drives and displays for Apple. At a board meeting held in Tokyo last week, Apple Chief Executive Officer John Sculley told reporters that his company is seeking further ties with Japanese firms as it tries to expand its still limited presence in the Japanese market. Apple was particularly interested in miniaturization, Sculley said. He also said his firm lacked a low-priced, portable book-size computer in its product line. Book-size computers are one of the fastest growing segments of Japan's computer market. Sony, known best for its audio-visual and electronics devices, has been unsuccessful in its attempt to break into the personal computer market, said Darrel E. Whitten, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. A tie with Apple could give it access to the American company's advanced multimedia computing expertise and an opportunity to study programming, he said. In turn, ``Apple's achilles' heel has been its manufacturers' cost, and an agreement with Sony would give it greater control,'' he said. Chuck Goto, a technology analyst for S.G. Warburg Securities (Japan), said computer hardware makers such as Apple have become more dependent on integrated circuit technology, one of Sony's strengths. The Japanese company also could offer experience in converting analog to digital processes, he said.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Limiting TV Commercials On Kids' Shows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House has sent legislation to President Bush that would reinstate limits on commercial advertising on children's television shows. The Bush administration opposes the legislation, saying it would ``create new and extremely serious First Amendment problems'' involving free speech. The bill was approved on voice vote Monday in the House without dissent. It also has been approved by the Senate. The legislation would limit commercial advertising during children's programming to 10{ minutes an hour on weekends and 12 minutes an hour on weekdays. Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., said too many stations now allow for 13 minutes to 17 minutes of advertising during each hour of children's programming. The bill also would require the Federal Communications Commission, in renewing the licenses of television stations, to weigh how well broadcasters are serving the educational and informational needs of children. And it would establish a federally funded National Endowment for Children's Educational Television to subsidize the production of children's programming. The endowment would be funded at $2 million in 1991 and $4 million the next year. The legislation would effectively reverse the Reagan administration's deregulation of the commercial content of children's TV programming in 1984. Similar legislation was passed by both the House and Senate two years ago, but it was vetoed by President Reagan after Congress had adjourned. ``The limits which we propose are reasonable,'' said Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas. ``I trust the support of various groups will persuade our president that this bill fits into his program as a kinder and gentler president who responds to family concerns.'' The House Energy and Commerce Committee estimates that the average child spends 10,000 to 15,000 hours in front of a television - more time than in school - and is exposed to more than 200,000 TV commercials by the time he or she reaches age 18. Prior to the FCC's deregulation in 1984, broadcasters had followed industry guidelines limiting ads in children's programming to 9{ minutes an hour on weekends and 12 minutes an hour on weekdays. Proponents said the commercial restrictions are necessary because many children are unable to discriminate between ads and programs until they reach the age of 4 or 5 and are unable to recognize an advertising pitch as such until they are 7 or 8.

DOC.HEAD: Soft Drink Giant Buys Into Big Mexican Cookie Maker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to restore dropped word `international.' Picks up third graf, `The Mexican . . .'
DOC.TEXT: PepsiCo Inc. said Tuesday it has bought more than 70 percent of Empresas Gamesa for about $300 million, giving the big U.S. beverage and snack foods maker a majority stake in Mexico's largest cookie manufacturer. The acquisition is PepsiCo's second largest international food acquisition ever. It ranks behind the 1989 purchase of two British snack chip makers, Smiths Crisps and Walkers Crisps, for $1.35 billion from the French company, BSN. The Mexican snack food subsidiary of PepsiCo, Sabritas SA de CV, made the acquisition by buying over 70 percent of the outstanding stock of Empresas Gamesa, which is a holding company that owns 68 percent of Grupo Gamesa, Mexico's major cookie company. The shares of Empresas Gamesa stock not bought by PepsiCo are publicly held. ``We were attracted to this opportunity for making a significant investment . . . by Mexico's considerable economic progress and its government's commitment to free market policies,'' said Wayne Calloway, chairman and chief executive officer of PepsiCo. Michael H. Jordan, president and chief executive officer of PepsiCo's worldwide food operations, said PepsiCo plans to invest more than $200 million in Gamesa and Sabritas over the next five years as the two businesses expand their penetration further into the Mexican snack foods market. Together, Gamesa and Sabritas will have annual sales of almost $1 billion. PepsiCo, which has operations in 160 countries, has had a major presence in Mexico for many years. It employs more than 14,000 people in that ountry, where its soft drinks have been manufacturered and sold for over 50 years. PepsiCo's Pizza Hut and Kentucky Fried Chicken businesses have been in Mexico for more than 20 years.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 359.97 up 5.32 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Fall Further in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices slid further this morning as traders kept betting on the possibility of peace in the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude was down $1.17 to $35.92 per barrel for November contracts in late morning trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for crude delivery in later months also traded lower. Energy analyst Thomas Blakeslee of Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J., said today's move down was a continuation of the sharp decline Monday, when oil fell by more than $2 per barrel. Traders sold oil on the belief that antagonists in the Middle East standoff were offering hints of a diplomatic solution to the Gulf crisis. Traders said increased OPEC production and the U.S. decision to tap its strategic reserve have also helped push prices lower. ``People are starting to realize that actual supply levels aren't any lower than they were a year ago, or before the crisis,'' Blakeslee said. As crude fell, refined petroleum products also traded lower this morning. Home heating oil dropped 1.68 cents to 98.35 cents a gallon for November delivery, while unleaded gasoline was off 1.31 cents to 92.60 cents per gallon for November delivery. Later contract months were lower for heating oil and gasoline. Natural gas was 2.1 cents higher, at $1.930 per 1,000 cubic feet on November contracts. Later delivery months were trading lower.

At first the market was depressed by continued selling from yesterday's lows, which pushed futures prices lower as traders worried about weak export demand and near-ideal harvest temperatures. But new forecasts of wetter-than-normal conditions in the Midwest over the new six to 10 days pushed soybean and corn futures prices higher because it may slow harvesting. DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with Xerox announcement
DOC.HEAD: Xerox Gambles on Machine That Copies, Faxes, Scans
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. today announced a new product intended to revolutionize the office as much as the modern copying machine it introduced 31 years ago. The new machine is a combination high-quality printer, image scanner and fax machine that costs $220,000 and is aimed at large corporations, universities and other businesses that produce numerous documents. Xerox says the machine, called the DocuTech Production Publisher, will replace offset printing presses and save companies time and money in producing forms, reports and other documents. However, a model that will allow the DocuTech to connect to desktop computers will not be available until the second half of next year, disappointing some industry analysts. Nancy Erskine, an analyst at the research firm Gartner Group Inc., in Stamford, Conn., said companies will need the networked version of the machine to truly take advantage of its features. Also, many companies lack the wiring between desktop machines that would be necessary for them to connect with DocuTech, she said. Xerox predicts a huge market for DocuTech and says it already has tested the machine at 28 companies and universities. Xerox said creation of DocuTech is a bid to put the copying machine at the center of computer networks, even though it will be next year before that can happen. Xerox calls the machine its most important development since it introduced the automatic, plain paper copier in 1959. Once the entire system is released, the souped-up copier would allow computer users to push a button and order up magazine-quality reproductions of a 50-page computerized report or to fax a document to another computer user. In addition, the machine can electronically ``scan in'' paper documents that then could be stored in a computer or manipulated on a computer screen. The device is considered a gamble by Xerox, which has been disappointed in the past by making technological breakthroughs only to lose the market for them to competitors. For example, Xerox invented the personal computer, the ``user-friendly'' graphical software to run it and the computer control device called the ``mouse,'' only to see them enrich competitors who marketed them better. Eugene Glazer, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the research on DocuTech cost hundreds of millions of dollars. ``The people that have seen it are very impressed,'' he said. But, he added, the market potential for the expensive device is uncertain, especially in light of the sluggish economy. DocuTech represents an entry by Xerox into the fledging market for ``imaging'' systems, which scan paper documents and photographs to turn them into computer language that can be stored electronically in much less space.

DOC.HEAD: GE Blames Economy For Appliance Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. officials said they plan to lay off 450 to 500 hourly workers at its appliance manufacturing complex in Louisville by Jan. 2 because of the nation's softening economy. Company spokesman Jim Allen said the economy has forced a change in GE's sales forecast for the rest of this year and for 1991. Allen said the economy would have to make an unlikely turnaround to forestall the job cuts. ``We're looking at a major appliance industry finishing this year 3 to 5 percent down, and falling off another 3 to 5 percent in 1991,'' Allen said Monday. Housing starts, at their lowest level in several years, are a key reason for the sluggishness, he said. Consumer polls indicate fewer people expect to buy such durable goods as the refrigerators, ranges, washers, dryers and dishwashers produced at the company's Appliance Park plant. Allen said the appliance division's sales already have begun to bear out that pessimistic forecast. ``They're starting to drop off,'' he said. ``This is not just a thing we're forecasting. We're experiencing it.'' Allen said employment at Appliance Park is now about 10,800 - 8,800 hourly and 2,000 salaried. That is just under half of its peak employment, which was about 22,000 in 1973. Much of the plant's business is tied directly to the housing industry, and rises and falls with it.

DOC.HEAD: Guinness Judge Rejects Tycoon's Appeal of Fine
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Tuesday rejected Gerald Ronson's appeal of his $9.2 million fine in the Guinness scandal case, saying rich men must not be beyond punishment of the law. Justice Denis Henry rejected Ronson's claim that the fine, the largest in British history, was too great and could not be paid in nine months as the court demanded. Ronson, 51, was found guilty last month, along with former Guinness chairman Ernest Saunders and stockbroker Anthony Parnes, of fraudulently engineering Guinness' 1986 takeover of a Scottish distiller. ``Punishments are, after all, intended to be punitive, and the court must ensure that a man's wealth and power does not put him beyond punishment,'' the judge said at a hearing. Ronson, 51, will have another chance to appeal the fine through the Appeal Court. Saunders, 55, was sentenced to five years in prison and Parnes, 45, received 2{ years in jail for their part in the case, which involved boosting Guinness shares during the company's takeover of the firm Distillers. Saunder and Parnes are also appealing their fines.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Address Nation on Budget Tonight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: EDITS thruout; no pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he would give a televised address to the nation at 9 p.m. EDT tonight to press his case for a $500 billion deficit-cutting package. Bush announced the speech himself at a meeting with a group of business leaders as the White House launched a major effort to sell the bipartisan package unveiled on Sunday. Earlier, he met with a group of skeptical and undecided Republican House members. Some participants at the meeting said that several lawmakers urged Bush to give a televised address to the nation. ``This budget agreement is our last best chance to get the federal budget deficit under control,'' Bush told the business leaders. ``You can pick the package apart, but you cannot realistically put a better package together.'' Bush said it was important for ``Congress to act and act soon on this vital legislation.'' ``I don't want to sound sanctimonious about this, but I was elected to govern,'' he said. The White House said Bush's speech to the nation would last about 10 minutes. Although Bush campaigned against new taxes and for a lower capital gains tax rate, he said, ``the philosophy I was elected on runs out of gas in terms of votes in the United States Congress.'' Earlier, lawmakers who met with the president said that deep divisions remain in Congress on the measure. ``I'm undecided. So's the nation,'' said Rep. Robert Dornan, R-Calif, after the first of three sessions between Bush and GOP lawmakers. Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., said Bush had not changed his mind and he still was likely to vote against the package. But Rep. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., said he was persuaded by the president to support the package. ``It's the only ball game in town,'' he said. ``If this goes down, you're going to see chaos,'' he said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that some Republicans up for re-election told the president that supporting the package ``will be tough. But they promised to consider it.'' ``It has opposition,'' he conceded. ``We need time to work it.'' Fitzwater said that for all Americans, the proposed agreement ``is paying the bills. And paying the bills is never fun.'' Fitzwater earlier said that Bush would make a strong pitch for the bipartisan budget accord unveiled over the weekend. ``We'll be talking in very strong terms to all the members about how important this is,'' Fitzwater said. ``He's going to be twisting arms and cajoling and telling people that if you are not supportive of this, we ask you to take another look and think anew,'' Fitzwater said. In its two-day life span, the plan has drawn barbs from lawmakers - Democrats and Republicans - wary of voting for a record amount of tax increases and spending cuts in an election year. Fitzwater also said Bush also planned to give speeches around the country in the coming weeks. ``He'll be all over the place,'' Fitzwater said. ``The president will go to the nation, he will go around the country in one speech after another and lay out what's in this package,'' Fitzwater said. Missing from the list of those invited to the White House today was one of the most outspoken critics of the compromise, House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga. However, Fitzwater said that nothing should be read into the fact that Gingrich's name had been omitted. Bush already talked to Gingrich, the spokesman said, ``and we'll talk to him again.'' ``We're talking to everybody,'' Fitzwater said. ``There are a lot of people who disagree with this, a lot of people have trouble with it and they need to be convinced. And we're doing our best.'' ``The deficit must be dealt with and it's not an easy fix,'' Fitzwater said. ``Everybody knew this deficit-reduction agreement was an ugly duckling,'' said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. ``Nobody expected it to sprout wings and fly like a swan.'' But Bush put an optimistic face on prospects of approval. ``It will all work out. Everybody will do what's right,'' he told reporters. Congressional leaders planned a series of votes over the next three weeks to etch the compromise plan into law. But reluctance to support the package comes from members of both parties. Rpublicans are leery of its $134 billion in new taxes on gasoline, alcohol, tobacco, airline tickets, incomes of the wealthy and other items. They also complained that defense cuts of up to $182 billion were too deep and that domestic programs were not pared enough. Numerous Democrats don't like the package's $105 billion in spending reductions for benefit programs such as Medicare and the fact that many of the taxes - such as those on gasoline and alcohol - take a deep bite out of poor peoples' incomes. And lawmakers of both parties from cold-weather states are furious over the plan's inclusion of a tax on home heating oil. Sensing that lawmakers would be more willing to embrace the plan if it was supported by the public, congressional Democrats called Monday for Bush to take to the airwaves to sell it to the voters. ``We've put together the pain,'' said Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., who was one of the bargainers during four months of budget negotiations this year. ``Now it's his job.''

DOC.HEAD: Lower Target Prices Seen as Part of Budget Accord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3 grafs for 17th graf pvs, Loan rates, to explain loan rates; also moved for PMs and on general news wires; stands for AM-Farm Scene.
DOC.TEXT: Farmers should prepare themselves for lower target prices, as Congress looks for ways to cut the agriculture budget by $13 billion over the next five years, farm organization officials say. Government officials said Monday that the cuts would be painful, although no one could give details yet on how the cut agreed to by White House and congressional negotiators to reduce the deficit would be accomplished. ``We want the target prices to stay at the current levels, but it would be difficult, if not impossible, to make the magnitude of cuts they have to make without doing something on the target prices,'' said Don Lipton, media relations director for the American Farm Bureau Federation. ``They said they were going to freeze target prices, (but) there's no way with this budget agreement that can happen,'' said David Senter, national director of American Agriculture Movement. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, who helped negotiate the agreement said ``agriculture has taken a tough hit.'' ``Any cut in USDA's budget is painful for our farmers and ranchers,'' said Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. ``However, we have no oter alternative as a country but to reduce our federal budget deficit.'' Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said: ``We will all have to make deep and painful cuts in many important programs to pay for a deficit caused by the S&L scandal and the freewheeling economic policies and tax giveaways of the 1980s.'' ``Unfortunately, the people who had the party aren't the ones paying the tab,'' said Leahy. Yeutter said farmers would be willing to take their share of the cuts as long as they are fair. ``In the short run, these budget reductions, coupled with rising fuel costs will squeeze agriculture hard,'' he said. ``We will have to tighten our belts, and that is not easily done. But in the long run, we will all be better off if we can restore fiscal sanity to this nation.'' The cuts ``will be as fair as possible,'' said Leahy, who also chairs the House-Senate conference committee working on the 1990 farm bill. The farm bills approved by the House and Senate call for $54 billion in spending on commodities subsidies over the next five years. Under the budget agreement, that figure must be cut 25 percent, with about $1.3 billion coming out of the budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which began Monday. The problem this year is that all but about $2.92 billion of the amount budgeted for fiscal 1991 is payment on expenses carried over from 1990 that cannot be eliminated. That means it might be back to the drawing board on commodity support programs in the farm bill, said several aides close to the process. ``We don't want to see target prices dropped, but we'd rather see target prices go down than loan rates go up,'' said Lipton of the Farm Bureau. Loan rates are the amount farmers can borrow from the government by using their crops as collateral. Thus, the loans are a support or a guaranteed floor price for the commodities. Farmers have the option of forfeiting their crops - collateral - and canceling the debt if market prices are low, or paying off the loan and selling or using the commodities when market prices improve. The administration and others favoring market-oriented programs, say high loan rates result in government ownership of surplus commodities that should be moving into export at world prices. Lipton said the agriculture industry as a whole won't suffer extremely if cuts are made. It's not as dependent on government programs as it was in the mid-80s, he said. Lipton said many farmers no longer participate in government programs, either because their farms are so big, they can sustain themselves even when market prices are low or because they are smaller, speciality operations. However, Leland Swenson, president of National Farmers Union, said the $13 billion slash in USDA programs would ``throw the farm sector into a tailspin.'' ``Farmers are facing disastrous grain prices, higher input costs as the result of oil prices, and now $13 billion in cuts that will come directly out of farm income under the 1990 farm bill structure,'' Swenson said. ``You've got some new variables to work with now. The Mideast situation, falling wheat prices and now budget cuts have all come to roost since the farm bill passed the two houses,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Names Seattle Best Place to Establish a Business
With AM-Top Cities-List
DOC.TEXT: In the eyes of corporate executives, the Northwest's biggest city is the best place in the nation to locate a business, elbowing out Atlanta for the top spot in an annual survey. About one-third of the 400 executives polled ranked Seattle as ``excellent,'' citing quality of life for employees and the likelihood that economic conditions will improve over the next year. Seattle finished second last year behind Atlanta in the survey by the commercial real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield. Atlanta dropped to sixth this year. ``I don't know whether we thought we'd stay No. 1 forever,'' said Roy Cooper, vice president of economic development for the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce. Atlanta had held the survey's top spot for the first four years the survey was conducted. Second place in this year's survey went to Sacramento, Calif., which was 15th last year, while Portland, Ore., moved up from 27th place to third. Rounding out the top 10 were Norfolk, Va., San Diego, Atlanta, Columbus, Ohio, Dallas-Fort Worth, Minneapolis-St. Paul and Tampa, Fla. Texas and other ``oil-patch'' cities made sizeable jumps in the survey. In addition to Dallas-Fort Worth, which was 17th last year, cities moving up the scale were San Antonio (11th from 22nd), Houston (15th from 26th), Denver (17th from 28th), and New Orleans (22nd from 31st). Houston, Dallas-Fort Worth, Denver and San Antonio all made the top five list of where CEOs believe general business conditions will improve in the next 12 months, Cushman & Wakefield said. By contrast, heavily populated and industrialized cities showed significant drops in the survey. Baltimore fell from 10th place to 27th, Chicago from fourth to 14th, Los Angeles from ninth to 20th, New York from 12th to 28th, Philadelphia from 18th to 30th and Washington from 11th to 21st. The cities tended to score poorly on quality of life. Cities were rated on access to markets and customers, the cost and availability of labor, cost and expandability of office space, availability of manufacturing sites with existing services, access to raw materials and the governmental climate. Seattle finished first in quality of life. It also was praised for a skilled labor force and access to Canadian and Pacific Rim trade. Seattle's access to international air and water shipping gives it an advantage over other cities, said Robert Fulton, president of Generic Software. However, he and others said labor shortages in certain skill classifications have created some problems. ``A lot of things are being done in remedying that situation,'' Fulton said. Despite those shortages, the region's labor costs are still considered good, said Reidun Crowley, manager of community and economic development at Puget Sound Power & Light, said of the business survey. ``People do want to come here and quality of life has a lot to do with that,'' he said. Seattle also fared well in a recent Money Magazine survey of the nation's most livable cities, ranking second behind its neighbor across Puget Sound, Bremerton, Wash. Asked to select American cities outside the top 31 that are attractive for business, the CEOs most often cited Charlotte, N.C., which earned the distinction for the fourth year in a row. Other cities that scored high in that category were Raleigh-Durham, N.C., Orlando, Fla., and Nashville, Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: Grains and Soybeans Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: Grains and soybeans closed higher Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, recovering from sharp losses a day earlier as harvest pressures eased amid forecasts of rain and reports of new export sales. Grain and soybeans futures prices opened lower on follow-through selling from Monday but quickly reversed on updated forecasts predicting rain in the regions where they are grown, analysts said. ``There were new forecasts of rains coming in over the next couple of days,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. ``Plus, there was a smattering of support from export business - some countries tendering small amounts for supplies.'' Traders in the past week have been worried about slow export demand in the face of a possible record grains and soybean harvest and near-ideal harvesting temperatures. An outlook for wetter-than-normal conditions in the Midwest and the Cornbelt over the next six to 10 days pushed soybean and corn futures prices higher because the rain may slow harvesting. Wheat futures prices also rose on spillover support from the other two markets. At the close, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 4{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.71} a bushel; corn was 2\ cents to 3\ cents higher with December at $2.25\ a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 3} cents higher with December at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 6{ cents higher with November at $6.07{ a bushel.

DOC.TEXT: These controversial choice and reproduction issues already have been debated in court, with conflicting rulings. This year, the California Supreme Court upheld a ruling against Johnson in which a lower court said, in part: ``We are in an era of choice. A woman is not required to become a Victorian brood mare.'' But in 1989, the 7th Circuit Court of Appeals supported Johnson, saying it is ``reasonably necessary to the industrial safety-based concern of protecting the unborn child from lead exposure.'' Judge Frank Easterbrook dissented in that ruling, being appealed to the high court. He called it likely the most important sex-discrimination case since the 1964 enactment of Title VII, which barred sexual bias in employment. Some business leaders say the potential impact is exaggerated, but Mrs. Seymore disagrees. ``I'm not fighting only for me,'' she said. ``This is for all women.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Sharon Cohen is the AP's Midwest regional reporter, based in Chicago.
