DOC.HEAD: Saturn TV Ads Pop Up in Southeast, California
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. has begun pitching its new Saturn car to the public, in an effort to increase its visibility before it finally hits the road. Commercials produced by Hal Riney & Partners of San Francisco began airing last week during prime news and late-night slots in the Southeast and California. ``Basically, we're trying to sell the Saturn story ahead of the product,'' said Donald Hudler, Saturn vice president of sales, service and marketing. The Saturn is an important development for GM, the nation's No. 1 automaker, which made the car to win back a chunk of the market lost to Japanese competitors. The project has been shrouded in secrecy since its inception eight years ago. Originally introduced as a boxlike subcompact car to sell for $6,000 to $8,000, it now has more interior room, more features and will sell for $10,000 to $12,000. It's slated to be introduced on Oct. 25. Six spots showing Saturn and employees from its $1.9 billion Spring Hill, Tenn., plant will air for several weeks. GM hopes the ads will make the car more popular. ``Very few people - other than in Tennessee and Detroit - know about Saturn,'' said Pat Sherwood, vice president and group account director for Hal Riney. One survey showed only 1 percent of Saturn's target group could name the car without prompting. ``(The first commercials) are directed at telling people the values and philosophies of Saturn and the things that make Saturn as a company unique and how those things will make Saturn a better car,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stampede To Stock Wine Cellar, Buy Diamonds To Beat New Tax
DOC.TEXT: Mercedes-Benz dealer Ray Latka says customers have begun pestering him to rush their orders through. One connoisseur plans to stock his wine cellar, while a spirits merchant is struggling to hold down the price of Dom Perignon champagne. Everybody who's anybody is trying to find ways to cope with upcoming tax increases on luxury goods. Merchants who cater to the carriage trade complain that the government's proposal to hike taxes on big-ticket items - including expensive cars, yachts, jewelry and furs, as well as wine and liquor - discriminates against their well-heeled clientele. Though they protest, many are bracing themselves for a flurry of sales as customers weigh the costs and benefits of putting an extra case of champagne or a pair of sapphire earrings on their tabs for the upcoming holidays. The taxes, if approved, could begin taking effect Jan. 1 as part of a federal budget agreement reached over the weekend. ``In all likelihood there will be a measurable increase in the sales of jewelry above $5,000 before the end of the year simply because buyers will recognize that such items will cost more next year,'' Ralph Destino, chairman of Cartier Inc., said Tuesday. For jewelry, plans call for a 10 percent tax on the amount over $5,000. That means buyers would pay $6,100 for a diamond brooch that sells for $6,000 today. ``Historically there has always been an upward blip on the eve of any new tax increase,'' Destino said. David H. Resler, chief economistat Nomura Securities International Inc., plans to ``stock my wine cellar for the next three years,'' adding that consumers might stock up on easy-to-store items. For Home Liquors Inc., the pickup in sales was ``pretty significant'' when higher taxes took effect in New Jersey in the 1980s, said Bill Kenny, who manages the company's Astor Wines & Spirits store in Manhattan. The government wants to raise the tax on wine by 22 cents a bottle and boost the tax on a bottle of 80-proof liquor by 24 cents. But Kenny said that just because the tax goes up, ``at the retail level there will be discretion over whether we want to increase'' prices. The price of Dom Perignon, a top-of-the-line champagne that sells for $810 a case, ``is just too crucial to raise,'' he said, particularly at holiday time when corporations and wealthy individuals buy clusters of cases at a time. Kenny envisions ``tremendous work'' ahead since he will have to decide on an individual basis whether to raise the price on a line of wine or liquor or whether the store will cut its profit to keep prices attractive to customers. Because many luxury goods are imported, their price is also dictated by the value of the dollar, which has taken a hit this year against most foreign currencies. A year ago, Kenny said, a case of Dom Perignon sold for ``somewhere in the $700s.'' At Continental Motors Inc., a Mercedes-Benz dealership in suburban Fairfield, Conn., salesman Latka said several customers want him to rush their orders through to make sure they beat the increase, even though it could be modified. When Connecticut raised taxes by a half a percentage point a few years ago, Latka said Mercedes sales jumped 20 percent, and that could happen again. The average price of a Mercedes-Benz is $50,000, making it liable to the proposed tax, which hits the amount of the purchase price in excess of $30,000. ``This is something very much biased against luxury cars,'' Latka said. But he said the decision to buy a Mercedes is probably based more on the fortunes of the stock market than the level of taxes. The tax increase is not expected do much to bolster furriers, who have been suffering from weak sales amid a lackluster economy and a publicity campaign waged by anti-fur activists. Furthermore, most furriers contend that a decent fur can be had for about $5,000 while the tax only applies to the amount above that level. ``You can find a lot of good things at that price,'' said Tony Marinakos of Marinakos Furs in Beverly Hills, Calif. Very stylish mink, linx and sable coats, though, generally sell for about $10,000.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Mixed As Profit-Taking Sets In
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed mixed on Wall Street today as nervous traders took their profits late in the day and ended the market's broad advance. Prices were higher - with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing as much as 49 points - until early afternoon as the stock market responded to another plunge in oil futures prices. The November contract for light, sweet crude skidded $3.14 to $33.95 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, following a plunge of $2.42 a barrel Monday. A decline in energy costs eases the threat of higher inflation and increases the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will allow interest rates to fall. Analysts also attributed today's early advance to ``follow-through'' buying after Monday's rally in which the Dow Jones average soared more than 63 points. But traders feared the market might resume its recent bearish course and began to take profits from the two-day advance while they could. Stock prices also surged in Tokyo early today, with the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues climbing 2,676.55 points, or 13.24 percent, to 22,898.41. The gain, the index's largest one-day advance, helped set a positive tone on Wall Street, analysts said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor Ordered to Pay $3.8 Million in Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: A manufacturer of the Army's main tactical field radio was ordered Tuesday to pay $3.8 million for conspiring to defraud the government on defense contracts by falsifying reliability test results. E-Systems Inc. of Dallas received the sentence from U.S. District Judge William Terrell Hodges after formally pleading guilty to a three-count criminal information. Prosecutors charged the company repeatedly altered performance records and concealed repairs and defects in tests of the field radios to ensure the Army would accept and pay for them. The investigation began in 1985 after the Army ended two E-Systems contracts to build radios at its Memcor Division in Bushnell. The company had been building the Army's principal vehicle-carried field radios since 1969. E-Systems appealed the termination, and the testing program irregularities were noticed at that time. The company later sued the government over the termination. In its plea, E-Systems agreed to pay a $2 million criminal fine and $1.8 million in restitution. The company also is to drop its pending $38 million lawsuit against the government. In addition, the company will pay $850,000 to cover any potential civil claims the government may bring. In August, three former managers and a former supervisor at Memcor were indicted on charges of repeatedly falsifying records and test results to conceal failures and defects in the radios. In January, a front-line production supervisor, Sadonna S. Hobbs, was convicted of perjury relating to her denials of this activity. She is serving a 16-month prison sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Metals Post Dramatic Gains
DOC.TEXT: Precious metals posted an impressive turnaround from weeks of sharp loss Tuesday amid gains on the Japanese stock market and new confidence in the U.S. economy, analysts said. On other commodity markets, energy futures extended their decline; grains and soybeans were higher; cattle futures were lower; and pork futures were sharply higher. Platinum had the strongest gains, followed by gold and silver. Platinum on the New York Mercantile Exchange settled $16.80 to $17.20 higher with the contract for delivery in October at $443.60. Gold settled $1.60 to $2.50 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with October at $389.10 a troy ounce. Silver settled 3.3 cents to 3.9 cents higher with October at $4.68 an ounce. Silver and platinum were long overdue to rebound from sharp losses and rose amid new perceptions that the crisis in the Middle East might be settled through diplomatic means, analysts said. ``Crude oil declined sharply, so today's economy looked a little better and people moved their money to safety,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, senior metals analyst with Prduential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. ``The rally in Japan also meant they had more money to buy metals.'' Speculators turn toward precious metals during a strong economy period because of inflationary fears. A weaker dollar supported the gains, analysts said, but added they could be quickly lost if crude oil prices rise during escalating tensions in the Persian Gulf. Energy futures prices extended their slide after traders speculated that President Bush's speech Monday at the United Nation means there may be room for talks on the Middle East crisis. Light sweet crude oil settled $3.14 to $1.30 lower with November at $33.95 a barrel; heating oil was 8 cents to 4 cents lower with November at 92.03 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 6.98 cents to 4 cents lower with November at 86.93 cents a gallon. Grains and soybeans closed higher on the Chicago Board of Trade, recovering from sharp losses a day earlier as harvest pressures eased amid forecasts of rain and reports of new export sales. Grain and soybeans futures prices opened lower on follow-through selling from Monday but quickly reversed on updated forecasts predicting rain in the regions where they are grown, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Deparmtent Inc. ``There were new forecasts of rains coming in over the next couple of days,'' Karlin said. ``Plus, there was a smattering of support from export business - some countries tendering small amounts for supplies.'' Traders in the past week have been worried about slow export demand in the face of a possible record grains and soybean harvest and near-ideal harvesting temperatures. An outlook for wetter-than-normal conditions in the Midwest and the Cornbelt over the next six to 10 days pushed soybean and corn futures prices higher because harvesting may be slowed. Wheat futures prices also rose on spillover support from the other two markets. Wheat futures settld 2{ cents to 5 cents higher with December at $2.72\ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 2} cents higher with December at $2.25\ a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 3} cents higher with December at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 3{ cents higher with November at $6.06\ a bushel. Cattle futures prices settled lower and hog futures were sharply higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Frozen pork bellies futures prices closed at their trading limits after speculators continued to react favorably to Friday's release of the Agriculture Department's quarterly hogs and pigs report, which showed slower-than-expected growth in the breeding herd and a decline in market hogs. Cattle turned lower amid profit-taking and reports of sluggish beef demand. Live cattle settled .45 cent to .05 cent lower with October at 79.92 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .83 cent to .30 cent lower with October at 87.82 cents a pound; hogs were .12 cent lower to .87 cent higher with October at 56.20 cents a pound; pork bellies closed at its trading limit 2 cents higher with February at 62.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: ICC Approves Purchase of D&H Railroad by Canadian Pacific
DOC.TEXT: The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed Tuesday to approve the sale of the Delaware & Hudson Railway to Canadian Pacific Ltd. for $25 million. The ICC voted 4-0 to authorize the sale of the D&H and certain trackage rights, said commission spokesman Dennis Watson. The matter now goes back to the bankruptcy court that's been overseeing reorganization of the financially troubled railroad, Watson said. Francis P. Dicello, the court-appointed bankruptcy trustee, accepted CP's $25 million bid in May. A bankruptcy judge sitting in Wilmington, Del., approved the sale pending ICC approval and completion of union negotiations with D&H workers. The Canadian carrier took over operation of the freight line in August and agreed to absorb any further financial losses. Dicello, who had been running the railroad since February, said in June that the carrier had been losing about $200,000 a month. D&H, the nation's oldest continually operated railroad, filed in July 1988 for protection from its creditors. It owes about $100 million. The D&H carries freight from Montreal to Washington, D.C., and from Albany to Buffalo, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down in U.S.; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar dropped against all major currencies in uneventful U.S. trading Tuesday after moving mostly higher overseas. Gold prices skidded on European and Asian markets. But gold gained modestly in the United States as the previous day's selloff here subsidied. Currency dealers could not put their fingers on precisely why the dollar weakened in the United States. But they said trading volume was light, indicating sellers lacked conviction. A widespread belief that U.S. interest rates eventually will move lower as the economy struggles to stay out of a recession was offered as a possible reason for the diminished demand for dollars. Lower U.S. interest rates would make returns on dollar-denominated holdings less appealing and could steer money into higher-yielding foreign investments. The chances that U.S. rates will fall have risen since White House and congressional negotiators reached agreement on a fiscal 1991 budget. Another slide in oil prices Tuesday helped ease inflation fears and also possibly curbed interest in dollars. The contract for November delivery of light, sweet crude tumbled $3.14 a barrel to $33.95 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Unleaded gasoline and home heating prices also closed down sharply. If the slide continues, the oil price retreat is expected to give the Federal Reserve Board greater leeway to relax its monetary policy. The central bank's mission is to promote economic growth while keeping inflation at bay. The dollar moved ahead against most of its foreign counterparts in European trading centers. But earlier in Asia, the dollar lost ground. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.42 yen to a closing 136.73 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 137.00 yen. In New York, the dollar traded at 136.72 yen, down slightly from 136.75 yen late Monday. The British pound fetched $1.8890 late in London, the same as Monday's late rate. In New York, it cost $1.8930 to buy one pound, up from $1.8830 late Monday. Other dollar rates late in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes included: 1.5495 German marks, down from 1.55735; 1.2885 Swiss francs, down from 1.2960; 5.1915 French francs, down from 5.2195; 1,160.75 Italian lire, down from 1,167.25; and 1.15265 Canadian dollars, down from 1.153825. Late European dollar rates compared with Monday's late levels, were: 1.5540 German marks, up from 1.5520; 1.2900 Swiss francs, up from 1.2885; 5.2050 French francs, up from 5.1985; 1.7502 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7495; 1,162.75 Italian lire, down from 1,163.50; and 1.1532 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1526. The declines posted in the price of gold overseas followed a steep tumble in the United States on Monday. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for October delivery settled at $389.10 a troy ounce, up $2.50 from Monday's close. The contract sank more than $15 on Monday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late gold bid of $389, $1.10 higher than Monday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Late in London, gold traded at $388.75 an ounce, compared with $395.25 late Monday. In Zurich, Switzerland, the late gold bid was $388.60, down from $396.60 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $10.82 to close at a bid of $387.25. Silver prices were unchanged to up slightly. On the Comex, silver bullion for October delivery settled at $4.679 a troy ounce, up from Monday's settlement of $4.64. In London, silver traded late at a bid of $4.72 a troy ounce, equaling late Monday's $4.72.

DOC.HEAD: Profit-taking Ends Wall Street Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Nervous traders, mindful of the continuing Persian Gulf crisis, took their profits and cut short a two-day surge on Wall Street Tuesday. Prices closed mixed after having been broadly higher until early afternoon. The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 industrials, up about 25 points for the first half of the day, closed down 10.64 at 2,505.20. But broader measures of the market's performance ended the day on the plus side. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a margin of about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,014 up, 582 down and 427 unchanged. Analysts said Tuesday's early advance was a continuation of Monday's rally, when the Dow Jones average soared more than 63 points in response to a plunge in oil prices. But nervous traders, fearing the market might resume a bearish course amid the uncertainties surrounding the Gulf, began to take profits from the two-day advance while they could. As they sold their holdings, traders ignored another, sharper drop in oil prices that raised prospects for a slowing of inflation and a decline in interest rates. The November contract for light, sweet crude skidded $3.14 to $33.95 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, following a plunge of $2.42 a barrel on Monday. Analysts said they were not surprised by the turnaround on Wall Street. Hildegarde Zagorski, and analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., commented that she had been looking at the market moving up in an almost straight line for two days, and that some profit-taking was inevitable. Stock prices surged in Tokyo Tuesday, with the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues climbing 2,676.55 points, or 13.24 percent, to 22,898.41. The gain, the index's largest one-day advance, helped set a positive tone on Wall Street, analysts said. The most-active issue on the NYSE was Unisys, off 1[ to 3~. The company's stock is taking a heavy toll from Unisys' announcement last week that it was suspending its common stock dividend. Polaroid was up 2| to 33[ while Kodak dropped 1| to 38 amid rumors the two companies were close to a settlement in Polaroid's patent infringement case against Kodak. Retailing stocks that have been struggling lately had a turnaround. J.C. Penney picked up 1| to 45, while Woolworth advanced 1[ to 25[. UAL shot up 8| to 112 on a report that the lead banks in the proposed employee buyout of the parent of United Airlines were making progress in getting other lenders to help finance the deal. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 188.32 million shares, down from 202.21 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 225.48 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $8.955 billion, or 0.30 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.37 to 172.59. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.51 to 371.05, and S&P's 500-stock composite index advanced 0.27 to 315.21. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.75 to 356.97. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 309.63, up 1.19.

The May Department Stores Co. on Tuesday said its directors had authorized distribution of stock in the discount store chain, Venture Stores, Inc. May will distribute 0.13 shares of common stock of Venture per share of May common stock to holders of record on Oct. 15. After the spinoff, May will own no more shares of Venture common stock. Originally, the company planned to offer 15 percent of the stock to the public, but canceled that in August because of the condition of the stock market, said company spokesman Jim Abrams. The market has been dragged down since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. May expects to distribute approximately 16 million shares of Venture common stock in the spin-off, which was announced last October. There are approximately 123 million shares of May stock outstanding.

DOC.HEAD: TI, Digital Equipment and Tandem Enter Marketing Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc. said Tuesday it has entered into marketing relationships with Digital Equipment Corp. and Tandem Computers Inc. concerning its software that is used to write computer programs. Texas Instruments also announced enhancements to the software, which it calls its Information Engineering Facility. Texas Instruments is a leading marketer of such software, called computer-aided software engineering, or CASE. CASE is used by computer programmers to make it easier to write new applications programs. Beginning in the first quarter of 1991, users of the software will be able to write programs that can run on Digital computers. Later in 1991, software developers will be able to write software for the Tandem computer system. ``Digital and Tandem platforms provide TI an opportunity to service business and government organizations worldwide and to increase its total available market in the CASE industry,'' said Mike Watters, vice president and general manager of TI's Advanced Information Management System.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Switching Strategy With New Computers
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. plans to offer cheaper versions of its Macintosh machine as part of a strategy to win market share that Chairman John Sculley hopes will help the company withstand a recession. The plan begins with three new Macintosh computers to be introduced Oct. 15 accompanied by a $40 million advertising campaign. The Macintosh Classic, comparable to the popular $2,569 SE model, will carry a list price of about $1,000 and a street price as low as $700 to $800, according to sources close to Apple. The other two models, available with color monitors, will be listed at about $3,000 and $5,000, or several thousand dollars less than comparable Macintoshes in the current line. ``The basic strategy is to go after (a larger) share of the market,'' Sculley said at a preview of the campaign. ``We have no sacred cows as far as pricing. This means that this will be the most aggressive pricing that Apple has ever had. ``In a weak economy, as the United States certainly is in, it's a lot more reassuring to be introducing three major products at price points that are going to be extremely affordable.'' Critics of Apple have long complained that its Macintosh line, which ranges from $1,799 for the MacPlus to $11,000 for the FX, is too expensive. Apple's gross margins on those products is about 50 percent, one of the highest in the industry, Sculley said. As a result, Apple has racked up profits but stagnated with only about 9 percent of the desktop computer market. Inexpensive ``clones'' of International Business Machines Corp. personal computers have dominated the low end of the market. The Windows software program from Microsoft, which gives IBM computers the ``look and feel'' of the Macintosh, also has forced Apple to examine how it can distinguish itself. ``For us to be really successful in the 1990s, we want to have much more than a 9 percent share'' Sculley said. He declined to say what share of the market he is aiming for or what gross margins he'll be satisfied with. Apple, which does nearly half of its business outside the United States, is introducing its new computers simultaneously in 121 countries. The company expects the computers to be a hit especially in Japan, where Apple's business has been doubling annually. ``Part of our business has been extremely strong,'' Sculley said. ``We've continued to gain market share with our high-performance modular Macs in business. While we clearly had some need for freshening up at the low end of our product line, the high end is very resilient and strong.'' Apple will adjust its prices throughout its Macintosh line, but it is not abandoning its top models. ``I want to make sure this isn't seen as a flip-flop, (as if) we're now only in low-end systems,'' said Michael Spindler, Apple's chief operating officer. ``We don't want to divest from markets. We want to invest to make this a much broader growth business for Apple.'' He said the company will ``pull all the stops out, go a little bit overboard'' in manufacturing the new machines in anticipation of strong demand. ``If you have a brand new product in which you believe, it doesn't make sense to run it tight,'' Spindler said. Sculley said the new products and new strategy are among the most important events in his eight years with the company. He said Apple is also working on several notebook-size computers. ``Miniaturization is one of the major themes we're focusing on in research and development,'' he said. ``I think that's going to be extremely important in the 1990s.'' Sculley acknowledged criticsim that Apple has failed to come up with a lightweight portable. The Portable Mac is a bulky, heavy machine that seems almost antiquated compared to competitive models. ``While Apple has started late in some of these areas we can do a lot more than just catch up,'' Sculley said. ``We see this as a chance to get real differentiation in the 1990s.'' He said miniaturization is evident in the new desktop models that Apple will show off. ``It means extremely high reliability because we have fewer components on the board,'' he said. ``The reliability of the new products we think is going to be significantly higher than anything that's been brought out. ``We're basically saying this is the year of the new customer and we are reaching out to people who have never experienced Apple before. Many of those people don't know an awful lot about personal computers, and we want their first experience to be extremely satisfying so the product reliability is important.''

DOC.HEAD: Maxwell To Shed TV Interests To Concentrate On Papers, Printing
DOC.TEXT: Robert Maxwell's Mirror Group Newspapers plans to sell its television broadcasting buisiness to concentrate on newspapers and printing, the publisher said in a statement Tuesday. Maxwell said the decision follows investment in new technology that has allowed three of the group's British newspapers to change to color. They include the Daily Mirror, the group's national-circulation tabloid flagship which has a daily sale of 3.9 million copies. The statement said: ``We have decided in the future the group should concentrate purely on newspapers and printing. ``We intend to expand our newspaper activities both at home and abroad, particularly in the USA where there are some excellent opportunities for expansion.'' It gave no other details about the planned expansion in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: MGM Shareholders Approve Pathe Merger
DOC.TEXT: Financier Kirk Kerkorian, who owns about 80 percent of MGM-UA Communications Co. stock, and other shareholders voted Tuesday to approve a $1.3 billion buyout offer from Pathe Communications Corp. The vote tally was not immediately available from the special meeting. So far, Pathe has paid $353 million toward the purchase price of about $1.3 billion. Questions still surround how Pathe's principal, Giancarlo parretti, will finance the remaining $900 million. The deal is scheduled to be consummated on Oct. 23. MGM-UA Chairman Jeffrey Barbakow said at the meeting he was optimistic the deal would be completed by the deadline. Time Warner, formerly Pathe's most solid source of funding for the merger, withdrew its pledge of $650 million in loans earlier this year and has sued Pathe for breach of contract.

DOC.HEAD: Mellon Bank Buys $110 Million Credit Card Receivables
DOC.TEXT: Mellon Bank Corp. said Tuesday it had purchased about $110 million in credit card receivables from Ameritrust Co. N.A. of Cleveland. Pittsburgh-based Mellon said the transaction, which was completed last week, was done through its credit card operation in Delaware. Included in the receivables are $73 million in American Automobile Association Club accounts in West Virginia, Kentucky, North Carolina and South Carolina. Ameritrust will continue to service the AAA accounts until they are converted to Mellon's computer system by the third quarter of 1991. The sale is expected to result in a one-time pre-tax gain of $14.6 million to Ameritrust, Mellon said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHN: balanced budget.
DOC.TEXT: Meanwhile, even as Bush called for public support for a measure designed to chart the way to a balanced budget, he signed legislation extending the nation's borrowing powers. He signed a bill extending the national debt limit of $3.2 trillion through Saturday. Congress is expected to vote then to extend it further. Earlier Tuesday, Bush sought to win over a group of House Republicans who were either undecided on the package or leaning against it. Some 35 members came, though the White House indicated about 60 had been invited. ``I'm undecided. So's the nation,'' said Rep. Robert Dornan, R-Calif, after the first of three sessions between Bush and GOP lawmakers. Bush, giving a preview of the evening television address, told a group of business leaders at the White House that he knew the deficit-fighting package would require sacrifices. ``This budget agreement is our last best chance to get the federal budget deficit under control,'' Bush said. ``To all the people that disagree and the people on the sidelines that are rushing out and having their press conferences and the critics, let me say this: You can pick the package apart but you cannot realistically put a better package together.'' He also apologized to the business group that in the course of forging the compromise he had abandoned his call for a cut in the capital gains tax. ``The philosophy I was elected on runs out of gas in terms of votes in the United States Congress,'' Bush said. The most vociferous opposition to the plan hammered out by White House and congressional leaders has come from Bush's own party. Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., said Bush had not persuaded him and he still was likely to vote against the package. But Rep. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., said he would support the package. ``It's the only ball game in town,'' he said. ``If this goes down, you're going to see chaos.'' With the first votes on the package scheduled for as early as Wednesday, both sides were scrambling to line up support. Congressional leaders pondered letting the Senate take the first vote on an outline of the plan. Support for the package is viewed as stronger in the Senate, if only because only one third of the 100-member Senate is up for re-election this year while all 435 House seats are up for grabs. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said letting the Senate cast the initial vote would ``put heat on the House.'' It was Bush's fourth televised speech from the Oval Office. He also addressed the nation to announce his drug strategy, to announce the invasion of Panama and to announce his Persian Gulf policy.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Downgrades Unisys Debt
DOC.TEXT: A major credit rating agency Tuesday downgraded Unisys Corp.'s debt and preferred stock saying the country's third-largest computer maker has dim prospects for sustaining any improved profits. Unisys spokesman Peter Hynes said the firm was dissappointed by Moody's Investor Service Inc.'s downgrade of about $5.2 billion worth of securities. Hynes cited the company's decision last week to suspend its common stock dividend as evidence of its efforts to maintain credit quality. The firm decided it would pay off debt with the $40 million normally paid each quarter to holders of common stock. Dividends will continue to be paid on preferred stock, Unisys said Tuesday. Unisys, based in nearby Blue Bell, Pa., wants to reduce its debt by $600 million to $800 million this year. The company owed $3.6 billion on June 30, down from a peak $4.1 billion in the middle of 1989. Moody's noted that Unisys's management has taken steps to improve its financial flexibility. ``Improvements, however, have been moderated by the ongoing challenges of the slowed growth and the increasing margin pressure that are endemic to the industry,'' Moody's said in a release. On Monday, Unisys announced a new strategy to shift the company's core business away from large mainframe computers, which are being pushed out of the market by cheaper, faster and more powerful desktop computers. The new plan is to market software that can integrate Unisys equipment and incompatible equipment made by IBM and other rival companies, Hynes said. The result would be computer networks that can share information regardless of the make or size of the machines, making it possible for customers to build upon existing equipment.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Asks Taxpayers to Share Burden; Tries to Sell $500 Billion Budget Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 27th graf with study results, ``A congressional...; minor editing; Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Americans Tuesday night to support a $500 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts that demands sacrifice from all. ``Everyone who can should contribute something,'' the president said. Claiming rare unity with leaders of the Democratic-controlled Congress, Bush said in a 10-minute televised speech from the Oval Office that the package was written in ``eight months of blood, sweat and fears - fears of the economic chaos that would follow if we fail to reduce the deficit.'' ``It is the best agreement that can be legislated now,'' Bush said of the compromise. ``This deficit reduction agreement is tough, and so are the times.'' Bush's address from the Oval Office was nationally televised, but his message was primarily aimed 16 blocks away: at Congress, where an initial vote on the plan may be held as early as Thursday. Although the package generally has support among Democrats, lawmakers from Bush's own party - particularly in the House - have balked at its tax provisions. Bush himself had to abandon his ``no new taxes'' pledge in the face of the growing deficit. ``I'm not, and I know you're not, a fan of tax increases,'' Bush said. ``But if there have to be tax measures, they should allow the economy to grow, they should not turn us back to higher income tax rates and they should be fair. ``Everyone who can should contribute something. And no one should have to contribute beyond their fair share.'' Bush pointed out that the agreement had been hammered out by a bipartisan group. ``The Democratic and Republican leadership tonight all speak with once voice,'' he said, and he urged people to tell their congressmen they support the package. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, joined Bush in urging passage of the fragile package, saying the future of the nation ``is more important than partisan differences.'' In a televised response, Mitchell acknowledged that Democrats and Republicans had ``deep differences over values and priorities'' that delayed an agreement for months. The Democratic leader called the agreement ``imperfect,'' and warned that the compromise budget cuts and tax increases will demand ``sacrifice from all Americans.'' ``But, if enacted, it holds the promise of restoring a sound economy, from which all Americans will benefit,'' Mitchell said. ``Everybody who can should contribute something,'' Bush said. ``Everyone will bear a small burden. But if we succeed, every American will have a large burden lifted.'' The alternative, Bush said, is recession. Wavering Republican lawmakers had told Bush earlier in the day that the plan was in trouble, and that a presidential address to the nation endorsing the package might be helpful if he expected GOP support for the package with congressional elections just a month away. Bush also planned to push for the three-day-old package, which the White House negotiated with congressional leaders, in a series of upcoming speeches around the nation. The budget package would raise taxes on gasoline, alcohol, cigarettes, boats and furs while trimming benefits to farmers and Medicare recipients. It also would reduce tax deductions for people who earn more than $100,000. Bush earlier Tuesday had pressed his case with skeptical and wavering House Republicans. He seemed to be making some headway and by late Tuesday, House GOP leaders were beginning to feel more optimistic about their chances of rounding up support from most of their members. ``We've made significant progress,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. One opponent, Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., agreed, saying, ``I'd guess right now it would be narrowly defeated. By tomorrow, it would be narrowly passed. ... People are being moved, one-by-one.'' Bush said the budget deficit was ``a problem that has lingered and dogged and vexed this country for far too long.'' Likening the budget crisis to the Persian Gulf stalemate, Bush said ``our nation is standing together against Saddam Hussein's aggression ' while at home ``another threat, a cancer, is gnawing away at our nation's health.'' The president said that ending deficit spending was simple ``common sense.'' ``No nation can continue to do business the way the federal government has been operating and survive,'' he said. ``When you get a bill, that bill must be paid,'' he said. Bush said that the plan was not ``a magic act'' but contained true deficit savings and would put the nation on the path toward lower interest rates and a balanced budget. A congressional study released Tuesday showed that the poor would be hit hardest by the package, the rich would feel its increases the least. The increased taxes and reduced benefits would take an average 2 percent of the earnings of Americans with the lowest incomes, according to the survey by the House Ways and Means Committee.

Japan's Biggest Market Jump Follows 48 Percent Decline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new third graf to UPDATE with morning session Wednesday; PICK UP 4th graf pvs, As the . . .
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Japan-Markets and AM-Japan-Point Gains
DOC.TEXT: A government support package helped propel Tokyo stocks to their biggest one-day jump in history Tuesday but left uncertain prospects for an extended rebound from the worst market decline in more than 30 years. The closely watched Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues leaped 2,676.55 points, or 13.24 percent, to 22,898.41 after the Ministry of Finance announced emergency measures to shore up the ailing market. The market receded slightly in early trading Wednesday on profit taking before resuming its climb as the Nikkei posted a 331.16-point gain in the morning session. As the largest single-day gain ever, Tuesday's market eclipsed the 9.29 percent rebound posted a day after the stock market crashed three years ago, when the Nikkei rose 2,037.32 points to 23,947.40. ``The support from the Finance Ministry boosted the market's sentiment. I believe institutional investors as well as individual buyers now can't resist investing at the current low levels,'' said Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, a trader with Daiwa Securities. The unprecedented jump came after a nine-month meltdown that had erased nearly half the market's value - the equivalent of $2.1 trillion - since the end of last year. The protracted slide was the worst since the Korean War in the early 1950s, market observers said. The Foreign Ministry's measures themselves were minor adjustments, but because they sent a message of support to the markets, their psychological impact was considerable. The measures were aimed at spurring buying and reducing market volatility. They included easing restrictions on the purchase of stock on credit and shortening the hours for futures and options trading. On Monday, before Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto signaled the government's intentions, market watchers had been predicting the Nikkei would plummet below the 15,000 mark. After the market began to rally, some were calling for a return to 23,000, or even 25,000. ``This just shows how very fragile investor sentiment is,'' said Amy Yip, manager of equity sales at Baring Securities Ltd. The Nikkei's comeback began late in Monday trading on comments from Hashimoto, indicating that the government was about to act to stem the market's slide. The Nikkei, which had slipped more than 1,200 points to below 20,000, rebounded to cut the day's loss to 761.64 points. The surge picked up momentum Tuesday. Volume was estimated at 550 million shares, up from 428 million shares Monday. ``Talk about herd mentality. . . . This market has gone completely and utterly bananas,'' Paul Muller, manager of international equity sales at Schroder Securities (Japan) Ltd., said before Tuesday's trading ended. The rise was accelerated by ``panic buying,'' according to Yip. ``Customers were worried about missing the boat,'' she said. They're afraid the market's going to pull back tomorrow. . . . They're moving entirely differently from logic.'' Dealers said the runup was fed by a so-called ``short squeeze,'' in which traders who had sold borrowed shares had to buy them back to avoid serious losses. ``The short squeeze is on,'' Schroder's Muller said. ``Everyone had been expecting it . . . and it came with a vengeance.'' Some traders believed the market had bottomed out and was ready for a change. ``In addition to the psychological effect of Hashimoto's measure, the market, weary of selling, was prepared for an upturn,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, a dealer with Nomura Securities. Diplomatic efforts by countries to settle the Persian Gulf crisis, falling oil prices, a surge in the Dow Jones industrial average on Wall Street Monday and a stronger bond market in Japan were also among the positive factors, he said. In bond dealings, bond prices advanced as the yield on the benchmark 10-year Japanese government bond closed at 8.185 percent, down sharply from 8.475 percent the previous day. ``We believe today's rebound is an indication of sustained recovery as long as the Middle East remains calm,'' Inoue said. Before the rebound, the Nikkei index had shed 10,616.13 points, or 34.4 percent, from its closing of 30,837.99 on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait. Japan is highly vulnerable to unrest in the Gulf because it imports virtually all its oil, with 70 percent coming from the Middle East. Because the economy remains susceptible to outside shocks, some doubted the lasting impact of the ministry's initiatives. But many felt they would give the market a healthy short-term boost. The principal change would increase the credit limit for investors buying stock on margin. The measure would allow investors to count 80 percent of the value of their holdings as collateral for stock purchases, up from 70 percent. A second measure, aimed at easing market volatility, reduces the time allowed for futures and options trading by 20 minutes to four hours and 10 minutes. As in the United States, traders in Japan have been hedging their stock bets with counterbalancing trades in stock-index futures and options. Some critics say those strategies have contributed to the market's uneasiness. The third measure loosens reporting requirements for big insurance companies investing in stocks, which could spur more buying by those companies.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Resumes Climb, Dollar Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei; Will be led again with comments.
DOC.TEXT: Following an early decline Wednesday morning, stock prices resumed climbing one day after the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange posted its largest single-day increase ever. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues added 331.16 points, or 1.45 percent, ending Wednesday morning's session at 23,229.57. The index gained 2,676.55 points Tuesday. The market got off to a slow start Wednesday, with the Nikkei losing 139.05 points on profit taking in the first 15 minutes of trading. Volume on the morning session Wednesday was estimated at 300 million shares, up from an estimated 200 million shares Tuesday morning. Advancing issues outnumbered declining issues 580 to 131, while 98 issues remained unchanged. About 30 percent of all shares were left unpriced at the end of the session due to lack of sufficient sell orders to match buy orders, traders said. The market rallied Tuesday on lower oil prices and moves by the Finance Ministry to spur buying and reduce market volatility. The changes included easing restrictions on the purchase of stock on credit and shortening the hours for futures and options trading. While the measures were minor adjustments, they had a strong psychological impact on the market Tuesday. In the foreign exchange market, the dollar fell slightly to 136.32 yen in the morning session. It opened at 136.33 yen, down 0.40 yen from Tuesday's close. It ranged between 136.32 yen and 136.58 yen by late morning. Currency dealers said the dollar declined against the yen because of falling oil prices. ``Lower oil prices will support the yen because it is considered to have a more positive impact on the Japanese economy than elsewhere,'' said Yasushi Nishikado of Daiichi Kangyo Bank. He added that the dollar is expected to stay in the 135 to 136 yen range until Friday when U.S. unemployment figures for September are announced. In bond dealings, the yield on the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 8.280 percent, from Tuesday's close of 8.185 percent. Their price fell to 82.41 points from 82.81.
